fields.headline: Radzinski double floors United
fields.standfirst: Ferguson's men in danger of elimination after another away defeat
fields.trailText: Ferguson's men in danger of elimination after another away defeat.
fields.byline: Daniel Taylor  at the Stade Constant Vanderstock
fields.body:
With obscene haste, Manchester United's pursuit of the European Cup is in danger of being ended before they have even worked up a stitch. The English champions left Brussels last night with their chances of qualifying for the Champions League second phase looking increasingly precarious after this vapid defeat.

Sir Alex Ferguson's team must now beat Dynamo Kiev in the final game of Group G if they are to progress. Otherwise the best English football can offer will be forced to plot a course in the Uefa Cup.

Having failed to glean more than a single point from their previous excursions against PSV Eindhoven and Dynamo Kiev, however, United have found their route lined with diversions. Anderlecht, playing with a self-assurance that comes from protecting a 100% home record, ensured there would be a wrong turn or two here.

It may look as though Ikea have supplied the parts but this flat-pack ground was drenched with a feverish expectation, the atmosphere intimate and intimidating. If David Beckham had collected the coins that were thrown at him every time he took a corner, he could have had a field day at duty free.

United also had to contend with the human mountain that is Jan Koller who, at 6ft 8in with size-17 boots, makes Jaap Stam resemble a jump jockey. On the sort of pitch that suggested the groundsman may have used grazing cattle to trim the grass, this was one of those nights when he threatened to trample anything that got in his way.

Only a fine interception from Mickael Silvestre denied the marauding Czech international an early chance from Tomasz Radzinski's layback and, as United struggled to find any momentum, their hosts threatened to overwhelm them.

If Ferguson's players had heard the alarm bells, they chose to ignore them. After 15 minutes the Belgians' pressure paid off. Yves Vanderhaeghe's ball caught the United defence flat-footed and Radzinski, apparently offside, ran unchallenged into the penalty area before finishing with a precise left-foot shot into the top right-hand corner of Fabien Barthez's net.

It could have been worse, and almost immediately. Bart Goor's cross caught Silvestre hopelessly and not unpredictably out of position and Koller lashed a venomous haymaker towards goal that Barthez managed to beat out.

The pattern had been set for the opening half and United did not gather their senses until Anderlecht had scored again, Koller breaking down the right before whipping in a low cross that Radzinski expertly turned in from the edge of the penalty area.

United were stumbling around with an intoxicated air but their first potent move paid dividends only two minutes later. Dwight Yorke linked with Andy Cole and as the England striker held off two challenges his run was unceremoniously halted by Glen de Boeck's tackle from behind. Despite slipping at the crucial moment, Denis Irwin converted the penalty and the visitors had been thrown a lifeline.

United had hope, but the referee's whistle could not bring inspiration. Too many passes were misplaced, too many tackles mistimed. Ferguson's team were desperately missing the hamstrung Roy Keane.

So pity the poor cleaner who has to clear up the broken chinaware from the visiting dressing room. "Until half-time we were a shambles," said Ferguson.

United re-emerged with greater purpose but with Beckham and Ryan Giggs playing only peripheral roles and Yorke and Cole rarely displaying the understanding of old there was more slack defending that slick attacking going on.

Radzinksi, in particular, was revelling in the visitors' anxiety. The Mounties may always get their man, but United simply could not get hold of the Canadian striker. And they will face Kiev in two weeks without Paul Scholes, after a handball offence earned him a suspension for his third yellow card of the competition.

Anderlecht (4-3-1-2): De Wilde; Crasson, Staelens, De Boeck, Dheedene; Vanderhaeghe, Baseggio, Goor; Stoica (Oyen, 80min); Radzinski (Dindane, 90), Koller.

Manchester United (4-4-2): Barthez; Irwin (Solskjaer, 78), G Neville, Johnsen, Silvestre (Brown, 62); Beckham, Butt, Scholes, Giggs; Cole, Yorke.

Referee: S Braschi (Italy).

fields.headline: Wenger shortens Crozier's short list
fields.standfirst: Arsène shrugs off England interest as Gunners prepare for next European venture
fields.trailText: Arsène shrugs off England interest as Gunners prepare for next European venture.
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger must be so sick of ruling himself out of the England job that it is no surprise he has started treating the matter as a joke. "My mind is not like the English weather forecast," Arsenal's manager emphasised yesterday. "It does not constantly change."

If that went down as well as a flash flood at Lancaster Gate, Wenger at least offered a glimpse of sunshine afterwards. Contrary to reports, the FA's chief executive Adam Crozier will not fly to Rome tomorrow to meet Lazio's Sven Goran Eriksson but he will soon approach all the candidates.

But Wenger suggested the Swede could well fill the void. "There are some positive signs that Eriksson would not be reluctant," he said. "I said 'I'm sorry, I'm at my club, so I rule myself out'. I have never heard him say that. The other thing is that a few years ago he signed for Blackburn [but never took the job] and that shows he is considering leaving Italy."

Wenger believes Eriksson, 52, whose Lazio contract expires in June, has the quality and experience required.

The Frenchman, who said he had not been approached by the FA and rubbished the thought of a proposal to stay at Arsenal until 2002 and then take over England, also offered support to the former Blackburn and Switzerland manager Roy Hodgson. "I would consider the two candidates at the same level," he said.

Hodgson's club Copenhagen last night softened their stance on their coach's availability after initially insisting he would not be released from his contract. "Money is not everything," said the sports director Niels Christian Holmstrom, "but it might make the negotiations easier. Letting Roy go now, while we are in the middle of the Danish season, would create a lot of problems, so we would not do that. But in football you should never say never."

Meanwhile Wenger hinted he will leave club football for the international arena when his Arsenal contract ends in two years if the European Commission's ruling on the transfer market is not to his liking. A Fifa-Uefa task force has until October 31 to present its case to the commission and a ruling is expected in December.

"If things go like they say there is no way to be in the job any more," he said. "Then international football would be attractive."

In the lead-up to his side's Champions League game at home to Sparta Prague tonight Wenger also assured Dennis Bergkamp that a new two-year contract is waiting for him. "It will be done in the next two or three weeks," he said.

Arsenal have already qualified for the next round but Wenger wants a win to ensure top spot and a more favourable second-phase draw. With Tony Adams injured and Martin Keown and Gilles Grimandi suspended, he will use Nelson Vivas and Oleg Luzhny as an emergency centre-half pairing.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Mooney penalty puts Watford top
fields.standfirst: Watford 1 - 0 Bolton
fields.trailText: Watford 1 - 0 Bolton
fields.body:
Watford displaced Fulham at the top last night when Tommy Mooney calmly struck from the penalty spot in the 87th minute after Bolton were undone when Anthony Barness handled in the area.

When these sides last met Watford were heading for the Premiership's promised land after beating Bolton 2-0 in the First Division play-offs.

But while their stay in the top flight proved short, Graham Taylor's side are determined to prove they have learnt their lessons in advanced football well.

The chief of which is resilience. Bolton, intent on extracting some form of revenge, started the match at a blistering pace - Michael Ricketts slicing wide of Alec Chamberlain's goal in the first 10 minutes.

The home side appeared content to probe the Bolton defence in a diffident manner. Tommy Smith, Alan Nielsen and Micah Hyde all taking turns to waste chances.

Few teams can carry off that sort of arrogance and Watford nearly paid for their attitude as Bolton's more physical game saw them increasingly dominate the midfield and much of the run of play.

Per Frandsen had the best chance of the half in the 25th minute, breaking from midfield only to see his powerful shot punched clear by Chamberlain. The ball was cleared only as far as Kevin Nolan but his shot was easily covered.

Nolan almost made amends for that miss just before half- time when he fired towards goal from 15 yards out with Chamberlain forced to full stretch to keep it out.

Yet for all Bolton's efforts, Watford's strength at the back made an away goal seem unlikely. It was turning into the sort of night where defence is the key and Paul Robinson, Neil Cox and Chamberlain were clearly intent on making amends for their anonymous team-mates in midfield.

Taylor made a double substitution for the start of the second half with the experienced Tommy Mooney replacing Heidar Helguson and Norden Wooter coming on for Smith.

Wooter, who has complained about his lack of a regular first- team place this season, added much-needed invention and was unlucky to have a penalty decision go against him when he was brought down in the area by Simon Charlton.

fields.headline: Fulham floored by Appleton fluke
fields.standfirst: Fulham 0 - 1 Preston
fields.trailText: Fulham 0 - 1 Preston
fields.body:
The word defeat entered the Craven Cottage vocabulary last night as Fulham proved to be human after all. Their unbeaten start to the season was just a memory as they fell to newly promoted Preston, whose carefully crafted gameplan was eventually rewarded .

Preston began with one aim: to close down and stifle Fulham's formidable passing game, the ploy which earned Wolves a point on Saturday and which ended the London club's run of 11 consecutive wins.

Thus the first-half turned into something of a struggle, with Michael Appleton and Mark Rankine in the Preston midfield throwing a blanket over most of their hosts' creative ideas.

With the visiting wide men eager to drop back and help the full-backs, Fulham's normal outlets on the flanks were also restricted. In fact it was Preston who almost took the lead. With only 50 seconds gone, Rankine found himself with a clear shot on goal but steered his effort wide.

Fulham began to exert a grip slowly, though when they did carve out a few decent chances, wayward finishing let them down too.

Twenty-yard shots from Fabrice Fernandes and Louis Saha were directed at the goalkeeper, as was the latter's close-range header from Steve Finnan's cross. Then just before the break Barry Hayles found himself with space at the far post, but he fired wide, too.

At least Fulham could take heart from the fact that they were getting their passing together after the break. And to help further the manager Jean Tigana brought on John Collins, who had been rested, early in the second half.

Fulham also needed to rediscover their ability to run at players and with that in mind, Fernandes was switched from the left wing to the right. Now able to cut inside on to his favourite foot he did just that to feed Hayles after 57 minutes, but the striker's shot was deflected wide.

Soon after Fernandes picked the ball up about 20 yards out, wriggled towards two defenders, and then got in a shot which was also deflected wide.

But the Preston defence held out well and after 68 minutes were rewarded when Appleton swung a corner in to the near post and the ball somehow sneaked in past the goalkeeper Maik Taylor.

webTitle: Hughes leaves Everton to become a Rover

fields.headline: Hughes leaves Everton to become a Rover
fields.trailText: Mark Hughes's insatiable desire for first-team club football persuaded the veteran striker to leave Everton yesterday and drop down a division with the aim of helping Graeme Souness's Blackburn Rovers back to the Premiership.
fields.body:
Mark Hughes's insatiable desire for first-team club football persuaded the veteran striker to leave Everton yesterday and drop down a division with the aim of helping Graeme Souness's Blackburn Rovers back to the Premiership.

The Welshman, who will be 37 next Wednesday and has amassed more than 550 league appearances in England, Spain and Germany, moved on a free transfer to Ewood Park and is confident he can help Blackburn back to the top flight by the end of his 18-month contract at the latest.

Indeed Hughes, who is in the Blackburn squad to meet Tranmere tonight, believes he can still play at the highest level "but players were coming back into the team at Everton and I wasn't always sure of a place".

Souness said Hughes's power and combativeness would ensure his side "don't get bullied", explaining: "When we go away in this division you have to fight and scrap and his presence will be a big bonus."

The former Manchester United striker, joining his fifth English club after spells abroad with Barcelona and Bayern Munich (loan), said managing Wales would not interfere with playing for Blackburn.

Laurent Charvet has become Joe Royle's latest defensive recruit, joining Manchester City from Newcastle for £1m, rising by £500,000 depending on appearances. The French defender has signed a 3-year contract.

Bryan Robson's Middlesbrough have hit more injury problems with the captain Paul Ince undergoing minor surgery on an infected knee.

After losing the £8m Ugo Ehiogu for a minimum of three weeks Boro will now also be without Ince at Ipswich on Saturday and possibly the Worthington Cup trip to Wimbledon. He is suspended for the home game with Arsenal on November 4, meaning his return could well be delayed until the visit to his old club Manchester United a week later.

Diego Maradona said yesterday that he was to make his return to professional football as manager of the Buenos Aires team Atletico Almagro.

webTitle: Tamudo just says no to Rangers

fields.headline: Tamudo just says no to Rangers
fields.trailText: Rangers' protracted interest in the Espanol striker Raul Tamudo looks certain to be over after the 23-year-old, who failed a medical at Ibrox over the weekend, was included in his club's squad for tomorrow's Uefa Cup tie against Graz of Austria.
fields.body:
Rangers' protracted interest in the Espanol striker Raul Tamudo looks certain to be over after the 23-year-old, who failed a medical at Ibrox over the weekend, was included in his club's squad for tomorrow's Uefa Cup tie against Graz of Austria.

Tamudo's knee injury, sustained in the final of the Olympic Games, was enough to deter Rangers from making an £11m investment. But the Espanol club doctor Salvador Oliveras said: "He just has a little bit of liquid on his right knee. He is not completely fit, but he could well play on Thursday." If Tamudo does play, he would be ineligible for Rangers' Champions League campaign.

Tamudo confirmed that he was now no longer interested in joining the Scottish champions. "I would rather play for the team which is in my heart," he said. "I was being sold because of the current situation at Espanol where they are struggling financially.

"They spoke to me and forced me to accept Rangers' offer to save the club but I would rather play for them than Rangers. I do not want to play for Rangers and I want to forget all about them."

fields.headline: Rangers in state of disrepair
fields.trailText: Rangers have a rattled look about them as they prepare for tonight's encounter with Sturm Graz in Austria, and none of it is any surprise.
fields.body:
Rangers have a rattled look about them as they prepare for tonight's encounter with Sturm Graz in Austria, and none of it is any surprise.

Suddenly, in a Group D voyage that initially looked buoyant, the Ibrox club may be about to endure a nerve-shredding six days. Already performing cantankerously in the Premier League, the Scottish champions are aghast at what might be unfolding in the Champions League.

A win tonight would guarantee Rangers a place in the next group phase but if, as is quite possible, they lose to Sturm Graz and Galatasaray win in Monaco, Rangers would face Monaco next Tuesday in Glasgow knowing that even three points might not be enough to guarantee qualification. For Dick Advocaat, this did not bear thinking about yesterday.

However, Rangers are in the midst of an injury crisis. Jorg Albertz has not even travelled with the squad to Austria and Giovanni van Bronckhorst, Arthur Numan and Fernando Ricksen are all doubtful, while the goalkeeper Stefan Klos and Michael Mols still cannot even be considered. It is a state of disrepair which, set beside the manager's agitation, gives the impression of a club in minor turmoil.

"We have not had our best preparation: we have lots of doubts with injured players, and every club is entitled to bad periods, but I hope my players react correctly tomorrow night," said Advocaat.

"We have a big enough squad and a good enough squad but what my players have to realise is that work comes first on the field, then the quality. Sturm Graz will show that tomorrow, I'm sure, so we have to do the same."

The home team, to Advocaat's comfort, are not entirely injury-free. Their talismanic striker, Ivica Vastic, was reported to have re-visited hospital yesterday with a knee injury, seeming to put paid to his comeback hopes.

Sturm Graz have been one of this season's great unpredictables, taking canings off Rangers and Monaco on their travels, but growing in accomplishment with every game at home. There could be bother tonight for Rangers.

Sturm Graz (probable, 3-5-2): Schicklgruber; Mamedov, Neukirchner, Popovic; Korsos, Schupp, Fleurquin, Reinmayr, Prilasnig; Yuran, Kocijan.

Rangers (3-5-2): Christiansen; Konterman, Amoruso, Porrini; McCann, Van Bronckhorst, Ferguson, Tugay, Adamczuk; De Boer, Dodds.

A win tonight would guarantee Rangers a place in the next group phase but if, as is quite possible, they lose to Sturm Graz and Galatasaray win in Monaco, Rangers would face Monaco next Tuesday in Glasgow knowing that even three points might not be enough to guarantee qualification. For Dick Advocaat, this did not bear thinking about yesterday. However, Rangers are in the midst of an injury crisis. Jorg Albertz has not even travelled with the squad to Austria and Giovanni van Bronckhorst, Arthur Numan and Fernando Ricksen are all doubtful, while the goalkeeper Stefan Klos and Michael Mols still cannot even be considered. It is a state of disrepair which, set beside the manager's agitation, gives the impression of a club in minor turmoil. "We have not had our best preparation: we have lots of doubts with injured players, and every club is entitled to bad periods, but I hope my players react correctly tomorrow night," said Advocaat. "We have a big enough squad and a good enough squad but what my players have to realise is that work comes first on the field, then the quality. Sturm Graz will show that tomorrow, I'm sure, so we have to do the same." The home team, to Advocaat's comfort, are not entirely injury-free. Their talismanic striker, Ivica Vastic, was reported to have re-visited hospital yesterday with a knee injury, seeming to put paid to his comeback hopes. Sturm Graz have been one of this season's great unpredictables, taking canings off Rangers and Monaco on their travels, but growing in accomplishment with every game at home. There could be bother tonight for Rangers. Sturm Graz (probable, 3-5-2): Schicklgruber; Mamedov, Neukirchner, Popovic; Korsos, Schupp, Fleurquin, Reinmayr, Prilasnig; Yuran, Kocijan. Rangers (3-5-2): Christiansen; Konterman, Amoruso, Porrini; McCann, Van Bronckhorst, Ferguson, Tugay, Adamczuk; De Boer, Dodds.

fields.headline: England comeback fuelled by Flintoff
fields.standfirst:
Pakistan 304 for 9 (50 overs)
England 306 for 5 (47.2)
England win by five wickets
fields.trailText:
Pakistan 304 for 9 (50 overs)

England 306 for 5 (47.2)

England win by five wickets
fields.body:
England produced what was arguably their finest victory in one-day cricket here last night when, chasing 305 to win the first of their three limited-overs matches against Pakistan, they reached their target with five wickets and 16 deliveries to spare.

This was the fourth highest successful chase in international one-day history; only India, Australia (both 316) and Sri Lanka (313) have done better than this. England's previous best was the 286 for four they scored against New Zealand at Old Trafford in 1986.

In the most exciting chase since Steve McQueen took to the streets of San Francisco in Bullet, England overcame not only one of the world's leading one-day sides but also some familiar umpiring problems and the early loss of both openers.

A partnership of 114 in 18 overs between the captain Nasser Hussain (73) and Graeme Hick (56) made it all possible. But, even when Hussain was fourth out at 164 in the 31st over, England's hopes looked far-fetched.

Andrew Flintoff, with 84 from 60 balls, and Graham Thorpe, with an unbeaten 64 off 66, then added 138 for the fifth wicket in 16 overs.

Flintoff hit six muscular fours and three sixes. In successive overs he pulled Abdur Razzak and Wasim Akram over the ropes and then - a remarkable shot - he check-drove Waqar Younis for another six before falling just before the end.

"It's something I've wanted to do and been threatening to do for a while - win a match for England," Flintoff said, "and that's why I was so annoyed about getting out."

But, just when England thought it was safe to go back into the hot water of another Pakistan tour, they discovered it can still leave scald marks.

They were four balls into their first meaningful innings in this country for 13 years when something happened that stirred uncomfortable memories of the umpiring of Shakeel Khan and Shakoor Rana, whose dark deeds did so much to dissuade them from returning.

Wasim appealed for a catch behind against Alec Stewart. Stewart, who did not appear to touch the ball, stood his ground. The umpire, Riazuddin, did not move either. But then, under intense pressure from the fielding side, the official gave Stewart out, some five seconds after the original appeal.

Stewart showed dissent. First he dropped his bat in an abject attitude of disbelief. Then he started a slow, head-shaking return to the dressing room.

England's attitude has been commendably positive but just over a week into their tour all those fears, of dazzling batting, fizzing fast bowling and iffy umpiring, not to mention the heat and turbulent tummies, had proved justified. But England's response to this setback was emphatic and heroic.

The Pakistan innings was a beast of a thing. It attacked the England bowlers with a chilling voracity at the start and then slumbered in a post-prandial, lip-smacking sort of way before slaying once more in the final overs, the last 10 of which yielded 106 runs.

Its pattern was set by the openers Saeed Anwar and Imran Nazir who plundered 21 runs from the first 12 deliveries. The fifty had come up in the eighth over and by the end of the important 15-over stage 92 had been scored.

Imran Nazir was third out, at 97, but Inzaman-ul-Haq then added 100 in 26 overs with Yousuf Youhana. By the time Inzamam was fifth out for an 87-ball 71 the remarkable Razzak was into his electric stride. He hit Craig White, Mark Ealham and Darren Gough for audacious sixes and there were also five fours in his 40-ball 75.

Gough and White together cost 141. They looked shell-shocked. It seemed unlikely that before the day was through they would be sharing a jig of pure joy.

Hussain said afterwards: "This was my most satisfying one-day win. We did something very special today. Andy Flintoff played as well as he can and showed how fit he was."

webTitle: Sulky survivor who took the long view

fields.headline: Sulky survivor who took the long view
fields.standfirst: Former prime minister Heath mellowed and stayed in the Commons long after his Thatcherite enemies had died or gone to the Lords
fields.trailText: More so than is the case with most prime ministers, history is still making up its mind about the career of Edward Heath. Man of destiny who wisely took Britain into Europe after the collapse of empire? Or clumsy, buttoned up politician who led the country into its worst decade since the second world war?
fields.body:
More so than is the case with most prime ministers, history is still making up its mind about the career of Edward Heath. Man of destiny who wisely took Britain into Europe after the collapse of empire? Or clumsy, buttoned up politician who led the country into its worst decade since the second world war?

It was a war in which he fought. As such he was the last British prime minister to experience battle at firsthand, as an artillery officer fighting his way into Germany after D-day in 1944, when his nemesis, Margaret Thatcher, was still an Oxford student.

But in a lengthy public career, Sir Edward also became the last world figure to have seen Hitler in the flesh. As a young Oxford student he made his way to a Nuremburg rally in 1937 where - as he often told dinner guests - the Fuhrer passed so near that "his shoulder brushed mine". A fierce anti-appeasement Tory at the time, he backed Churchill against Chamberlain, yet remained in public life long enough to face similar accusations after he flew to Baghdad in 1990 to talk with Saddam Hussein and bring home 33 British hostages.

Obsession

Did he ever wonder if he was wrong as Chamberlain had been, he was later asked. "No," Sir Edward tersely replied. That was typical, though he could be kind and funny, a generous host, passionate musician, and, in middle age, an unexpectedly successful ocean yachtsman. Thanks to his obsession with the fate of British apples he is still "The Grocer" to the magazine Private Eye.

Someone once said "Ted" would have been a better politician had he lost his temper in public as he did in private. As it was he served Churchill as deputy chief whip (two Churchill paintings, gifts from the great man, still decorate his Salisbury home), was Eden's chief whip in the Suez crisis of 1956, and Macmillan's thwarted European negotiator in the 60s - who finally got Britain in during 1973.

He had won the party leadership in 1965 in reaction to Harold Wilson's election victory over the 13th Earl of Home. As such the music scholar from Balliol, was the first Tory leader of working class stock and became known as a "moderniser".

He lost in 1966 by 100, dared to sack Enoch Powell from the shadow cabinet after the racist "rivers of blood" speech in 1968, then won the June 1970 election in the biggest upset since 1945. Next day an angry woman voter threw red paint over him outside No 10. (He sometimes had that effect on women; it happened again in Brussels, though he also had close women friends - none of whom he married. His long-dead mother appeared to remain the most important woman in his life.) By the time Sir Edward announced his retirement from the Commons yesterday - after 50 years of unbroken service as MP for the Bexley area - his vast experience was increasingly out of kilter with young politicians such as Tony Blair and William Hague. The two leaders were not even born when he won his seat in 1950 thanks to a communist called Job whose 481 votes exceeded his 133 majority, and whose memory Sir Edward would occasionally toast.

Elections

That was when his career was on the fast track upwards. After 1974 he lost two elections in one year - the first an unnecessary "who governs Britain?" election against the striking miners, said critics. Powell, who had said "Vote Labour", sung a gleeful Te Deum. Within months he lost the Conservative leadership to his former education secretary, Mrs Thatcher, and his career went into decline. Close friendship and business ties with communist China did not help. As his reaction to the Tiananmen Square massacre underlined, he could be insensitive to the winds of democratic change. Whereas premier Heath had recoiled from the effects of free market policies on jobs and industry in 1972 - the much scorned u-turn - Thatcher pressed on. Heath, already hurt by her ignoring him, was appalled. Their feud turned into a mega sulk by Heath, whom "Thatcher's children" at Westminster came to despise.

Impressive

Eventually he mellowed from the prickly, formal character which had put so many backs up, and stayed in the Commons long after his Thatcherite enemies had died or gone to the Lords. Alan Clark, an enemy, told his diaries that Ted had become impressive. It did not stop him predicting that Thatcher would be no more than a footnote in history. That verdict is premature. But Heath, who knew Chairman Mao, Charles de Gaulle, Richard Nixon, Khruschev and the rest, has always taken the long view.

The sayings

"I owe everything to my mother" 1950

"This would at a stroke, reduce the rise of prices" Heath press release during 1970 election campaign

"It is the unpleasant and unacceptable face of capitalism" Commons statement, 1973, on Lonrho affair

"Our problem at the moment is a problem of success" Six weeks before the three-day week, 1973

"They have made a grave mistake choosing that woman" On Margaret Thatcher's election to lead Tories, 1975

"He is not mad in the least. He's a very astute person, a clever person" On Saddam Hussein

"It was the most enthralling episode in my life" Interviewed in 1984 about taking Britain into Europe

"Rejoice! Rejoice!" On hearing the news of Margaret Thatcher's resignation, November, 1990

"A tragedy for the party. He's got no ideas, no experience and no hope" On William Hague's election to lead the Tories, 1997

The Career

 Born in Broadstairs, Kent on 9 July 1916.

 Educated at Chatham House school, Ramsgate. Balliol College, Oxford.

 Mentioned in despatches and awarded MBE on demobilisation from army as lieutenant-colonel in 1946.

 Adopted as Tory candidate for Bexley in Kent, 1947.

 Elected MP in February 1950.

 Chief whip under Eden, 1955.

 Appointed minister of labour, 1959.

 Elected leader of Tories, 1965.

 Elected prime minister with 30-seat victory, 1970.

 Signed treaty of accession, 1972.

 Calls early general election resulting in hung parliament in February 1974. After desperate attempts to do a deal with Jeremy Thorpe's Liberals, Heath quits Downing Street, never to return.

 Harold Wilson gained tiny overall majority for Labour in October 1974.

 The following year, Margaret Thatcher wrested leadership of the party from Heath in ballot of Conservative MPs. Heath went to the backbenches, refusing to serve under her.

webTitle: Working Lives: Britain's MPs in their plush new offices

fields.headline: Would you stay in a job for the shagpile?
fields.standfirst:
As Britain's MPs move into their plush new offices, Oliver Burkeman and Merope Mills ask whether handmade leather in-trays and forests of fig trees really make for better workers

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: As Britain's MPs move into their plush new offices, Oliver Burkeman and Merope Mills ask whether handmade leather in-trays and forests of fig trees really make for better workers.
fields.body:
Lembit Opik had a good day at the office yesterday. Perhaps it was the sensual contours of his hand-made leather in-tray that did it, or the way the luxurious (and luxuriously priced) carpet caressed his shoes; or the way the light in the atrium glinted off the water in the fountain. Either way, the Liberal Democrat MP for Montgomeryshire - usually perceived as a man of rather more apocalyptic temperament, given his role as a key voice in the campaign to warn the world of the catastrophic consequences of being hit by a meteorite - certainly enjoyed his first day at work in what is, yard for yard, Britain's most expensive, and arguably most contentious office building, Portcullis House. "Despite all the controversy, it feels good and I think it will feel good for our visitors," he says of the new Westminster home for 210 MPs. "And it did feel great walking into the building."

Once upon a time, the opulent office could be justified - if it needed to be justified at all - on the old-fashioned principles of conspicuous consumption: who could doubt the power and credibility of a government - or a bank, or a management consultancy - that could afford to transform countless tonnes of marble and gleaming steel into a vast, mortality-defying, space-wasting monument to corporate might? But in an age of efficiency, the more likely rationalisation speaks of the need to attract the best talent; to provide them with airy cathedrals in which to worship the god of productivity. Which rather prompts the question: do they work?

Luxury has always been a critical part of the subtle lines of power that crisscross every office floor: used aggressively, the ostentatious demonstration of opulence can be wonderfully flattering - or absolutely terrifying. "The chief executive's office was amazing: awesome mahogany, indescribably deep carpets," recalls a former employee of a major London bank. "If you were summoned, you knew it was because you were pretty special - or because you were in for a serious dressing-down." But whether the marble and the gurgling fountains actually make a serious difference to workplace morale and productivity - whether, in other words, Lembit Opik and his fellow MPs would be one iota less effective in their work if a few thousand pounds less had been spent on the office carpet - seems rather more questionable.

Those who have worked in similarly plush environments testify to the little jolt of happiness - of being wanted - that hit them every time they showed up for work. "Every day I worked in that building I walked through the doors and thought: this feels good ," says one City worker. "You walked off the street and immediately you felt special," another recalls.

Yet complacency settles in pretty fast, even in palaces such as the notorious European Bank of Reconstruction and Development near London's Liverpool Street, where a £66m marble-heavy refurbishment earned it the epithet "the Glistening Bank" and was a key factor in the resignation of its president, Jacques Attali. At one point, more had been spent on revamping the office than on the projects the bank had been established to support. "There was a lot of marble - it was real Bonfire of the Vanities stuff," one former employee recalls. "But, hey - you got used to it."

Organisational psychologists don't buy the luxury-productivity link either (although that might just be jealousy). "There are hygiene factors and motivating factors," says Dr Rob Yeung, a business psychologist at the consultancy Kiddy and Partners. "Hygiene factors are things like having a sufficiently warm office, access to food, drink, shelter - the physiological needs. Once these are satisfied, they no longer actually motivate any further or produce greater performance or quality of thought or things like that. Pay, even, is quite often described as a hygiene factor: once people are paid enough to live OK and go on a few holidays, it doesn't actually motivate people to work any harder."

Forget deep-pile carpets and deeper leather armchairs: quality relationships and control over one's working environment - however grotty - matter more. "The kind of things that make people work harder are feeling valued, feeling like their efforts are recognised, having a good working relationship with colleagues, customers and suppliers, and feeling their needs for achievement are being met in the workplace."

Luxurious surroundings "can make people feel good about themselves, but can have a rebound effect," says Dr Valerie Lamont, a chartered counselling psychologist. "In some people, it creates a sense of 'What am I doing here? This doesn't feel like a comfortable place to work', particularly if there is any discrepancy between the image of the office and the actual working practices."

Then there is the famous "lobby factor" - the predictable tendency for spacious grandeur to be rapidly replaced by low-ceilinged, fluorescent-lit squalor the moment employees pass from the public areas to the private offices. "The lobby was full of marble and chrome and big fountains with goldfish and lovely plants," is a typical observation. "The communal areas were lovely, but the actual offices were horrid. I had to leave because there was a real culture of terror, backstabbing and bullying that was so awful, the lobby frankly wasn't going to keep me."

There is, in any case, something almost embarrassingly old-fashioned about Portcullis House's approach to luxury - the armchairs with snooze buttons, the notorious fig trees. The new economy it ain't: ask any of the burgeoning ranks of edgy, up-to-the-minute office designers to work you up a symphony in marble and cascading fountains, and they would drop their laptops in horror.

"Ten years ago, maybe," says Arnold Levin, director of the Center for Workplace Innovation, a Washington DC-based office design firm. "Then, the law firms we designed for would always be opulent; always stone, wood, marble. But even our law firm clients, though they spend a bit more than our dot.com startups, are very concerned that their clients don't get the impression their fees are being poured into the workplace. Across the board, there's so much more money being spent on technology and wiring and cabling that opulence is the last thing on anybody's mind."

"There has been a dramatic improvement in the work environment - it's acoustically well-designed, natural light is used well - it feels good, and that's got to be good for productivity ... "Despite all the controversy, it feels good and I think it will feel good for our visitors," he says of the new Westminster home for 210 MPs. "And it did feel great walking into the building." fields.headline: Sun Ra Arkestra
fields.standfirst: Jazz Cafe, London ***
fields.trailText: Jazz Cafe, London ***
fields.body:
Just for their gravity-defying headgear, implacably communal, anti-corporate lifestyle, and the claimed capacity for interplanetary travel of its late founder, the Sun Ra Archestra would have been a jazz legend even if it had hardly played a note. Add a bizarrely cross-fertilised repertoire, from 30s big band swing to free improvisation, and you have a unique jazz phenomenon. When the Arkestra flew in to the the Jazz Cafe from whatever galaxy it inhabits, it exhibited its familiar tendency to spend a good while searching for the plot, and then build an increasingly compelling mixture of drama and vaudeville out of it.

Arkestra's detractors often complain that the band can't stay in tune. That point of view wouldn't have been disproved by some of the engagingly sagging, approximately harmonised slow material early in the show, but it only served to confirm the group's street-band strengths.

Lurching episodes of 30s big band swing (Sun Ra was associated with the Fletcher Henderson Orchestra early on), full of squashy, bucolic saxophone voicings, oompah rhythms and ferocious percussion, were followed by Duke Ellington's Sophisticated Lady, boldly delivered as a bowed double base solo, accelerated into jaunty swing for its finale, with Stormy Weather finding its way into the alto sax break. A whooping trombone intro gave way to a tumult of snorting free improvisation, turning abruptly into the kind of surreally cheesy Arkestra vocal performance in which they all sound like Georgie Fame with a sock in his mouth.

Space is the Place, the band's theme song, brought the house down. Fastidious listeners would probably have been happy to discover that by this time they were even more or less in tune.

webTitle: Post Office offers sweeter deal for universal bank players

fields.headline: Post Office offers sweeter deal for universal bank players
fields.standfirst:
Money Unlimited
Special report: the countryside in crisis
fields.trailText: The aims of the controversial universal bank have been broadened by the Post Office to include a wider range of "universal banking services" to increase its chances of winning the support of a sceptical financial services industry, writes Jill Treanor.
fields.body:
The aims of the controversial universal bank have been broadened by the Post Office to include a wider range of "universal banking services" to increase its chances of winning the support of a sceptical financial services industry, writes Jill Treanor.

Basil Larkins, the network banking managing director for the Post Office, said yesterday: "No bank has said they don't want to contribute. No one has turned us down."

So far, however, Barclays is the only major banking group to offer some tentative support for the plan which is at the core of the government's intentions to throw a lifeline to the post office network.

Sources in the Department of Trade and Industry insisted last night that other banking groups would soon start to demonstrate their support.

The Post Office believes the broad plan - under which post office bank ac counts, to be known as "Clear", run alongside the banks' own basic accounts - has "an 80% chance" of winning over the reluctant banks.

The financial services industry is being asked to stump up £130m each year towards providing bank accounts for the 16m benefit claimants who receive their social security payments in cash over post office counters.

After delicate negotiations with major banking groups, the Post Office wants to offer a "tiered portfolio of banking services" through the 18,000 post offices around the country.

Mr Larkins said yesterday that the range of "universal banking services" would include a "simple account for the payment of benefits" in addition to the basic, no-overdraft accounts which the banks have until the end of the month to provide. HSBC, the last of the major banks to announce its basic bank accounts, is now expected to meet he deadline imposed by the Treasury.

Mr Larkins said yesterday that negotiations between the financial companies and the Post Office were continuing.

He confirmed that he was aiming to put out to tender the running of the new accounts next year.

The new accounts are likely to be launched under the "Clear" brand, although Mr Larkins refused to confirm that yesterday.

He indicated that the cost of running the post office accounts would depend on their popularity.

"Our aim if not to compete with other financial institutions over basic bank accounts, but to support their services with a simple account for the payment of benefits and expand the existing successful partnership we already have with a number of banks," Mr Larkins said.

fields.headline: Halifax admits letter gaffe
fields.standfirst:
Bank tells 200,000 customers they risk higher costs with revamped current account

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Halifax has written to more than 200,000 current account customers informing them they risk being penalised with a halt on interest payments, higher charges, and a longer wait for cheques to be cleared.
fields.body:
Halifax has written to more than 200,000 current account customers informing them they risk being penalised with a halt on interest payments, higher charges, and a longer wait for cheques to be cleared.

The bank, which admits its letter was misguided, has just embarked on a highly publicised campaign to shake up the staid current account market.

While the bulk of Halifax customers are being offered lower charges and a ground-breaking 4% interest rate on accounts in credit, letters sent to about 10% of its 2m current account holders make no reference to the new rates and simply warn that their service is being changed and that costs will rise.

"The period you have to wait before you can withdraw money against a cheque paid into your account will increase by one bank working day," the letter informs customers.

The charge for processing cheques, standing orders or direct debits which cannot be paid because of insufficient funds is to be raised from £25 to £28 from December. In addition, to withdraw cash amounts of less than £300, customers will only be able to use cash machines. However, they will not be charged.

The recipients of the letter are also told that the name of their account is being changed to Cardcash from January 9 next year, at which point interest payments, currently 0.25%, will be stopped.

The letter has been sent to those Halifax customers who possess what the bank terms "limited facilities," such as no overdraft facilities.

The bank is also in the process of writing to 2m existing customers of Cardcash, the basic bank account it helped to pioneer for customers who might be turned away from other banks. The treasury has demanded that other banks make such accounts available by the end of this month.

The letters sent to Cardcash customers contain details of improved terms. For instance, "disloyalty charges" will be scrapped, which might save such customers £12 a year. The Cardcash customers are also informed about the new 4% interest rate current account.

A Halifax spokesman last night admitted that the bank had made a mistake in the letters to "limited facilities" customers and pledged to write to them again.

"We're sorry. We've made a mistake and we're going to put it right," the spokesman said. He denied that the move amounted to a surcharge on one class of customer designed to subsidise its aggressive move to win custom from high street rivals, which the Halifax has said will cost it £50m.

Halifax said it would review the details of the customers who received the letters to check their eligibility for the 4% interest rate current account, which it intends to launch next year. To be eligible, the customers must pay £1,000 a month into the account.

Halifax is leading a charge on the current account market, which is dominated by the "big four" - NatWest, Barclays, Lloyds TSB and HSBC. Between them they control about 80% of the current account industry and generally offer low interest rate payments, as little as 0.25%, to accounts in credit.

At the same time, Halifax has been alone amongst the major banks in offering facilities to those with poor credit histories or limited incomes -an area where its rivals are still resisting government pressure to improve their service.

fields.headline: Keepers
fields.standfirst: Hampstead Theatre, London **
fields.trailText: Hampstead Theatre, London **
fields.body:
Some believe that chimpanzees have the cognitive abilities of human five-year-olds and that it is only language that separates us from them. Like us, they certainly have complex social relationships.

In Michele Winstanley's debut play, set in a failing zoo that is about to close unless a philanthropist can be found to save it, it is the keepers who behave like animals. Maggie is intense and uptight, and the strongest relationship in her life appears to be with a sign-reading chimp called Florence; and the bullying, sexist Derek, the headkeeper, treats both staff and animals with contempt. His indifference to the animals and Maggie's unhealthy obsession with them provide the catalyst for Winstanley's drama.

However, while she touches on the way that the characters use animals for their personal agendas just as we use animals in zoos for our entertainment, she never explores the issues or the drama in any depth. With the exception of one dramatically tight, tense scene just before the interval in which Derek physically abuses a chimp who has just given birth, the play refuses to take itself seriously and is always slipping into sitcom mode. At one point things get so lame that a joke is raised from hard-of-hearing Chick's inability to differentiate between the words vegan and virgin.

Plotting is clearly Winstanley's strong point and the play is not just well constructed but thematically clever too. However, the subtleties tend to be lost in writing that can never resist passing up a joke when one looms over on the horizon. There are plenty of signs that this could have been a far better play. Its subject matter is interesting and Winstanley clearly has talent. Its failure is not her failure but the failure of those producing it to shape, prune and develop it into a story worth telling and one that tells us more than that life's a zoo.

 Until November 18. Box office: 020-7722 9301.

webTitle: Working Lives: The way we work: Richard Reeves

fields.headline: Play's the thing
fields.standfirst:
The way we work: Richard Reeves

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The way we work: Richard Reeves...
fields.body:
When Richard Branson jumps into, or off, a moving object, it is easy to see the activity as a publicity stunt for his businesses, building up his image as trusted buccaneer. But PR isn't what drives him. The same spirit that makes him an entrepreneur, a corporate risk-taker, drives him to daredevil activities in his leisure time. And the more on-edge his business life, the more dangerous his out-of-hours pursuits are likely to be because the way we work impacts enormously on the way we play. Air traffic controllers are much more likely to have challenging hobbies, such as rock-climbing, than civil servants, who are keener on a game of chess. We carry our work-shaped traits into the rest of our lives.

Of course, it is possible that we simply choose jobs and hobbies that suit our personalities. But there is good evidence that the nature of our work has an influence on what we do after we clock off. The sociologist Stanley Parker tracked workers over a six-year period and found that those whose jobs had become more passive had become more passive in their leisure hours (TV watching increased, for example), while workers in jobs that had become more active took up more stimulating leisure pursuits. Work maketh the man.

All of which makes even more worrying the recent comments by Labour MP Tess Kingham on the working culture of the House of Commons. She describes the worst part of the job as "hanging around a dank, dark, claustrophobic place until 2am" and the whipping process as "an appalling, bullying system" which supports "schoolboy politics". The pettiness of the systems and debates has driven her away: she is standing down at the next election.

We often criticise our politicians for being bullies, egomaniacs, in love with the sound of their own voices, full of petty jealousies and generally socially dysfunctional - and assume these are the traits that made them go into politics. Perhaps, though, it is the absurd nature of the work that creates the absurd natures of many politicians.

At the other end of the occupational scale, Joanne Ciulla, a US academic, cites bingo as an example of the work-leisure link. Bingo is most popular among workers with low-skilled, production line jobs - disproportionately women. Ciulla points out the eerie similarities between bingo and routine work: "It is played in a large hall and the players sit at tables in rows. There is a caller and a 'supervisor'. Players ... 'work' through their card and if it goes well they get paid. The supervisor designates periods for refreshment. There is no skill or personal challenge in the game. Bingo allows for socialising, but that, too, is somewhat limited by the nature of the game."

If you find yourself TV-watching for long periods, it's probably time for a new job. Recruitment firms might want to set up in bingo halls.

The umbilical cord between our work and play personas demonstrates the falsity of the division between work and home, labour and leisure. Pat Kane, the former pop singer and social commentator, has called for a new "play ethic" to replace the obsolete work version, arguing that we need to rediscover creativity, freedom, fun. He's right that we need a more playful philosophy of life - but he is wrong to counterpoise work and play. His call for a 35-hour week is based on an assumption that work cannot be playful, when it can and should be. Indeed, a fun and friendly environment consistently tops polls of what workers want from their jobs.

The play ethic is a great idea, but we won't get it by corralling work into a corner of our lives and treating it as the penance we pay for our hours of fun. If work is drudgery, chances are the rest of our lives will be, too. The point is to inject play into work, not take it away. As self-styled "philosopher for the proletariat" Bob Black puts it: "You are what you do. The problem is that if you do boring, stupid, monotonous work, chances are you'll end up boring, stupid and monotonous."

Filthy lucre

Gordon Brown is a crusader for "full and fulfilling" employment, and has called for better working conditions for all Britain's workers. But at the Treasury, magnet for the brightest and best of Whitehall's workers, it seems that some have failed to take his message to heart. On the wall of a Treasury toilet is the following sign: "To the person who is wiping excrement on the cubicle walls/floors. This is disgusting. Please have some respect for your fellow workers." Disgusting indeed. Still, where there's muck ...

He's right that we need a more playful philosophy of life - but he is wrong to counterpoise work and play. His call for a 35-hour week is based on an assumption that work cannot be playful, when it can and should be. Indeed, a fun and friendly environment consistently tops polls of what workers want from their jobs. The play ethic is a great idea, but we won't get it by corralling work into a corner of our lives and treating it as the penance we pay for our hours of fun. If work is drudgery, chances are the rest of our lives will be, too. The point is to inject play into work, not take it away. As self-styled "philosopher for the proletariat" Bob Black puts it: "You are what you do. The problem is that if you do boring, stupid, monotonous work, chances are you'll end up boring, stupid and monotonous." Filthy lucre Gordon Brown is a crusader for "full and fulfilling" employment, and has called for better working conditions for all Britain's workers. But at the Treasury, magnet for the brightest and best of Whitehall's workers, it seems that some have failed to take his message to heart. On the wall of a Treasury toilet is the following sign: "To the person who is wiping excrement on the cubicle walls/floors. This is disgusting. Please have some respect for your fellow workers." Disgusting indeed. Still, where there's muck ...

fields.headline: Alison Wilding
fields.standfirst:
Henry Moore Foundation Studio, Halifax
***
fields.trailText: Henry Moore Foundation Studio, Halifax ***
fields.body:
Alison Wilding is a sculptor of primal abstraction. She curls metal plates around pillars of stone, slots wedges into hollows, creates pools of colour your eyes can dive into. Impenetrable steel opens to reveal organic depths. If her works tell a story, it is the story of their own making. They are constructions that have found their true form through a painstaking orchestration of the innate qualities of the rawest of raw materials. Her sculptures are never representations of things; they are things in themselves.

They are self-referential, self-sufficient: so what is the artist doing accepting a commission to produce 12 sculptures based on The Passion? And why show the half-completed project within the imposing post-industrial grandeur of the Henry Moore Foundation Studio?

The Dean Clough Studio is haunted by its industrial history as a monolithic carpet factory. It is also haunted by a history, established by its recently deceased director, Robert Hopper, as one of the most prestigious warehouse venues for international installation art. Yet this is really an exhibition, not an installation. Wilding's works are scattered around the dusty slab-stone floors as if they have arrived from another, more appropriate, place, perhaps a white-cube gallery or a modernist church.

She has titled the exhibition Contract and based individual pieces loosely on the themes of Christ's entry into Jerusalem, the betrayal and the entombment. She masks such references with titles like Deep Water, Inversion and Harbour and she does right. In fact, I can't help but think she might have been better keeping quiet about the whole business of the contractual theme. As it is, an upended circular slab of concrete set against a latex carpet of hairy spikes automatically brings to mind haloes and crowns of thorns. A slit carved into a block of alabaster and filled with a black tarry spillage is reminiscent of a wound.

Worse, the red of a roll of translucent plastic is blood red. This surely goes against the Wilding grain, according to her past achievements. A good piece by this artist can be a profound sensuous presence. She is one of those rare artists capable of momentarily freeing the viewer from the clumsiness and complication of wordy thought.

Here the words, and they are pretty serious words, just get in the way.

 Until January. Information: 0113 247 0505.

webTitle: Abbey upbeat on financial services breakthrough

fields.headline: Abbey upbeat on financial services breakthrough
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Abbey National's drive to recruit current account customers has resulted in a 50% rise in applications in the past three months compared with the first half of the year.
fields.body:
Abbey National's drive to recruit current account customers has resulted in a 50% rise in applications in the past three months compared with the first half of the year.

Updating the City on its business in the crucial financial services battlefield in the third quarter of the financial year, Abbey also said it was on track to have its best year for mortgages since 1993.

Along with Halifax, Abbey is trying to crack open the 80% share of the current account market dominated by the "big four" - NatWest, HSBC, Barclays and Lloyds TSB.

Abbey, which bought Scot tish Provident last month, is also under pressure to show it is performing strongly in order to stem speculation that investors are pressing for the removal of Ian Harley as chief executive, clearing the way for a takeover by a rival.

The bank last week revealed it had made a £70m profit on the sale and lease-back of its properties, including its head office and branches, to a property group backed by international financier George Soros.

It is also running pilot "franchise" schemes for the management of some of its 650 branches which it believes will boost sales.

The bank intends to try attracting new business next month with a product aimed at customers with £50,000 or more to invest.

Abbey's Cahoot internet bank has prompted 145,000 inquries and 92,000 applications, of which only 45,000 have been accepted.

While the bank tried to paint an upbeat picture for the majority of its operations, it admitted that business conditions in the motor industry were "depressed".

Abbey's shares ended the day 1p higher at 875p.

John-Paul Crutchley, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said: "Indications are that cost spend on new initatives will ease in 2001. We remain cautious on the revenue outlook".

fields.headline: Simon's still up there after all these years
fields.standfirst:
Paul Simon
Hammersmith Apollo, London
****
fields.trailText:
Paul Simon
Hammersmith Apollo, London ****
fields.body:
Since 1991, when Paul Simon last toured Britain, he has not burnt the candle at either end. Until the new album, You're the One, there have been only compilations, The Capeman - 1997's unsuccessful musical - and a US tour last year with Bob Dylan.

Simon's status as a great 20th-century artist rests chiefly upon his songwriting, with a nod to his appealing and careful voice. But it has nothing to do with his stage prowess. He hardly looks the part, a tiny 58-year-old son of New Jersey, clad in black, crowned by a baldness-hiding baseball cap.

No snake-hips, Simon settles on a non-committal bobbing and weaving, enhanced by some peculiar circular waving, which is eventually revealed as conducting motions. When, however, he takes the microphone off its stand and into his hands, as on the deceptively upbeat death song, Darling Lorraine, he is compelling.

Simon's albums are all subtle words and crafted sounds. Live, his genius lies within his exquisitely drilled, all-male band, 11 of them and not one an extravagance.

Diamonds on the Soles of her Shoes is a slight tune at best on record. Here, without sacrificing the song's template, what is now a musical behemoth begins with a startling a cappella chant, glides into the township jive alongside which Simon's voice is so comfortable, quickly diverts into a Mardi Gras brass carnival and then exits via a clattering percussion finale. Wonderful stuff.

There is much more over the 150 minutes: drummer Steve Gadd's apocalyptic introduction to The Boy in the Bubble; the gorgeous cascading melodies of The Teacher; the brass salute on You Can Call Me Al, and a rambunctious Me and Julio Down by the School Yard, a simpler song from more gentle times attacked with modern vigour.

As much old folkie as world traveller, Simon aired a mere smidgen of his canon with Art Garfunkel. A strangely truncated Bridge Over Troubled Water never quite soared but I Am a Rock, Homeward Bound and Old Friends/Bookends were stripped down for crowd singalongs. Back on the solo trail, 50 Ways to Leave Your Lover (there are still only five) and Late in the Evening, the 1980 song that shaped much of Simon's subsequent work, were given more luxurious musical treatment, bathed in sumptuous lighting.

He says little bar a repeated, oleaginous "thank you sooooo much", but the set is so brisk that his versatile band swap instruments while finishing the previous song.

Given his age and rate of touring, it may be some time before Britain sees Paul Simon again, but this was special.

 Ends tonight. Box office: 0870 606 3400).

fields.headline: LPO/Nagano
fields.standfirst:
Royal Festival Hall, London
**
fields.trailText:
Royal Festival Hall, London
**
fields.body:
Kathleen Battle's appearance with the London Philharmonic Orchestra and Kent Nagano was the sort of display of brute diva-force that one assumed had disappeared with the downfall of the great musical and political dictatorships of the 20th century.

Even off-stage, Battle was determined to rule the rostrum. Preceding her first entrance with a series of proclamatory warm-up scales, Battle then interrupted Nagano's up-beat before Mozart's Overture to the Marriage of Figaro. Nothing was going to get in the way of her winning the audience's attention - certainly not the small matter of being in the green room rather than on the platform.

In a bizarrely ordered sequence of numbers - the overture was sandwiched between two of Susanna's arias from Figaro and the concert aria Misera, dove son! - Battle was at pains to give each a contrasting dramatic profile. Her costume - a black dress topped off with a swathe of pink extravagance - responded compliantly to her every command, creating a suitable coquettishness for Un moto di gioia (written for Figaro's 1789 Vienna run) and a seductive glamour in Deh vieni. But, sadly, this attire proved capable of greater variety than her voice.Unevenly balanced across her range, Battle was ill-equipped for the subtleties of some of Mozart's most delicate music.

But then subtlety was hardly on the cards in Battle's presentation. The way she ended Deh vieni with a sultry kiss to the audience signalled her concern for flamboyance first and music second. The nadir of her disregard of musical sense and structure was her performance of Mozart's motet, Exultate jubilate. Using Mozart to show off her prowess, she abused words and music alike in a wilfully distorted interpretation.

Some of Battle's grotesque milking of the audience might have been excusable had her singing come close to matching the supreme confidence of her showmanship. But there were few hints of any transcendent musicality.

Throughout, Nagano and the LPO were in bemused submission to the hollow domination of Battle's overpowering presence. The rest of the programme restored a balance of seriousness and integrity. The totally focused energy of Thomas Adès' These Premises are Alarmed - originally written in 1996 for Nagano and the Hallé Orchestra - was magnificently ebullient in the LPO's performance.

Nagano's well-judged account of Strauss's Also Sprach Zarathustra ended the concert.

fields.headline: Avanti!/ Oramo
fields.standfirst:
Symphony Hall, Birmingham
****
fields.trailText: Symphony Hall, Birmingham ****
fields.body:
Avanti! is Finland's equivalent of the London Sinfonietta or Ensemble Intercontemporain - a chamber orchestra, founded in 1983 by the conductors Esa-Pekka Salonen and Jukka-Pekka Saraste, to specialise in contemporary music. The City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra's music director, Sakari Oramo, has appeared with Avanti! as both violinist and conductor, and that was the connection which brought the band to Symphony Hall on Tuesday, under the auspices of the Birmingham Contemporary Music Group.

There was new and nearly new Finnish music from a new composer and a major European figure respectively. The premiere came from Uljas Pulkkis, who at the age of 25 has already picked up a clutch of prizes, and boasts Lindberg and Salonen as former teachers. This joint Avanti! and BCMG commission, At the Scarlet Sage, inspired by a film of hummingbirds feeding, showed that he already has a well-honed technique: he fills its 15 minute with cunningly layered orchestral textures which constantly change their harmonic relationship. The sound is Boulez-like, harking back to his Eclat/Multiples in its shimmering tremolos and busy, intricate details, but there is strength and sinew behind the delicacy, sudden thrusts that give the work its direction and rigour.

Kaija Saariaho's Graal Theatre was not a British premiere - the work was commissioned by the BBC and performed first at the Proms in 1995 - but it was the first chance to hear the scaled-down version of what was originally a concerto for violin and full orchestra.

Even in this scoring it is a substantial work; dense, tangled and sometimes hard to grasp, with the challenging solo part (authoritatively negotiated by the leader of Avanti!, John Storgards) swathed in instrumental lines. It is one of the pieces in which Saariaho was preparing the way for her first opera, premiered in Salzburg this year; the landmarks are vivid, theatrical gestures which emerge from the fabric to take on immense significance - a descending series of tones in the second movement, for instance, seems to open up unexplored vistas in the work.

Avanti performed with great confidence and concentration and Oramo showed again that he is an expert conductor of new scores. An account of Schreker's Chamber Symphony was less convincing - ideally, the lush sonorities need more rhapsodic treatment than Oramo gave them in his bright-toned performance, which unexpectedly conjured up echoes of Delius.

fields.headline: B&B payouts estimated at £700
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Windfalls to Bradford & Bingley members should be worth around £700 each, according to a new forecast from financial bookmaker City Index.
fields.body:
Windfalls to Bradford & Bingley members should be worth around £700 each, according to a new forecast from financial bookmaker City Index.

The bookmaker yesterday opened a grey market on the Bradford & Bingley flotation, due on December 4, when every eligible member will receive 250 shares.

City Index has set its prediction for the share price at the end of the first day's trading at a range of 275p to 285p, which translates into a predicted total windfall of between £687 and £712 and would give B&B a market value of around £1.9bn.

This compares with the official estimate earlier this year from Goldman Sachs - which is advising on the flotation - of a price between 259p and 326p a share, which would mean hand-outs worth between £647 and £815.

However, the new forecast is substantially higher than earlier predictions from analysts who claimed windfalls could be as low as £400 because of the competition raging in home loans and banking.

"This estimate means we think every Bradford and Bingley saver will get around £700," said a City Index spokesman. B&B is sending letters giving more details of the float to members, who must decide whether they wish to keep their shares.

Members will be able to sell their shares immediately if they wish, and if they elect to do so they will be sent a cheque for the proceeds around December 12. Alternatively they can opt to hold their shares in a Bradford & Bingley nominee account or request a share certificate be sent to them.

With the flotation coming just three weeks before Christmas, analysts expect up to 40% of members will choose to sell their shares.

Members must return their form saying what they wish to do by November 24.

But the packs being sent out include no new information on the prospective value of Bradford & Bingley plc. This has led some commentators to claim members are being asked to make their decision armed with very little information about what the shares may be worth.

The conversion was approved by more than 90% of members.

webTitle: Flintoff finally plays big innings on big stage

fields.headline: Flintoff finally plays big innings on big stage
fields.trailText: England have now played 321 one-day internationals, but not one of them was like this. In Karachi today they pulled off the biggest run-chase in their history, and one of the greatest, right up there with Allan Lamb's 18 off the final over in Sydney 14 years ago.
fields.body:
England have now played 321 one-day internationals, but not one of them was like this. In Karachi today they pulled off the biggest run-chase in their history, and one of the greatest, right up there with Allan Lamb's 18 off the final over in Sydney 14 years ago.

The magic on that occasion was the twist in the tale, the shock on the faces of the Aussies as the story changed in a few minutes. Today the magic lay elsewhere, in the steadiness with which England climbed the mountain that Pakistan had set in front of them. They didn't just score 300; they scored 300 without having to accelerate at the end. The closing slog which huge totals usually entail - and which Abdur Razzaq had demonstrated briliantly earlier in the day - was never needed, because the foot on the gas had come an hour earlier. In four overs from the 36th, Graham Thorpe and Andy Flintoff added 43. "You can't just go out and smack bowlers like Pakistan's around," Nasser Hussain had warned yesterday. Just occasionally, when the force (and the dew) is with you, you can.

For two years, we have waited to see Flintoff in full flow. Today he delivered - almost literally, as the sweat poured off him like rain at Old Trafford. At last, after all those 16s and 27s, the big bully was playing a big innings on the big stage. He has arrived now; there will be no jibes about his weight as long as he plays like this. When he told everyone he didn't have a weight problem, maybe he was right after all: he just needed to spend time in the middle, in the 40-degree heat of Asia. Allrounders? Who needs 'em?

Thorpe played the perfect foil to Flintoff, older, wiser, and less explosive, but almost as effective. He played second fiddle, but he was also the conductor, controlling the tempo. And don't forget Hussain, who proved himself right, and pundits like me wrong, by staying at No.3 and rebuilding the innings with a wily mixture of patience and controlled aggression. This was his first 50 against major opposition since South Africa, nine long months ago, and it came, with perfect timing, after Alec Stewart and Marcus Trescothick had both failed. Among other milestones, this was the first time England had won with both of those two failing - the only other time it happened was against South Africa in Kenya the other day, and they lost heavily.

When Pakistan concede this many runs, the question inevitably pops into people's heads: were they trying? Imran Nazir certainly was, flinging himself about at backward point like a Jonty. Abdur Razzaq was too. Later, there were one or two misfields or botched slower balls that made you wonder. But everyone makes mistakes and every cricket match should be taken at face value until there is actually hard evidence to suggest otherwise. This was a memorable one-day game, a tale of two firework displays. And anything Abdur Razzaq could do, Andy Flintoff could do better.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com. To read Lawrence Booth's regularly updated bulletins on the match, click here. For the scorecard, click here

In four overs from the 36th, Graham Thorpe and Andy Flintoff added 43. "You can't just go out and smack bowlers like Pakistan's around," Nasser Hussain had warned yesterday. Just occasionally, when the force (and the dew) is with you, you can. For two years, we have waited to see Flintoff in full flow. Today he delivered - almost literally, as the sweat poured off him like rain at Old Trafford. At last, after all those 16s and 27s, the big bully was playing a big innings on the big stage. He has arrived now; there will be no jibes about his weight as long as he plays like this. When he told everyone he didn't have a weight problem, maybe he was right after all: he just needed to spend time in the middle, in the 40-degree heat of Asia. Allrounders? Who needs 'em? Thorpe played the perfect foil to Flintoff, older, wiser, and less explosive, but almost as effective. He played second fiddle, but he was also the conductor, controlling the tempo. And don't forget Hussain, who proved himself right, and pundits like me wrong, by staying at No.3 and rebuilding the innings with a wily mixture of patience and controlled aggression. This was his first 50 against major opposition since South Africa, nine long months ago, and it came, with perfect timing, after Alec Stewart and Marcus Trescothick had both failed. Among other milestones, this was the first time England had won with both of those two failing - the only other time it happened was against South Africa in Kenya the other day, and they lost heavily. When Pakistan concede this many runs, the question inevitably pops into people's heads: were they trying? Imran Nazir certainly was, flinging himself about at backward point like a Jonty. Abdur Razzaq was too. Later, there were one or two misfields or botched slower balls that made you wonder. But everyone makes mistakes and every cricket match should be taken at face value until there is actually hard evidence to suggest otherwise. This was a memorable one-day game, a tale of two firework displays. And anything Abdur Razzaq could do, Andy Flintoff could do better. Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com. fields.headline: RCN deplores senior nurse downgrading
fields.standfirst: Trusts are downgrading senior nurse jobs in order to save money, claims RCN.
fields.trailText: Senior nurses are being downgraded by stealth while being given increased responsibilities, according to the Royal College of Nursing.
fields.body:
Senior nurses are being downgraded by stealth while being given increased responsibilities, the Royal College of Nursing said yesterday.

In its evidence to the pay review body, the RCN claimed that chronic shortages and a reduction in the number of staff in top grades could jeopardise government plans to modernise the NHS. Big pay rises were needed to halt the numbers leaving the profession and to encourage more people into nursing.

Christine Hancock, general secretary of the RCN, said: "A substantial pay rise for every nurse would kick start recruitment, motivate nurses to return and others to stay."

The government has pledged an extra 20,000 nurses by 2004 as part of the NHS plan published in July, which also includes the creation of "modern matrons" who would have greater power on the wards.

The RCN said that the number of nurses in the top three clinical nursing grades (G, H and I) had shrunk by more than 13% in the past eight years. Hardest hit were the grade G senior nursing sisters whose numbers had fallen by 9,000.

There are 20,000 nursing vacancies across the country, with 9,900 posts left vacant for three months or more. Last year the NHS spent £344m on agency staff to cover shortages.

The RCN survey, which canvassed the views of up to 6,000 nurses, blamed the downgrading of roles on NHS trusts trying to meet government efficiency savings.

In 1992, 64% of ward managers were grade D and above. This figure dropped to 52% in 2000. Of district managers 84% were grade F or higher in 1992, compared with 57% now.

The RCN membership survey also found that only 12% of nurses thought they were well paid for their workload. About 26% of nurses indicated they intended to leave the profession in the next two years.

fields.trailText: THE GUARDIAN

THE GUARDIAN

Actors in the US have agreed terms with advertisers that could mean a return to work within the next few days. (p3)
The investigative journalist Donal MacIntyre launched a libel action against a police force yesterday over comment it made about his report into abuse at a care home. (p9)
NewsCorp has cut about 15% of the editorial jobs at News Digital Media, its online media division. (p24)
A teenage entrepreneur has made £300,000 by selling a website he set up in his bedroom 18 months ago. (p24)
Internet users who spend hours searching the web are being targeted by KeepUpdated.com, a website that goes live today. (p24)
A website that allows users to talk to experts simply by logging on, Questico, launched yesterday.
WPP yesterday announced bumper figures on the back of millennium celebrations, the Olympics and new business from global companies such as Ford and Nike. (p25)
Anthea Turner on the violence she says she suffered at the hands of her former lover, Bruno Brooks. (G2, p4)

THE INDEPENDENT

Undercover television reporter Donal MacIntyre has launched a libel action against the police. (p5)
The Clangers are being reincarnated as soft toys by Golden Bear Products. (p12)
WPP has shrugged off a slowing worldwide advertising market to report buoyant third-quarter revenue figures with new business pouring in from top clients such as Ford and Nike. (p17)
Totally, the Aim-listed operator of the totallyjewish website, is taking over rivals sojewish and freesheet newspaper the London Jewish News, in an all-paper deal. (p17)
Richard Li, the son of Li Ka-shing, Hong Kong's richest tycoon, is reported to be turning to his father to help bail out his Pacific Century CyberWorks, the internet and telecoms company. (p20)
