David Lister looks at "instant experts", who can be called on at short notice for comment in situations such as last week's fatal rail crash. (p8)
Want to see as well as hear Sue MacGregor grill a minister on BBC Radio's Today programme? Now, thanks to BBC Online, you can. (p8)
MT Rainey has a strong admiration for M&S and Rainey Kelly Campbell's advert, with model Amy Davis, has redefined a brand that was seeing its profits slump. (p9)
Israeli outrage at the BBC's coverage of hostilities in the Middle East has provoked not just a robust defence, but an editorial change of tack.(p9)

THE DAILY TELEGRAPH

Cable & Wireless yesterday dipped 2% as the market worried about the impact of the $1.6bn funding raising exercise announced yesterday by Pacific Century CyberWorks. (p34)
WPP yesterday reported more than 25% growth in third quarter revenues. (p34)
Dominic Mills, editorial director of Campaign and Marketing, looks at the rise of radio advertising and WPP's Sir Martin Sorrell in his adhoc column. (p35)
The Telegraph also carries a two-page special report on mobile telecoms. (p38-9)

Camelot's lottery contract may be extended into 2002 because of worries that there will be a further delay in the award of the next franchise. (p4)
Television licence payers will pay for a costly libel action begun yesterday by Donal MacIntyre, the undercover reporter, against a police force that accused him of making a misleading documentary. (p10)
Sir Martin Sorrell, chief executive of WPP, yesterday appeared to dampen speculation that Sir Christopher Lewinton, the retiring chairman of the TI Group, might join the board as chairman. (p27)
Richard Li yesterday said he would sink $500m (£343m) of his own money into a new bond issue aimed at refinancing Pacific Century CyberWorks. (p32)

WPP is widening its search for a new chairman beyond initial favourite Sir Christopher Lewinton following negative response from some shareholders, people familiar with the situation said. (p4)
Manoeuvring Microsoft: Ballmer says "right set of tools" can slingshot internet use in Europe. (p31)
Dynamics shift between AOL and Time Warner. (p31)
The companies that sell and register website addresses are about to see the market open up drastically. (p32)
Boxman.com will commence liquidation proceedings today, after failing in a last-ditch effort to raise funding. (p32)
Firm says it can track America Online advertisers. (p33)
US advertisers and the actors' unions have reached a tentative contract agreement. (p33)

Coronation Street fans will next week be dying to snap up a new book celebrating 40 years of the hit show. (p19)
Top TV shows are to be interrupted by more commercial breaks. (p19)
Hit telly quiz Who Wants to be a Millionaire? is to hold a special show - for couples. (p21)
Soccer fans are facing a World Cup blackout in 2002 because of a huge hike in TV rights. (p50)

FINANCIAL TIMES

Internet executives are four times more likely to have "unsavoury backgrounds" than executives from other industries, according to an investigation by Kroll Associates, the corporate security company. (p1)
Shopsmart.com, the online directory of shopping websites, yesterday ejected one of its featured retailers after up to 7,000 customers and card details were exposed on the internet. (p6)

Internet "cybersquatting" individuals are registering possible domain names ahead of merged groups. (p18)
US actors and advertisers end dispute. (p18)
Ross Kemp features on front page of Companies & Markets section as Carlton Communications closes in on HTV. (p29)
WPP has shrugged off a downturn in the internet sector by recording a 26% jump in revenues in the third quarter.(p30)
The Rugby Football Union has agreed a three-year sponsorship deal with Investec, the banking group, worth £1.55m.
The strong demand for a public relations service from the burgeoning number of high technology companies was highlighted yesterday by the 60% advance in turnover achieved by Text 100 at the end of its first year as a listed company. (p34)
A strong first half performance by Silvio Berlusconi's Fininvest has increased the chances of an offering of holding next year. (p36)
Pacific Century Cyberworks, Richard Li's internet company, is to fight its rising debt with a bond and rights issue. (p37)
Four of Japan's largest electronics companies are joining forces to exploit the rapidly expanding market for interactive television. (p37)
French telecoms equipment manufacturer Alcatel and US internet software firm Oracle are building a joint technology platform, Thirdspace, that will enable telecoms companies to offer interactive TV services. (p38)

THE MIRROR

Anthea Turner has claimed that her former lover Bruno Brookes beat her up during their stormy years together. (p7)
ITV is planning a husband and wife version of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? . (p11)
ITV's Heartbeat hammered BBC's Casualty by five million viewers on Sunday. (p23)
And more on Charlie Dimmock's cheating. (p25)

Anthea Turner: Brutal Bruno Brookes used to beat me. (P1)
Cold Feet stars have pocketed £1m from overseas programme sales. (p3)
The Royle Family is about to go into mourning with a mystery death. (p3)
Panorama US election special a turn-off. (p6)
A-Z of Britain's luvvies including Melvyn Bragg, Greg Dyke and Waheed Alli. (p15)

THE DAILY EXPRESS

A supermarket magazine edited by Delia Smith's husband has been criticised by a watchdog for encouraging children to eat junk food. (p11)

DAILY MAIL

Brutal Bruno beat me up, says Anthea Turner. (p23)
WPP says the controversial Sir Christopher Lewinton may still become its chairman. (p66)

webTitle: Patients at risk from locums system

fields.headline: Patients at risk from locums system
fields.standfirst: Anaesthetist struck off is one of many poorly trained locums
fields.trailText: The government is likely to come under renewed pressure to put a stop to the wholesale - and unchecked - employment of locums after the General Medical Council struck off an anaesthetist whose blunders led to the death of a 10 year-old boy.
fields.byline: Sarah Boseley, health correspondent, The Guardian
fields.body:
The government is likely to come under renewed pressure to put a stop to the wholesale - and unchecked - employment of locums after the General Medical Council yesterday struck off an anaesthetist whose blunders led to the death of a 10 year-old boy.

John Evans-Appiah worked for more than 20 years as an NHS locum doctor before finally getting full registration just a year before the boy, Darren Denholm, died after dentistry treatment. Three weeks later, a woman was put through a nightmare of pain when Evans-Appiah inadequately anaesthetised her for a caesarean section.

Despite a devastating report by the audit commission 18 months ago, which said that patient safety was being put at risk by the failure of hospital trusts and health authorities to check employed locums, nothing has yet been done.

The audit commission found that although just over 70% of trusts saw references from past employers, only 38% checked them, and fewer than 10% saw certificates establishing the doctors' qualifications.

Evans-Appiah was described by the fatal accident inquiry held in Edinburgh, following Darren's death, as one of "a tribe of wandering locums". The audit commission report said there could be 3,500 locums working in the NHS on any day. A third of the trusts had reported adverse events of some kind, from very minor to serious, associated with locums in the past year.

Evans-Appiah was one of the 70% who qualified overseas - a group considered insufficiently trained to have full status and a permanent job and yet who were employed often without question. The NHS relies upon them to fill its staff shortfalls.

The GMC's professional conduct committee found 17 charges proved against Evans-Appiah. Yesterday it said it amounted to professional misconduct and ordered his name be erased from the register.

Mary Clark-Glass, chairing the committee, said EvansAppiah had been guilty of "critical failings" and failed to meet "basic standards" of patient care. The Ghanaian-born doctor, who trained in Ukraine, was also found guilty of dishonestly trying to cover his tracks by creating false medical records relating to Darren's death and trying to get staff at the Peffermill dental clinic to agree to them.

The British Medical Association said it had supported the audit commission's call for reform of the locum system. Ian Bogle, BMA chairman, said: "We said action was needed to provide effective supervision and careers guidance for such doctors early in their careers, otherwise they tend to become permanent locums without access to proper training and study leave. When doctors are moving from post to post, often for short periods of employment, quality checks on their competence are vital."

Last November, the government published a consultation document on dealing with poorly performing doctors, which recognised that locums represented "a particular problem because there is seldom an on-going relationship with a single employer". It suggested "smart cards" for locums to prove they had no black marks against them. Last night a Department of Health spokesman said the system needed "someone to own and be responsible for locums".

Delivering the GMC's decision on Evans-Appiah, Mrs Glass told him: "You failed to ensure an adequate level of anaesthesia before instructing the dentist to go ahead. When Darren moved you compounded this by failing to administer more anaesthetic. Instead you instructed the dentist to administer a local anaesthetic which [had] adrenaline and which you should have known was contraindicated." She said he had failed to adequately monitor Darren's physiological state and to follow even "the basic life support procedure".

Three weeks later Evans-Appiah had failed to ensure an adequate level of anaesthesia during a caesarean operation on 33-year-old Hazel Woolger. In July 1993, while he was a locum registrar at the Falkirk and district hospital, he had also put a patient's life in danger by mistakenly giving a paralysis-inducing drug for a caesarean, which stopped the woman breathing. He was then put on limited registration on condition that his performance be monitored.

webTitle: Flintoff leads England to historic win

fields.headline: Flintoff leads England to historic win
fields.standfirst:
Pakistan 304 for 9 (50 overs)
England 306 for 5 (47.2 overs)
Click here for the full scorecard
fields.trailText: Close-of-play bulletin
fields.body:
Close-of-play bulletin

England pulled off an outstanding five-wicket win over Pakistan in Karachi to go 1-0 up in the best-of-three one-day series. They reached their target of 305 with 16 balls to spare - only three sides have scored more to win a one-day international. Four batsmen passed fifty, but the best innings was played by Andy Flintoff, whose 84 from 60 balls contained the sort of clean hitting he had previously reserved for the county game. He shared a matchwinning fifth-wicket stand of 105 with Graham Thorpe, who finished unbeaten on 64.

England began the final 15 overs still needing 106 to win and with the game in the balance. But Thorpe used his feet to drive Abdur Razzaq through the covers on the up, and when Flintoff pulled Razzaq for six in the next over, it began to look as if England could do it.

Flintoff pulled a waist-high no-ball from Wasim Akram into the stands at midwicket in the next over and soon after moved to a 39-ball half-century. It was awesome stuff, and a crowd that had heaved with delight during Abdur Razzaq's dazzling 75 not out from 40 balls was reduced to a quiet hum.

Thorpe got to 50 himself, from 51 deliveries, and the 100 stand came up in the 42nd over. Flintoff promptly lifted Waqar Younis over long-off for his third six. Maybe England will think twice before sending him home after the one-day series.

It looked as if Flintoff would be there at the end, but with three runs needed he edged Razzaq to Moin Khan and left cursing angrily. He needn't have been so harsh on himself: he had just played one of England's great one-day knocks.

35-over bulletin

England and Pakistan were on course for a tight finish in the first one-day international at Karachi. Set 305 to win, England had reached 199 for 4 after 35 overs, and needed a further 106 to win off 15 overs. A lot depended on Graham Thorpe (35) and Andy Flintoff (13).

The pressure finally got to Hussain, who had already got away with a couple of mishits into empty spaces. He lunged forward at Mushtaq Ahmed and was beaten by a ball that didn't turn much. Video replays confirmed Moin Khan's stumping had been successful, and Hussain departed for 73 to make it 164 for 4.

webTitle: 3m Palestinians trapped in prison that once was home

fields.headline: 3m Palestinians trapped in prison that once was home
fields.standfirst:
3m Palestinians trapped by war

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Malake Kafishe was seven months' pregnant and happily looking forward to the birth of her second child. Then, last Thursday night, as on so many nights in Hebron's old city lanes - among the fiercest battle grounds in the West Bank - she heard gunfire.
fields.body:
Malake Kafishe was seven months' pregnant and happily looking forward to the birth of her second child. Then, last Thursday night, as on so many nights in Hebron's old city lanes - among the fiercest battle grounds in the West Bank - she heard gunfire.

She froze. "There was shooting, and then I heard the helicopter gunships coming in and my heart just stopped." She began to bleed and ran for the stairs, stumbling over the last few rungs and collapsing in a heap on the doorstep.

Her family rang for an ambulance. Because of the shooting and a curfew imposed on 40,000 Palestinians in Hebron's old city, it took an hour to arrive. Two soldiers insisted on examining Ms Kafishe.

There were four more checkpoints before the ambulance arrived at Alia hospital. At each roadblock, soldiers swung open the vehicle doors and peered at the ashen-faced woman inside. By the time she reached the hospital, a journey that normally takes five minutes, one and a half hours had elapsed. The baby was dead.

"The doctor told me 'If you had got here 20 minutes earlier you could have saved the baby'," she says.

The Kafishes are among the hidden casualties of nearly four weeks of killing. On October 6, in an effort to choke off protests by Palestinians armed with catapults as well as guns, the Israeli army sealed off the the West Bank and Gaza, consigning nearly 3m Palestinians to an open-air prison.

In the old city of Hebron - a particularly volatile flashpoint because of the presence of some 200 Jewish settlers in a fortress-like compound - the restrictions are even harsher. Since October 1, Palestinian residents have been under 24-hour curfew and barred from leaving their homes. The Jewish settlers are free to leave at any time.

Aside from the Israeli soldiers hunkered down in watch-towers above the Abraham Avinu settlement, or training their guns on the deserted alleys from their sandbagged enclosures on the rooftops of Palestinian houses, the old city of Hebron was like a ghost town yesterday morning. Shops were shuttered and curtains drawn.

There was no sign of life until 1pm, when an Israeli jeep equipped with a megaphone rumbled through a market that in normal times is thronged with people, and announced a four-hour reprieve. It was only the fifth break in the curfew in 23 days.

Children cooped up for days tumbled into the streets, women in headscarves and long cloaks scurried out to search for food and men congregated at doorways, smoking cigarettes.

The ceasefire proclaimed at last week's emergency summit in the Egyptian resort town of Sharm el-Sheikh compelled Israel to gradually lift the closure on the West Bank and Gaza.

Now, with the ceasefire in tatters, Israel is tightening its grip on Palestinian territories, severing roads to towns and villages with concrete barricades, and sandbags. Nablus, Bethlehem, Jenin and Ramallah are virtually sealed off.

In Gaza, which is ringed by an electrified fence, the closure is total. Yesterday, Israel again shut down the strip's airport, severing the territory's last exit to the outside world.

Such measures are among the most hated of the occupation, a reminder that despite seven years of self-rule in Gaza and some parts of the West Bank, Israeli troops remain the real masters of Palestinian life.

Some 110,000 Palestinians who work in Israel are idle. Thousands more who work in the West Bank simply cannot reach their jobs.

The present closure is the most severe since 1996, according to Amira Hass, an Israeli journalist who covers Palestinian affairs for the Ha'aretz newspaper and author of Drinking the Sea at Gaza. "It is an inner closure now which is even worse. It disconnects all parts of the West Bank from each other.

"Officials in ministries cannot reach their work, teachers cannot reach schools. You can get to places, but it takes twice as long. In effect, the roads belong only to Jews," Ms Hass said.

Under the wary gaze of an Israeli sentry on the neighbouring rooftop, Nasiha Abu Dahoud is scrubbing her courtyard. Yesterday, she collected two carrier bags of spent ammunition, including a 3-metre roll of machine-gun bullets.

Of all the shut-in families of Hebron's old city, hers carries the indignity of being among the poorest. At the best of times her husband, Naif Mohammed, works just one day a week as a labourer, taking home 100 shekels (£18) a time. With her husband out of work for the duration of the curfew, they are penniless. Most days she feeds her family of six just one meal, a bowl of thick soup doled out by a local charity.

"It has been 23 days, and I still cannot understand why," she says.

"Sure, there are kids throwing stones, but is that a reason to put 40,000 people in prison? Why can't they just catch those kids and let the rest of us live in peace?"

The present closure is the most severe since 1996, according to Amira Hass, an Israeli journalist who covers Palestinian affairs for the Ha'aretz newspaper and author of Drinking the Sea at Gaza. "It is an inner closure now which is even worse. It disconnects all parts of the West Bank from each other. "Officials in ministries cannot reach their work, teachers cannot reach schools. You can get to places, but it takes twice as long. In effect, the roads belong only to Jews," Ms Hass said. Under the wary gaze of an Israeli sentry on the neighbouring rooftop, Nasiha Abu Dahoud is scrubbing her courtyard. Yesterday, she collected two carrier bags of spent ammunition, including a 3-metre roll of machine-gun bullets. Of all the shut-in families of Hebron's old city, hers carries the indignity of being among the poorest. At the best of times her husband, Naif Mohammed, works just one day a week as a labourer, taking home 100 shekels (£18) a time. With her husband out of work for the duration of the curfew, they are penniless. Most days she feeds her family of six just one meal, a bowl of thick soup doled out by a local charity. "It has been 23 days, and I still cannot understand why," she says. "Sure, there are kids throwing stones, but is that a reason to put 40,000 people in prison? Why can't they just catch those kids and let the rest of us live in peace?" fields.headline: My claim to Jerusalem
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: When I first travelled to the Holy Land in 1991, the best friend I made was neither Jewish nor Palestinian; he was English. Shahid was a happy-go-lucky school-leaver from Manchester; like thousands of other Britons who travel to Jerusalem each year, he might have been there to backpack or test his mettle on a kibbutz.
fields.body:
When I first travelled to the Holy Land in 1991, the best friend I made was neither Jewish nor Palestinian; he was English. Shahid was a happy-go-lucky school-leaver from Manchester; like thousands of other Britons who travel to Jerusalem each year, he might have been there to backpack or test his mettle on a kibbutz.

But he wasn't. Like myself, he was drawn by a very different force - the pull of Al-Masjid Al-Aqsa in Jerusalem, "the farthest mosque" as it is known in the Koran and the third most sacred site in the Islamic faith.

We were here on pilgrimage and our main purpose was to "connect" with the place from where, Muslim tradition holds, the Prophet Mohammed ascended to heaven in a physical affirmation of the spiritual return each soul aspires to make to his Creator.

Visiting a region then in the grip of the intifada does not conform to most peoples' idea of a summer getaway. But for us the violence only validated our choice of destination. There was something all the more fascinating about a holy place for which so many of our co-religionists had laid down life and limb.

This dimension - the meaning of Jerusalem to Muslims beyond the Arab speaking nations - has been overlooked in recent coverage of the conflict. Israel's conflict is with the whole Muslim world. Every Muslim from Marakesh to Mindanao has an interest in Al-Aqsa.

In Yasser Arafat, Israel has been dealing with a man who has been prepared to sign away vast tracts of the Palestinian homeland but who they know hasn't got an inch to manoeuvre when it comes to the status of Al-Aqsa.

It's simple. The mosque is not the Palestinians' to give away. Like other mosques, under Islamic law it is the property of God and its administration and security are the collective responsibility of all believers.

Shahid and I are fortunate in that Muslims from western countries (barring refusals to such high profile figures as Yusuf Islam, formerly Cat Stevens) are allowed by Israel to visit the country.

But it is a dubious honour to know you can worship in a place which is out of bounds not only for the vast majority of the world's Muslims, but for most Palestinians themselves. Forced to endure roadblocks, permit checks and summary arrest if they try to reach Al-Aqsa, they are treated like prisoners in their own land.

The most serious outbreaks of violence since the intifada have erupted each time Palestinian Muslims have perceived a new threat to Al-Aqsa. Since the Israeli right makes no secret of its desire to build a new temple on the ruins of the mosque, every incursion is viewed with the utmost suspicion.

In 1996 the discovery of more Israeli tunnel excavations under the raised site, which Palestinians say is undermining its foundations, provoked similar unrest.

Six years earlier Palestinian attempts to resist an attempt by hard-line Zionists to erect a foundation stone for the new temple led to the bloodiest scenes ever seen on the mosque complex as soldiers ran amok with automatic weapons.

There are many religious reasons why Jerusalem is important for Muslims. But for Muslims the occupation of Jerusalem by the Jewish state is also a symbol of how the international world order is stacked against them, representing the prevalence of might over right, imperialism over independence, subjugation over freedom.

Among British Muslims, nothing excites passions like a threat to Al-Aqsa, as several demonstrations in Manchester and London have already shown. Some of the most generous supporters of the Palestinian cause, they have dug deep for lobby groups and charities in the hope that helping those closest to Al-Aqsa is an investment in the future of the mosque itself.

But as anger and frustration mount and faith in the peace process withers the mood could easily turn militant. On campuses, the festering injustice of Palestine has been the single biggest force responsible for radicalising Muslim students.

In the inner cities there is much that the average Muslim youngster has in common with the foot soldiers of the intifada. Jobless, discriminated against, marginalised and devoid of any hope, he too feels victim to a system that appears to exist only to oppress his people.

With this time bomb on our doorstep we should be less worried about the conflict putting a few more pennies on fuel than about the likelihood of a major Middle Eastern conflict unleashing an army of angry young men to vent their frustrations on the streets.

Muslims find it difficult to distinguish between the west's component parts when it comes to the relationship with Israel.

fields.headline: Edward Heath: a life
fields.standfirst: Heath to quit commons
fields.trailText: Sir Edward Heath's unbroken survival as an MP, from the age of Atlee to that of Tony Blair, would be enough to earn him a place in British political history. Add to the record four years as prime minister, two spells as leader of the opposition and a crowded case of other jobs from chief whip to the father of the House, and Sir Edward's status is established beyond doubt.
fields.body:
Sir Edward Heath's unbroken survival as an MP, from the age of Atlee to that of Tony Blair, would be enough to earn him a place in British political history. Add to the record four years as prime minister, two spells as leader of the opposition and a crowded case of other jobs from chief whip to the father of the House, and Sir Edward's status is established beyond doubt.

That makes his decision to retire from the Commons at the next election, announced this afternoon, a landmark in parliament's evolution, a more interesting event than, say, John Major's similar announcement earlier this year. He is one of the last active connections with a political age which took parliament seriously. Tony Blair is unlikely to clock up five decades in the Commons, and would not hope to do so. The Commons is no longer where it is at.

Not that Sir Edward Heath was entirely a parliament man. In the late 1960s his party saw him as a telegenic leader who could challenge Harold Wilson, a break with the slow pace of the previous Conservative party leader, Sir Alec Douglas-Home. As prime minister, Sir Edward became was famous for his addiction to yacht racing. Less well-known is that he took up sailing on the advice of Conservative image makers.

And even Sir Edward's time in parliament after his prime ministership had its mysteries: not least his apparently close relationship with the leaders of communist China and the real nature of his views on Margaret Thatcher.

That, though, will not prevent MPs from all sides of the house regretting his impending departure. With Sir Edward in his place on the green leather benches, among the Liberal Democrats, the chamber somehow seemed a little more important than it will once he has gone.

Sir Edward Heath factfile

Born: 9 July, 1916
Elected to Parliament: February 1950
First political job: Assistant whip, February 1951
Chief whip: December 1955, to Anthony Eden
Entered Cabinet: October 1959, as minister of Labour
Key role: Negotiating entry to the EEC, 1963, as president of the board of trade
Party leader: July 1965, replacing Alec Douglas-Home
Became prime minister: June 1970, replacing Harold Wilson
Key event: Taking Britain into EEC, 1972
Defeated: February 1974, in wake of three-day week
Defeated once more: October 1974
Replaced as leader of the opposition: 1975

webTitle: Pearson fixes price for Recoletos sale

fields.headline: Pearson fixes price for Spanish sale
fields.trailText: Pearson has set a final price of E12 for the upcoming sale of a 21% stake in Spanish media group Recoletos, writes Faisal Islam.
fields.body:
Pearson has set a final price of E12 for the upcoming sale of a 21% stake in Recoletos, its Spanish media group.

The price is just below the range stated in the offer document and values the company at E1.57bn (£900m). Trading is expected to begin on the Madrid stock exchange tomorrow.

Marjorie Scardino, Pearson's chief executive, said:"Recoletos is one of Spain's very best media companies. This IPO helps Recoletos to grow more quickly online and in Latin America and enables Pearson to share in the value it creates'.

Recoletos publishes the popular daily football newspaper, Marca, and Expansion, Spain's version of the FT. Last week it raised the cover price of both newspapers.

The group has a 30% stake in the publisher of daily newspaper El Mundo as well as growing web and international interests.

webTitle: Sharon demands high price for loyalty to Barak

fields.headline: Sharon demands high price for loyalty to Barak
fields.standfirst:
Middle East conflict Israeli hawk who sparked the latest explosion of violence meets the prime minister today
Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Ariel Sharon, the Likud party hawk, meets Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, today to try to harvest the maximum political gain from setting off his country's descent into blood and mayhem.
fields.body:
Ariel Sharon, the Likud party hawk, meets Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, today to try to harvest the maximum political gain from setting off his country's descent into blood and mayhem.

As negotiations get under way for the formation of an emergency government to rescue Mr Barak from a crisis that has unfolded with dizzying speed, Mr Sharon made it plain yesterday that he expects a steep price for his support.

A two-hour conclave failed to agree the terms of his participation in an emergency government, largely because he is demanding a veto on security decisions and a guarantee that Israel will not return to the negotiating table with the Palestinians.

The talks come a day after Mr Barak declared an indefinite time-out in the peace process, following 26 days of violence which have claimed at least 127 lives. The slaughter was provoked by Mr Sharon's visit to the Haram al-Sharif, seen by Palestinians as an intolerable expression of Israel's determination never to relax its grip on the Muslim holy places of occupied Jerusalem.

Events continued to unravel on the ground yesterday as the army blockaded Beit Jalla, a Palestinian village on the southern fringes of Jerusalem, after gunmen fired on the nearby Jewish suburb of Gilo.

Overnight, tanks opened up with machine guns, and helicopters fired rockets at several buildings, destroying a factory, a church club, and plunging the village and parts of Bethlehem into darkness. There were also gun battles in Hebron, and 36 Palestinians were wounded at a flashpoint in the Gaza Strip.

Amid the violence, Shalom Silvan, a Likud party leader, said that Mr Sharon had demanded assurances from Mr Barak that "two, three months from now" he would not return to the offers he made at Camp David in July.

Mr Sharon is also unwillingly to be a silent partner in this coalition. If Mr Barak wants his party's support, it will have to toe the Likud line, which is fundamentally opposed to the ideals of trading land for peace that have guided the negotiations.

Israeli newspapers reported that Mr Sharon was demanding the post of deputy prime minister, with a power of veto over security decisions. "We are looking for a partnership which would be on an equal basis between the Likud and Labour," said Meir Shitreet, a Likud member of the knesset, the Israeli parliament.

However, those demands are unacceptable to Mr Barak's Labour party, which reacted with dismay to the prime minister's decision to embrace a man so reviled by Palestinians.

It is clear that Mr Sharon and Mr Barak are eager to do a deal as soon as possible. The prime minister, who commands the loyalties of only a quarter of the members of the knesset, is desperate to hang on to power. Mr Sharon is under pressure to head off a possible Likud leadership challenge from the former prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu.

The solution may lie in first declaring an emergency government, in which the Likud will simply help shore up the crumbling Mr Barak for a relatively short term of three to four weeks. The next step would be a true government of national unity, in which the Likud would be able to dictate terms.

With the violence in the West Bank and Gaza now virtually on the do13orstep of Jewish west Jerusalem, postures are hardening. Although the Palestinians argue that Mr Sharon's participation in the government would signal Israel's abandonment of negotiations, the government remains unmoved. "I really do not think that Arafat cares about who is in the Israeli government," the cabinet secretary, Yitzhak Herzog, said.

fields.headline: Ex-shop steward Martin is Speaker
fields.trailText: Labour MPs last night defied pressure from senior ministers when they voted to elect Michael Martin, a former shop steward from Labour's industrial heartlands, to become 152nd Speaker of the House of Commons - instead of the Old Etonian Tory ex-cabinet minister Sir George Young.
fields.body:
Labour MPs last night defied pressure from senior ministers when they voted to elect Michael Martin, a former shop steward from Labour's industrial heartlands, to become 152nd Speaker of the House of Commons - instead of the Old Etonian Tory ex-cabinet minister Sir George Young.

After the father of the Commons, 84-year-old Sir Edward Heath, had rejected pleas for a straightforward ballot to choose from the 12 contenders, it took more than six hours of cumbersome voting to complete the election as even no-hopers took their turn - to the dismay of Westminster modernisers.

By the time it was over, the once crowded chamber was almost deserted. Mr Martin was never fewer than 76 votes ahead of his 11 rivals and in no serious danger of defeat.

In the end, Mr Martin's nomination was backed by 370 votes to eight - with only 11 votes coming from Tories. As tradition dictates, he was dragged to the Speaker 's chair to assume the post.

With the help of the ministerial "payroll vote", Sir George was his closest challenger, losing by 317 to 241. Labour's strongest challenger, the sacked cabinet minister David Clark, managed only 192 votes to the winner's 257. Menzies Campbell in the Lib Dem corner lost 381 to 98.

With Tony Blair not voting in person, but privately keen not to be seen to insist on a Labour Speaker, at least 25 ministers, including David Blunkett, Margaret Beckett, Jack Straw and Peter Mandelson, supported Sir George. But the move backfired as angry backbenchers protested at the tactic when the parliamentary Labour party met on the Commons' first day back since July 27.

In picking the 55-year-old MP for Glasgow Springburn as successor to Betty Boothroyd, Labour backbenchers sent a complex series of messages to the government and the wider, watching electorate months before the general election.

Mr Martin is the first Speaker to be an authentic representative of the industrial working class, the child of an impoverished broken home who met his wife in a factory. He will also be the first Roman Catholic Speaker since Henry VIII's Protestant Reformation.

Mr Blair paid tribute to Mr Martin after his appointment. He said: "Much has been made of your origins, of the hardship and difficulty in being brought up in Scotland in circumstances of poverty, and no doubt those will give you a special insight into the position of many people in this country. But I want to lay stress not on your origins but on your quality, your integrity and your worldly wisdom."

Yesterday's contest was conducted in fierce but fair-minded terms after Sir Edward had resisted calls from senior MPs on both sides, led by Tony Benn, to use his power to tear up rules not devised for a multi-candidate contest.

He expressed "considerable sympathy" and offered his version of a compromise. That was to set out the order in which he intended to call the 12 contenders, who would be voted on two at a time. Unexpectedly, he started with the bookies' favourite, Mr Martin. Equally unexpectedly, he let the contest run to the bitter end.

Each rival's name was added as an amendment to the motion:

Sir Alan Haselhurst (Con) lost by 140 to 345

Alan Beith (Lib Dem) 83 to 409

Gwyneth Dunwoody (Lab) 170 to 341

Sir George Young (Con) 241 to 317

Menzies Campbell (Lib Dem) 98 to 381

David Clark (Lab) 192 to 257

Nicholas Winterton (Con) 116 to 340

John McWilliam (Lab) 30 to 309

Michael Lord (Con) 146 to 290

Sir Patrick Cormack (Con) 130 to 287

Richard Shepherd (Con) 136 to 282

Final vote: Michael Martin backed by 370 votes to eight

MIchael Martin: victor

webTitle: BT faces £1.2bn fine over Italian mobile phone auction

fields.headline: BT faces £1.2bn fine over Italian mobile phone auction
fields.trailText: Blu, the BT-backed mobile phone consortium, may be fined £1.2bn by the Italian government for alleged 'collusive behaviour' during its failed bid for a 3G mobile phone licence. By Faisal Islam.
fields.body:
Blu, the BT-backed mobile phone consortium, may be fined £1.2bn by the Italian government for alleged 'collusive behaviour' during its failed bid for a 3G mobile phone licence.

The Italian auction for the right to operate the advanced mobile services, including video-on-demand, ended after just two days yesterday following Blu's exit from the bidding.

Blu's move left its competitors, including Vodafone, with relatively cheap licences. The Italian government raised £3bn less than it expected from the auction, and far less than the 3G auctions in the UK and in Germany.

The government said that Blu had failed to respect confidentiality arrangements for the auction and that it was examining the consortium's £1.2bn deposit.

Blu countered that the Italian government had validated the result of the auction and there were therefore no grounds for keeping the deposit.

Separately, BT was today challenged by the consortium's main shareholder, the Benetton family-controlled Autostrade, to raise its stake in Blu considerably or withdraw.

A BT spokesman said the company was committed to Blu, and acted in good faith throughout the auction.

fields.headline: Get off your ivory towers
fields.standfirst: State admissions to Oxbridge may be down. But does that really matter? Lee Elliot Major questions the assumption that Oxbridge is everything to everyone
fields.trailText: Cambridge University today reports a slump in undergraduate applications for the first time in years. We wonÕt know until December whether this is because state school applications have fallen in particular. But it is already being predicted that Cambridge's experience will mirror that of Oxford, where a smaller proportion of state applicants will begin new courses this autumn. Predictably, some are suggesting that this could be all down to the Laura Spence effect: that OxfordÕs much publicised rejection of the talented state school pupil has put off other state pupils who want to apply to Oxbridge.
fields.body:
Cambridge University today reports a slump in undergraduate applications for the first time in years. We wonÕt know until December whether this is because state school applications have fallen in particular. But it is already being predicted that Cambridge's experience will mirror that of Oxford, where a smaller proportion of state applicants will begin new courses this autumn. Predictably, some are suggesting that this could be all down to the Laura Spence effect: that OxfordÕs much publicised rejection of the talented state school pupil has put off other state pupils who want to apply to Oxbridge.

But before we slip, like chancellor Gordon Brown, into making glib judgements about something we in fact know little about, we should stand back and question the prevailing assumptions surrounding the issue of Oxbridge admissions.

First, is it a bad thing that state school students with top A-level grades chose to apply to prestigious departments and courses at universities other than Oxbridge? Academic excellence in the university world is judged within subject areas. So while Oxford and Cambridge may be unrivalled in reputation as whole institutions, in many subject areas their departments may be the fourth or fifth best in the country. For some subjects and types of training, Oxbridge courses simply do not exist.

Perhaps it is hard for some ministers surrounded by Oxbridge-educated advisers, civil servants and journalists to envisage the factors which inform the choice of an average 18 year old considering which university to apply to. Ask around and you find a multitude of reasons: the academic reputation of courses; the nightlife and music scene on offer; the advice of parents or teachers; the need to be as far away from parents as possible. Should we worry that in many cases state school leavers chose not to opt for the particular university life offered at Oxbridge?

In fact, there are good academic reasons for state school pupils to study outside Oxbridge. With the same A-level grades, state school pupils are more likely than their privately educated counterparts to secure firsts in their degrees - in every university except Oxford and Cambridge.

Government officials and advisers say that Oxbridge graduates still secure the most influential jobs after university, and therefore it is unfair that such a relatively low proportion of state pupils attain these privileged positions. But is this still the case? The current Cabinet is filled with graduates from outside Oxbridge, for example. (How much genuine influence does the Oxbridge-educated crowd of government advisers, journalists and lobbyists have on these ministers?) There is also growing evidence that the most recent Oxbridge graduates are shunning public sector jobs for the more lucrative offers from management consultants and accountancy firms. Will these (albeit well-paid) careers in the private sector have much impact on the rest of us?

All this is not to denigrate Oxford and Cambridge, whose elite academic strengths should be a source of national pride. But we must get away from the short sighted expectation that Oxbridge is everything to everyone. The perspective from the real world for the 18 year old university applicant can be very different.

webTitle: 9-year-old Americans have discovered that algebra = fun

fields.headline: Catch them young
fields.standfirst: Fear + loathing = algebra. Unless you're one of the thousands of 9-year-old Americans to have discovered that algebra = fun
fields.trailText: Fear + loathing = algebra. Unless you're one of the thousands of 9-year-old Americans to have discovered that algebra = fun.
fields.body:
The equation on the blackboard reads 2 (3x + 1) = x + 22. "Who wants to explain how they solved this?" asks the teacher, Vicki Fisk. A forest of young hands shoots up. Jack, aged 10, is chosen. He jumps up and runs to what looks like a colourful toy set up on a desk in front of the blackboard. He rearranges the blue pawns (representing x) and red numbered cubes set out on a plastic balance beam to produce the right answer, amid nods from his classmates at Somerset Elementary in Maryland, US.

"It's easy and it's fun. I really enjoy maths lessons now," confides Richard Kingdom, nine, whose family moved from Wiltshire to America two years ago. "Last year I was trying to do algebra in my head and I found it very difficult. Now I can take the pieces away with my hands and make the two sides balance and I understand what it's all about."

Had he stayed in England, Richard would not have been taught such a complicated equation until he was at least 12 years old. But in the US, a new philosophy of demystifying algebra - a subject that traditionally terrifies pupils - by starting children younger is producing highly encouraging results. And for thousands of American teachers it is a new breed of educational toy that is making all the difference.

The balance beam system used by Vicki Fisk, for example, has been made a mandatory part of maths lessons for eight- to 11-year-olds in Maryland's Montgomery County, one of the US's largest school districts. Nationwide, tens of thousands of teachers have had training in using the system, know as Hands On Equations, which was developed by Dr Henry Borenson, a Pennsylvania maths teacher.

"I wanted to literally make algebra child's play," explains Borenson, who developed his system with the help of children with learning difficulties. "We have had a lot of feedback that using the equipment greatly boosts children's self-esteem. Teachers who struggled themselves with algebra have called it a revelation."

America's National Council for Teachers of Mathematics is spearheading the drive to begin teaching some high school maths concepts, algebra in particular, to children as young as six. According to the council's president, Lee Stiff, results over the past five years have been impressive, aided by educational toys such as Borenson's. "We have evidence from a number of states showing that nine-year-olds are doing better at basic algebra than older kids who come to it cold," he said.

The American approach was welcomed last week by British maths experts, many of whom believe algebra is introduced too late into UK schools. Roger Fentem, a maths educator who trains primary and secondary teachers at the College of St Mark and St John in Plymouth, described as "astonishing" the prowess shown by Vicki Fisk's class. "In Britain we would expect a bright 12-year-old or an average 14-year-old to solve that equation," he said.

Barry Lewis, director of UK Maths Year 2000, launched in January to "challenge the national fear of figures", agreed. "The leap from physical numbers into abstract qualities such as using letters in equations is the critical place where maths leaves many students behind," he said. "We support making algebra accessible and exciting at as young an age as possible. This kind of educational toy, which emphasises the concept of balance as the central principle of algebra, is spot on."

Such educational toys, however, are not generally used in British schools although many secondary-school textbooks and maths computer games use balance beam illustrations to teach algebra. What's more the national numeracy strategy, launched in September 1999 to raise basic maths standards, explicitly excludes algebra teaching in primary schools. As a result, children do not start learning even the most basic algebraic equations or formulae, such as 5 plus x = 8, therefore x = 3, until they reach 11 or 12.

"Really children should be learning such formulae as soon as teachers start asking them "five plus what is eight?" which is usually around seven or eight years old," said Fentem. "Part of the way ahead is to raise primary school teachers' knowledge of basic algebra and their confidence in their ability to link numeracy lessons with algebra. Based on the success of the numeracy strategy so far, I believe we should see great strides in algebra standards among British children over the next few years."

Making such strides is not just about academic success. American research suggests that pupils who drop out of algebra are less likely to achieve successful careers in well-paid fields such as computing and engineering. And a recent British study found that students achieving maths A-level went on to earn incomes roughly 20% higher than fellow students with only arts A-levels.

Meanwhile, a pioneering maths-teaching programme developed by Exeter University's School of Education will give some insight over the next few years into whether teaching algebra early could be as successful here as in the US. Forty primary schools around the country are using specialised lesson plans to introduce simple algebraic concepts to children as young as five. "I believe teaching algebra at 11 or 12 is far too late. Pupils find it very scary because they have no foundations in place to understand what the x and the brackets mean," says Professor David Burghes, who heads Exeter's School of Education and sat on the government's national numeracy task force.

"We find that five-year-olds have no problems understanding that 5 plus a square box equals 7 and then working out that the box equals 2. In fact they love it. But my views are not mainstream in Britain. I am out on a limb."

Back in Montgomery County, Vicki Fisk has no doubts about the pluses of teaching algebra at an age when some children are still learning to read. "The kids just love it - and they learn very fast," she says. "I have a friend who teaches seven- and eight-year-olds using Hands On Equations and they actually start crying when they have to miss a maths lesson!"

A class of nine- and 10-year-old American children individually solved these eight equations in just under half an hour. Can you do better? (Answers at bottom of page)

1 3x + 2x = 10

2 4x + 2x = x + x + 20

3 3x + 5 = x + 19

4 2(3x + 1) = x + 22

5 5x + 2 = 3x + 12

6 2x + 1 + x + 4 = x + 16 + x

7 5x - 3x + x + 8 = 2x + 1 + x + x

8 2(x + 4) = x + 10

The authors of two recent books from the Institute of Education, Why Learn Maths? and The Maths We Need Now, will be live online to answer questions and fight their corners.

webTitle: Guardian MBA scholarship: Year 2000 award winner

fields.headline: Guardian MBA scholarship
fields.trailText: Year 2000 award winner
fields.body:
This year's winner of the Guardian-Manchester Business School scholarship is a Brazilian who showed he best represented the scholarship's new focus on creativity, innovation and technology.

Julian Hester won the scholarship for his demonstration of leadership ability, experience working in management, and his case study of a natural rubber company's successful resurrection.

This year, the 10th anniversary of the scholarships, instead of writing an essay, applicants were required to submit a 1,500-word case study and make a PowerPoint presentation of it at the interview.

The competition was so strong that Manchester Business School decided to award two additional bursaries.

Karen Jemison, from Australia, worked at Tourism Victoria for five years before deciding to enter an MBA programme.

Yiu Mo Cheung studied information engineering at the Chinese University of Hong Kong before going on to City University, London, where he studied business systems analysis and design. He has worked for Bank of China, London, for the past six years, as deputy IT manager.

fields.headline: Heath to quit Commons
fields.standfirst: Edward heath: a life
fields.trailText: Former prime minister Sir Edward Heath today announced his retirement from the Commons at the next election after 50 years in parliament.
fields.body:
Former prime minister Sir Edward Heath today announced his retirement from the Commons at the next election after 50 years in parliament.

Sir Edward, 84, has been an MP for half a century and served as prime minister from 1970 to 1974. As father of the House - its longest serving member - Sir Edward yesterday conducted the arduous procedure to elect the new Speaker.

Announcing his decision in a letter to his Old Bexley and Sidcup constituency, Sir Edward said: "I am immensely proud of having been returned by the electorate of Bexley at every general election since February 23 1950, a period of more than 50 years."

Despite his age, Sir Edward regularly attends the Commons. His occasional speeches are conducted without notes and are invariably witty - and he never misses an opportunity to proclaim his pro-European views.

He treats Eurosceptics with withering disdain and has made clear his dislike of the Conservative party's policy under William Hague.

He regards his greatest achievement as taking Britain in to the Common Market in 1972. At the time he said: "What we have got to do is to get rid of the idea of us and them, and work together." It was a plea which, in the case of the Eurosceptics, was to fall on deaf ears for decades to follow.

But Sir Edward stated in February 1974 after a wave of industrial strife: "The challenge is to the will of Parliament and a democratically-elected government."

That was translated in headline journalism to: "Who rules Britain: the unions or the government?"

This "ultimatum" followed industrial action which, combined with an embargo by Arab oil producers, reduced British industry to a three-day week. He called a general election 14 months before he needed to, and was defeated by Harold Wilson's Labour party.

After a second general election defeat, Sir Edward was ousted from the Tory leadership in 1975 by Margaret Thatcher, heralding what has been described as "the longest sulk in history".

webTitle: Comment: Connex's popular replacement comes with baggage of its own

fields.headline: Connex's popular replacement comes with baggage of its own
fields.standfirst: Keith Harper on GoVia, the company picking up the franchise from the much loathed Connex
fields.trailText: Keith Harper on GoVia, the company picking up the franchise from the much loathed Connex.
fields.body:
Step forward GoVia, the Anglo-French company, which has been given the impossible job of trying to run the most congested rail network in Britain. It happened today when the French run Connex became the first victim of one of the government's two rail regulators.

Sir Alastair Morton, the man responsible for building the Channel tunnel, wielded his sharp axe on the neck of Connex, one of Britain's worst performing rail companies. It has become a legend in its lifetime, famous for running short trains, packing its passengers in until they are breathless, and allowing the public to sit in some of the dirtiest rolling stock in Britain.

The good Sir Alastair, now chairman of the shadow strategic rail authority, a sort of son of British Rail, had little option. The SSRA is the government's representative on earth. It has the power to divvy out 25 rail franchises and to withdraw them if the rail companies underperform.

In the case of Connex, the public has long decided that it should go, so Sir Alastair was only responding to the public mood. If he had decided to award Connex a 20-year franchise from 2003, angry commuters would have strung him up on platform one at East Croydon station.

Unfortunately for the SSRA, it got itself into a position where it had little to choose from. The two final bidders for the franchise to run commuter services out of Charing Cross and Victoria to Surrey and Sussex, were GoVia and of course, Connex. Not much of a choice.

Connex is so unpopular that even its staff cheered this morning when they heard the news. GoVia is less familiar to the travelling public, but runs two important franchises, Thameslink and Thames. Both carry passengers from within a 50 mile radius of London into the capital each day. Part of GoVia therefore is directly involved in a franchise at the heart of the Paddington rail crash.

It operates Thames Train, the company whose driver passed through a signal at red. During the course of Lord Cullen's inquiry into Paddington, Thames was exposed for its poor training methods for drivers and failure to vet staff adequately. So it is carrying with it a certain amount of baggage. Let's hope that the "New Southern Railway'' will strike a immediate chord with passengers. They will start with some goodwill, but they will need to deliver improvements quickly. It will not be easy with such a difficult franchise.

fields.headline: The RIP Act
fields.standfirst:
The RIP Act, which comes into force today, allows the government to intercept online communications. Julian Glover and Patrick Barkham examine the controversy surrounding the new act and the implications for privacy and e-commerce
Special report: privacy on the net
fields.trailText: Explained: The RIP Act, which comes into force today, allows the government to intercept online communications. We examine the controversy surrounding the new act and the implications for privacy and e-commerce.
fields.body:
What is the RIP Act?
The Regulation of Investigatory Powers (RIP) Act sets out the government's plans for how the security services can monitor and access communication over the internet. It passed into law hours before the Commons rose for its summer break and has now come into force.

Why is it so controversial?
Critics say the act is a gross invasion of privacy which will scupper e-commerce in Britain; the government argues it is necessary to crack down on internet crime and paedophilia.

What are the key areas of controversy? The first is "black box" interception. Security services, such as MI5, will be able to monitor people's internet habits through the collection of "communications data". This data is not website or email content, but users' "clickstream" - the websites and chatrooms they visit and the addresses of emails they send and receive. If security services suspect criminal activity, they request a government warrant to intercept and decode internet content.

The Home Office says the interception procedures are in line with the right to privacy enshrined in article eight of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR - now part of UK law) and simply brings the monitoring of the internet in line with that of telephone calls. All telephone numbers are logged (call content is not) and some telephone companies are required to enable security services to intercept calls. But web addresses also show exactly what people have been looking at and build up detailed profiles of where people go online and who they communicate with.

Under RIP, some UK internet service providers (ISPs) will be asked "to maintain a reasonable intercept capability". This will come in the form of the much hyped "black boxes", a piece of computer technology enabling the security services to monitor the flow of data. Critics say that the black boxes will be hugely expensive and will have difficulty keeping pace with fast-changing internet technology as well as the ever-growing volume of internet traffic.

The Home Office claims the power of interception is rarely used. All security service warrants for the interception of data will require the personal approval of the home secretary and must meet stringent criteria - national security must be threatened or serious crime must be suspected. Critics prefer an independent judicial panel, which would provide external checks on the system and ensure spies and governments maintain the rule of law.

The second key controversy is the legislation's reverse burden of proof. If intercepted communications are encrypted (encoded and made secret), the act will force the individual to surrender the keys (pin numbers which allow users to decipher encoded data), on pain of jail sentences of up to two years. The government says keys will only be required in special circumstances and promises that the security services will destroy the keys as soon as they are finished with.

Human rights campaigners argue the act reverses the burden of proof in UK law. There is also the threat of stiff prison sentences if an individual who has been required to hand over keys tells a third party. However, the Home Office says the burden remains on the prosecution to prove "beyond reasonable doubt that an accused person is, or has been, in possession of a key to unlock particular protected data." The act also contains a defence for individuals who have lost or forgotten a key, and a person is no longer liable if they are judged to have done all they can to help the authorities to recover a key.

Critics argue that innocent people could still be jailed for innocently forgetting keys, while drug smugglers and paedophiles would happily settle for a two-year prison sentence rather than face far harsher penalties for being found guilty of the crime they are suspected of.

What about employers?
The act also allows employers to intercept emails and internet use by their staff, on grounds such as monitoring for computer viruses.

Will the act compromise e-commerce?
Many in business fear the act will scare off e-commerce entrepreneurs. A fiercely critical British Chambers of Commerce (BCC) report estimates the RIP Act could cost business £46bn in the first five years of operation, as ISPs are compelled to install costly black boxes, e-commerce firms are forced out of the country and new firms are dissuaded from basing their operations in the UK.

The act's potential to enable unlimited "fishing expeditions" in companies' databases compromises corporate privacy, they argue, while security service knowledge of clickstreams and encryption keys could fall into criminal hands, compromising the security of e-commerce. Forcing employees to secretly hand over encryption keys could also breach trust and rules within a company.

In turn, the home secretary, Jack Straw, says the BCC's figures are "incredible" given that the value of UK e-commerce is currently estimated at around £5bn. He prefers to highlight what he says is the overall cost of crime - £50bn a year.

What do other countries do?
There is no comparable legislation in the US. Tim Berners-Lee, the British inventor of the world wide web, has said that RIP would have been thrown out of the US "in a second". Ireland recently sought to encourage e-commerce by passing a law making it illegal for government to access commercial encryption keys. France has relaxed controls on domestic encryption, while Germany is opposed to restrictions on citizens' use of encryption. Russia, Singapore and Malaysia have passed laws similar to RIP.

The RIP bill
The Home Office RIP site
The British Chambers of Commerce information and communication technology page
House of Commons library research report (pdf)
The Human Rights Act 1998 (enshrines the ECHR into British law)

webTitle: Barak looks to coalition and ignores peace

fields.headline: Barak looks to coalition and ignores peace
fields.trailText: Israeli prime minister looks to Sharon to support his tottering government, while peace looks equally precarious.
fields.body:
Israeli prime minister Ehud Barak turned his back on the peace process again today as he pressed ahead with negotiations to form a coalition with opposition leader Ariel Sharon.

With no current prospects for a peace deal, Mr Barak is searching for partners to bolster his vulnerable minority government, which is in danger of collapse.

"Friends, this is a time of emergency, and in an emergency, brothers walk together," he said on Israeli radio.

Many Palestinians blame hardliner Mr Sharon for sparking the current violence when he visited a Muslim shrine in Jerusalem on 28 September.

Clashes again broke out today on the Gaza Strip and West Bank. Palestinian authorities reported three more deaths.

A 55-year-old Palestinian man was killed in his house overnight when he was shot in the head in Hebron. A teenager was shot dead in clashes near the Erez crossing and a 13 year-old Palestinian boy, Iyad Shaath, died of a gunshot wound to the head suffered four days ago in the Gaza Strip.

Israeli army commander colonel Noam Tivon said the military does not expect the clashes to end soon. "We definitely need to prepare for a long period of conflict," he said.

The clashes have now claimed 126 lives in almost four weeks of fighting.

Mr Barak called on Sunday for a "timeout" in the peace process - a move Sharon had urged - and launched talks with the opposition leader.

Mr Sharon, who leads the right-wing Likud party, reportedly demanded measures to ensure his equal say in whether the peace process is renewed.

Palestinians and Israeli liberals have warned that Mr Sharon's inclusion in the government will crush the peace process.

"Sharon is simply not interested in the peace process," said Ziad Abu Amr, a Palestinian political analyst.

Mr Sharon believes that Israel should cling to land captured in the 1967 six day war rather than trade it for a peace with the Palestinians

Mr Barak's decision to withdraw from the peace process has put on hold seven years of negotiations with the Palestinians.

webTitle: Only Fools and Horses, Friends, and Never The Twain

fields.headline: Only Fools and Horses, Friends, and Never The Twain
fields.trailText: STICK A TRAPPATONI IN ME POCKET, I'LL GET THE SUITCASE FROM THE VAN GAAL
fields.body:
STICK A TRAPPATONI IN ME POCKET, I'LL GET THE SUITCASE FROM THE VAN GAAL

Ignore the refined Scottish accent for a moment - not to mention the designer duds - and the resemblance between FA chief Adam Crozier and Peckham market trader Derek "Del Boy" Trotter becomes a lot clearer. Like Del on the make with a suitcase of Lithuanian Pokémon, Crozier is having a bit of difficulty punting his product to punters. His product is, of course, the England manager's job and the punters are, well, anybody Crozier can get his hands on. Which rules Arsène's Arsenal Wenger out for starters.

"If I was free then maybe it might be different, but I am not," Wenger told the world today. "I am under contract to Arsenal for the next two years." The Gunners boss then proceeded to talk about the future of English football with the honesty of someone who will never have to do anything about it. "There is much more potential in the English game than you would believe by listening to people here!" he said. He also advised any future coach not to pick Joe Cole or Michael Carrick just yet, and to keep an eye on Kieron Dyer and Steven Gerrard as "you need a minimum of experience for this level". All of which sensible talk must have brought tears to Crozier's eyes.

Or maybe not, as Cro and co. could have been crying over the fact that Roy Hodgson is unlikely to take the job either. The former Blackburn boss, endorsed only this morning by Sheffield Wednesday striker Efan Ekoku, is to stay with FC Copenhagen - according to his club chairman Niels-Christian Holmstroem. "Under no circumstances can we just release Mr Hodgson just like that in the middle of the season," he said. Which leaves only one name on the FA's supposed three-man shortlist: Lazio coach Sven Goran Eriksson. That would explain why reports in the Italian press claimed Crozier went to Rome this morning. Either that or he had to see a man about a lorry-load of chocolate-flavoured olive oil.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THANK YOU FOR BEING A FRIEND

On Saturday night, Howard Wilkinson sat back in his cushioned chair and smelt power. Power, he decided, smelt good. Real good. And at that moment, Sgt Wilko began to dream. He dreamt of his previous triumphs at the FA: of how he seized the office photocopier from some woman from accounts, and how he stole the position of England's U-21 coach from right under Peter Taylor's nose. And surely there was more to come. Like an extended run as England manager, for example.

But then Howard woke up to find his empire crumbling. The FA's chief executive Adam Crozier had put Peter Taylor in charge of England for the friendly against Italy. And, worse still, Brian Kidd had been "asked" to help out with the U-21s - right in the heart of Wilko's empire. Suddenly, Wilko's friends - well, former Leeds chairman Bill Fotherby - had turned on him too. "Howard will view Peter Taylor's appointment as an insult," said Fotherby. "I am not criticising Peter because he is a good manager but it appears as though Howard will have to leave the FA."

Who would want the gruff Yorkshireman? "I think he could walk out and immediately find himself a new job because everybody knows what a good manager he is," claimed Fothers, deftly skipping over the fact that Wilko was sacked from the last proper job he had. However, this afternoon, Wilko stepped in to end all the rumours. "My position has not changed at all," he droned. "I think everything has been said that needs to be said." Apart from the words "I'm" and "off", of course.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I don't think Steve McClaren or Peter Taylor have done anything in management to warrant being in charge of an England team, at any time. My qualifications are better than theirs." Peter Shilton is back. But who rattled his cage is anyone's guess.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

I'M H-A-P-P-Y WHERE I AM, THANK YOU

It's hard being a Rangers fan at the moment. League form is nothing short of abysmal, qualification for the second phase of Big Cup teeters on a knife-edge, and the price of bowler hats has gone through the roof. But most worrying of all is the club's inability to find a player fit enough to pass an Ibrox medical - "the most stringent in the world and that's official!" - with an £11m deal for Espanol striker Raul Tamudo the latest to collapse.

The 23-year-old was set to join the Teddy Bears until doctors, no doubt still smarting over the £2.6m signing of Romanian wreck Daniel Prodan, noticed a small problem with his knee. Before you could say John Hartson, Rangers' offer was withdrawn. However, it now transpires that Tamudo is "almost fully fit" - so much so that he could be playing for his club in Euro-Vase on Thursday. "He just has a little bit of liquid on his right knee," explained exasperated Espanol club doctor Salvador Oliveras. "The ligaments are in perfect condition and he is virtually recovered. I don't know what the Rangers doctors have picked up."

Sadly for the popular Glasgow giants, the broken deal is unlikely to be fixed as easily as Tamudo's so-called knackered peg. "I would rather play for the team which is in my heart," the messed-about player explained in the Scottish Sun. "Espanol spoke to me and forced me to accept Rangers' offer to save the club but I would rather play for them than Rangers. I do not want to play for Rangers and I want to forget all about them." Do you think a sheepish football executive will be giving Wimbledon a call?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Dennis Bergkamp is losing patience in his contract negotiations with Arsenal. "I'm quite angry that I'm not making any progress," he said. "It leaves me with an extremely negative feeling." The 31-year-old striker has already been linked with a return to former club Ajax.

Everton are interested in signing Eyal Berkovic from Celtic, according to his agent Pini Zahavi.

Spurs are watching striker Mika Wayryren, according to Teamtalk. The teenager plays for Finnish side FC Lahti.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson has admitted he will consider his position at the end of the season if he doesn't turn things around. "We need to be achieving things, that's why I came to Middlesbrough," he said. "That's why if we don't have a good season, I might have to look at the situation and see if the chairman might be better off looking elsewhere to improve the club."

The Mayor of Zagreb has written to the Scottish FA to praise the behaviour of the Tartan Army during Scotland's recent World Cup qualifier against Croatia. "The Scottish fans delighted the citizens of Zagreb, not only by the way they represented their national colours, but with their vivid and colourful national garb, which lent a special atmosphere to our city", mayor Milan Bandic said.

Manchester City are finally set to complete the signing of Laurent Charvet this afternoon.

Blackburn Rovers have signed Mark Hughes on a free transfer.

Ryan Giggs will captain Manchester United in their Big Cup match against Anderlecht tonight, after Roy Keane was ruled out with a hamstring injury.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

ITV: The Big Match (10.30pm, 11.30pm) Two programmes about Big Cup with some news in the middle.

Channel 4: Football Italia (3.20am) Hundreds of great players and one big ignorant thick-necked Yugoslavian oaf.

Sky Sports 1: Inside Scottish Football (6.30pm) Yes, we're laughing at useless old Rangers too. Now all we need is for Hibernian and Kilmarnock to overhaul Celtic and everybody's happy.

Soccer Special (7.30pm) Watch old men watching telly without visiting the local hospice.

You're On Sky Sports! (10pm) Should a publicity-seeking Premiership footballer ring up, watch McCaff go all McObsequious.

Sky Sports 2: World Football Show (11pm) You call this a show? There isn't an opening number, for a start.

Sky Sports 3: Live First Division Football (7.30pm) Do we not like not watching Watford play Bolton? Yes. We think.

ONsport1: Live Big Cup Football (7.30pm) We think there may be more of this on ONsport2. The transmission time is a guess as well.

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Football (7.30pm) How can you be that unhappy when you're paid to travel all around the world?

webTitle: 'Disunity is a luxury that Israel can no longer afford'

fields.headline: 'Disunity is a luxury that Israel can no longer afford'
fields.trailText: With the peace process apparently stalled, Israel seems more pre-occuppied with domestic political battles, reports Derek Brown.
fields.body:
As the Palestinian uprising nears the end of its fourth week and the death toll rises to 135, the Israeli press is more concerned with the political battle going on in Jerusalem.

The Jerusalem Post reports rising hopes that a government of national unity will be formed by Thursday, with the hard right Likud faction, led by Ariel Sharon, joining prime minister Ehud Barak's Labour-led coalition.

But deep differences remain: "Wary of Barak's future peace moves, the Likud is demanding as much authority as possible to forestall a return to the understandings reached at July's Camp David summit. The Likud believes that Barak made too many concessions, especially on the status of Jerusalem and the Jordan valley."

In its leader column, the paper says that the new government should be more than a device to stave off early elections. It urges the inclusion of the leftist Meretz faction and the left wing of the Labour movement: "Any scent of division will be viewed as weakness by the Arab world, and therefore fan the euphoric Nasserism that has emerged in recent weeks. A united Israel, by contrast, will close the war option and force the Palestinians, sooner or later, back to the path of a negotiated peace. Disunity is a luxury that Israel can no longer afford."

The liberal daily Ha'aretz is not keen on the entry of Likud to government: "To friends of Israel, Barak's reckless announcement of a 'time-out' from the peace process as the Arab summit was set to convene looked like a hasty retreat from the political process. Now, the news of a possible partnership with the right has come along, completely ravaging the image of Israel's prime minister as a man who is bound by his election promises and truly committed to striving for peace. Striving for peace is not a practical option if the right, which has a different set of priorities, is brought into the government."

Ha'aretz also reports the gloomy assessment of military planners that violence in the Palestinian territory is likely to continue into next year: "The general staff completed its revised analysis of the situation in the territories and its budget implications yesterday. The virtually unanimous opinion was that if diplomatic negotiations resume, there might be a long hiatus in the current disturbances - but the violence is likely to erupt again after any such lull. Regarding Lebanon, the opinion of the general staff is that hostile parties in Lebanon, whether Palestinians or Hezbollah, may soon join the fighting with the backing of either or both Syria and Iran." The army, not surprisingly, is looking for more money - more than £400m - to stock up its arsenal.

The Arab press is also watching closely the political upheavals in Israel. The inclusion of Ariel Sharon in a unity government is a frightening prospect for the Jordan Times: "There is worry in the Arab world that if the idea of a national emergency government is too unpalatable for either the public or Barak's allies in government, a last unthinkable option might become a new reality: The reoccupation of Palestinian-controlled territory or other major military initiatives against the Palestinians."

The paper also reports that radical Palestinian groups, as well as countries like Libya and Iran, believe that the strong words that issued from last weekend's Cairo summit are worthless without some form of action. It quotes the somewhat cynical view of the Tunisian newspaper Tunis Metro: "The fact that an Arab summit takes place somewhere is in itself a miracle as divisiveness among Arab states was so deep. This miracle is owed to the intifada (Palestinian uprising)."

In the United Arab Emirates, the Gulf News makes the most of the summit, noting that the Arab world has been deeply divided since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990: "It is therefore rather a shock to find that an Arab summit can happen, even if the resolutions at this week's Cairo summit were not powerful enough, and even if the summit did not make as much of an impact as it could have done. The very fact that the meeting happened, and came to more or less complete agreement on a course of action, was lifting to the spirits, as was the decision to meet again in March - the first of a future series of regular meetings."

Finally, the website Arabia.net carries a thoroughly depressing discussion board, supposedly on the aftermath of the Cairo summit, but in reality a compendium of racist hate-messages from both sides of the Middle East divide.
