webTitle: Should we be allowed to commentate?

fields.headline: Should we be allowed to commentate?
fields.trailText: Henry Blofeld has struck another blow for cricket's bold, modern image in his new autobiography (A Thirst for Life, Hodder & Stoughton, £18.99). Blowers, over-30 years a commentator, has decided that the time has come for him to get something off his chest. Something that has been bugging him for a while. Because much as he loves having women in the box with him (and there have, as you can imagine, been hundreds) "no-one has yet convinced me that they add more to the commentary than we [men] already have."
fields.body:
Henry Blofeld has struck another blow for cricket's bold, modern image in his new autobiography (A Thirst for Life, Hodder & Stoughton, £18.99). Blowers, over-30 years a commentator, has decided that the time has come for him to get something off his chest. Something that has been bugging him for a while. Because much as he loves having women in the box with him (and there have, as you can imagine, been hundreds) "no-one has yet convinced me that they add more to the commentary than we [men] already have."

In fact, says Blowers,"It is perhaps another example of women striving regardless to do anything and everything men used to do on their own." (A good test in these circumstances is to substitute the word blacks and whites for women and men - ouch, that hurts doesn't it.)

How scandalous that women might want to be able to do the same things as men. To have the same opportunities. And to want to be a cricket commentator really is taking things too far. Next stop, the sperm bank. But even Blowers would have to admit that women on the radio are a good thing - Libby Purves, Sue McGregor, Kate Adie. And that women talking about sport on the radio hasn't exactly been an unmitigated disaster - think Eleanor Oldroyd or Claire Balding. So what is so different about cricket? Perhaps those laws are a little complicated for our pretty little heads. Perhaps we haven't got the concentration for five days. Perhaps we might giggle ("The batsman's Holding, the bowler's Willey") and lower the tone.

Surely Blowers is missing the point. If the entire Test Match Special box consisted of men of his patrician, fruity tones, he wouldn't be so well loved, or such a novelty in places like Australia. It is the mix of people, the interaction between the team that makes TMS so wonderfully addictive. No-one would now dream of having a commentary team which consisted entirely of people who went to Eton. Not that they wouldn't be any good, just that they would alienate some sections of the audience and would tend to have a certain outlook on life.

TMS employed a woman commentator in the summer - Donna Symmonds, the lawyer who runs an all-female law practice in Barbados. She has come joint fifth (with Dermot Reeve) in the favourite-commentator section of Wisden Cricket Monthly's Readers' Poll, to be published in full in December's issue. Not everyone loves her of course. Some find her intensely irritating. But so what? That, surely is the whole point. Different voices for different people.

Women are increasingly being heard talking about cricket. Sarah Potter has done women's matches for Sky, Karen Smithies for TMS and Clare Connor for CricInfo.

Ralph Dellor, the director of cricket operations at CricInfo says: "Providing they reach the required criteria, our commentators can be white, black, asian, male, female. We like a variety of voices. But I will employ whoever is best to do the job. I won't have women just for a token or for a novelty and I don't subscribe to the school of thought of gosh isn't it clever we've got a woman."

Fair enough. Quota systems aren't for everyone. You can't even get a roomful of women to agree upon them, let alone men. But the major cricket stations must have searched high and low for a female voice this winter, especially after the success of Sybil Ruscoe on Channel 4.

How many women will be commentating on the forthcoming Test series in Pakistan? Talk Radio have a female producer, Claire Furlong, who sometimes does off-field snippets. But as for women commentators - forget it. Sky? Despite the female faces of their sports' news coverage, there will be no women playing a straight bat or otherwise. From the proposed CricInfo team, proud sponsors of the Women's World Cup? None.

Not one of the three British teams covering the cricket could find a single woman who would be willing and able to commentate on England's return to Pakistan. I wonder how hard they looked.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read her previous Women's Page, on England's preparation for the World Cup in New Zealand, click here

(A good test in these circumstances is to substitute the word blacks and whites for women and men - ouch, that hurts doesn't it.) How scandalous that women might want to be able to do the same things as men. To have the same opportunities. And to want to be a cricket commentator really is taking things too far. Next stop, the sperm bank. But even Blowers would have to admit that women on the radio are a good thing - Libby Purves, Sue McGregor, Kate Adie. And that women talking about sport on the radio hasn't exactly been an unmitigated disaster - think Eleanor Oldroyd or Claire Balding. So what is so different about cricket? Perhaps those laws are a little complicated for our pretty little heads. Perhaps we haven't got the concentration for five days. Perhaps we might giggle ("The batsman's Holding, the bowler's Willey") and lower the tone. Surely Blowers is missing the point. If the entire Test Match Special box consisted of men of his patrician, fruity tones, he wouldn't be so well loved, or such a novelty in places like Australia. It is the mix of people, the interaction between the team that makes TMS so wonderfully addictive. No-one would now dream of having a commentary team which consisted entirely of people who went to Eton. Not that they wouldn't be any good, just that they would alienate some sections of the audience and would tend to have a certain outlook on life. TMS employed a woman commentator in the summer - Donna Symmonds, the lawyer who runs an all-female law practice in Barbados. She has come joint fifth (with Dermot Reeve) in the favourite-commentator section of Wisden Cricket Monthly's Readers' Poll, to be published in full in December's issue. Not everyone loves her of course. Some find her intensely irritating. But so what? That, surely is the whole point. Different voices for different people. Women are increasingly being heard talking about cricket. Sarah Potter has done women's matches for Sky, Karen Smithies for TMS and Clare Connor for CricInfo. Ralph Dellor, the director of cricket operations at CricInfo says: "Providing they reach the required criteria, our commentators can be white, black, asian, male, female. We like a variety of voices. But I will employ whoever is best to do the job. I won't have women just for a token or for a novelty and I don't subscribe to the school of thought of gosh isn't it clever we've got a woman." Fair enough. Quota systems aren't for everyone. You can't even get a roomful of women to agree upon them, let alone men. But the major cricket stations must have searched high and low for a female voice this winter, especially after the success of Sybil Ruscoe on Channel 4. How many women will be commentating on the forthcoming Test series in Pakistan? Talk Radio have a female producer, Claire Furlong, who sometimes does off-field snippets. But as for women commentators - forget it. Sky? Despite the female faces of their sports' news coverage, there will be no women playing a straight bat or otherwise. From the proposed CricInfo team, proud sponsors of the Women's World Cup? None. Not one of the three British teams covering the cricket could find a single woman who would be willing and able to commentate on England's return to Pakistan. I wonder how hard they looked. Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly. To read her previous Women's Page, on England's preparation for the World Cup in New Zealand, click here

fields.headline: Skinner carves up BBC1 news
fields.trailText: 1.30pm overnights: ITV's Frank Skinner Show saw its ratings rise last night at the expense of the BBC's Ten O'Clock News. By Jason Deans
fields.body:
ITV fought back on the second Monday of BBC1's ratings drive, with the Frank Skinner Show making the biggest gains at the expense of the Ten O'Clock News.

The Frank Skinner Show averaged a 7.7m audience and 37% share from 10pm, up by 0.8m compared with last Monday, according to unofficial overnights. The BBC1 Ten O'Clock News lost exactly that number of viewers, falling back to 5.1m - and a 25% share - compared with its debut last week.

Overall, ITV's share of peak time viewing (6pm-10.30pm) rose by 1.6 percentage points to 37.9%; while BBC1 fell back from 32.8% to 31.8%. Between 7pm-10.30pm ITV was even more dominant, with a 40.3% share compared with BBC1's 31.4%.

Who Wants to be a Millionaire? got the better of BBC1 comedies One Foot in the Grave and the Royle Family between 9pm and 10pm, with 10.8m and a 41% share across the hour. One Foot in the Grave averaged 9.8m and a 37% share from 9pm, while the Royle Family followed up with 8.3m and a 32% share.

Earlier in the evening, Liz McDonald's return to Weatherfield helped Coronation Street to post big ratings, even by the soap's own blockbusting standards. Coronation Street averaged 15.3m and a 65% share from 7.30pm.

There was better ratings news for BBC1 yesterday morning, with new starters House Invaders and Neighbours Revealed combining to defeat ITV's ratings stalwart, This Morning.

House Invaders, a Changing Rooms-style format fronted by Linda Barker, led off with 1.4m - and a 28% share - from 11am. Neighbours Revealed, a behind-the-scenes look at the Australian soap import, followed up at 11.30am with 1.8m and a 31% share.

This Morning, which has seen off numerous BBC1 pretenders to its morning ratings crown over the years, was beaten for once, averaging only 1.3m and a 25% share from 10.30am-12.15pm.

On BBC2 last night Ruby Wax returned with her quirky, dinner party-style chat show and a guest list including Roseanne at 11.20pm. Ruby managed 0.7m and a 9% share.

fields.headline: Failing train firm is sacked
fields.trailText: The French-owned rail company Connex will today become the first victim of the industry's strengthened regulatory regime when it is stripped of one of its operating franchises.
fields.body:
The French-owned rail company Connex will today become the first victim of the industry's strengthened regulatory regime when it is stripped of one of its operating franchises.

The announcement will be highlighted by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, as an indication of the government's determination to improve the country's beleaguered rail infrastructure in the aftermath of last week's crash at Hatfield.

Connex's south central franchise is expected to be removed after a period in which it has been awarded poor grades by the shadow strategic rail authority. Commuters and rail passenger groups have consistently criticised its poor punctuality and dirty rolling stock.

Connex has pledged more than £1bn for improved services for the suburban services from London to Surrey and Sussex, but the SSRA is unconvinced that its plans will work. It lies ninth in the list of the 25 rail companies. Connex will continue to operate its south-east franchise and wants the opportunity to continue expanding in the UK.

The removal of the franchise, which is expected to be handed over to the rival Go-Ahead company, will be seized on by Mr Prescott in his first Commons statement since the Hatfield crash as an example of the new power of the industry's regulatory control.

But the SSRA has been given little room for manoeuvre in deciding who should get the franchise. The other bidder, Go-Ahead, is involved with Thames Trains, which was associated with last year's Paddington rail crash in which 31 people died. But it also operates the largely successful Thameslink services from Luton to Brighton, for which it receives no subsidy.

Mr Prescott is likely to emphasise that safety is of paramount importance and that Lord Cullen's forthcoming report into the Paddington rail crash will set new guidelines for the next decade.

Lord Cullen's report is expected to result in the setting up of a independent national rail safety authority for Britain, similar to the airline industry, which is supervised by the Civil Aviation Authority. The move against Connex follows yesterday's decision by Tom Winsor, the rail regulator, to give an extra £855m of taxpayers' money to Railtrack to make the railways safe. But it must improve its performance.

In his first comments since the Hatfield crash, in which four people died, Mr Winsor said that one of the causes was the failure of Railtrack and its contractor, Balfour Beatty, to communicate with each other about the state of the track at Hatfield.

The £855m is part of a £14.9bn package that Railtrack will be allowed to spend on improvements over the next five years. The money will come from £30bn set aside by the chancellor for rail spending in his financial announcement in July.

Mr Winsor said Railtrack would spend £8bn of the £14.9bn on maintenance, renewal and replacement of track and signalling. Of this, £3.5bn would go on track maintenance, with £150m to reduce the number of broken rails. Maintenance and renewal of signalling systems would account for £4bn, while £500m would be spent on the train protection warning system supposed to stop trains passing through signals on red at up to 70mph.

The review is the first since privatisation and it will operate until 2006. The review says that the regulator will consider a target for Railtrack to reduce the number of broken rails from an expected figure of 765 in this financial year to 615 by 2006. This figure may be tightened following a consultant's report due to be handed to Mr Winsor next month.

If Railtrack fails to meet this target it could be penalised by £80,000 for each broken rail. Conversely, it would receive £80,000 for every broken rail fixed beyond the 615 target.

Mr Winsor said: "Railtrack has to to improve its performance. It has an obligation to run a safe railway and that is what it must do."

fields.headline: Rail franchises
fields.standfirst: The rail regulator has stripped Connex of its train operating franchise. Simon Jeffery explains why
fields.trailText: The rail regulator has stripped Connex of its train operating franchise. We explain why.
fields.body:
What are rail franchises and why are they in the news?

A rail franchise gives a private company the right to run trains along designated routes. Today Connex lost its franchise to run suburban routes between London, Sussex and Surrey.

How did that happen?

The shadow strategic rail authority ended Connex's tenure four years into a seven-year franchise. The regulator was unconvinced that the £1bn Connex had promised to upgrade the service would make any difference to what was one of the most dirty, unloved and delayed rail franchises in the country. So the authority awarded it to the Anglo-French consortium Govia instead.

Is it a popular move?

Travellers have long criticised Connex, which is owned by French conglomerate Vivendi, for its late running and overcrowded trains. The company has also suffered industrial relations problems in recent years.

Where did Connex go wrong?

A rail watchdog, the rail passengers committee for southern England, says that passengers' satisfaction on the Connex servives was "dismally low" despite recent investment. Just one in three passengers believed their journey was value for money and complaints about the company's south-central train services rose 31% in the year to March.

Will Govia be any different?

It has promised £1.5bn of investment to include an upgrade of the busy London-Brighton line and new services throughout south London. As part of the deal, all the present slam-door trains will be replaced within the next few years. All new trains in service after 2003 will be fitted with the train protection warning system.

What about punctuality?

Govia has given an undertaking that by the year 2005, nine out of 10 trains would arrive within five minutes of the scheduled time, rising to 15 out of 16 trains by 2010. Just over 80% of Connex's Sussex trains arrived on time.

How has Connex reacted?

A spokeswoman said the company was "very disappointed" with the announcement. Connex pledged to spend almost as much over the next 20 years on improving services as Govia. The company will retain its south-east franchise.

What do the passengers say?

Commuters are glad that Connex has lost its franchise. "It's been delay after delay after delay. I'm sick of having to turn up to work late and blame it on the train," said 28-year-old secretary Jane Williams, who makes the journey from Beckenham to Victoria station every day.

Will there be an improvement in services?

Many rail users were sceptical that the £1.5bn promised by Govia will make a difference. The consortium also runs Thames Trains, which was involved in the Paddington rail crash. So it cannot claim to be making a complete break with the unpopular private train operators of the past.

fields.headline: NTL inks content deal with MyMovies website
fields.trailText: 1pm: Fan-based movie website MyMovies.net has signed a deal with NTL to distribute its content to the cable and digital TV giant's customers. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Fan-based movie website MyMovies.net has signed a far-reaching deal with NTL to distribute its content to the cable and digital TV giant's customers.

The deal, said to be the first of its kind in the UK, will enable MyMovies.net to push its content to NTL users across digital cable TV (initially just the interactive platform), NTLWorld and its planned cable modem (broadband) service.

To bolster MyMovies.net's content, the website has teamed up with the Short Film Bureau to develop a short films channel on its website to stream movies over the internet and across new platforms. The tie-up is part of MyMovies.net's ambition to become "the ultimate interactive online movie broadcaster".

MyMovies.net, which launched last year, also plans to launch a broadband video-on-demand service for feature films at the start of next year.

Partnerships are already in place with major film distributors including UIP, 20th Century Fox, Buena Vista International, FilmFour, Entertainment, Downtown and Path. The site already features an archive of audio/visual content that includes daily news, movie shorts, trailers and interviews.

Stuart Dennis, managing director of MyMovies.net, said: "We have spent a year developing our product to ensure that we were credible and authentic from the day we launched the MyMovies on demand service. Joining forces with the Short Film Bureau enables us to roll out mould-breaking, movie-related content to the UK market.

"NTL's multi-platform strategy and broadband capacity will allow us to deliver this content to a variety of audiences both on PC and TV."

Douglas Miller, director of the Short Film Bureau, said: "This partnership will provide a massive boost for the British film industry, helping to ensure more raw talent makes the breakthrough."

It is expected that a dedicated TV channel of short films will be eventually developed on NTL as part of the tie-up.

webTitle: Earl Spencer's writing to go on the net

fields.headline: Earl Spencer signs internet publishing deal
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Earl Spencer has signed up to write for the internet through new digital content syndicator eSubstance, reports Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Earl Spencer has signed up to write for the internet.

The brother of the late Princess of Wales has written 22 articles, mainly about his aristocratic ancestry, for new digital content syndicator eSubstance.

Earl Spencer, who will receive a set fee plus royalties each time his work is sold on to third-party websites, said of the move: "As a writer and journalist I'm excited to be a part of an innovative new way to digitally distribute my work."

The deal is the third to be struck by eSubstance, which is signing up traditional publishers to repackage and sell their content to websites.

Other deals include a far-reaching syndicate agreement with Carlton Books to "repurpose" its lifestyle content for sites such as Mothercare, and a deal with bestselling author Frederick Forsyth.

A further 15 deals with "big publishing houses" are in the process of being wrapped up, according to Mark Bishop, marketing director at eSubstance and former head of new media at HarperCollins UK.

Mr Bishop said: "The Earl Spencer deal is a bit different from most of the publishing deals we're doing as the business is not really about commissioning." He hinted that the articles were likely to be sold on to relevant US websites.

ESubstance said that the Spencer articles will provide "a fascinating insight into homes with which the Spencer family has been associated through the centuries".

One of the first pieces eSubstance will offer relates to Earl Spencer's family seat at Althorp, while others will cover houses with which the family has connections including Spencer House and Dublin Castle.

Earl Spencer's move on to the internet echoes Prince Edward's attempts to make money out of his ancestry through the TV series Crown and Country.

Explaining the purpose of eSubstance, Mr Bishop said it was like putting the wheels on a Ferrari. "The traditional publishing industry has 400 years' experience, so we're taking that and making offline content fluid while answering the need in the marketplace for strong content that consumers don't have to pay for."

The company boasts an impressive team drawn from both traditional and online publishing. It was founded by Jeffrey O'Rourke, former director of content strategy at online auctioneer Icollector.com, and Adrian Sington, who has more than 20 years' publishing experience.

ESubstance is launching with the backing of £7.5m in venture capital, the bulk of which came from 3i.

webTitle: News in brief and the latest casting news

fields.headline: News in brief and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: No old fogeys for Angelina - except in real-life, Ecks marks the spot for Banderas, golddigger extraordinaire Anna Nicole Smith sued for pulling out of B-movie, Josh Hartnett goes from Pearl Harbor to Somalia, and Mel Gibson makes dog's dinner of Million Dollar Hotel
fields.body:
 Angelina Jolie (pictured) has allegedly put the future of the forthcoming Oliver Stone film Beyond Borders in the balance by refusing to play love scenes with her co-star Kevin Costner. Jolie, who is 25, claimed that 45-year-old Costner is far too old to be her love interest in the film. A source close to the film said: "Jolie is flatly refusing to play love scenes with Costner because she reckons he's old enough to be her dad." Ironically, her husband in real life is Billy Bob Thornton, who is also 45.

 Antonio Banderas is in final negotiations to star in the action movie Ecks Vs Sever, according to Yahoo News. The film will be the English-language debut of Thai director, Kaos, and will feature Banderas as Ecks, a covert operative locked in mortal combat against his nemesis, Sever. The two agents engage in a vicious and clandestine cat-and-mouse game before realising they must unite to defeat a common enemy.

 Model-turned-actress Anna Nicole Smith, who was recently awarded $450m from her late husband's estate, is now being sued by a film producer for a project she pulled out of in 1996. Obviously smelling a buck or two, B-movie producer Vince Offer is suing Smith for breach of contract for the film Underground Comedy Movie, which co-starred the then famous adulterer Joey Buttafuoco. Smith pulled out after deciding the project was not good for her career or public image. However, the trial has been suspended while Smith recovers from a weight lifting accident.

 Josh Hartnett, who has just finished filming the second world war drama Pearl Harbor with Ben Affleck and Alec Baldwin, is close to signing up for another war movie, this time for Blade Runner director Ridley Scott. Based on the novel by Mark Bowden, Black Hawk tells the true story of a 1993 American humanitarian mission in Somalia which becomes involved in the longest sustained battle since Vietnam. Filming is due to begin early next year.

 Mel Gibson has described the ill-fated Wim Wenders project, Million Dollar Hotel, as "boring as a dog's ass". He made the comments at a press conference in Sydney last week when promoting his new film, What Women Want. Million Dollar Hotel also starred Milla Jovovich and U2's Bono in a series of vignettes that was universally slammed by British critics. The Observer's Philip French wrote that "it moves at the pace of the London Eye and is a feast of over-acting". A spokesman for Gibson was quick to try and brush over his remarks saying: "He has a great sense of humour."

The two agents engage in a vicious and clandestine cat-and-mouse game before realising they must unite to defeat a common enemy.  Model-turned-actress Anna Nicole Smith, who was recently awarded $450m from her late husband's estate, is now being sued by a film producer for a project she pulled out of in 1996. Obviously smelling a buck or two, B-movie producer Vince Offer is suing Smith for breach of contract for the film Underground Comedy Movie, which co-starred the then famous adulterer Joey Buttafuoco. Smith pulled out after deciding the project was not good for her career or public image. However, the trial has been suspended while Smith recovers from a weight lifting accident.  Josh Hartnett, who has just finished filming the second world war drama Pearl Harbor with Ben Affleck and Alec Baldwin, is close to signing up for another war movie, this time for Blade Runner director Ridley Scott. Based on the novel by Mark Bowden, Black Hawk tells the true story of a 1993 American humanitarian mission in Somalia which becomes involved in the longest sustained battle since Vietnam. Filming is due to begin early next year.  Mel Gibson has described the ill-fated Wim Wenders project, Million Dollar Hotel, as "boring as a dog's ass". He made the comments at a press conference in Sydney last week when promoting his new film, What Women Want. Million Dollar Hotel also starred Milla Jovovich and U2's Bono in a series of vignettes that was universally slammed by British critics. The Observer's Philip French wrote that "it moves at the pace of the London Eye and is a feast of over-acting". A spokesman for Gibson was quick to try and brush over his remarks saying: "He has a great sense of humour."

fields.headline: Kaess to succeed Reinhard at DDB
fields.trailText: 12.45pm: Ken Kaess, the president of DDB Worldwide, has been named successor to the agency's CEO, Keith Reinhard. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Ken Kaess, the president of DDB Worldwide, has been named successor to the advertising agency's longstanding CEO, Keith Reinhard.

Mr Kaess, 46, will become CEO of DDB Worldwide on January 1. He seizes control of the industry's third largest and most creative multinational network, which has a presence in 100 markets worldwide.

Mr Kaess, who first joined DDB in 1976, has been viewed as its likely heir-apparent since Mr Reinhard signed him up to DDB's worldwide operating committee in May 1999. He was later promoted to president of DDB North America - and had ultimate responsibility for its six full-service US offices and all Canadian offices.

He has led the agency's development of internet strategy and will continue to develop its range of marketing services.

Mr Kaess will now work closely with Bernard Brochand, 62, president of DDB International, and John Bradstock, 66, president of North American and Pacific operations, when each becomes a vice-chairman of DDB on January 1.

Mr Reinhard, 65, will remain chairman and has no immediate plans for retirement. He has held the CEO title since 1986.

fields.headline: A race against time
fields.standfirst:
Football Italia's head honcho on why racism in Italian football doesn't stop with Sinisa Mijhalovic

Continental football special report
fields.trailText: Football Italia's head honcho on why racism in Italian football doesn't stop with Sinisa Mijhalovic
fields.body:
Last week we heard the one about the Frenchman, the Serb and the Italian tifosi, and funny it wasn't. For those who missed it first time: in the course of Arsenal's ill-tempered match with Lazio in Rome, Italian fans relentlessly booed the visitors' black players. Additionally, Lazio's Serbian defender Sinisa Mihajlovic allegedly subjected Patrick Vieira to racial abuse for the entire 90 minutes - sample quote: "N*gg*r of sh*t". "Yes, I said that" admits Mihajlovic, "but Vieira started it." Uefa have given Mihajlovic a two-game European suspension, and his club have fined him £30,000.

Our Sinisa is no stranger to controversy, of course. He had close ties with the indicted Serb war criminal Arkan, and on his murder last season invited the Lazio supporters to indulge in their infamous homage: "Honour to the Tiger". This summer he was publicly attacking the excess of Argentines in his own team. And now come Vieira's accusations. You might marvel at the irony of a Serb immigrant in Italy making racist remarks, but since Lazio have now imposed a press silence on their players, that's not a point Sinisa can respond to.

So on then to the fans, and the back page question in last week's British press: are all these eyeties racists or what? Answer: no, but please put on your sociology hat and consider the following. Racial integration in Italy is 30 - 40 years behind many other European countries, because here large-scale immigration is a relatively recent phenomenon. Despite this, racial attacks and violence of the kind found in Germany are almost unheard of. That's the good news.

The bad news is that Italian football does have a very visible problem with racism. Neo-fascist symbols and sloganeering remain popular here, and they've become attached to football in the same way hooliganism did in Britain during the 70s and 80s. In the notoriously un-policed world of the 'Ultras', right-wing groups have bloomed. Last year on 'Gazzetta', for example, we visited the headquarters of Lazio's 'Irriducibili' supporters where a portrait of 'Il Duce' Mussolini hung happily on the wall.

It was supporters like these that daubed "Winter Raus" on the walls of Rome before Dutchman Aaron Winter arrived at Lazio in 1992. (He was black and Jewish, and was advised by the club to deny the latter.) "For a few days it was horrible," he says now. "I was afraid to leave the house or mix with people." Curiously though, having endured the early atmosphere, Winter found himself "treated like a King" by the fans during his four highly successful years in Rome - which helps explain why Lazio's manager Sven Goran Eriksson advises signing another black player now. It's crude but perhaps effective.

Worryingly though, while clubs and government stress their anti-racist commitments, some in Italy would prefer to see the issue buried. For them, the booing of black players is merely an unpleasant but unremarkable means of provoking the opposition - in much the same tradition as previous generations' taunts of visiting Neapolitans or Torinese - and despite the fines the League now imposes on clubs here, there's little sign of the practice dying out.

Nor have fan-based initiatives met with any long-term success. Maybe it's unrealistic to imagine these mentalities disappearing without the arrival of a generation of black Italian players, and a real integration in the rest of the community. In the meantime though, the behaviour of these Italian fans insults their own nation far more than any visiting players - and with the rest of Europe beginning to point the finger, Italy can't afford to wait too long. Sound familiar?

webTitle: Compete, show less respect and stay cool

fields.headline: Compete, show less respect and stay cool
fields.standfirst: As England begin their three-match one-day series against Pakistan today, Tim de Lisle pinpoints six goals they should be aiming for
fields.trailText: Three years ago, England went to Pakistan for a couple of one-day warm-up games. They won both with ease, and went on to lift the Champions Trophy in Sharjah - the only one-day cup they have won abroad in the past decade. Last week, they returned to Pakistan for two one-day warm-ups, and won both with ease. So one omen is good for the three-match one-day series which begins today. Whether England can be expected to beat Pakistan on their own turf, or baked mud, is another matter. Can they do it? Yes. Will they? Probably not. Here are six targets for England that are a little more realistic.
fields.body:
Three years ago, England went to Pakistan for a couple of one-day warm-up games. They won both with ease, and went on to lift the Champions Trophy in Sharjah - the only one-day cup they have won abroad in the past decade. Last week, they returned to Pakistan for two one-day warm-ups, and won both with ease. So one omen is good for the three-match one-day series which begins today. Whether England can be expected to beat Pakistan on their own turf, or baked mud, is another matter. Can they do it? Yes. Will they? Probably not. Here are six targets for England that are a little more realistic.

1 To compete
England have improved at one-day cricket since the miserable low point of the 1999 World Cup, winning 10 games and losing six with two no-results. But the wins have nearly all come when facing the game's smaller fry. Against Zimbabwe, West Indies and Bangladesh England have won nine games and lost only two. Against South Africa - even though most of the meetings came in the final, tainted, leather-jacketed days of Hansie Cronje - England have won only one game and lost four.

Pakistan are much closer to South Africa than to any of the other teams England have encountered lately. There would be no shame in, say, a hard-fought series ending in a 2-1 defeat.

2 To find a role for the captain
From June 1999 to February 2000, Nasser Hussain was a one-day opener. In England last July, he got injured, and Marcus Trescothick and Alec Stewart made so many runs that when Hussain returned, it was at No.6. On this tour so far, in both Kenya and Pakistan, he has been at No.3. Hussain has got into an uncharacteristic muddle. No.3 is where he should be in England, with its green seaming pitches. No.6 is where he should be in Africa or Asia, ready to play the sort of innings Jonty Rhodes plays for South Africa, a scampered 30 or 40. On flat pitches, Hussain (career average: 27) should not allow himself to delay the entrance of Graeme Hick (38) or Graham Thorpe (also 38).

3 ... and for Andy Flintoff
Too many of Flintoff's 20-odd international innings have been a quick slog. By sticking him down at No.6, England are all but ensuring that that is the height of his ambitions. If he is in the team at all, he should be in the top four, with a chance of wreaking sustained havoc, as he did for Lancashire against several of his England team-mates - and, more significantly, Saqlain Mushtaq - at The Oval last summer.

4 To collect experience
There are two ways to do this: play a lot of matches, and make consistent selections. Pakistan, for all their changes of captain and coach, have managed this: Abdur Razzaq, still only 20 (apparently), has already played 66 one-day internationals and has become one of the world's most effective bowlers, with 96 wickets at 23.

England's policy over the years has been the exact opposite - few games, and many changes, so that in almost every one-day game they play, they have far less experience than their opponents. But they have begun to mend their ways now. The team that played Bangladesh in Nairobi was the same XI that beat Zimbabwe in the Triangular final at Lord's in July apart from Alan Mullally, who was ruled out by injury. When they can wobble, they still do: Mullally's place went first to Mark Alleyne, a thoroughly English player who has only ever been picked for England abroad, then to Paul Grayson (ditto) - who can only have been preferred to Robert Croft by selectors who were oblivious to the value of experience. Now that place is poised to go to Ashley Giles. But at least the core of the team is settled. And although England's experience of Pakistan is laughably slight - five of them played there in the 1996 World Cup - the Pakistanis themselves have been so busy flying to Sharjah and Toronto in the past few years, they haven't played many one-dayers at home themselves. Of Razzaq's 66 one-day caps, five have come in Pakistan.

5 To show a little less respect
England's summer took a clear turn for the better when they stopped being cowed by the mere sight of Curtly Ambrose or Courtney Walsh lolloping in to bowl to them. One of the moments of the season came when Michael Vaughan pulled Ambrose for four at Lord's. Then Vaughan and Hick took cheeky twos to the two old boys at Headingley, and by the end of the series, even Mike Atherton was playing the pull shot off Ambrose, and Craig White was cover-driving Walsh with some panache. In this series, the role of Walsh is being taken by Wasim Akram, another great old bowler (putting the Qayyum Report aside) who is refusing to fade away. But like any bowler, he can be expensive in one-dayers. Alec Stewart, who plays him better than almost anyone in the world and has a Test average of 66 against Pakistan, must take the lead in treating Akram with a healthy disrespect.

6 To keep their cool
In 1987, Mike Gatting was right: the umpiring was appalling. But he was also wrong, because his response didn't make it any better. Umpires give batsmen the benefit of the doubt; England are going to have to give the umpires it too. If they do get sawn off by a bad decision, those that played in the Headingley Test of 1998, when England beat South Africa, should remember how Mike Atherton handled it: by smiling, ruefully.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com. To read regularly updated bulletins on England's progress today, click here

webTitle: Shaky future for time-travelling Don Quixote

fields.headline: Shaky future for time-travelling Don Quixote
fields.trailText: The future of Terry Gilliam's pet project, The Man Who Killed Don Quixote, looks in serious doubt as leading actor Jean Rochefort has been struck down with a double disk hernia
fields.body:
The future of Terry Gilliam's pet project, The Man Who Killed Don Quixote, looks in serious doubt as leading actor Jean Rochefort (pictured) has been struck down with a double disk hernia.

The 70-year-old actor will not be able to resume filming until at least January, which may make it unfeasible for the star-studded cast to reassemble, according to ScreenDaily.

The film, a time-travelling update of the Cervantes classic, has been a project close to Gilliam's heart for over five years. He finally got the financial backing and shooting began on September 26 with an all-star cast, including Johnny Depp and his real-life partner Vanessa Paradis, British actors Miranda Richardson, Christopher Eccleston and Peter Vaughan, as well as veteran French actor Rochefort, whom Gilliam had apparently always intended to play Don Quixote.

Gilliam is expected to fight against the possibility of the whole project being abandoned, although a spokesperson for Pathe has confirmed, "Don Quixote is on hold until further notice." It is thought the final decision on the fate of the film will be made by the end of the week.

Meanwhile, the ex-Python's next project has been revealed as a film version of the bestselling Terry Pratchett-Neil Gaiman book, Good Omens. The film's plot centres on an angel and a demon who are sent together on a mission to track down the Anti-Christ, who is somewhere on Earth. Filming is scheduled to begin in Britain towards the end of 2001.

webTitle: Tony Blair's speech on the environment

fields.headline: Tony Blair: 'A new coalition for the environment'
fields.standfirst: Blair announces £100m boost for environment
fields.trailText: Full text: Tony Blair's speech on the environment
fields.body:
There are at points real conflict between the immediate interests of consumption and the longer term interests of the environment; and to be frank, between the politicans' need to woo the electorate a well as lead them.

My point is simply this. We must work at resolving these conflicts or finding a way through. And we should recognise that to be environmentally conscious isn't a punishment. It is indeed in our long term interests; and it can also be of benefit, short and medium term too. What's more there is a real concern and desire amongst our people, within realistic bounds, to do the right thing. We have children and granchildren.

We care for them. We know that despoiling the environment today will mean hardship, even death for them tomorrow. Call it idealism or even just family values: there is an energy and commitment there we can harness.

Where 15 years ago many thought that there would always be a trade-off between progress and the environment, we can now see a way through. What becomes clear is that to preserve what we value most - our local environment, the countryside around us - we must protect the whole earth, and do so by pioneering new ways of building, working, living. New technologies to deliver a low carbon economy; to use our finite resources more efficiently, to reform national and international institutions and create positive incentives to be green.

In short, we don't halt progress and retreat into the past, nor do we carry on regardless. Instead we take pride in our progress. Using our creativity in partnership to protect the environment.

The threat

We have made a lot of progress over this Parliament. Through John Prescott's leadership, and the hard work of Michael here on the platform with me, we can point to measurable achievements. We are on track to meet our Kyoto targets. Air quality is improving. London now has the cleanest river of any major city.

But we have to face a stark fact. Neither we here in Britain, nor our partners abroad, have succeeded in reversing the overall destructive trend. The environmental challenge continues to grow and become more urgent:

 There are alarming changes in our atmosphere, in global temperatures, in weather patterns, in sea levels and in the protective ozone layer. As a result, across the world millions face drought, flooding, disease. Here in the UK we too face threats - the prospect of exotic diseases becoming commonplace, of increased levels of skin cancer, of floods in some years, droughts in others, of low lying areas being swallowed by the sea.

 Global population growth will put increased pressure on natural resources. The world pop is set to rise from 6bn to 9bn by 2050. So that economies across the world have the opportunity to develop, we must all use resources far more efficiently and switch to clean technologies.

 Fresh water is being polluted or simply used up. Demand is doubling every 21 years while supply is broadly unchanged.

 Soil degradation has affected two-thirds of the world's agricultural lands over the last 50 years, and the situation is getting worse.

 Half the world's wetlands have been lost over the past century and with them their unique plants and animals; and this is accelerating

 One in ten of the world's tree species are at risk of extinction, and increasingly whole forest systems are under threat

 Fishing fleets are still 40 per cent larger than the oceans can sustain and yet it still benefits from subsidies, world wide

 Here in the UK farmland birds are disappearing, the house sparrow, once more cockney than the Cockneys, is now a rarity in London, and congestion means that urban traffic moves at the same speed as in 1890.

Of two things I am certain. We are not going to turn this round unless we re-engage the political system on the importance of the environmental challenge. We are not going to be able to engage consumers and business unless we offer them a positive agenda.

A new approach to the environment

We need to build a new coalition for the environment, a coalition that works with the grain of consumers, business and science, not against them. A coalition that harnesses consumer demand for a better environment, and encourages businesses to see the profit of the new green technologies. and a coalition that stretches across national frontiers.

The central theme of our approach is a more productive use of environmental resources. It is clear that if we are to continue to grow, and share the benefits of that growth; we must reduce the impact of growth on the environment. Some commentators estimate that we'll need a tenfold increase in the efficiency with which we use resources by 2050 only to stand still. Above all, we need to be clear about our priorities, and the principles that underlie our approach:

 First, the greatest threat to our environment today is climate change. The Royal Commission on Environmental Pollution has said that the UK will have to cut the CO2 we produce by 60% by 2050 if we are to slow down the pace of change. If there is one immediate issue that threatens global disaster, it is the changes in our atmosphere.

 Second, problems need to be addressed at the right level. A problem like climate change requires international as well as national action. The reason for taking the lead in cutting national emissions, as we have in the UK, is to give us the standing and authority in international negotiations. And developed countries, as the principle producers of greenhouse gases, should set an example for developing ones.

 Third, we should harness consumer demand, not stifle it. We should not be trying to reduce people's aspirations, but rather find innovative ways of satisfying those aspirations. As our societies become more prosperous, so people's demand for a better environment is growing. More and more people want to buy green. We should encourage that, and harness that green consumer power in our environmental policies

 Fourth, we must stimulate science and innovation. I reject the pessimistic notion that most environmental problems can only be managed, not solved. Technological advance does offer opportunities, particularly to counter climate change and provide alternatives to finite energy resources.

 Fifth, we need to use environmental resources more efficiently and to become a low-carbon, recycling economy. We need to become much more effective about how we use finite resources. Stephen Byers set out a radical new direction in his speech to Greenpeace's Business Conference earlier this month, focussing on resource productivity and the Government's programme to boost renewable energy.

 Lastly, we should see protecting the environment as a business opportunity. There is a growing market for environmental goods and services - currently worth an amazing US$335 billion - as large as the world market for pharmaceuticals or aerospace. I am not saying that the interests of business and the environment have become identical. But we should exploit them and develop them when they are. Otherwise, history shows us the environment risks being the loser.

New Labour's Green Agenda

I make no apology for the priority we have given education, health and crime. Yet no other British Government has had a Deputy Prime Minister in charge of environment policy. And no other British Government has put the environment at the heart of its policy-making across the board - from foreign affairs to the national curriculum - in the way this Government has. Since 1997, we have:

 Taken a lead internationally, as at Kyoto.  Introduced an air quality strategy going beyond even the tough new European standards  Cleaned up decades of pollution of our beaches and rivers, and given greater protection to important wildlife sites  Factored environmental considerations into all our legislation and policy, from the Utilities Act to innovative fiscal measures such as incentives and hypothecation  And as a result of the Comprehensive Spending Review, started to invest billions in transport to increase choice and cut congestion and pollution

Yet I would be the first to say that there is still a lot more we could and will do.

John Prescott will shortly publish the final version of our strategy on Climate Change. It will set out how Britain plans to deliver its international obligations to cut greenhouse gases by 12.5% and move towards a 20% reduction in CO2 emissions. This will include a 10% target for energy from renewables by 2010.

As part of the Climate Change Levy package, businesses will be able to claim capital allowances for investments they make in energy-saving technologies from next April. I can also announce that we will shortly be launching a new Carbon Trust in Britain that will channel up to £50 million a year developing low-carbon technology, partly funded from the Climate Change Levy. We have worked closely with business and the research community since their participation is vital to the Trust's long-term success. The Trust will take the lead on low-carbon technology and innovation in this country, and put Britain in the lead internationally.

We will also be setting up an office to export Britain's low-carbon technologies, the Kyoto Mechanisms Office. This was suggested to me at a meeting I had on climate change with business leaders earlier this year. By encouraging the private sector to invest in innovative energy projects abroad, it will help tackle climate change and allow British business to seize new opportunities. The Office will start work in April 2001.

Next Spring, we will be launching the first national CO2 emissions trading system anywhere in the world. Emissions trading is one of the most powerful ways of harnessing the market to cut greenhouse gases. The trading system will set overall limits on emissions for CO2 producers entering the system, and allow them to trade "emission allowances" amongst themselves, to the profit of the cleanest factories and companies.

I believe government has a key role to play in assisting business build up the economies of scale in these new technologies so that they can compete effectively. Today, we are announcing proposals for £50 million from the New Opportunities Fund to support offshore wind and biomass. The DTI is already providing £39 million for new offshore wind turbines, and the first are about to go into operation off Blyth. Helen Liddle has set up a task force to examine ways of promoting solar energy. And I have also asked the Performance and Innovation Unit to undertake a comprehensive study into the future of renewable energy, with a view to increasing substantially our long-term investment.

Any environmental policy has to address the implications of the car. Transport produces around 25% of global CO2 and rising. Making public transport more attractive will take us only so far. The long-term solution is to make vehicles cleaner and more fuel efficient. That is why we have used the tax system to roll out cleaner fuels. Lead in petrol is now a thing of the past, and we are now using tax incentives to promote ultra-low sulphur petrol. Through the EU, we have persuaded manufacturers to improve fuel efficiency by 25%. In our forthcoming Rural White Paper we will set out policies for a living countryside which is economically vibrant, conserves wildlife and landscapes and which everyone can enjoy. And the Urban White Paper will set out our National Strategy for Neighbourhood renewal. We are also proposing that the New Opportunities Funds should invest another £50 million for quality of life in urban and rural settlements and for green spaces.

On recycling, we want to do more to harness the power of the market. The new Waste Resource Action Programme, led by business, will develop markets for recycled materials. A proposed further 50 million pounds from The New Opportunities Fund will help provide kerbside recycling for 700,000 households. I want to see every local authority offering doorstep recycling to take advantage of these new markets. And the office co-ordinating government procurement will soon begin trialling the purchasing of recycled products, using government purchasing to expand the market.

On regulation, our aim must be to raise environmental standards without imposing unnecessary burdens on business. Often, the most effective approach to raising standards is a cross-border one. That is why we are working with the European Commission and other member states to improve the regulatory process in Europe.

This brings me to environmental diplomacy. The international climate change negotiations remain a key government priority, and we will be taking a leading role in The Hague next month. I also want to extend the EU's economic reform agenda to new energy saving technologies. And I can announce today that I plan to attend the next Earth Summit in 2002, and I will be encouraging other world leaders to join us there.

Fifteen years ago, if you said business will help save the environment people would have laughed at you. Today, I believe that is a serious proposition.

As BP's John Browne has said, the enlightened company increasingly recognises that there are good commercial reasons for being ahead of the pack when it comes to issues to do with the environment.

Environmentally-aware oil companies are finding ways to recapture the CO2 produced by plant and equipment and pump it back underground to enhance the recovery of oil. They are working with car manufacturers on new technologies, from developing fuel cell cars, to putting hydrogen-powered buses on the road in Europe.

Shell is playing a major role in the move away from oil in power generation. Like its competitor BP, it is investing heavily in solar power. ABB recently shifted its focus from being a builder of traditional large-scale power plants to focus on small scale renewable technologies. It expects alternative energy solutions to account for US$1 billion worth of business for the company within the next five years.

It is increasingly clear that energy generation in the future will become a spectrum: from the cleaner extraction of energy from fossil fuels; through the move from liquid to cleaner gas fuels; new technologies that convert hydrocarbon fuels into energy without combustion; to, at its greenest end, the carbon free technologies of wind and solar.

The City and investment community is beginning to recognise the new commercial and environmental realities, and to make money out of them. I would also like to see more reporting on environmental and social performance. The pioneers of environmental reporting - companies like BA, BT, British Gas, and BP - are seeing increasing benefits from both improved efficiencies and public image as a result. This is something that all companies should be doing, and I am issuing a challenge, today, to all of the top 350 companies to be publishing annual environment reports by the end of 2001.

Increasingly, NGOs are also putting more and more energy into offering solutions in partnership with business and government.

For example, the Worldwide Fund for Nature and Unilever have set up the Marine Stewardship Council to protect our endangered fish stocks. Thames Water and the Wildfowl and Wetlands Trust have converted redundant reservoirs and treatment at Barn Elms into a fantastic new wildlife habitat. Fourteen companies, eight NGOs and three Government departments are working together on the Digital Futures project, to try to ensure that the e-commerce revolution happens in the most environmentally friendly way possible. It is now a highly successful example of green organisation and industry working together for the benefit of the Ozone layer. Coca Cola and Unilever have just announce they will move towards such alternative refrigerants such as Greenfreeze by 2005.

I have asked Jonathan Porritt to chair it and I am very pleased to launch it today. The members, drawn from business, local government, pressure groups and academia, will build a consensus, monitor our progress, and suggest ways we can reconcile the needs of the environment, the economy and society.

So the outlook is not all bleak. There is real progress. But it is a race against time, lethargy, and indifference. It is an urgent issue. People feel it; but they don't always know how to make a difference.

Millions of people around the country are "green" in their actions, their beliefs, what they care about. They want the air they breath to be fresh. They want the countryside they live in or visit to be protected. They have respect for the world around them - hate cruelty to animals, hate the destruction of natural beauty. They want their neighbourhoods to have parks and be free from litter, grafitti, kids with nothing to do, and crime. Millions recycle, more would like to. The essence of environmental politics is the notion of responsibility to nature and future generations to protect and enhance the environment. We have to show how this strongly held belief can translate into practical action. fields.headline: Blair announces £100m boost for environment
fields.standfirst: Full text of Tony Blair's speech
fields.trailText: Tony Blair announced a £100m boost for green policies today as he called for a "new coalition" to protect the environment.
fields.body:
Tony Blair announced a £100m boost for green policies today as he called for a "new coalition" to protect the environment.

In a speech to the CBI and Green Alliance in London, the prime minister said that environmental groups and business people had to work together with consumers and sciencists to see the profit of green technologies.

The address was Mr Blair's first on environmental issues for three years. In it he argued that prosperity and the environment were not enemies.

"We get richer by being greener and by being greener we will enrich the quality of our lives," he said. "The central theme of our approach is a more productive use of environmental resources. It is clear that if we are to continue to grow, and share the benefits of that growth, we must reduce the impact of growth on the environment."

The £100m promised by the prime minister will be used to help carbon emissions and improve the take up of renewable energy. A £50m "carbon trust" will encourage low carbon technologies, reducing harmful "greenhouse gas" emissions, and £50m from the government's new opportunities fund will encourage research in renewable energy such as solar or wind power.

But Mr Blair conceded there were "hard choices" to be made between "ideals and realism" in key areas such as petrol consumption and the need to build new houses in the south east.

"There are at points real conflict between the immediate interests of consumption and the longer term interests of the environment - and to be frank, between the politicans' need to woo the electorate as well as lead them." The Conservative leader, William Hague, attacked the government's environmental policy as "all talk, no action".

webTitle: Kostunica accepts blame for Kosovo killings

fields.headline: Kostunica accepts blame for Kosovo killings
fields.trailText:
Yugoslavia's new president has admitted for the first time 
that Yugoslav army and police forces committed widespread killings in Kosovo last year.
fields.body:
Yugoslavia's new president has admitted for the first time that Yugoslav army and police forces committed widespread killings in Kosovo last year.

Vojislav Kostunica's remarks, in a television interview released early today, marked the first time any Yugoslav has accepted responsibility and expressed remorse for any of the conflicts in the last decade in the Balkans. Former president Slobodan Milosevic steadfastly blamed the West for fomenting violence in the region.

"I am ready to... accept the guilt for all those people who have been killed," Mr Kostunica said. "For what Milosevic had done, and as a Serb, I will take responsibility for many of these, these crimes."

Asked by the US television network CBS News whether Yugoslav forces were guilty of genocide in the southern province of Kosovo, Mr Kostunica admitted that crimes had occurred, but said that both Serbs and ethnic Albanians had been killed.

"Those are the crimes and the people that have been killed are victims," Mr Kostunica said, adding: "There are a lot of crimes on the other side and the Serbs have been killed."

The interview is to be aired tonight in the US on CBS's 60 Minutes II nightly news programme. webTitle: McClaren reveals his masterplan for United and the nation

fields.headline: McClaren reveals his masterplan for United and the nation
fields.standfirst: Champions League
fields.trailText: Steve McClaren spread his wings further yesterday by revealing that he plans to apply for Sir Alex Ferguson's job when the Manchester United manager relinquishes his duties in 18 months' time.
fields.body:
Steve McClaren spread his wings further yesterday by revealing that he plans to apply for Sir Alex Ferguson's job when the Manchester United manager relinquishes his duties in 18 months' time.

McClaren is hoping the exposure of working alongside Peter Taylor for England will elevate him to a position of increased strength when United begin the task of sifting through the list of Ferguson's potential successors.

Although the Old Trafford hierarchy are optimistic about tempting Ferguson into an upstairs role, the 58-year-old has repeatedly made it clear he is to step down as manager and it is an opening that his ambitious deputy is eyeing.

"It's not silly to talk about the possibility of me taking over here," McClaren said yesterday. "Everyone knows about the benefits of continuity and how it can help development. It's a year and a half down the line and in the meantime I want to make sure we keep winning things. If we can do that, we will have to see what position that puts me in."

McClaren, 39, clearly has a masterplan that, if fulfilled, would eventually see him take a permanent role with England. "One day I would love to manage England full-time," he added. "It's always been my ambition. I'm still learning and enjoying my job immensely at United and it's too early now. But maybe in four or five years' time. When I set out in this career I always aimed to be the best and that means going as high as possible."

For the time being, however, McClaren has more pressing matters of concern after joining the United squad here for tonight's Champions League game against Anderlecht.

Ferguson says he has been impressed by Anderlecht's recovery since losing 5-1 at Old Trafford and expects "a sterner test" in the Stade Constant Vanden Stock. But, having upset PSV Eindhoven with some of his comments before United's last European game, the acrimony has spread to Belgium after the Walloon press quoted him describing Anderlecht as "a small team".

"We are not a small team. Ferguson has no right to say that," retorted the Belgian champions' president Roger Vanden Stock. "We have proved that with our results against Dynamo Kiev and PSV and I believe we will prove that now to Ferguson. He will see."

Victory would send United into the second phase but Ferguson will be missing Teddy Sheringham (calf) and Roy Keane (hamstring). In the midfielder's absence Ryan Giggs will take over the captaincy.

Anderlecht (probable, 4-4-2): De Wilde; Crasson, Staelens, Doll, Ilic; Goor, Vanderhaeghe, Baseggio, Dindane; Koller, Radzinski.

Manchester United (probable, 4-4-2): Barthez; Irwin, Brown, G Neville, Silvestre; Beckham, Butt, Scholes, Giggs; Yorke, Cole.

fields.headline: Testimoni: Andrea Serafini
fields.standfirst: Andrea Serafini talks about his sudden fame as a film and soap opera director in Italy
fields.trailText: Andrea Serafini talks about his sudden fame as a film and soap opera director in Italy.
fields.body:
Cosa significa fare la regia di una soap opera? Lavoro a blocchi di cinque puntate: una settimana di preparazione, una per girare gli esterni, una in studio e una per il montaggio. Giriamo 18 scene al giorno, molto diverse tra loro: si passa dal comico all'altamente drammatico. È un lavoro duro, ma bello. Bisogna fare molto in poco tempo, ragionare in fretta, pianificare tutto prima di iniziare poiché le scene si girano senza interruzioni, come in diretta.

"Un posto al sole" è stata la prima soap italiana. Entra ora nel suo quinto anno. È basata sul formato australiano di Neighbours, ma ambientata a Napoli. Il suo successo sta proprio nel fatto che i personaggi sono riconoscibili dagli spettatori. Non appartengono a culture straniere, ma rappresentano stereotipi italiani. Si tratta di un gruppo di famiglie di diverso ceto sociale che vivono nello stesso palazzo, dalla famiglia ricca a quella del portiere.

Un altro punto forte è che le puntate sono trasmesse a poche settimane da quando le giriamo e hanno uno stretto legame con la realtà: i personaggi vanno allo stadio per applaudire il Napoli passato in serie A, accolgono un bambino albanese, si trovano a dover fare i conti con la camorra... Anche gli esterni sono luoghi riconoscibili e non falsi; recentemente abbiamo girato a Pompei, ad esempio.

Tutto questo è molto diverso dal lavoro nel cinema; la soap è decisamente più elementare come linguaggio delle immagini, ma interessante. Una bella esperienza.

 Andrea Serafini's short film Block and Tackle, shot in North Yorkshire, was awarded the first prize in two festivals in Italy. He is now one of the directors of the first Italian soap opera, Un posto al sole. He was speaking to Mariacarla Pavoni.

fields.headline: Beauty to make the spirit soar, rubbish to make the heart sink
fields.standfirst:
This year's Turner prize show, by Adrian Searle

Special report: Turner prize 2000
fields.trailText: We need take only two of this year's contenders seriously, says Adrian Searle
fields.body:
This year's Turner prize show opens to the public at Tate Britain tomorrow. The shortlist for the £20,000 prize, which will be awarded on November 28, has already generated a small controversy. Only one finalist, Glenn Brown, is actually British, although the other three - German photographer Wolfgang Tillmans, Dutch painter Michael Raedecker and Japanese installation artist Tomoko Takahashi - all live and work in Britain. Takahashi and Tillmans also studied here.

On the strength of the displays at Millbank, we need take only two of this year's contenders seriously. Wolfgang Tillmans is exhibiting a compendium of 57 images, with yet more in display cabinets in the centre of the room. This is a cool, elegant exhibition, filled with startling, gorgeous, sexy pictures. Some are very large, others little more than snapshots, hung in a disarming and deceptively casual manner. It is the best display of his work I have seen. Some are displayed in groups and grids, others hung very high or low on the walls. There appears to be no order. All the images are either taped directly to the walls or hung on bulldog clips.

These are pictures from a life: friendships and loves and places travelled. I get the feeling that every time Tillmans takes a photo or arranges his images he is trying to make sense of his existence. Here's a naked friend on the sand dunes, grimacing. Here's a pair of jeans, pulled down to reveal a shaven male crotch. Here's flowers in a jam jar.

It could be twee, but as we jump from image to image a dispassionate view of the world emerges. Twenty-one shots of the solar eclipse hang beside a woman bending over in the bath. Next comes a snap of a wisp of hair. Then a bee, and a city at evening. This is like walking in and out of someone's life, taking pleasure in unexceptional moments.

A doorway frames a Glenn Brown painting, a distorted Salvador Dali image, painted in an all-grey palette and extruded even beyond Dali's own distortions of form. The title of Brown's painting is Oscillate Wildly, which comes from a track by the Smiths, while the painting is an attempt to fuse Dali's painting, which dates from the Spanish civil war, with the black and whites of Picasso's Guernica. It is as if the horizontal hold on Brown's painting needs retuning, and other stations are leaking in. The levels of association and mental play in Brown's work are labyrinthine.

Brown's work gets richer and better as it goes along. The references multiply and the complexities keep compounding. Best known for his "appropriations" of the work of Frank Auerbach, in which the expressionist painter's thickly laden, swerving brushstrokes are ironed out by Brown's flat, trompe l'oeil technique, Brown has gone on to borrow and rework images by Dali and the visionary painter John Martin, morphing them with sci-fi book jacket art and album covers for the seriously stoned. He does similar things with his choice of colours, conflating one painter's image with another's palette and adding a title that deepens the game still further. So we have an oval painting by Brown, containing a painting copied from Auerbach, given the title The Marquess of Breadalbane. The painting's colour is derived from Landseer's Victorian potboiler The Monarch of the Glen, which was commissioned by said marquess.

In front of Brown's painting is one of his sculptures, a gnarled, heaving lump of plaster and globby paint, which sits on a plinth under glass. The sculpture is called 1880, after the date of the unnamed French still life that inspired it. I bet this was a still life of roses by French 19th-century painter Henri Fantin-Latour, because that painting decorates an album cover by Joy Division, and Joy Division's singer, the late Ian Curtis, inspired a painting by Julian Schnabel, and Schnabel's dedication appears in the titles to a couple of Brown's paintings. I hope you are still with me.

This is how Brown's mind works. The layers - of art history and art fashion, picture borrowing, play with titles and music - go on piling up. The overall effect, however, goes beyond the quotes and free associations. His visionary scenes, in which space stations sit on rocky outcrops in apocalyptic infernos, and Auerbach-inspired portraits are given perfect halos, leave me spinning. Brown's is a lurid, corrupted grand manner. One painting is titled after Studio 54, the coke-fuelled hangout for the smart set in New York at the height of the 1980s art boom. I almost believe Brown has a moral purpose.

How demoralising it is to walk into Tomoko Takahashi's installation. Takahashi is best known for the vast sprawl of dud computers and photocopiers that filled part of the Saatchi Gallery last year. It was an extreme work from an artist who hates having her photo taken and is rumoured to live among her piles of detritus while she makes her works. Her agglomerations of junk and rubbish proceed, like Brown's work, by an intuitive process of ordering that, once identified, leaves one little the wiser. Learning To Drive is a very dull affair.

Metal shelving units, a builder's wheelbarrow, chairs and much else dangle from the ceiling. The floors are piled with traffic signs, plastic bollards, broken Scalextric track, toy trucks and tractors. Road-menders' barriers keep the public at bay and the Tate security happy. Arcs and clusters of yellow plastic tubing and gas pipes give some kind of form to the shelf units, old tables and office junk that are piled about. Somewhere in here, Learning To Drive has careered into a Tate office clear-out.

Takahashi scribbles notes to herself around the walls, while a kind of annotated map covers the free space on the floor. This turns out to be an installation plan as much as a route map. The clutter doesn't add up to much. The American artist Jason Rhoades does exactly this sort of thing with 100 times more verve and wit. He is also much more extreme, while still remaining conceptually and formally coherent.

One can't help comparing Takahashi with better work going on elsewhere. And how can one not measure Michael Raedecker's paintings against Spanish artist Miquel Barcelo? Raedecker uses an unlikely compilation of materials in his paintings - patches of sewing among the curdled paintwork, nests of wool for the foliage of his lollipop trees, tufts of wool in place of a painted carpet. He does odd things with the paint, too, turning it into worm casts, maggoty flecks, grub-like excrescences. But it is the quality of draw ing, as much as the peculiarity of surface, that make me think of Barcelo, who is just better at this sort of thing. Raedecker's subjects - a lit window beyond a patio at night, a grey bedroom with an unmade bed, wooden houses in the backwoods - also make me think of Peter Doig (a previous Turner finalist). Glenn Brown would turn such odious comparisons into subject matter; Raedecker turns them into style. Raedecker, unaccountably, is William Hill's current favourite, at 13/8.

Tillmans or Brown? I like Tillmans's work more and more. There's something relaxed, generous and beautiful about it. His work makes a perfect foil to Brown's insane language games. A photographer has never won the Turner prize, even though photo-graphy is the medium of the moment. Still, Brown's impeccable exercises in style are highly engaging, visually spectacular and very intelligent. I have a feeling he will win.

 Turner Prize 2000 is at Tate Britain, London SW1 (020-7887 8008), until January 14.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: All today's gossip goes on holiday to Thailand and comes back with a lovely bride
fields.trailText: Here's a new name in the frame for the England job former AC Milan and Italy coach Arrigo Sacchi. Planet Football claim the 54-year-old, who had such a hellish time on these shores with his country during Euro 96, is one of the three men on FA chief executive Adam Crozier's shortlist.
fields.body:
Here's a new name in the frame for the England job former AC Milan and Italy coach Arrigo Sacchi. Planet Football claim the 54-year-old, who had such a hellish time on these shores with his country during Euro 96, is one of the three men on FA chief executive Adam Crozier's shortlist.

It is rumoured that Bradford will replace manager Chris Hutchings with Tottenham director of football David Pleat later this week.

An angry Dennis Bergkamp is once again being linked with his former club Ajax, after losing patience with Arsenal's behaviour during contract negotiations. "I really think it shows a total lack of respect for me," said the 31-year-old striker. "I'm quite angry that I'm not making any progress on my contract negotiations with the club. It leaves me with an extremely negative feeling."

Everton are one of many clubs interested in landing Celtic midfielder Eyal Berkovic, according to the player's agent. Pini Zahavi told Planet Football: "It is not only Walter Smith, other clubs appreciate his ability and will step in if things remain as they are."

It's tug-of-war time again for Millwall's teenage striking sensation Cherno Samba. Depending on who you listen to, Arsenal, Liverpool or Manchester United are about to land the 16-year-old prodigy.

Newcastle are considering a bid for 29-year-old PSV Eindhoven defender Ernst Faber.

Ghanaian striker Kwame Ayew is about to join Sunderland on loan. The 26-year-old Sporting Lisbon man will join permanently in a £1.5m deal if he impresses.

Teenage striker Mika Wayryren is being watched by Tottenham, claim Teamtalk. Director of Football David Pleat has been impressed by the 19-year-old Finn and may make FC Lahti a bid in the near future. Wimbledon are lurking in the wings should the deal fall through.

Everton striker Mark Hughes has been targeted by Blackburn, according to the Mirror. Leicester are also interested in the former Manchester United player, but as Hughes would only be a "squad man" at Filbert Street, he may choose to drop down a division instead. Indeed, Teamtalk claim Hughes will move to Ewood this morning.

Planet Football report that Cork City defender Damien Delaney has joined Leicester for £50,000. The 19-year-old has signed a two-year deal.

Icelandic striker Tryggvi Gudmundsson is on the verge of joining Blackburn, according to Teamtalk. The 26-year-old, who plays in Norway for Tromsø, has scored 18 goals in 26 games this season.

Marcelo Salas is expected to move from Lazio to Internazionale today, reports onefootball.com, with defender Dario Simic moving in the opposite direction.
