It is rumoured that Bradford will replace manager Chris Hutchings with Tottenham director of football David Pleat later this week. An angry Dennis Bergkamp is once again being linked with his former club Ajax, after losing patience with Arsenal's behaviour during contract negotiations. "I really think it shows a total lack of respect for me," said the 31-year-old striker. "I'm quite angry that I'm not making any progress on my contract negotiations with the club. It leaves me with an extremely negative feeling." Everton are one of many clubs interested in landing Celtic midfielder Eyal Berkovic, according to the player's agent. Pini Zahavi told Planet Football: "It is not only Walter Smith, other clubs appreciate his ability and will step in if things remain as they are." It's tug-of-war time again for Millwall's teenage striking sensation Cherno Samba. Depending on who you listen to, Arsenal, Liverpool or Manchester United are about to land the 16-year-old prodigy. Newcastle are considering a bid for 29-year-old PSV Eindhoven defender Ernst Faber. Ghanaian striker Kwame Ayew is about to join Sunderland on loan. The 26-year-old Sporting Lisbon man will join permanently in a £1.5m deal if he impresses. Teenage striker Mika Wayryren is being watched by Tottenham, claim Teamtalk. Director of Football David Pleat has been impressed by the 19-year-old Finn and may make FC Lahti a bid in the near future. Wimbledon are lurking in the wings should the deal fall through. Everton striker Mark Hughes has been targeted by Blackburn, according to the Mirror. Leicester are also interested in the former Manchester United player, but as Hughes would only be a "squad man" at Filbert Street, he may choose to drop down a division instead. Indeed, Teamtalk claim Hughes will move to Ewood this morning. Planet Football report that Cork City defender Damien Delaney has joined Leicester for £50,000. The 19-year-old has signed a two-year deal. Icelandic striker Tryggvi Gudmundsson is on the verge of joining Blackburn, according to Teamtalk. The 26-year-old, who plays in Norway for Tromsø, has scored 18 goals in 26 games this season. Marcelo Salas is expected to move from Lazio to Internazionale today, reports onefootball.com, with defender Dario Simic moving in the opposite direction.

fields.headline: Jazz FM upbeat despite losses
fields.trailText: 11.30am update: Jazz FM has posted pre-tax losses of £489,000, but said it has been trading at break-even for six months. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Broadcaster Jazz FM today announced pre-tax losses of £489,000 in the year to June 30, but said it has been trading at break-even for the past six months.

The losses were well down on the previous nine months, when Jazz FM made a £2m loss.

Jazz FM's chairman, Harry Roche, said: "Following the restructure of the company last year the board's main focus has been on improving the performance of the business. I am pleased to report that this effort has borne fruit."

Turnover was up to £5.1m compared with £2.8m for the nine months to June 30 1999. The increase was driven largely by CD sales from the company's Jazz FM Enterprises arm, which accounted for 45% of turnover.

The division sells its own range of Jazz FM-branded CDs, including Listen in Colour - the very best of Jazz FM and the Spirit of the Street range, as well as books, videos and MP3 players.

During the past year Jazz FM Enterprises has also launched a concert business, which it plans to expand next year. It organises concerts for the public and music events for its corporate clients, which include the National Trust and the Institute of Directors.

Combined total listening hours for Jazz FM 102.2 and Jazz FM 100.4 reached 5m hours in the last quarter of 1999, according to Rajar figures.

webTitle: Language resource: Quel avenir pour l'ële de Beaut?

fields.headline: Quel avenir pour l'ële de Beaut?
fields.standfirst: Corsica may be about to win some legislative power from France. What do youngsters think?  Karine Vandenhove finds out
fields.trailText: Corsica may be about to win some legislative power from France. What do youngsters think?  Karine Vandenhove finds out.
fields.body:
La Corse, également appelée, non sans raison, l'Île de Beauté, est certainement l'une des plus belles régions de France. Territoire français depuis plus de 200 ans, elle a été le siège, à maintes reprises, de violents attentats perpétrés par des groupes nationalistes, partisans de l'indépendance. Afin de mettre un terme à cette violence, le gouvernement français, avec à sa tête Lionel Jospin, l'actuel Premier Ministre, propose que l'Assemblée territoriale corse puisse voter, dans certains domaines, des adaptations locales aux lois françaises, susceptibles d'être ratifiées, ou non, par le Parlement, après une période d'expérimentation. La Corse se verrait ainsi concéder un pouvoir législatif encadré et partagé . Cette proposition fait des remous au sein de la classe politique. Certains reprochent au Premier Ministre d'avoir cédé au chantage des nationalistes.

Voici l'opinion de trois jeunes Français.

Vous sentez-vous concernés par les débats qui ont lieu actuellement sur la Corse ?

Sarah, 16 ans, lycéenne: Pas vraiment. C'est une région touristique magnifique, mais c'est tout. On oublie souvent qu'elle est française. Remarque, les Corses nous font bien sentir qu'ils sont là-bas chez eux, qu'ils ont leur culture et leurs traditions et qu'ils n'aiment pas beaucoup la France.

Michel, 24 ans, Corse, employé d'une compagnie aérienne corse, vit en Corse: Bien sûr, en tant qu'insulaire et habitant de Corse.

Renée-Jeanne, 21 ans, Corse, étudiante en histoire à Paris: Évidemment, c'est l'avenir de la Corse, donc mon avenir. Ils ont généré un formidable espoir pour les Corses. Rien ne dit que les discussions vont aboutir, mais c'est un premier pas. C'est la première fois que la France prend le problème corse à bras-le-corps et qu'un dialogue s'établit entre les différents protagonistes.

Que pensez-vous du plan Jospin?

Sarah: C'est quoi exactement le plan Jospin ? Plus d'autonomie pour la Corse? C'est très bien. De toute façon, les Corses ne se sont jamais sentis bien avec la France, alors...

Michel: C'est risqué de réviser la constitution pour accorder à la Corse un pouvoir législatif restreint. Je pense que pour les nationalistes, c'est un simple tremplin pour accéder à l'indépendance.

Renée-Jeanne: Si les élus corses ont plus de pouvoirs et peuvent assumer plus de responsabilités, c'est déjà ça. Tout n'est pas fait, mais ça va dans le bon sens. C'est une démarche courageuse de la part du Premier Ministre. Il serait dommage qu'on mette un frein à ce processus démocratique auquel adhèrent 65 % des Corses. C'est un ouf de soulagement, et une voie de sortie aux problèmes corses, notamment à celui de la violence. S'il est bien utilisé, le processus Matignon peut amener à une meilleure compréhension et à un apaisement.

Certains disent que le gouvernement a cédé au chantage des terroristes et de la violence. Qu'en pensez-vous?

Sarah: Le chantage, ça marche. Jospin a préféré céder pour épargner la vie d'un grand nombre de personnes et assurer la sécurité de la population. Si les nationalistes corses ne font plus d'attentats, ça vaut le coup.

Michel: Ils n'ont pas tout à fait tort. Ça part d'une bonne intention, mais il y a un risque de s'associer aux nationalistes. Ils vont continuer leurs attentats. Ça peut être très néfaste pour la Corse.

Renée-Jeanne: Il faut bien, un jour, accepter de négocier.

Cela constituerait-il un risque pour l'unité de la République française?

Sarah: D'autres régions pourraient demander plus d'autonomie. Si le gouvernement accepte pour la Corse, il sera obligé de le faire pour les autres régions telles que le Pays Basque, la Bretagne ou l'Alsace-Lorraine. Le territoire risque de voler en éclats.

Michel: Pas dans l'immédiat, mais dans 30 ans peut-être. On risque d'être pris dans un engrenage. Ça peut faire boule de neige et pousser d'autres régions à revendiquer leur autonomie voire leur indépendance.

Renée-Jeanne: Non, au contraire. Quand on accorde un peu plus de démocratie, ça ne fait jamais de mal. Cela permettra de prendre des décisions plus cohérentes avec la réalité corse. Il y a trop souvent un décalage entre ce qu'on décide à Paris pour la Corse et ce qui convient vraiment à la Corse. Avec une plus grande démocratie et plus de responsabilités aux élus corses, la Corse s'intégrera mieux à la France. En règle générale, renforcer les identités régionales tend à renforcer l'identité française.

Pour ou contre l'indépendance totale de la Corse?

Sarah: Pour, si la France sucre toutes leurs subventions. Et ça, les Corses risquent de ne pas apprécier.

Michel: Contre l'indépendance, pour une autonomie régionale encadrée. Que l'État conserve ses pouvoirs régaliens.

Renée-Jeanne: Je suis partisane de l'indépendance. Je conteste la république jacobine, car elle est profondément antidémocratique, elle ne laisse pas la liberté aux gens de s'exprimer suffisamment.

Glossaire/Glossary

c'est déjà ça = c'est déjà pas si mal: it's not bad for a start

ça va dans le bon sens: that is going in the right direction

le chantage: blackmail

tre pris dans un engrenage: to get caught up in a spiral

faire boule de neige: (fig.) to snowball

ça peut être néfaste: it can be harmful, inauspicious

pousser un ouf de soulagement: to heave a sigh of relief

un premier pas: a first step

prendre un problème à bras-le-corps: to grapple with a problem

sucrer les subventions: (coll.) to take away grants

un tremplin a springboard

voler en éclats to burst into pieces

webTitle: JWT to buy Tonic 360 San Francisco

fields.headline: JWT to buy Tonic 360 San Francisco
fields.trailText: 10am: J Walter Thompson is to acquire online advertising and branding specialist Tonic 360 San Francisco. By Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
J Walter Thompson is to acquire San Francisco-based online advertising and branding specialist Tonic 360 San Francisco.

The acquisition, expected to be announced today, will expand the interactive marketing capabilities of the WPP Group unit.

The two companies already have close links, and last month formed an alliance to successfully bid for the entire £71m Sun Microsystems account.

JWT will now be in a strong position to extend the services it offers to existing and more traditional clients, such as Unilever, Pfizer and Ford, which are increasing their presence on the internet.

The move comes at a time when the big, traditional Madison Avenue ad agencies are reassessing their future in the digital advertising field as the carnage mounts among dot.coms.

Agencies devoted to online marketing are also suffering as websites report declining ad revenue.

Tonic 360 will operate as a standalone unit of the Thompson North America division, which is separate from Digital@JWT and has offices in several European and North American cities, but not San Francisco.

Tonic 360 has 85 employees and estimates its billings at $150m (£98m), with clients including AvantGo, Go.com, iBeam Broadcasting and TechTV. It opened in December 1999.

fields.headline: Jean Peters
fields.standfirst: Film starlet who famously became involved with Howard Hughes
fields.trailText: The film actress Jean Peters, whose screen career lasted from 1947 to 1955 but who became better known for her relationship with the eccentric billionaire Howard Hughes, has died aged 73
fields.body:
The bruised face of Jean Peters, with a sticking plaster as strategically placed as a beauty patch, was a striking film image of the 1950s; from Sam Fuller's 1953 A-quality B-movie, Pickup on South Street, in which Peters played an innocent (almost) courier for a commie spy, romanced by Richard Widmark's pickpocket. Tough movie, savvy dame.

That part, and her tailored costumes for Rossano Brazzi in Three Coins in the Fountain (1954), were about the best roles that Peters, who has died aged 73, took on in her screen career: one that lasted from 1947 to 1955 and included the westerns Apache (1954) and Broken Lance (1954).

Peters gatecrashed the movie business at 20 after winning a Miss Ohio State University popularity contest. Among its prizes was a 20th Century Fox screen test. Her mother drove her from Canton, Ohio to Los Angeles, where Peters was offered a seven-year contract and the female lead in Captain From Castile (1947), an epic filmed in remotest Mexico. Peters looked terrific, in accord with the period's preference for spirited females. In Anne of the Indies (1951), it was she who did the swashing as a woman pirate, self-possessed far beyond her years.

Peters seemed not to take Hollywood seriously. She avoided lunch in the commissary (she picnicked with hair and makeup assistants on the floor of the set instead) and went along with the studio publicity presentation of herself as a bejeansed farm girl: "Back home I still have three dogs, 18 cats, a goat named Josephine and a lamb called Ali Baba."

This unseriousness might also explain her relationship with the eccentric billionaire, Howard Hughes, who first noticed her at a Santa Catalina Island Fourth of July party in 1946, where her date was the war-hero actor, Audie Murphy. By the next year she had ditched Murphy (so angering him that he tried to bribe Hughes's guards for an opportunity to take a shot at the man), and resided in a Westwood house which Hughes provided.

It was rumoured - falsely - that the couple married under the stars on Mulholland Drive; though they did see each other at least weekly for movies in his screening rooms (he owned RKO studios). While Hughes publicly dated better-known movie glamour, Peters passed on night life and arrived on set on time - "punctual Pete" - for, among other films, Viva Zapata! (1952), again almost combusting as a fake Latina, and Niagara (1953) as a dignified newlywed up against Marilyn Monroe's wiggling.

Accounts vary, but either on a plane from Rome where she filmed Three Coins, or because of an airport luggage switch, in 1953 she met a Texas oil man, Lockheed plane executive and possible CIA employee, Stuart Cramer III. Though Hughes was also seeing Susan Hayward and Merry Anderson, he was displeased when newspaper gossip Louella Parsons phoned to get his reaction to the Peters-Cramer engagement. Their marriage in 1954 lasted 33 days before a separation, possibly expedited by the pryings of a private eye hired by Hughes.

Whether because of these matrimonial worries, or her drinking problem (Hughes ordered the Beverly Hills Hotel to serve her no liquor but a half-bottle of champagne on her birthday), Peters was distracted enough to accidentally burn herself with a branding iron on the set of Broken Lance, and to have a fling with co-star Robert Wagner. She made only one film after that, the sombre biopic A Man Called Peter (1955), then endured studio suspension for refusing films and loan-outs.

Peters finally married Hughes in 1957 in Tonopeh, Nevada, under the name Marian Evans (his alias was GA Johnson), followed much later by a properly monikered ceremony on his yacht off Miami Beach.

Hughes expected his staff to be on 24-hour call, and Peters soon found he demanded the same from his wife: she wasn't even allowed out shopping. Their later cohabitations were tense because of his bizarre hangups (he hated her smoking or using a vacuum cleaner).

Finally they arranged parallel lives. Peters was guarded in a phony French chateau on a Bel Air hilltop, while Hughes remained depressed and dependent on weird aides in his sanitary redoubt above a Las Vegas casino. He proposed reconciliation in 1966, but couldn't cope with even her vestigial normality: Peters sued for divorce. In return for a $70,000-a-year settlement, granted in 1971, she promised not to return to the movies while he lived, or to discuss their private life.

Not long before his death in 1976, Peters received a last letter from Hughes telling her that he had always loved her. By then, she had remarried 20th Century Fox vice-president Stanley Hough.

After Hughes's death, she appeared in a few television productions (notably a public broadcasting version of Winesburg, Ohio) and did an old star's ritual guesting on TV series. She returned to university, too, completing the BA that had been interrupted by 30 years of fame and secrecy. She intended to teach, but never did.

 Jean Peters, movie actress, born October 15 1926; died October 13 2000

fields.headline: Minnelli on the mend
fields.standfirst: Star recovering from viral encephalitis
fields.trailText: Liza Minnelli is suffering from viral encephalitis but is now recovering, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Liza Minnelli is suffering from viral encephalitis but is now recovering, it was revealed yesterday.

Minnelli, 54, was treated for the brain disease two weeks ago and had been released from the Cleveland Clinic in Fort Lauderdale, Florida, Dr Maurice Hanson said, but had to return to the hospital a few days ago.

"She was quite sick and was in very serious condition but is now recovering well and we expect to release her in a few days," Dr Hanson said.

fields.headline: Jazz FM upbeat despite losses
fields.trailText: 10.45am: Jazz FM today announced pre-tax losses of £489,000 in the year to June 30, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Broadcaster Jazz FM today announced pre-tax losses of £489,000 in the year to June 30, but said it has been breaking even for the past six months.

The losses were well down on the previous nine months, when Jazz FM lost £2m.

Jazz FM's chairman, Harry Roche, said: "Following the restructure of the company last year the board's main focus has been on improving the performance of the business. I am pleased to report that this effort has borne fruit."

Turnover rose to £5.1m, compared with £2.8m for the nine months to June 30 1999. The increase was driven largely by CD sales through Jazz FM Enterprises, which accounted for 45% of turnover.

fields.headline: The Edge
fields.standfirst: Tired of meaningless statistics? With The Edge from IQ Sports, you get the numbers that count, so you can see precisely where a match was won and lost
fields.trailText: Monday
fields.body:
Monday

Southampton 0 - 2 Manchester City

Key man

Spencer Prior carried the workload for City's defence with great effectiveness, winning 17 of 22 tackles, completing 24 of 28 passes and making 15 clearances.

Weak Link

Southampton's back three, Dodd, Lundekvam and Tahar, passed 37 times to opposition.

The edge

Southampton enjoyed most of net possession (54%), but City were the more physical side - making 196 challenges to the Saints' 154. Southampton's three substitutes could not manage a shot on target in 110 combined minutes.

Sunday

Aston Villa 0 - 0 Sunderland

Key man
In a dismal passing performance -- a 67% success rate for both sides -- Gareth Barry (25 of 28) and Kevin Phillips (19 of 24) displayed some basic skills.

Weak link
Villa won fewer than half their tackling attempts -- the worst in the Premiership all weekend.

The edge
Villa had most of net possession (56%) and most scoring attempts. Sunderland had one first-half scoring attempt, but came closest to scoring by hitting the frame of the goal in the second. Eleven of Niall Quinn's 18 passes went to the opposition. So did 10 of Dion Dublin's 18.

Saturday

Bradford 0 - 2 Ipswich

Key man
Jamie Clapham completed 18 of 24 passes in the forward zone and opened the scoring.

Weak link
Bradford failed to record a single shot at goal in the final 15 minutes.

The edge
Ipswich were more economical, attempting 92 tackles to Bradford's 128. The Bradford midfield was predictable -- Peter Beagrie completed only 34 of 52 passes.

Charlton 1 - 0 Middlesbrough

Key man
Eight saves and a clean sheet for Dean Kiely in goal for Charlton.

Weak link
Boro desperately missed Alen Boksic's ability in front of goal: their strikers Ricard, Deane and Campbell managed only 2 shots on target and 4 of their team's 14 shots on goal.

The edge
Charlton's efficiency in completing 270 of 332 passes and winning 118 of 126 tackles. Boro led in attempts (14 to 5) and attempts on target (8 to 1) though.

Chelsea 6 - 1 Coventry

Key man
JFH scored, but it was Zola's creativity that really impressed -- he was effective with 10 of 12 crosses, 2 of 3 through balls and 63 of 74 passes.

Weak link
Coventry's midfield quartet of Chippo, Hadji, Palmer and Eustace made only 20 tackles.

The edge
Chelsea completed more than twice as many passes as Coventry (601 to 215) and registered an amazing 29 attempts on goal to Coventry's paltry two.

Liverpool 1 - 0 Leicester

Key man
Markus Babbel completed 51 of 59 passes, including the game-winning cross.

Weak link
Leicester midfielders Lennon, Impey, Savage and Izzet completed only 12 passes in the forward third of the field.

The edge
Leicester had less than 40% of net possession. Sami Hyypia won 12 of 13 tackles and had 9 clearances to stabilize his defence. Emile Heskey's holding up front -- 19 of 27 passes completed in the forward third -- created constant pressure. Tim Flowers conceded his first away goal of the season but prevented a hammering with eight saves.

Manchester United 3 - 0 Leeds

First, a comparison between David Beckham and the entire Leeds team:

Good crosses (Beckham - Leeds) 10 - 6
Good passes in forward third 29 - 55
Attempts 3 - 8
Attempts on target 1 - 1
Minutes 60 - 990

Key man
Beckham aside, Dwight Yorke completed 32 of 36 passes. He chased the Leeds defence with 21 tackling attempts, had 7 scoring attempts with 2 on target and one goal.

Weak link
As in Barcelona, Leeds travelled to glamour opposition and completely surrendered ball possession -- their hosts enjoying more than 65% of net play.

The edge
United accuracy: 14 of 27 attempts were on target, producing three goals and a world-class performance from Paul Robinson, the stand-in Leeds keeper. In the 15 minutes following Beckham's entrance, United had 7 scoring attempts -- 5 from Beckham crosses.

Newcastle 0 - 1 Everton

Key man
David Weir won 28 of 30 tackles, and made 16 clearances and 10 interceptions.

Weak link
With Kieron Dyer subdued in the middle and Nolberto Solano forced to fill in at right-back, only 10 of the home team's 35 crosses were effective.

The edge
For all Newcastle's efficient use of the ball (401 effective passes to 265), Everton managed as many attempts on goal (11) and led 6 to 4 in shots on target. Everton were the keener tacklers as well -- attempting 155 to Newcastle's 103.

Tottenham 3 - 1 Derby

Key man
Stephen Carr continued to fuel Manchester United transfer rumours -- winning all 8 tackles, scoring a goal and completing 28 of 33 passes, including 10 of 13 in forward third.

Weak link
Derby's wing defence allowed 16 of 17 Spurs crosses find their target.

The edge
Derby chased hard for possession -- 199 tackling attempts and almost 55% of possession -- but allowed 24 attempts at goal. There was a professional tackling performance from the Spurs defence, who won 78 of 87. Oyvind Leonhardsen was rewarded for 7 scoring attempts with a goal.

West Ham 1 - 2 Arsenal

Key man
Patrick Vieira won 10 of 12 tackling attempts, and all 8 tackling attempts made against him.

Weak link
West Ham's central defence allowed four successful through balls to set up opportunities for Arsenal.

The edge
The unlucky own goal. The Hammers dominated the second half, leading 13 to 6 in attempts. West Ham's wing defenders did well to allow only one good Arsenal cross, but Arsenal's tackling was almost flawless -- winning 90 of 103 challenges.

webTitle: Linda Grant on how Israel thinks

fields.headline: What lies beneath
fields.standfirst: We see angry Palestinian children being shot by soldiers and are outraged. The Israelis don't see the children - they see millions of Arabs, intent on their destruction.  Linda Grant  visited Israel five times to research her Orange Prize-winning book, When I Lived in Modern Times. Here she reveals what she learned about the inner workings of the Israeli psyche
fields.trailText: We see angry Palestinian children being shot by soldiers and are outraged. The Israelis don't see the children - they see millions of Arabs, intent on their destruction. Linda Grant visited Israel five times to research her Orange Prize-winning book, When I Lived in Modern Times. Here she reveals what she learned about the inner workings of the Israeli psyche...
fields.body:
Over the past month you will probably have been looking at the murder and mayhem in Israel, the West Bank and Gaza and asking yourselves what kind of people can behave like this? The killing of children, deliberately targeted - what kind of a person could commit such an act? What sort of people could, for years on end, deny the basic human rights of an oppressed nation? And the answer might come to you, for want of any other: heartless, monsters, that's who.

I also watch the news, just as desperate and heart-sick, but I do, however, know exactly who is on the other side of those guns, and who is sitting at home in Jerusalem or Tel Aviv watching the events on Israeli television - and why they fail to rise up in rage against their government for perpetrating all this in their name.

I went to Israel five times in less than two years, not as a journalist or a tourist or a human rights worker but as a novelist. I didn't go to Gaza or the West Bank because the object of my research - the Jewish war against the British in Tel Aviv in 1946 - wasn't going to be found in either of those places. I didn't set out to discuss the then peace process, but you can't go to Israel without getting an earful, in cafes, buses, taxis. I listened with the ear of a novelist. The psychology of the Israelis was what I wanted to understand. When you ask, why, in Israel, you are asking for a political explanation but the why goes far deeper - the politics is a symptom. I was left with three strong impressions.

The first, and easiest to explain, is the mentality of the religious right. In the past month I have read time and again the statement, "The Jews stole the Palestinians' country, it's as simple as that." To the Orthodox however, the facts are the exact opposite. They have the deeds to the country. You probably have a copy, as it happens, in your own home. Take it down from the shelf. It's the first part you want, the Old Testament, and the first chapter, Genesis, which contains the world's first recorded real-estate deal: "And I will give to thee and to thy seed after thee, the land wherein you are a stranger, all the land of Canaan for an everlasting possession." And if you want to know where that is, here are the ground plans, the map: "Unto this seed I have given this land, from the river of Egypt, unto the great river, the river Euphrates."

As far as the Orthodox are concerned, they are bunkered down in a tiny portion of what is rightfully theirs. As for how they defend what they have and get their rightful due, the God of the Old Testament who visited 12 plagues on the Egyptians including the slaying of the first-born, is beyond the jurisdiction of Amnesty International. How do you argue with this? You can't. To tell the Orthodox that God's covenant with the Jews, ritually re-enacted at the ceremonies of circumcision and Bar Mitzvah is a fairy story, a myth, is to deprive people who have spent their entire lives locked up in yeshivas, studying the Torah and the Talmud, not just of their beliefs but of their very selves. Without God they are naked and shivering in the world. All you can do is marginalise them out of harm's way, as Barak did when he put together his first coalition.

On the first three of my visits to Israel, which were before the 1999 elections, the Orthodox were what everyone wanted to talk about. The religious right had assumed too much power and were interfering in the everyday lives of secular and moderately religious Israelis, preventing them from shopping or taking public transport on Shabbat. The Orthodox were driving people nuts. They were Netanyahu's coalition allies in blocking the peace process and in opinion poll after opinion poll around 70% of the population repeatedly said that they believed there would be a Palestinian state. They didn't necessarily say they supported it, but they agreed on its inevitability.

The majority of Israelis have arrived at an uneasy acceptance of the proximity of yet another country full of people they regard as their enemies. This has happened partly because they have been worn down by the intifada, partly because of the success of the long campaign by the Israeli Left in convincing them that they can "trust the Arabs" as they put it. And here, I came to think, was the heart of the Israeli mentality. Ordinary Israelis are sick of wars, they are sick of sending their teenage sons to the army, but they are deeply insecure about whether they can risk peace. It isn't the memory of the Holocaust that drives them; it is the memory of over 50 years of Arab nations telling them that they will "drive the Jews into the sea". The Israeli terror is that in delivering the justice to the Palestinians that the world demands, they may be signing their own death warrants. "They call us colonialists," a man said to me, "but if we lose, where do I go? Back to Yemen where my grandfather came from in the 1930s?" Like fairground distorting mirrors, the world looks at the Israelis and sees a giant, a monster, but the Israeli looks and sees a tiny, cowering figure, the puny kid walking to school, tormented by bullies. He needs a Charles Atlas course. He needs to make himself stronger, not weaker.

When the cameras report from Gaza and we see a boy, not unlike a boy we have ourselves at home perhaps, but with a stone in his hands, we are looking at an angry child. That's not what the Israelis see. The boy is a hazy presence, ill-defined. They are peering past him to glimpse the shadowy figures in the windows of the apartment building, the Tanzim, the armed civilian militias and beyond them Hamas, who are the Islamic version of the Orthodox, locked into their rejection of Israel's right to exist. And beyond Hamas is the figure of Sadaam Hussein surrounded by the four million Iraqis who have, in the past few weeks, volunteered to sign up to destroy Israel.

When I listened to Israelis on my visits what struck me was how very little they thought about or even mentioned the Palestinians, and this seems to have been true from the earliest days of Zionism. Asking old people, both left and right, what they thought the resident Arab population would make of the longing for a Jewish homeland, they answered, on the whole, "We didn't think about them at all." They were too intent on their war with the British. In his book The Yellow Wind, the Israeli novelist David Grossman, an opponent of Occupation, describes a journey in the occupied territories in the 1980s in which he talked to Palestinians and settlers. Grossman summed up in the mindset of a settler what I think remains today the Israeli refusal to engage with the Palestinians' anguish: "He does not want to think even for a minute about the situation of the Arabs around him, because he is caught up in a struggle with them, at war, he said, and were he to allow himself to pity, to identify, he would weaken and endanger himself."

The "tough Jew" is not a new phenomenon, it only has a new setting. In another book Tough Jews: Fathers, Sons and Gangster Dreams, the author, Rich Cohen, writes of the world of the American Jewish gangsters in the 1920s and 1930s and what they meant to his father and to his father's best friend, Larry King, growing up as Jewish kids in Brooklyn, listening every day on the radio to bad news from Europe. He asked why his father's generation began to even deny that the gangsters - Arnold Rothstein, Meyer Lansky, Dutch Schultz - had ever existed. The answer, Cohen thought, was that the Jews have always needed iconic tough guys and have always had them, but after 1948 they had the Israeli army, fighters who were legit, who didn't have to break the law. Andrea Dworkin, in her recently published book Scapegoat: The Jews, Israel and Women's Liberation, describes how the ideal of the Jewish man - bookish, gentle, family-loving - was banished in shame after the Holocaust. They turned themselves into cartoon alpha males. A Jewish boy in a soup kitchen in Jaffa, when I asked him what a Jew was, raised a pimple-sized bicep and said: "Strong".

So if the Israelis have turned themselves into tough guys, how do they see the Palestinians? If the Arabs - in particular Hezbollah and Syria - are a military threat then the Palestinians are merely an irritant. The ugly truth, I think, is that what they feel for the Palestinians is contempt, that they are losers, and this instinct is built into the founding ideals of the first Zionists. In a refugee camp, David Grossman asks a woman who has lived for 40 years in the same United Nation refugee house if she would be happy if she was given "a dunam . . . of land in a nice place, with light in the open air. 'Yes, yes - she laughs - of course, but only on my own land'". Then Grossman remembers, "how many times Palestinian leaders missed opportunities to gain themselves a homeland: there was the partition proposal of 1936 and the second proposal of 1947, and maybe there were other chances. They - in their blindness - rejected them all".

Deep in the Jewish psyche is the legacy of cutting your losses, moving on, reinventing yourself in order to survive. Deep in the Arab psyche is the attachment to the land, to patience and endurance. A boy tells Grossman of "his" house in Jaffa. He has never seen it but his grandfather did. What is Jaffa like, Grossman asks? A place of orchards, the boy replies. Actually it is part of the conurbation Tel Aviv-Yaffo, near the business district, circled with motorways. Why, the Israelis ask, perplexed, can't the Palestinians get over the loss of their homeland, why can't they live for the future instead of the past, like the Jews did? If the Jews have been such a roaring success in 20th-century America it has been, in part, because they left Eastern Europe, which had, after all been their home for centuries and never once looked back.

And when they ask themselves this question - why can't the Palestinians be like us? - the only answer they can think of is that the Palestinians are losers. Whatever their strategy it always fails. Invited by the UN in 1947 to form a country, the Jews seized the chance, and declared independence. The Palestinians rejected the opportunity to form theirs and sat back waiting for the Arab armies to defeat the new state. They attacked and lost and the result was that the Palestinians were driven out or fled, washing up in camps where they remain today. When the two sides in the cold war picked their teams, Israel got the US and the Palestinians and the Arabs got the Soviet Union. The latter no longer exists to back them. In the Gulf War the Palestinians supported Sadaam Hussein, currently the world's pariah leader. Some Palestinians have enthusiastically embraced Holocaust denial, their hero the "distinguished historian" David Irving. And all this time the Israelis, backed by the only remaining superpower, forged into the new hi-tech age, positioned themselves for globalisation.

In their own minds the Jews are better than the Arabs, and this goes further back than the consequences of the grim conditions imposed on the Palestinians by the occupation or the restriction on the civil liberties of the Arab Israelis. The earliest Zionists, coming from Russia after the failure of the 1905 revolution, saw themselves as bringing ideas of soviet socialism to the benighted peoples of the Middle East. Later, when the Yekkes, the Jews from Germany reluctantly arrived, torn away kicking and screaming from the cafes of Berlin, they saw themselves as the Weimar Republic in exile, bringing socialism, feminism, psychoanalysis and cubism to a land slumbering in the Middle Ages. It was another form of colonialism, of course, but a cultural one.

How do the mentalities of nations change? Not quickly. Here in Britain we are still dealing with the vestiges of the anger that many feel because we are no longer an empire. It took the Germans until the 1960s, 25 years after total military defeat, before a new generation even began to throw a searchlight on the activities of their own parents. In Austria, it is argued, this process hasn't even begun. What will it take to make the Israelis see the Palestinians as a wronged people in pursuit of justice, the victims of Jewish racism? Not yet another photo of a murdered child, nor even a whole album, but only peace itself will do it, which is why the Israeli left felt so badly let down by the new intifada. Instinctively, they knew that the mass of Israelis can only begin to respect the Palestinians when the threat from them is not to their borders but to their computer industry.

 When I Lived in Modern Times, is published by Granta. It will be serialised on Radio Four's Book at Bedtime from Monday 30 October.

Grossman summed up in the mindset of a settler what I think remains today the Israeli refusal to engage with the Palestinians' anguish: "He does not want to think even for a minute about the situation of the Arabs around him, because he is caught up in a struggle with them, at war, he said, and were he to allow himself to pity, to identify, he would weaken and endanger himself." The "tough Jew" is not a new phenomenon, it only has a new setting. In another book Tough Jews: Fathers, Sons and Gangster Dreams, the author, Rich Cohen, writes of the world of the American Jewish gangsters in the 1920s and 1930s and what they meant to his father and to his father's best friend, Larry King, growing up as Jewish kids in Brooklyn, listening every day on the radio to bad news from Europe. He asked why his father's generation began to even deny that the gangsters - Arnold Rothstein, Meyer Lansky, Dutch Schultz - had ever existed. The answer, Cohen thought, was that the Jews have always needed iconic tough guys and have always had them, but after 1948 they had the Israeli army, fighters who were legit, who didn't have to break the law. Andrea Dworkin, in her recently published book Scapegoat: The Jews, Israel and Women's Liberation, describes how the ideal of the Jewish man - bookish, gentle, family-loving - was banished in shame after the Holocaust. They turned themselves into cartoon alpha males. A Jewish boy in a soup kitchen in Jaffa, when I asked him what a Jew was, raised a pimple-sized bicep and said: "Strong". So if the Israelis have turned themselves into tough guys, how do they see the Palestinians? If the Arabs - in particular Hezbollah and Syria - are a military threat then the Palestinians are merely an irritant. The ugly truth, I think, is that what they feel for the Palestinians is contempt, that they are losers, and this instinct is built into the founding ideals of the first Zionists. In a refugee camp, David Grossman asks a woman who has lived for 40 years in the same United Nation refugee house if she would be happy if she was given "a dunam . . . of land in a nice place, with light in the open air. 'Yes, yes - she laughs - of course, but only on my own land'". Then Grossman remembers, "how many times Palestinian leaders missed opportunities to gain themselves a homeland: there was the partition proposal of 1936 and the second proposal of 1947, and maybe there were other chances. They - in their blindness - rejected them all". Deep in the Jewish psyche is the legacy of cutting your losses, moving on, reinventing yourself in order to survive. Deep in the Arab psyche is the attachment to the land, to patience and endurance. A boy tells Grossman of "his" house in Jaffa. He has never seen it but his grandfather did. What is Jaffa like, Grossman asks? A place of orchards, the boy replies. Actually it is part of the conurbation Tel Aviv-Yaffo, near the business district, circled with motorways. Why, the Israelis ask, perplexed, can't the Palestinians get over the loss of their homeland, why can't they live for the future instead of the past, like the Jews did? If the Jews have been such a roaring success in 20th-century America it has been, in part, because they left Eastern Europe, which had, after all been their home for centuries and never once looked back. And when they ask themselves this question - why can't the Palestinians be like us? - the only answer they can think of is that the Palestinians are losers. Whatever their strategy it always fails. Invited by the UN in 1947 to form a country, the Jews seized the chance, and declared independence. The Palestinians rejected the opportunity to form theirs and sat back waiting for the Arab armies to defeat the new state. They attacked and lost and the result was that the Palestinians were driven out or fled, washing up in camps where they remain today. When the two sides in the cold war picked their teams, Israel got the US and the Palestinians and the Arabs got the Soviet Union. The latter no longer exists to back them. In the Gulf War the Palestinians supported Sadaam Hussein, currently the world's pariah leader. Some Palestinians have enthusiastically embraced Holocaust denial, their hero the "distinguished historian" David Irving. And all this time the Israelis, backed by the only remaining superpower, forged into the new hi-tech age, positioned themselves for globalisation. In their own minds the Jews are better than the Arabs, and this goes further back than the consequences of the grim conditions imposed on the Palestinians by the occupation or the restriction on the civil liberties of the Arab Israelis. The earliest Zionists, coming from Russia after the failure of the 1905 revolution, saw themselves as bringing ideas of soviet socialism to the benighted peoples of the Middle East. Later, when the Yekkes, the Jews from Germany reluctantly arrived, torn away kicking and screaming from the cafes of Berlin, they saw themselves as the Weimar Republic in exile, bringing socialism, feminism, psychoanalysis and cubism to a land slumbering in the Middle Ages. It was another form of colonialism, of course, but a cultural one. How do the mentalities of nations change? Not quickly. Here in Britain we are still dealing with the vestiges of the anger that many feel because we are no longer an empire. It took the Germans until the 1960s, 25 years after total military defeat, before a new generation even began to throw a searchlight on the activities of their own parents. In Austria, it is argued, this process hasn't even begun. What will it take to make the Israelis see the Palestinians as a wronged people in pursuit of justice, the victims of Jewish racism? Not yet another photo of a murdered child, nor even a whole album, but only peace itself will do it, which is why the Israeli left felt so badly let down by the new intifada. Instinctively, they knew that the mass of Israelis can only begin to respect the Palestinians when the threat from them is not to their borders but to their computer industry.  When I Lived in Modern Times, is published by Granta. It will be serialised on Radio Four's Book at Bedtime from Monday 30 October.

fields.headline: BBC1 takes first blood in peak time war
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BBC
fields.trailText:
9am: The new-look BBC1 peak time schedule has been an initial ratings success, despite signs that the revamped line-up is running out of steam. By Jason Deans.
Special report: the BBC
fields.body:
The new-look BBC1 peak time schedule has been an initial ratings success, despite signs that the revamped 10pm news line-up is running out of steam.

Figures just out for the first week of the schedule show the BBC's ratings were up almost 4 percentage points during peak time and at one stage audience share soared to 37 per cent, a height rarely seen.

BBC1 raised its peak time game across the seven days to Sunday October 22, averaging a 30.3% audience from 6pm-10.30pm, compared with 26.6% the week before, according to unofficial overnights.

The BBC1 Ten O'Clock News averaged 5.2m viewers and a 25.4% share across its first week, just a shade above the 5m the old Nine O'Clock News averaged last week and the 5.1m - and 22% share - the bulletin had averaged this year.

The channel made significant gains on the first three nights last week, with the most spectacular improvement on Tuesday, when the terrestrial premiere of movie Men in Black helped BBC1 to increase its peak time share by 11 percentage points compared with the previous week, to 37.2%.

But BBC1 will not be able to repeat -his scheduling stunt. Pete Postlethwaite drama The Sins tonight opens a seven week, Tuesday night run that looks like being a critical success but is unlikely to garner Men in Black-style ratings.

BBC1's performance was less spectacular in final four days of last week. Small advances were made on Thursday and Saturday, but on Friday and Sunday the channel's peak time share was lower than the previous week.

Moreover, the channel only beat ITV in peak time on two nights - Tuesday and Saturday (which is a night the BBC1 regularly wins). And ITV, which for the purposes of its ratings targets counts peak time as 7pm-10.30pm, was still claiming a peak time victory for Saturday night.

Still, ITV was hurt by BBC1's ratings offensive, losing peak time share every night bar Saturday. Overall, ITV was down by 3.4 percentage points on the previous week, to 35.4%.

Of the other broadcasters, BBC2 appeared to be worst hit, dropping from 10% to 8.9% in peak time.

Channel 4 improved its audience share week on week, claiming 7.6% after enduring a post-Big Brother peak time slump in the past month.

Channel 5 was virtually unchanged at 5.3%, largely thanks to a Sunday peak time boosted by the film Mrs Doubtfire, which averaged 3.8m and a 21% share.

webTitle: Nurseries close as council faces £40m cash gap

fields.headline: Nurseries close as council faces £40m cash gap
fields.standfirst:
Furious parents threaten to sleep at pre-school centres as desperate local authority tries to cut costs
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: At two nursery schools in Stoke Newington, north London, the finger paintings that used to adorn the wall have been replaced. In their stead hang the sort of posters more usually associated with industrial action than early learning. "Stop the council wrecking our lives ... stop the cuts," they say.
fields.body:
At two nursery schools in Stoke Newington, north London, the finger paintings that used to adorn the wall have been replaced. In their stead hang the sort of posters more usually associated with industrial action than early learning. "Stop the council wrecking our lives ... stop the cuts," they say.

This outbreak of militancy among the parents of the under-fives who attend the Fernbank and Atherden Road nurseries was sparked last Friday evening when parents collecting their children were told that as of yesterday they would have to attend other nurseries within the borough; the two centres would be closed until further notice.

Outraged, the parents announced they would occupy the centres, sleeping over if necessary, so that their children could continue to be cared for in familiar surroundings. Yesterday, despite the provision of places for the children elsewhere, the occupation continued.

The underlying cause of the closures is the financial bog in which the local authority, Hackney council, has become mired. Last week the borough treasurer ordered that spending be frozen and told the council to produce a cuts package within 21 days amid fears of an overspend approaching £40m. The closure of Fernbank was an early indication that the emergency measures were beginning to bite.

In a special report to the council, which is run by a Labour-Conservative coalition, treasurer George Jenkins forecast that the overspend would fall between £14.5m and £22m with the worst case scenario seeing the council £40m in the red. No new staff can be taken on and no spending commitments made until a cuts package has been accepted. Before the special measures were introduced the council was already committed to trimming £22m from council spending for the 2000-2001 financial year.

The malaise in Hackney, where gentrification has set some of the capital's most desirable real estate alongside desperately needy estates, is deep rooted. Years of council infighting impeded decision making and a series of high profile projects have ended in overspend and confusion.

A leisure centre in Stoke Newington has run £10m over budget and is still not open, and the council is embroiled in a legal battle after a disastrous attempt to privatise its revenue, benefits, council tax and business rates collection and payment system.

In 1997 the council signed a 10-year £70m contract with ITNet which resulted in 20,000 people incurring rent arrears and hundreds facing eviction. The council is currently aiming to bring the service back in-house once a contract termination package has been settled.

Former managing director Tony Elliston, architect of the ill-fated and expensive "Transforming Hackney" project is also the subject of local opprobrium, being blamed for removing a system of accountability that might have prevented the current crisis. In March last year he stood down saying he wanted to get "a balance" back into his life as the council was "on the road to continued improvements".

Teaching and public sector unions in the borough are now fearful that the latest package of cuts will lead to widespread job losses and cuts in essential services. Local teachers fear that the education budget, which accounts for 40% of council spending, will inevitably be cut with such a large deficit to clear, and have written to the education secretary, David Blunkett, appealing for central government assistance. On Friday, 45 head teachers and deputy heads backed a motion of no confidence in the council.

Meanwhile, the public sector union Unison is predicting up to 10,000 redundancies as a result of cuts, a figure dismissed by Max Caller, Hackney's managing director, as "completely invented". He does accept however that there will be some redundancies. "I think it is inevitable there will be a reduction in the number of staff.

"Hackney's budgets and financial systems have, for far too long, not been up to scratch, disguising the true problems we are now facing and senior managers have failed to deal with the growing budget problems," said Mr Caller, who joined from Barnet council in June, and does not see a swift resolution to Hackney's problems.

"It took some time to get into this mess and it will take some time to get out. I suspect it will not be in this financial year. I don't blame councillors for this: they tried to balance the budget, but they couldn't do it on their own.

"We have got to reduce the cost base of this council. We have been talking to central government about the situation but they would like to see this council better managed first," he said.

The council was the only authority from a list of 524 town halls to have its performance plan rejected by the auditor, and earlier this year a review by the Improvement and Development Agency (Idea), a self-policing organisation run by councils, blamed local politicians for incompetence and said a mediator should be appointed to end in-fighting.

Meanwhile parents at Fernbank, which was visited yesterday by local MP Diane Abbott, are left wondering when their children can return to normal: "We think this nursery is crucial to our children for their social and educational development. It is a crucial resource that should not be bulldozed or privatised just because the council can't balance a budget," said one.

webTitle: Dickov keeps City on the move

fields.headline: Dickov keeps City on the move
fields.trailText: Asked to name a football superstar, more people might plump for George Weah than Paul Dickov. But whereas the Liberian has departed Maine Road in a huff, Dickov underlined his enduring value to Manchester City last night by scoring the 50th goal of his club career to lift his side by four places to 10th.
fields.body:
Asked to name a football superstar, more people might plump for George Weah than Paul Dickov. But whereas the Liberian has departed Maine Road in a huff, Dickov underlined his enduring value to Manchester City last night by scoring the 50th goal of his club career to lift his side by four places to 10th.

Dickov ended the night with an 89th minute yellow card for tripping Marian Pahars but it all ended sweetly for City when Danny Tiatto finished off a fine overlapping move with a rasping cross-shot.

With City resolute at the back and lively on the break, they deserved to beat a laboured Southampton who created little and remain fourth from bottom. The Dell, so often their safe haven and rescue in the past, has provided them with only one win.

The Saints manager Glenn Hoddle had complained beforehand that his players were not ruthless enough and must have seen this as a chance to put that right. City arrived having conceded 10 goals in five away matches, including two at First Division Gillingham in the Worthington Cup.

In an attempt to clamp down on such generosity and inflict damage on the counter-attack, Hoddle's opposite number Joe Royle deployed Gerard Wiekens just in front of his back line and gave a debut at right-back to Richard Dunne, a £3 million signing from Everton who was given the No22 shirt vacated by George Weah.

The change of personnel in that jersey was an apt reflection on the match's early exchanges. Physical and committed as expected, City lacked that touch of the unexpected, while Southampton were uninspired in the face of some impressive defending.

What invention there was from Southampton usually came from Pahars, who drew an early save from Nicky Weaver and provided two impressive crosses from the right. Spencer Prior did well to head out the first as Hassan Kachloul closed in and the lanky Moroccan headed the second wide.

Dickov had a shot blocked by Lundekvam and Jason Dodd lunged to keep out a Tiatto effort before City took the lead shortly before half-time. The impressive Jeff Whitley slipped a neat pass to Dickov and the striker, who has enjoyed a fine month in keeping Weah out of the side and winning his first Scotland cap, hit a sharp shot across Paul Jones for his second goal in as many matches.

Le Tissier departed at half-time with what appeared to be a knee injury from a tackle with Dunne. In his place came Kevin Davies but even with that belated focal point, Southampton still struggled for fluency.

Southampton (4-4-2): Jones; Dodd, Lundekvam, El Khalej, Bridge; Ripley (Beattie, 72min), Oakley (Marsden, h-t), Soltvedt, Kachloul; Le Tissier (Davies, h-t), Pahars.

Manchester City (4-1-3-2): Weaver; Dunne, Prior, Howey, Ritchie; Wiekens; Jeff Whitley, Haaland, Tiatto; Dickov, Wanchope (Goater, 68).

Referee: A Wiley (Burntwood).

webTitle: Britvic trawls for Orchid ad agency

fields.headline: Britvic seeks Orchid ad agency
fields.trailText: 8.45am: Britvic is understood to be seeking an ad agency to boost its Orchid drinks brands, reports Jade Garrett.
fields.body:
Britvic is understood to be seeking an advertising agency to boost its recently acquired portfolio of Orchid drinks brands, including Purdy's, Aqualibra and Ame.

One agency source confirmed it was approached by the drinks giant but declined to comment further.

To date, the brands have not been supported by a significant media spend.

The pitch could see another ad agency added to the Britvic roster, which already includes Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO, which handles the Pepsi business, and HHCL & Partners, which handles Tango.

Orchid Drinks was acquired by Britvic Soft Drinks in July. The move brought together the Orchid range of adult lifestyle brands with Britvic's well-established brand portfolio, which includes Pepsi, Tango, 7-Up and Robinson's.

Britvic's expertise across the soft drinks market will allow Orchid to target its brands at a wider consumer base. The distribution of its brands in the UK has until now been restricted primarily to multiple retailers.

A senior Britvic spokesperson declined to comment on the review.

webTitle: Shock of the old as paint returns to the Turner Prize

fields.headline: Shock of the old as paint returns to the Turner Prize
fields.standfirst: Alternative show denounces what organisers call an ongoing national joke - but 'pukka' landscapist emerges as favourite for top art award
fields.trailText: After all the years of videos, rumpled beds and elephant dung, a truly shocking contemporary artist emerged last night as the bookie's favourite to win the £20,000 Turner Prize - Michael Raedecker, who creates delicately beautiful, eerie landscapes in the traditional materials of paint and embroidery on canvas.
fields.byline: Maeve Kennedy, Arts and Heritage Correspondent
fields.body:
After all the years of videos, rumpled beds and elephant dung, a truly shocking contemporary artist emerged last night as the bookie's favourite to win the £20,000 Turner Prize - Michael Raedecker, who creates delicately beautiful, eerie landscapes in the traditional materials of paint and embroidery on canvas.

The Turner Prize Exhibition, which opens today at Tate Britain for press and private views, will reveal that painting, abandoned by many contemporary artists and written off by critics as a dead medium, is back: the walls of two of the four rooms will be hung with large paintings on canvas.

The organisers of a rival exhibition, The Real Turner Prize Show, which opened in London yesterday, denounced the prize, one of the most prestigious in the world, as "an ongoing national joke". They plan to picket the prize dinner dressed as clowns, and yesterday launched a CD of their Turner prize song: Art or Arse? You be the Judge.

The insistence that the arts establishment has betrayed painting is the core creed of their movement, Stuckism.

At the Tate, however, Simon Wilson, curator of interpretation, said the Stuckists had picked an unfortunate year to mount their protest.

"The most striking thing about the Turner list this year is that we have two absolutely pukka painters" he said, describing Raedecker's work as "magical" and the other painter in the show, Glenn Brown, as "utterly contemporary in subject, but old masterly in technique".

"Painting is back, big time," Patrick Painter, Los Angeles agent for Glenn Brown, said. "You've got great painters in Britain.The buyers are mad for them in Los Angeles. It's old-school painting, baby, hell yes."

The other artists are opening favourite Thomas Tillman, who began in fashion photography, and Tomoko Takahashi, whose work really is rubbish, assemblages of waste and discarded objects described by Mr Wilson as "enchanting".

The Stuckists believe in getting their retaliation in first, and their bribes upfront: the invitations for their exhibition opening gave the lunch menu, running from champagne to bitter chocolate tarts, more prominence than the artists.

The Stuckists owe their existence to an insult hurled at Billy Childish by his former girlfriend Tracey Emin - whose stained and crumpled bed was on last year's Turner short list. "Your art is stuck, stuck, stuck!" she cried, and they wear the badge with pride.

Their serious point is that the traditional skills of painting and sculpture have been rubbished by what they call "the Serota brigade" after Sir Nicholas Serota, director of the Tate.

The Stuckists sent him their two-page manifesto, and a two-page letter headed "Shock of the new or yawn at the obvious".

Sir Nicholas sent a three-line reply: "Thank you for your open letter dated 6 March. You will not be surprised that I have no comments to make on your letter, or your manifesto "Remodernism".

"We are not the joke," Mr Childish said yesterday. "The Turner prize is the joke, a pathetic, boring, humourless joke that just feeds pretentiousness and alienates real lovers of art."
fields.bodyText: After all the years of videos, rumpled beds and elephant dung, a truly shocking contemporary artist emerged last night as the bookie's favourite to win the £20,000 Turner Prize - Michael Raedecker, who creates delicately beautiful, eerie landscapes in the traditional materials of paint and embroidery on canvas. The Turner Prize Exhibition, which opens today at Tate Britain for press and private views, will reveal that painting, abandoned by many contemporary artists and written off by critics as a dead medium, is back: the walls of two of the four rooms will be hung with large paintings on canvas. The organisers of a rival exhibition, The Real Turner Prize Show, which opened in London yesterday, denounced the prize, one of the most prestigious in the world, as "an ongoing national joke". They plan to picket the prize dinner dressed as clowns, and yesterday launched a CD of their Turner prize song: Art or Arse? You be the Judge. The insistence that the arts establishment has betrayed painting is the core creed of their movement, Stuckism. At the Tate, however, Simon Wilson, curator of interpretation, said the Stuckists had picked an unfortunate year to mount their protest. "The most striking thing about the Turner list this year is that we have two absolutely pukka painters" he said, describing Raedecker's work as "magical" and the other painter in the show, Glenn Brown, as "utterly contemporary in subject, but old masterly in technique". "Painting is back, big time," Patrick Painter, Los Angeles agent for Glenn Brown, said. "You've got great painters in Britain.The buyers are mad for them in Los Angeles. It's old-school painting, baby, hell yes." The other artists are opening favourite Thomas Tillman, who began in fashion photography, and Tomoko Takahashi, whose work really is rubbish, assemblages of waste and discarded objects described by Mr Wilson as "enchanting". The Stuckists believe in getting their retaliation in first, and their bribes upfront: the invitations for their exhibition opening gave the lunch menu, running from champagne to bitter chocolate tarts, more prominence than the artists. fields.headline: Cyber-rabbi to go global
fields.trailText: 8am: A teenage entrepreneur has made £300,000 by selling his website to a company planning to build a global multi-media firm focused on the Jewish community. By John Cassy.
fields.body:
A teenage entrepreneur has made £300,000 by selling a website he set up in his bedroom 18 months ago to a company planning to build a global multi-media firm focused on the Jewish community.

Benjamin Cohen, 18, from Elstree in north London, has sold his sojewish.net website to AIM-listed Totally in return for shares. The site, which was set up in 1997, originally featured a cyber-rabbi, agony aunt and business listings. It now includes synagogue listings and kosher recipes.

Totally has also bought London Jewish News, a free newspaper with a shareholding in sojewish, for around £3m, including £1.5m debt.

London Jewish News has a circulation of 40,000. Revenues in the year to December 1999 were £720,000. It is forecast to break even next year.

The present owner is Michael Sinclair, a prominent businessman in the Jewish community who will become non-executive chairman of the enlarged group.

Totally chief executive Steve Burns said the company planned to break into the US market by buying a Jewish television station or newspaper. An approach for the Jerusalem Post, owned by Conrad Black's Hollinger Group and valued at around £100m, has been rejected. Observers believe virtualjerusalem.com or one of the Jewish TV channels in the US could be a target.

"We want to build a Jewish-focused group that can achieve critical mass, harness serious sales and marketing skills and become a sizeable and profitable concern," Mr Burns said.

Totally was set up to create specialist websites for defined communities.

Its existing Jewish assets include Totallyjewish.com.

Mr Burns hopes to emulate ZeeTV, which has focused on the British Asian community after buying a series of television, print and film assets. He believes that in time his media group will expand into Jewish-focused restaurants, clubs and travel services.

fields.headline: Ex-shop steward Martin is Speaker
fields.standfirst: Special report: Electing a new Speaker
fields.trailText: Labour MPs last night defied pressure from senior ministers when they voted to elect Michael Martin, a former shop steward from Labour's industrial heartlands, to become 152nd Speaker of the House of Commons - instead of the Old Etonian Tory ex-cabinet minister, Sir George Young.
fields.body:
Labour MPs last night defied pressure from senior ministers when they voted to elect Michael Martin, a former shop steward from Labour's industrial heartlands, to become 152nd Speaker of the House of Commons - instead of the Old Etonian Tory ex-cabinet minister, Sir George Young.

After the father of the Commons, 84-year-old Sir Edward Heath, had rejected pleas for a straightforward ballot to choose from the 12 contenders, it took more than six hours of cumbersome voting to complete the election as even no-hopers took their turn - to the dismay of Westminster modernisers.

By the time it was over the once crowded chamber was almost deserted. Mr Martin was never fewer than 76 votes ahead of his 11 rivals and in no serious danger of defeat.

With the help of the ministerial "payroll vote" Sir George got closest, losing by 317 to 241. Labour's strongest challenger, the sacked cabinet minister David Clark, managed only 192 votes to the winner's 257. Menzies Campbell in the Lib Dem corner lost 403-89.

With Tony Blair not voting in person, but privately keen not to be seen to insist on a Labour Speaker, at least 25 ministers, including David Blunkett, Margaret Beckett, Jack Straw and Peter Mandelson, backed Sir George. But the move backfired as angry backbenchers protested at the tactic when the parliamentary Labour party met on the Commons' first day back since July 27. What they saw as inadvertent control freakery may cost another of yesterday's Young-backers, Clive Soley, his job as PLP chairman next month.

In picking the 55-year-old MP for Glasgow Springburn as successor to Betty Boothroyd, Labour backbenchers sent a complex series of messages to the government and the wider, watching electorate months before the general election.

He is the first Speaker to be an authentic representative of the industrial working class, the child of an impoverished broken home who met his wife in a factory. "My origin should be no reason for me being elected, nor should my origin be a reason to debar me," Mr Martin told MPs yesterday.

Mr Martin will be the first Roman Catholic Speaker since Henry VIII's Protestant Reformation, a symbol of old barriers falling as British political culture evolves. As an anti-devolution Scot he may also prove a symbol of the enduring union between England and Scotland.

After the traditional dragging of the new Speaker to the chair - a relic of times when it was a high-risk office - Mr Martin last night promised to uphold the rights and duties of the Commons, not least in resisting a government whose huge majority allows it to bypass the House. "Michael will be tough," one close ally predicted.

Yesterday's contest was conducted in fierce but fair-minded terms after Sir Edward had resisted calls from senior MPs on both sides, led by Tony Benn, to use his brief afternoon of power to tear up rules not devised for a multi-candidate contest. He expressed "considerable sympathy" and offered his own version of a compromise.

That was to set out the order in which he intended to call the 12 contenders, who would be voted on two at a time. Unexpectedly he started with the bookies' favourite, Mr Martin. Equally unexpectedly he let the contest run to the bitter end.

By general consent Gwyneth Dunwoody made the most impassioned speech and Sir George the most elegant. But Mr Martin did what ex-shop stewards do: won the vote by planning and hard graft.

Each rival's name was added as an amendment to the motion:

Sir Alan Haselhurst (Con) lost by 140 to 345

Alan Beith (Lib Dem) 83 to 409

Gwyneth Dunwoody (Lab) 170 to 341

Sir George Young (Con) 241 to 317

Menzies Campbell (Lib Dem) 98 to 381

David Clark (Lab) 192 to 257

Nicholas Winterton (Con) 116 to 340

John McWilliam (Lab) 30 to 309

Michael Lord (Con) 146 to 290

Sir Patrick Cormack (Con) 130 to 287

Richard Shepherd (Con) 136 to 282

fields.headline: Fresh start for rail
fields.standfirst:
But the taxpayer should get a stake as well

Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railway travellers will breathe a sigh of relief at yesterday's decision by the regulator to allocate £855m of the kitty Gordon Brown set aside in July to make the railways safer. But the problem does not end there.
fields.body:
Railway travellers will breathe a sigh of relief at yesterday's decision by the regulator to allocate £855m of the kitty Gordon Brown set aside in July to make the railways safer. But the problem does not end there. It ought to mark merely the beginning of a reappraisal of Britain's railway system following privatisation.

There clearly needs to be a much closer relationship between the large number of train operating companies (suitably slimmed down) and Railtrack and, even more vitally, between Railtrack and its sub-contractors so there is absolutely no doubt who is responsible for what repairs and when. Some of the new money must be used to set up a computer data base of all Railtrack's activities. It almost beggars belief that this did not happen years ago. It is also important that the upgrading of the track is not used by the train operators as a convenient excuse to abandon their duty to keep the trains running on time.

Nor must the urgent need to make rail travel safer obscure the issues of public accountability. Clearly, if the railways are to invest more, then they must make decent profits otherwise they will not be able to. But the idea of shareholders' profiting from public money injected to make railways safer will make taxpayers cringe. Yesterday, the shares of Railtrack rose 5.6% on news of the fresh public money.

Total public spending by the taxpayer on the railways is planned to rise from £1.6bn this year to £4bn by 2006. By then over £18bn of public money will have been invested in the railways. Not all of this goes to Railtrack- but the sum is so large in relation to Railtrack's stock market capitalisation (£5.4bn before yesterday's rise) that the question of value for money inevitably arises.

There is no political appetite for renationalisation. The government wants the railways off its hands in the long term so that its borrowings do not inflate the borrowing requirement. But that does not alter the case - on prudential investment grounds - for the government to take an equity stake in the industry in return for the vast sums invested. Privatisation was done at a break-neck speed for political reasons - to ensure that it was signed and sealed before the last election. As a result, it was sold far too cheaply. And privatisation has turned out to be a ticket for the government to spend yet more money. The benefits from that investment - potentially huge - ought to be shared with the taxpayer.

webTitle: BSkyB faces ban over PPV soccer rights

fields.headline: BSkyB faces legal block over PPV soccer rights
fields.trailText: 8.15am: BSkyB could be banned from bidding for the pay-per-view football amid fears that the Premier League could face legal action over the collapse of last week's NTL deal. By Jessica Hodgson..
fields.body:
BSkyB could be banned from bidding for pay-per-view football rights amid fears that the Premier League could face legal action over the collapse of last week's deal with NTL.

Lawyers at the Premier League are already poring over documents relating to the original auction and executives admit that they could face legal action if Sky is allowed re-enter the bidding.

A spokesman confirmed that the Premier League was looking at possible legal complications resulting from a broadcaster owning more than one football rights package.

He said: "Our legal team is looking at two issues. Whether or not Sky would be able - legally - to bid for the package, and if they were able to, would we want them to. Our legal team is looking at every eventuality."

The bidding process was set up to prevent a single broadcaster gaining too much control over rights, and no broadcaster was allowed to win more than one rights package.

An insider close to the talks said that the Premier League faced "a fundamental pay-per-view reappraisal" after the collapse of the £328m NTL deal. "It was a very carefully balanced deal and if you suddenly remove one leg of the tripod the whole thing falls over," said the source.

The Premier League says it has been inundated by bids after the collapse of the deal. "We've got a huge number of broadcasters interested," said a spokesman. "We're looking at bids from people who didn't bid last time round and we're considering a whole range of options, from a single bid to a collection of bids from different broadcasters to our own pay-per view service".

But a source at BSkyB, while conceding that multi-channel broadcasters would all be looking to buy the rights, said that the price of the contract would have to fall "dramatically".

One well-placed source said the Premier League originally valued the PPV package as low as £100m.

ONdigital, BSkyB and Telewest are all in the frame for the pay-per-view rights.

Channel 5 has ruled itself out of the bidding and senior sources at the BBC say that, contrary to reports, the corporation was not looking to make an offer.

BBC Sports, however, is desperate to strike up a production deal with the potential rights holder. It had been lined up to produce all of NTL's coverage in a lucrative deal worth up to £20m a year.

A BBC Sport spokesman said "We'd certainly be interested in a similar contract." But he added: "We've got lots of football coming up next year, and it's not an essential." Other BBC sources say the loss of the production and resources contract was a source of concern to managers.

fields.headline: Connex loses train service franchise
fields.trailText: French-owned Connex today became the first train company since privatisation to lose its franchise.
fields.body:
French-owned Connex today became the first train company since privatisation to lose its franchise.

The much-criticised firm will have to give up its south central service within the next year. The new operator will be the consortium Govia, whose main partner, Go-Ahead, operates Thames Trains, which was involved in last year's Paddington rail crash in which 31 passengers died.

Govia, which is part owned by French firm Via-GTI, also runs the Thameslink services throughout southern England and London.

The company is promising £1.5bn investment in services throughout London and the south east which are currently run by Connex South Central, including more trains, refurbished stations and improved performance.

The south central franchise covers Surrey and Sussex, and services are due to continue to be run by Connex for at least the next year.

Connex will retain its neighbouring south east franchise, which is not yet due for renewal.

Travellers have criticised Connex, which is owned by French conglomerate Vivendi, for late running and overcrowded trains. The company has also suffered industrial relations problems in recent years.

Govia will rename the franchise New Southern Railways, a name which was last used more than a decade ago.

An upgrade of the busy London-Brighton line will be one of the top priorities, as well as new services throughout south London.

As part of the deal, announced today by the shadow strategic rail authority, all the present "slam door" trains will be replaced within the next few years.

Govia has also pledged that all new trains in service after 2003 will be fitted with the Train Protection warning system.

It has also given an undertaking that by the year 2005, nine out of 10 trains would arrive within five minutes of the scheduled time, rising by 2010 to 15 out of 16 trains. Additional trains would be brought into service and £1.2m a year will be spent on staff training and development. The company also announced a huge investment programme to upgrade and improve depots and stations.

Govia managing director Keith Ludeman said he was "absolutely delighted" that the company had been awarded the franchise. Negotiations would now be held with Connex for the transfer of its south central services, which was likely to happen in around a year's time.

Mr Ludeman promised staff a "new vision" and said he believed that there were a number of staff shortages which would have to be addressed as soon as possible. "We will be aiming to run more trains, more reliably and quickly," he said.

New trains would be brought into service and infrastructure will be improved and developed to cope with the extra services being planned. "There will not be many parts of the south central franchise which will not see the benefit of our planned investment," he said.

Priorities would include improving the Brighton to London service and upgrading scores of stations to provide extra parking, bus/rail connections and better ticketing arrangements. He also hinted that peak fares on some routes could actually fall.

Mr Ludeman said he was keen to hold early talks with unions but said he "could not imagine" that any staff would lose their jobs. "Our belief is that Connex has a number of staff shortages," he added.

fields.headline: Peter Rabbit launches multi-lingual website
fields.trailText: 8am: Beatrix Potter's books are to be marketed to international audiences with the launch of a multi-lingual website for Peter Rabbit. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Beatrix Potter's books are to be marketed to international audiences following the launch today of a multi-lingual website for Peter Rabbit.

Until yesterday the much-loved character had only been available online in English. Now French and German speakers can visit the website, PeterRabbit.com, and follow the tales of the mischievous rabbit. A Japanese-language site is planned for later in the year.

The site was designed by Kabel New Media in conjunction with Frederick Warne, a division of Penguin Books that publishes Beatrix Potter's books.

Max Crisfield, spokesman for Frederick Warne, said: "We want to offer a wealth of information for children, parents, grandparents, teachers, enthusiasts and anyone interested in the life and works of Beatrix Potter."

As well as an online biography of Beatrix Potter's life and art, a gift shop and some talking storybooks, the site features games, competitions, postcards and videoclips.
