webTitle: Cold Feet is ITV's big earner

fields.headline: Cold Feet is ITV's big earner
fields.trailText: Cold Feet, the quirky television drama that set the mould for "thirtysomething" television, has been sold to the United States in a $1m deal that has unexpectedly made it one of ITV's most lucrative assets.
fields.body:
Cold Feet, the quirky television drama that set the mould for "thirtysomething" television, has been sold to the United States in a $1m deal that has unexpectedly made it one of ITV's most lucrative assets.

The series, nicknamed "Gold Feet" by the TV press after reports of the high salaries of its stars, is now second only to Coronation Street in the amount of income generated by overseas drama sales for its producer, Granada.

In fact, the stars are on contracts that are more modest than tabloid speculation would suggest. But the latest deal, thought to be worth at least $1m (£700,000), means the cast led by Helen Baxendale, James Nesbitt and Fay Ripley is now one of the most successful groups of young actors on British television.

Cold Feet is shown in more than 20 countries, yet as its success abroad increases, its future in Britain is in question. The Guardian has learned that its creator and executive producer, Christine Langan, is leaving Granada to go freelance. Also, the actors now enjoy successful careers outside the show and their fees are rising.

Ms Langan said yesterday it was "50-50" whether the show, which began in 1997 and follows the lives of three couples, would continue beyond a fourth series. The third starts on ITV next month. "If it were kept fresh and distinctive, I don't see why it couldn't run and run. But if it gets to the point where the financial demands of the cast limited the technical side of things, then I don't think there would be much point in doing it."

She attributed the appeal of the programme, which went from a tentative pilot episode to winning the Golden Rose at the Montreux television festival, to the accuracy of its portrayal of modern life. Granada had previously sold the format to the US - but the American remake was a flop.

This time, the 21 British-made episodes will be screened on one of the biggest cable broadcasters in the US, Bravo. It will be shown in a prime-time slot from January.

webTitle: Actors end strike but sequel is in the making

fields.headline: Actors end strike but sequel is in the making
fields.trailText: The longest and most acrimonious strike in entertainment business history ended yesterday. Actors in the United States, who had been refusing to take part in commercials for nearly six months, have agreed terms with advertisers that could mean a return to work within the next few days.
fields.body:
The longest and most acrimonious strike in entertainment business history ended yesterday. Actors in the United States, who had been refusing to take part in commercials for nearly six months, have agreed terms with advertisers that could mean a return to work within the next few days.

The strike has been costing actors an estimated $1m a day in lost wages. It led to a flight of production to Canada, Australia and Europe and is seen as a dress rehearsal for what is likely to be an even more bitter dispute involving both actors and writers next year which could shut down the whole film and television industry in the US.

The dispute was over how actors should be paid for their work in the growing cable and internet industry. Advertisers had wanted to pay actors a flat fee for all work while actors held out for "residuals", repeat payments made every time a commercial is shown.

Following negotiations which started last week in New York, a tentative agreement has been reached which will give actors an agreed separate fee for cable television commercials. Advertisers have also accepted that they will only use union actors for commercials on the internet. The new contract, if it is ratified by the membership this week, will last for three years.

Union negotiators estimate that actors' fees will be increased by around 10% as a result of the deal. Under the new agreement, a flat fee of $2,460 will be paid to actors who appear in commercials that are used on cable television in addition to network television.

The Screen Actors' Guild (Sag) and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (Aftra) called the strike on May 1 after failing to reach an agreement with advertisers represented by the American Association of Advertising Agencies and the Association of National Advertisers.

As the strike dragged on, the actors organised boycotts of advertisers who made commercials using non-union films. The latest boycott, aimed at Proctor and Gamble, asked people not to buy Crest, Tide and Ivory soap and led to the involvement in the negotiations of P&G management.

There had been growing tension within the unions over the last few weeks with the LA strikers seen as more militant and the New York end more anxious to seek a compromise.

The strike hit the headlines when well-known actors became involved, either wittingly or unwittingly. Last week, Liz Hurley apologised for making an Estee Lauder commercial during the strike and made a $25,000 donation to the hardship fund. She said she had been unaware that the commercial was in breach of the strike but actors picketed the premiere of her film Bedazzled in Los Angeles last week.

Paul Newman, Julia Roberts and Tom Hanks all offered public support to the strikers at rallies and Nicolas Cage, Kevin Spacey, Helen Hunt and John Travolta made large donations.

What could be a much more divisive strike, involving both actors and writers, is predicted for next year. Both Sag and the Writers' Guild of America are due to renegotiate their contracts next summer and are likely to reach the same sticking-point over cable and the internet. As a result, many studios are hurrying through production in an effort to complete projects before the strike begins. The Writers' Guild has written to members telling them to start saving in preparation for a shutdown.

fields.headline: George warns against devaluing pound
fields.trailText: The governor of the Bank of England today warned against any attempt to force down the value of the pound in order to prepare the ground for Britain to join the European single currency.
fields.body:
The governor of the Bank of England today warned against any attempt to force down the value of the pound in order to prepare the ground for Britain to join the European single currency.

Speaking in Paris, Sir Eddie George said that sterling was still "substantially overvalued" against the struggling euro. But he warned that lowering interest rates to try to drive down sterling to a "more sustainable level" risked stoking inflation and destabilising the whole British economy.

"Frankly it is not clear to me that this is a risk which would be in the interests of either the UK or the euro-zone to take in today's conditions," he said.

Sir Eddie, who has in the past expressed reservations about UK joining the euro, went out of his way to praise the single currency, saying it had contributed to strong performance of the euro-zone economies over the past two years.

But while he indicated that, at some point in the future, Britain may be able to exist "relatively comfortably" as a member of the single currency, with interest rates set centrally by the European central bank, the conditions were not yet right.

"For the time being our best bet, it seems to me, is for both the euro-zone and the UK to continue to pursue macro-economic - both fiscal and monetary - stability in parallel, and to hope that the euro recovers, as I continue to expect that it will," he said.

"That strikes me as a more reliable path to the sustainable convergence which the British government has set as the essential economic criterion on which its decision to move ahead to a referendum on UK entry to the euro will be based."

He admitted that the weakness of the euro remained puzzling, but suggested that it may be linked to the continuing strength of the US economy.

"On the basis of what we do know, it seems unlikely that the euro's weakness in the foreign exchange market is pushed by any obvious macro-economic failure in the euro-zone," he said.

"It is much more likely that it reflects the magnetic attraction of the US at present as a destination for long-term investment."

He said the euro-zone economies had turned in a "pretty good performance" since the introduction of the single currency and that much of the media criticism had been "wholly misplaced".

fields.headline: More mileage
fields.standfirst:
A £50 reduction in road tax would undercut the fuel protesters and do more for poor motorists than the Tories' proposed 3p fuel tax cut

Special report: the petrol war
fields.trailText: There is a way for Tony Blair to defuse the threat of further fuel protests and trump the Tories' proposal to reduce fuel duty by 3p a litre: cut Vehicle Excise Duty for small- and medium-size cars. Low-income rural motorists would be the biggest winners but some two thirds of all drivers would benefit.
fields.body:
There is a way for Tony Blair to defuse the threat of further fuel protests and trump the Tories' proposal to reduce fuel duty by 3p a litre: cut Vehicle Excise Duty for small- and medium-size cars. Low-income rural motorists would be the biggest winners but some two thirds of all drivers would benefit.

A road tax rebate targeted only at rural residents - which has been suggested - is too problematic. It would result in a postcode lottery where one person gets the discount but people on a neighbouring street do not and tax evasion where city dwellers register their cars with country relatives or at their second homes. The main objection, though, is that it does not help the majority of middle Britain.

Tax on petrol and diesel is part of the government's long-term strategy to cut carbon dioxide emissions to help prevent global warming. Increases in fuel duty between 1996 and 1999 are estimated to save between one and 2.5m tonnes of carbon emissions by 2010, a significant contribution to the UK's climate change strategy. A recent report by Stephen Glaister and Dan Graham for the Automobile Association concluded that a 10% increase in fuel prices would lead to a reduction in fuel consumption of about 7%, mainly through improved fuel economy.

There is a fundamental inconsistency between the government claiming to lead the international community in combating climate change and their calling on Opec to increase oil production. The Royal Commission on Environmental Pollution, based on the overwhelming consensus of scientific opinion, argues that the UK needs to cut carbon dioxide emissions by at least 60% by the middle of this century to avert the worst effects of global warming. We need to kick the fossil fuel habit, not to exacerbate it.

Road tax as currently structured contributes virtually nothing to the climate change strategy. It is Treasury policy to rebalance taxes on motoring from tax on ownership, such as road tax, to tax on car use, such as road tolls. The government has made a start with a new lower £100 rate for cars with engines up to 1,100cc, extended to cars up to 1,200cc from next March. From next year there will be a graduated system for new cars, with four bands based on carbon dioxide emissions. Those with higher emissions will pay more. But for the vast majority of existing cars there is a flat rate of £155 independent of engine size or fuel economy.

It would be entirely consistent to introduce a more graduated system of road tax for existing cars. For example a £50 cut for all cars up to 1,800cc would create three bands, a £50 rate for cars up to 1,200cc, £105 for cars up to 1,800cc and £155 for those more than 1,800cc. This would include more than two thirds of the cars on the road and nine out of the 10 most popular models on sale this year, while encouraging the purchase of smaller, more fuel-efficient cars and discouraging the gas-guzzlers.

For most motorists this would be worth more than a 3p cut in fuel duty, which would save a typical motorist about £35 a year. For example, the saving on fuel costs for a 1.8 litre Ford Fo cus doing 10,000 miles at 38 miles per gallon would be about £36.50.

In particular, low-income rural motorists who need their cars but drive fewer miles than average would have more to gain from a £50 cut in road tax. Average annual car mileage for low-income rural motorists, those in the bottom 40% of the income distribution, is about 8,000 miles. As the chart shows, a typical low-income rural motorist would save less than £30 from a 3p cut in fuel duty. Relative to a 3p cut in fuel duty, the winners from a £50 cut in road tax would be the owners of small- and medium-sized cars who drive less than about 15,000 miles a year (depending on fuel efficiency). The losers would be those who drive gas-guzzlers or do more than about 15,000 miles a year (about 16% of cars).

None of this addresses the problems of hauliers, which stem more from over-capacity in the industry than from taxation. Official statistics show that more than 99.9% of deliveries within Britain are by UK-registered hauliers, so there is little evidence of competition from overseas. Current levels of taxation are justified to cover the costs of road haulage in pollution, congestion, accidents and damage to the roads. But there is a case for recognising the short-term pain of the haulage industry and levelling the playing field with foreign lorries on international journeys.

A cut in road tax for lorries, which ranges from £280 a year to about £3,500 for different sizes, could be appropriate if at the same time the government signalled the introduction of the "Eurovignette" or "Brit-disc" at a later date. This is similar to road tax but can also be charged on lorries registered abroad when they visit the UK. An average cut in road tax of £500 for lorries and a £50 cut for cars up to 1,800 cc would cost about £1bn a year compared with the £1.26bn cost of a 3p cut in fuel duty in the next financial year.

There would be room for a further package of measures to promote public transport, rural services and alternative fuels. IPPR's proposals include extra money for buses, tax-free travel vouchers to encourage green commuting and grants to convert cars and lorries to cleaner fuels.

Tony Grayling is a senior research fellow at the Institute for Public Policy Research

t.grayling@ippr.org.uk

fields.headline: The RIP Act
fields.standfirst:
The RIP Act, which comes into force today, allows the government to snoop on all electronic communications. Julian Glover and Patrick Barkham explain
Special report: privacy on the net
fields.trailText:
What is the RIP Act?
The Regulation of Investigatory Powers (RIP) Act sets out the government's plans for how the security services can monitor and access communication over the internet. It passed into law hours before the Commons rose for its summer break and has now come into force.
fields.body:
What is the RIP Act?
The Regulation of Investigatory Powers (RIP) Act sets out the government's plans for how the security services can monitor and access communication over the internet. It passed into law hours before the Commons rose for its summer break and has now come into force.

Why is it so controversial?
Critics say the act is a gross invasion of privacy which will scupper e-commerce in Britain; the government argues it is necessary to crack down on internet crime and paedophilia.

What are the key areas of controversy? The first is "black box" interception. Security services, such as MI5, will be able to monitor people's internet habits through the collection of "communications data". This data is not website or email content, but users' "clickstream" - the websites and chatrooms they visit and the addresses of emails they send and receive. If security services suspect criminal activity, they request a government warrant to intercept and decode internet content.

The Home Office says the interception procedures are in line with the right to privacy enshrined in article eight of the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR - now part of UK law) and simply brings the monitoring of the internet in line with that of telephone calls. All telephone numbers are logged (call content is not) and some telephone companies are required to enable security services to intercept calls. But web addresses also show exactly what people have been looking at and build up detailed profiles of where people go online and who they communicate with.

Under RIP, some UK internet service providers (ISPs) will be asked "to maintain a reasonable intercept capability". This will come in the form of the much hyped "black boxes", a piece of computer technology enabling the security services to monitor the flow of data. Critics say that the black boxes will be hugely expensive and will have difficulty keeping pace with fast-changing internet technology as well as the ever-growing volume of internet traffic.

The Home Office claims the power of interception is rarely used. All security service warrants for the interception of data will require the personal approval of the home secretary and must meet stringent criteria - national security must be threatened or serious crime must be suspected. Critics prefer an independent judicial panel, which would provide external checks on the system and ensure spies and governments maintain the rule of law.

The second key controversy is the legislation's reverse burden of proof. If intercepted communications are encrypted (encoded and made secret), the act will force the individual to surrender the keys (pin numbers which allow users to decipher encoded data), on pain of jail sentences of up to two years. The government says keys will only be required in special circumstances and promises that the security services will destroy the keys as soon as they are finished with.

Human rights campaigners argue the act reverses the burden of proof in UK law. There is also the threat of stiff prison sentences if an individual who has been required to hand over keys tells a third party. However, the Home Office says the burden remains on the prosecution to prove "beyond reasonable doubt that an accused person is, or has been, in possession of a key to unlock particular protected data." The act also contains a defence for individuals who have lost or forgotten a key, and a person is no longer liable if they are judged to have done all they can to help the authorities to recover a key.

Critics argue that innocent people could still be jailed for innocently forgetting keys, while drug smugglers and paedophiles would happily settle for a two-year prison sentence rather than face far harsher penalties for being found guilty of the crime they are suspected of.

What about employers?
The act also allows employers to intercept emails and internet use by their staff, on grounds such as monitoring for computer viruses.

Will the act compromise e-commerce?
Many in business fear the act will scare off e-commerce entrepreneurs. A fiercely critical British Chambers of Commerce (BCC) report estimates the RIP Act could cost business £46bn in the first five years of operation, as ISPs are compelled to install costly black boxes, e-commerce firms are forced out of the country and new firms are dissuaded from basing their operations in the UK.

The act's potential to enable unlimited "fishing expeditions" in companies' databases compromises corporate privacy, they argue, while security service knowledge of clickstreams and encryption keys could fall into criminal hands, compromising the security of e-commerce. Forcing employees to secretly hand over encryption keys could also breach trust and rules within a company.

In turn, the home secretary, Jack Straw, says the BCC's figures are "incredible" given that the value of UK e-commerce is currently estimated at around £5bn. He prefers to highlight what he says is the overall cost of crime - £50bn a year.

What do other countries do?
There is no comparable legislation in the US. Tim Berners-Lee, the British inventor of the world wide web, has said that RIP would have been thrown out of the US "in a second". Ireland recently sought to encourage e-commerce by passing a law making it illegal for government to access commercial encryption keys. France has relaxed controls on domestic encryption, while Germany is opposed to restrictions on citizens' use of encryption. Russia, Singapore and Malaysia have passed laws similar to RIP.

If intercepted communications are encrypted (encoded and made secret), the act will force the individual to surrender the keys (pin numbers which allow users to decipher encoded data), on pain of jail sentences of up to two years. The government says keys will only be required in special circumstances and promises that the security services will destroy the keys as soon as they are finished with. Human rights campaigners argue the act reverses the burden of proof in UK law. There is also the threat of stiff prison sentences if an individual who has been required to hand over keys tells a third party. However, the Home Office says the burden remains on the prosecution to prove "beyond reasonable doubt that an accused person is, or has been, in possession of a key to unlock particular protected data." The act also contains a defence for individuals who have lost or forgotten a key, and a person is no longer liable if they are judged to have done all they can to help the authorities to recover a key. Critics argue that innocent people could still be jailed for innocently forgetting keys, while drug smugglers and paedophiles would happily settle for a two-year prison sentence rather than face far harsher penalties for being found guilty of the crime they are suspected of. What about employers? The act also allows employers to intercept emails and internet use by their staff, on grounds such as monitoring for computer viruses. Will the act compromise e-commerce? Many in business fear the act will scare off e-commerce entrepreneurs. A fiercely critical British Chambers of Commerce (BCC) report estimates the RIP Act could cost business £46bn in the first five years of operation, as ISPs are compelled to install costly black boxes, e-commerce firms are forced out of the country and new firms are dissuaded from basing their operations in the UK. The act's potential to enable unlimited "fishing expeditions" in companies' databases compromises corporate privacy, they argue, while security service knowledge of clickstreams and encryption keys could fall into criminal hands, compromising the security of e-commerce. Forcing employees to secretly hand over encryption keys could also breach trust and rules within a company. In turn, the home secretary, Jack Straw, says the BCC's figures are "incredible" given that the value of UK e-commerce is currently estimated at around £5bn. He prefers to highlight what he says is the overall cost of crime - £50bn a year. What do other countries do? There is no comparable legislation in the US. Tim Berners-Lee, the British inventor of the world wide web, has said that RIP would have been thrown out of the US "in a second". Ireland recently sought to encourage e-commerce by passing a law making it illegal for government to access commercial encryption keys. France has relaxed controls on domestic encryption, while Germany is opposed to restrictions on citizens' use of encryption. Russia, Singapore and Malaysia have passed laws similar to RIP. webTitle: News: Shock of the old as paint returns to the Turner prize

fields.headline: Shock of the old as paint returns to the Turner Prize
fields.standfirst: Alternative show denounces what organisers call an ongoing national joke - but 'pukka' landscapist emerges as favourite for top art award
fields.trailText: Alternative show denounces what organisers call an ongoing national joke - but 'pukka' landscapist emerges as favourite for top art award
fields.body:
After all the years of videos, rumpled beds and elephant dung, a truly shocking contemporary artist emerged last night as the bookie's favourite to win the £20,000 Turner Prize - Michael Raedecker, who creates delicately beautiful, eerie landscapes in the traditional materials of paint and embroidery on canvas.

The Turner Prize Exhibition, which opens today at Tate Britain for press and private views, will reveal that painting, abandoned by many contemporary artists and written off by critics as a dead medium, is back: the walls of two of the four rooms will be hung with large paintings on canvas.

The organisers of a rival exhibition, The Real Turner Prize Show, which opened in London yesterday, denounced the prize, one of the most prestigious in the world, as "an ongoing national joke". They plan to picket the prize dinner dressed as clowns, and yesterday launched a CD of their Turner prize song: Art or Arse? You be the Judge.

The insistence that the arts establishment has betrayed painting is the core creed of their movement, Stuckism.

At the Tate, however, Simon Wilson, curator of interpretation, said the Stuckists had picked an unfortunate year to mount their protest.

"The most striking thing about the Turner list this year is that we have two absolutely pukka painters" he said, describing Raedecker's work as "magical" and the other painter in the show, Glenn Brown, as "utterly contemporary in subject, but old masterly in technique".

"Painting is back, big time," Patrick Painter, Los Angeles agent for Glenn Brown, said. "You've got great painters in Britain. The buyers are mad for them in Los Angeles. It's old-school painting, baby, hell yes."

The other artists are opening favourite Thomas Tillman, who began in fashion photography, and Tomoko Takahashi, whose work really is rubbish, assemblages of waste and discarded objects described by Mr Wilson as "enchanting".

The Stuckists believe in getting their retaliation in first, and their bribes upfront: the invitations for their exhibition opening gave the lunch menu, running from champagne to bitter chocolate tarts, more prominence than the artists.

The Stuckists owe their existence to an insult hurled at Billy Childish by his former girlfriend Tracey Emin - whose stained and crumpled bed was on last year's Turner short list. "Your art is stuck, stuck, stuck!" she cried, and they wear the badge with pride.

Their serious point is that the traditional skills of painting and sculpture have been rubbished by what they call "the Serota brigade" after Sir Nicholas Serota, director of the Tate.

The Stuckists sent him their two-page manifesto, and a two-page letter headed "Shock of the new or yawn at the obvious".

Sir Nicholas sent a three-line reply: "Thank you for your open letter dated 6 March. You will not be surprised that I have no comments to make on your letter, or your manifesto "Remodernism".

"We are not the joke," Mr Childish said yesterday. "The Turner prize is the joke, a pathetic, boring, humourless joke that just feeds pretentiousness and alienates real lovers of art."

webTitle: Fraud squad decides against charging Robinson over grants

fields.headline: Fraud squad decides against charging Robinson over grants
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: An investigation by the West Midlands police fraud squad has concluded that Geoffrey Robinson, the former paymaster general, will not face charges over claims that government grants for his engineering company, TransTec, were improperly used.
fields.body:
An investigation by the West Midlands police fraud squad has concluded that Geoffrey Robinson, the former paymaster general, will not face charges over claims that government grants for his engineering company, TransTec, were improperly used.

After consulting the serious fraud office, police said yesterday there was "insufficient evidence to justify prosecution of any individual or company".

The allegations, made five years ago by former staff members, concerned grants of £500,000 from the Department of Trade and Industry to Transfer Technology, as it was called, and its subsidiaries between 1986 and 1989.

The police were asked to investigate in February after the DTI passed on the results of its own internal inquiry.

The MP for Coventry North West, whose memoirs, An Unconventional Minister, rekindled the row over his home loan to the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, which had led to both resigning from the government, received the news from police yesterday morning.

"This is a complete vindication of my position," he said. "I'm pleased, but not surprised at the finding. It's another investigation that has proved absolutely nothing improper in my business dealings."

The closure of the police file, however, is not the end of formal investigations into Mr Robinson's financial affairs.

DTI inspectors are still investigating the collapse of TransTec last December after it emerged that Ford had an undisclosed claim for $18m (£12m) against the company over a contract to supply parts for its Explorer vehicle. The claim was made on April 23 1997, two days before Mr Robinson, as chairman, signed off the previous year's accounts which contained only a pass ing reference to concerns about the contract.

He resigned from the company on May 1 when he was appointed paymaster general.

After the receivers were called in last year, Mr Robinson admitted that he knew there were "big problems" with the Ford contract but he said that, as a non-executive chairman, he was not told about the claim before he stepped down. It was settled in the third quarter of 1997, but the details were not recorded in the accounts.

The Tories, meanwhile, are hoping for further disclosures if the inspectors look into how TransTec was formed in the early 1990s from companies controlled by Robert Maxwell. One of the investors was the Belgian heiress Joska Bourgeois who left Mr Robinson £9m, when she died in 1994 aged 81.

fields.headline: What do you mean, there's no brief and no deadline?
fields.standfirst:
Dan Glaister on the Guardian's new cyber artist-in-residence

Special report: artist in residence
fields.trailText: Dan Glaister on the Guardian's new cyber artist-in-residence.
fields.body:
It is a strange appointment for a newspaper to make. Six months after we announced in these pages that the Guardian was to take part in the Year of the Artist scheme - dedicated to placing 1,000 artists in 1,000 workplaces - we can announce the name of the selected artist.

Michael Atavar is a digital artist, working with text, sound and images, all channelled through the world wide web. But, unlike most people working in a newspaper office, Atavar dedicates himself to slowing down the communication of information. "My work is almost the antithesis of the newspaper environment," he says. "It's a radically different perspective. The work I make draws on the potential intimacy between the user and screen. It slows down the pace to the speed of the heartbeat, and runs contrary to the madness of the www.

Michael Atavar's best-known project, * * * *, draws the user into a tranquil constellation worlds away from the frenetic pace of the internet. He is currently working on two other long-term projects: e-say, a series of online essays about the potential for art on the world wide web, and a VRML project (that's Virtual Reality Modelling Language) called .sciis (sensitive cumulative intelligent immersive systems). This aims to create complex virtual 3-D environments.

"The world wide web is a container that can hold text, images, sound and give them all equal value," says Atavar. "I think I'd always been searching for this sophisticated holding formula."

So what's in it for the Guardian? Well, who knows? One of the Guardian's concerns is to link the various branches of its media, from newsprint to website - both internally (for the people working in its offices) and externally (the readers of the newspaper and the people who visit our websites). And one of the Guardian's most obvious available resources is its computer system.

Atavar, playing the role of idiot savant outsider, may illuminate some aspect of our work, or he may add previously unimagined meaning to it. Then again, he may just shrug and wander off. It really doesn't matter. In a giant shift of culture, we're trying not to be prescriptive: so no deadlines, no brief, and no project as such. Just a chance for someone to work with us, observe us and possibly learn something from us or teach us something.

We aim to provide regular updates on his work, but in the meantime anyone interested in what he's doing can look on the world wide web at www.atavar.com or on this site.

webTitle: Consumer experts online - at a price

fields.headline: Consumer experts online - at a price
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: A website that allows users to talk to experts - on subjects such as finance, health and travel - simply by logging on, launched yesterday. It hopes to emulate the success of dot.coms exploiting the billion dollar American market.
fields.body:
A website that allows users to talk to experts - on subjects such as finance, health and travel - simply by logging on, launched yesterday. It hopes to emulate the success of dot.coms exploiting the billion dollar American market.

Questico plans to establish a pan-European venture, based on a "people-to-people" system, charging up to £3 a minute. Datamonitor research estimates the sector will generate $6bn of direct information exchange revenues by 2005.

Questico will allow users to search the company's database. Once a suitable expert is found, his or her qualifications can be pulled up. The user can then click the experts 'call' button and connect via a separate phone line.

Instant access to experts comes at a price, however. Experts charge between 10p and £3.00 per minute for their time and information and the company adds a commission charge of about 25% to 30%. Questico says it is the first company to bring the "people to people" concept and technology to Britain.

Richard Barker, managing director of Questico, said: "Real people are the most powerful piece of content on the planet. We're the first internet platform to harness that."

webTitle: US praises Blair for hi-tech successes

fields.headline: US praises Blair for hi-tech successes
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Senior US diplomats have praised the efforts of Tony Blair's government to capture the drive and productivity of Britain's emerging technology and internet sectors and help them turn the domestic economy into Europe's top performer, according to documents obtained by the Guardian.
fields.body:
Senior US diplomats have praised the efforts of Tony Blair's government to capture the drive and productivity of Britain's emerging technology and internet sectors and help them turn the domestic economy into Europe's top performer, according to documents obtained by the Guardian.

In private dispatches to Washington this year, officials at the US Embassy in London have reported that US firms "have taken notice of how the one-time 'sick man of Europe' is now the economic leader" on the continent".

They added that Britain's hi-tech entrepreneurs have cast off the old "British reserve" and are now imbued with a new "can-do" spirit.

A campaign to increase trade between US and British firms should "go a long way to fulfilling the needs of our new generation of exporters," the Americans wrote.

The officials wrote in June: "As New Labour enters its fourth year in power, the government is taking action to build on the macro-economic success it enjoys in having created the strongest UK economy in more than two decades.

"By introducing new policies and legislation to foster entrepreneurs and the emerging technologies needed to transform the economy, the government intends to increase productivity, and hence UK global competitiveness, far into the 21st century."

In March, the officials had told colleagues in Washington: "The prime minister and the New Labour government have set out to make the UK the economic engine of the EU, with e-commerce and emerging technologies the means to achieve this goal."

The reports underline how the embassy has been working closely with the "highest levels" of the Blair government to encourage American firms to invest in Britain. Ambassador Philip Lader has met chancellor Gordon Brown and trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers several times.

In the spring, a team of embassy officials were tasked to investigate "Britain's second industrial revolution, the change to an information-based economy".

The diplomats reported: "The team criss-crossed 'Silicon Fen', the area surrounding Cambridge, to meet the inventors, entrepreneurs, academics, venture capitalists and officials that have turned this area into Europe's leading area of innovation."

They added that a "rapidly increasing number" of American IT and internet companies were seeking business partners in this "hotbed of cutting-edge technology companies".

The embassy reports were disclosed to the Guardian under the US freedom of information act.

They show that the Americans were pleased with a conference which they organised in March this year on new technologies.

"One event, a panel discussion by local 'start-up' business leaders most of whom are now billionaires, epitomised the switch from the old 'British reserve' to the new 'can-do' approach of UK industry - with US technology and partners."

Despite the diplomatic backslapping, many industry executives are concerned with the latest corporate developments in Britain. Smaller start-ups say provisions for share options in their profit and loss accounts - recommended by the Accounting Standards Board - could cost the industry billions.

The government's controversial regulation of investigatory powers (Rip) bill, which relates to computer communications, was deemed so draconian that companies such as Nokia and Yahoo! warned they might move from British shores.

The chief executive of one UK internet success story said: "What the government has got to stop doing is treating the internet as a photo opportunity and more as a serious commercial prospect."

Live wire ideas

Tony Blair pledged to put electronic business at the heart of the British economy. Initiatives included:

Appointment of Patricia Hewitt as e-commerce minister.

Working with Oftel to foster competition in telecoms markets and drive down the cost of net access.

A 100% first year capital allowances for IT investment by small businesses .

Getting schools online and fostering students' IT skills.

A national network of online business advisers, helping firms go online.

The Electronic Communications Act provided for electronic signatures to be admissible as evidence in legal proceedings.

webTitle: Simon Hoggart: A chaotic election for Speaker

fields.headline: Mr Grumpy's bizarre contest
fields.standfirst: Special report: who will be the new Speaker?
fields.trailText: Since MPs had had less than four months to prepare for it, the election for Speaker naturally began in chaos.
fields.body:
Since MPs had had less than four months to prepare for it, the election for Speaker naturally began in chaos. Piss-up in a brewery? This lot couldn't organise an orgy in a massage parlour, or a sit-in at the Parker-Knoll factory.

With no fewer than a dozen candidates, most MPs clearly felt they ought to have a full ballot, just like we used to elect them. They put the point to Ted Heath who, as father of the house, had replaced Betty Boothroyd in the chair - not so much Madam Speaker as Mister Grumpy. His voice creaked like the lowering of an ancient drawbridge.

MPs such as Tony Benn pleaded with him to have a proper ballot. "This house must have the Speaker it wants, and he must have authority," Mr Benn pointed out to an unfamiliar sound -loud and raucous Tory cheers. "I believe we would become very confused if we changed the rules," creaked Mr Grumpy, to shouts of "No! No!" from the Conservative benches. But Ted Heath has heard Tories yell "No, no!" at him for decades. He ignored them all then and he ignored them yesterday.

Member after member begged him to change his mind. "That motion would require notice," he grumped. "Let's put this to the test!" demanded Peter Pyke. "I won't accept a dilatory motion," said the Grumpster, making it sound like a medical condition. "It's a simple solution that wouldn't be simple at all," he said with aggressive finality. If Anne Robinson ever packs it in, they could get him to host The Weakest Link. In fact, that was more or less the game show format they adopted.

So finally the house began this bizarre election process, by which Michael Martin, as front runner, was put up first, and the other 11 could take a crack at him in order. It was a version of musical chairs, in which one player was allowed to sit down all through the game.

Peter Snape proposed him, pointing out that he was chairman of the committee which banned journalists from the Commons terrace. "Actually he prevented journalists from buying each other drinks, and perhaps inadvertently putting the wrong name on their expenses claims." Centuries of history, of speakers proudly defending the rights of our elected representatives, sometimes at the risk of their own lives, now picked to stop journalists fiddling their expenses! And they say that Parliament is in decline.

Tony Benn knows it is. He pointed out that since the house rose in July we had had a fuel crisis, the Danish "no", the collapse of the euro and war in the Middle East. "And what are we talking about tomorrow?" he barked. "The insolvency bill (Lords). It should be the bankruptcy bill (Commons)!"

After Michael Martin we had the parade of no hopers. Up in the press gallery we pondered how long Mr Grumpy could go without a bathroom break, while we weren't fiddling our expenses. Everybody proposed combined "passion, independence and honesty" while being "forthright, direct and tactful", or some permutation of the above. I longed for someone to say, "he will be evasive, cowardly and indifferent." Mo Mowlam came closest when she said that Gwynneth Dunwoody would be "gusty". Perhaps she meant "gutsy"; perhaps she just meant "full of wind".

Sir George Young, the only person who might stop Mick Martin, said he was "in the Conservative party but, in a familiar phrase, not run by the Conservative party." It won a hearty laugh but only 241 votes. We knew it was all over. All we need to do now is to work out on earth what Mr Martin means when he talks in that Glasgow accent.

"This house must have the Speaker it wants, and he must have authority," Mr Benn pointed out to an unfamiliar sound -loud and raucous Tory cheers. "I believe we would become very confused if we changed the rules," creaked Mr Grumpy, to shouts of "No! No!" from the Conservative benches. But Ted Heath has heard Tories yell "No, no!" at him for decades. He ignored them all then and he ignored them yesterday. Member after member begged him to change his mind. "That motion would require notice," he grumped. "Let's put this to the test!" demanded Peter Pyke. "I won't accept a dilatory motion," said the Grumpster, making it sound like a medical condition. "It's a simple solution that wouldn't be simple at all," he said with aggressive finality. If Anne Robinson ever packs it in, they could get him to host The Weakest Link. In fact, that was more or less the game show format they adopted. So finally the house began this bizarre election process, by which Michael Martin, as front runner, was put up first, and the other 11 could take a crack at him in order. It was a version of musical chairs, in which one player was allowed to sit down all through the game. Peter Snape proposed him, pointing out that he was chairman of the committee which banned journalists from the Commons terrace. "Actually he prevented journalists from buying each other drinks, and perhaps inadvertently putting the wrong name on their expenses claims." Centuries of history, of speakers proudly defending the rights of our elected representatives, sometimes at the risk of their own lives, now picked to stop journalists fiddling their expenses! And they say that Parliament is in decline. Tony Benn knows it is. He pointed out that since the house rose in July we had had a fuel crisis, the Danish "no", the collapse of the euro and war in the Middle East. "And what are we talking about tomorrow?" he barked. "The insolvency bill (Lords). It should be the bankruptcy bill (Commons)!" After Michael Martin we had the parade of no hopers. Up in the press gallery we pondered how long Mr Grumpy could go without a bathroom break, while we weren't fiddling our expenses. Everybody proposed combined "passion, independence and honesty" while being "forthright, direct and tactful", or some permutation of the above. I longed for someone to say, "he will be evasive, cowardly and indifferent." Mo Mowlam came closest when she said that Gwynneth Dunwoody would be "gusty". Perhaps she meant "gutsy"; perhaps she just meant "full of wind". Sir George Young, the only person who might stop Mick Martin, said he was "in the Conservative party but, in a familiar phrase, not run by the Conservative party." It won a hearty laugh but only 241 votes. We knew it was all over. All we need to do now is to work out on earth what Mr Martin means when he talks in that Glasgow accent.

fields.headline: Side lines
fields.body:
Not so very long ago, Germaine Greer saw fit to inform the nation of her predilection for going sans underwear. Now John Mushet, jilted lover of gardeners' favourite Charlie Dimmock, has revealed that "when she was gardening she never wore a bra and she rarely wore knickers". Either the Beeb is determined to win the ratings war or something more sinister is afoot. Ladies, Sidelines is greatly concerned about chafing. Pull yourselves together and get yourselves some nice, sensible drawers. Or a large tub of Vaseline.

 Following the success of Puppetry of the Penis, currently keeping audiences entertained and cross-legged at London's Whitehall Theatre, comes the news that two Taiwanese martial arts students have set a world record by tugging an 11-tonne lorry 12 inches with their "swords". Well done, chaps! We can only congratulate these enterprising fellows - and await the next fuel crisis with interest.

 British pro-democracy activist James Mawdsley, freshly released from Keng Tung prison in Burma, paid a touching tribute to his mother at his Bangkok press conference. "At 8am this morning, I was told that my mother was still at Rangoon waiting to rescue me. At 9am I was told I was to be released. I am not ashamed to be 27 years old and still rescued by my mother." We twice salute you, Mr Mawdsley. Mother and son return to England today, where James will be reunited with his father and Diana will do his laundry.

webTitle: Women: Anthea Turner on the violence she suffered

fields.headline: 'I felt it was my fault'
fields.standfirst: The affair, the autobiography ... you may be forgiven for thinking there is no stone Anthea Turner has left unturned. But there is one secret she has never shared, until now: the violence she says she suffered at the hands of her former lover, Bruno Brookes. Here she talks to  Scarlett MccGwire
fields.trailText: The affair, the autobiography ... you may be forgiven for thinking there is no stone Anthea Turner has left unturned. But there is one secret she has never shared, until now: the violence she says she suffered at the hands of her former lover, Bruno Brookes.
fields.body:
You probably think you know everything there is to know about the television presenter Anthea Turner. The eight-year relationship with former Radio 1 DJ Bruno Brookes. The dream marriage to her manager, Peter Powell. The passionate, adulterous affair with their mutual friend, Grant Bovey. How Bovey left his wife, Della, and their three girls for Anthea. How he went back to Della. Then back to Anthea. Finally wedding bells for Grant and Anthea, paid for by OK! magazine, with the unwitting happy couple used to promote a chocolate bar. Then the torrent of abuse in the press. (How could they sink so low?) And then, in case you missed a word of it in the papers, along came 40-year-old Anthea's newly-published (ghosted) autobiography.

Given all this - given this life reduced to soap opera - it may come as something of a surprise that Anthea Turner has never said a word about what is probably the most shocking part of her life story: years of alleged physical and mental abuse at the hands of her long-term partner, Bruno Brookes. Though he admits the couple had a tempestuous and sometimes violent relationship, the former Radio 1 DJ dismisses Turner's claims insisting she is "dramatising" a handful of minor incidents to bolster her flagging popularity. "She's at an all-time low and she's trying to find someone to use to get back public sympathy."

What's not in dispute is that Turner and Brookes spent eight years together in the late 70s and early 80s. Brookes says it's unlikely they would have stayed together so long if Turner's allegations were true; she says she stayed with him just as countless other abused women stay with their tormentors. And just like all the other women out there - the ones who aren't on TV - who get hit, she says she never had the guts to say anything about it. So why this deathly quiet, from someone who has said so much? And why has Turner decided to talk about it now, for the first time, and to the Guardian?

The answer to the first question, she says, is that she was ashamed. She says she kept the violence out of her autobiography "not to protect him, but [because] it was a key area of my life that I had no pride over. I was protecting myself. I had boxed it away and I wanted it to stay there."

As with any long relationship that has long ago dissolved into acrimony, each side proffers a different version of every incident. But what emerges clearly from the accounts of both Turner and Brookes is a volatile relationship that often teetered on the brink of violence - and, according to Turner, often tipped over it.

Brookes concedes that, particularly in the last year of their relationship, the couple argued frequently. "Ninety-nine per cent of the time it was purely loud voices and we would cool off but at other times she would push me and I would push her."

Turner has a somewhat less benign recollection of events. During the first of their violent rows, she says: "He just suddenly started floundering around. He hit my chin and I fell to the floor. I curled up and then he was kicking me. Afterwards I remember going to the bathroom and looking in the mirror. I looked terrible and I had a problem moving my jaw." She claims she chipped a tooth and told her dentist she had caught her mouth opening a window.

"I don't remember there being a huge amount of remorse from him afterwards," she adds. "In fact, I had the feeling I was the one who should be apologising. I suppose I felt it was my fault. Bruno had a temper that doesn't take much to flare up and I always believed it was me. He always blamed me."

Brookes insists he didn't kick Turner - "She wouldn't have got up to remember it if I had done that" - but accepts that he may have struck her with his elbow in an attempt to protect himself. "Self-defence might be a bit strong but she was shouting at me and I was shouting at her and you're in a situation where you're clearly on at each other ... when she hurt her jaw as a result of it I remember thinking 'Oh my God, they'll think I've hit Anthea.' "

Turner is sitting, sipping peppermint tea, in the large kitchen of the Surrey home she shares with Bovey. His three daughters wander in and out. She says the decision to talk about the physical violence now has been forced upon her - that she has learned it has been Radio 1 gossip for years and had recently been questioned about it by a tabloid reporter. If it is to come out, she says, then at least let it be her who tells it.

Now that she is talking about it, she says, there is an element of relief. "I felt I had dealt with it by wrapping it up and putting it away, by just not thinking about it. I would tell myself that if I hadn't been in that relationship, however destructive, I wouldn't have met Peter Powell. I wouldn't be where I am today. But perhaps now that it is out, I can come to terms with it, because it won't be just wrapped up and put away. I can forgive myself. I can stop hating myself."

Turner says there were a number of incidents of violence in her relationship with Brookes. She says that on one occasion in early 1986, he was driving her to a gig he was doing in Birmingham when she told him she was going to do a broadcast for her local commercial radio station, Signal Radio. "He got my head and cracked it on the dashboard, then pulled some of my hair out," she says. "He was driving at the time. I was in complete shock. He made me feel I'd done something awful: bringing it up while he was driving." Brookes doesn't remember it that way. He insists her head hit the dashboard accidentally when he braked sharply to leave the motorway and emphatically denies pulling her hair. "We were so angry, I needed to get off the motorway on to the hard shoulder. If it had got any worse, we might have killed ourselves."

Shortly before Christmas the previous year, when the couple were living together in London, she says he threw a portable TV at her, after she had allowed her sister to use the telephone, without asking his permission first. One of her elbows was dislocated as she tried to shield herself. Once again, Brookes disputes Turner's account, though not her claim that they had a violent altercation. Though he concedes he's thrown a few objects in his time, he insists he's never thrown anything at Turner. He admits, though, that she did suffer an injury, possibly a dislocation of the shoulder, during a violent row: "She twisted her body is if to walk away quickly and that's how she did it."

Turner maintains that she wasn't a "victim". "I wasn't a woman married to a man coming home on a Friday night and knocking seven bells out of me," she says. "There were just lots of arguments. He would be pushing and shoving me and going for my throat. And saying: 'You're worth nothing without me. You're nothing. I need you, you need me.' "

She pauses. "It's a textbook case," she says, smiling weakly, meaning that the continual verbal abuse caused her to lose confidence and become emotionally dependent.

Like many women in her position, Turner blamed herself. "I still, to this day, believe it was my fault - even though I know I shouldn't. Whether it was an argument or a physical assault, at the end of the day I had made it happen. I had made him angry. I started the argument or I stood up for myself. He always said: 'You know how to wind me up and make me angry.' I always believed it was me, that I was a bad person to bring it out. I could have left, but I thought I could change this person."

The psychotherapist Susie Orbach says women often stay in violent relationships for that very reason. Not because they are victims, but because they believe they hold the key to stopping the abuse and changing the man. "It's understandable that [Anthea] doesn't want to see herself as a victim; passive victims feel like idiots. She thought she could transform him. Consciously or unconsciously, the woman thinks she is doing something to provoke the violence. She feels that even if she's not responsible, she has the key to figure it out."

The relationship itself still haunts Turner: "I have the occasional nightmare that he's there and I'm being put down." But she has never forgiven herself for staying. "I kicked myself for years about it. I wasn't a woman living in a council house with children. Why didn't I pack my bags and go back home? No woman should allow that to happen and I consider myself a fairly strong person."

It is justifying the staying - not remembering the violence - that brings on the tears. She feels that she let herself down. "I firmly believed, because he told me so many times, that I was nothing without him. I was emotionally dependent. I can't believe that the Anthea in the 80s can be the same person I am now. I can't believe I let it happen and went through it. I just thank my lucky stars I'm not there any more."

In the end, Turner did leave, of course. Since then she has given her support to the Elizabeth Trust - a small Stoke-on-Trent charity that provides a safe house, counselling and a helpline for women who have been battered.

The fact is that hundreds of thousands of women in this country have suffered domestic violence in silence. The Home Office estimates that every year, one in 10 women in Britain experience domestic violence, while a quarter suffer at some point in their lives. Senior officers in London's Metropolitan police force say that only 20% of incidents are reported and believe there could be as many as 35,000 cases per month. Turner hopes her decision to talk publicly about her own experience will do all those women some good.

Brookes insists her allegations have less to do with a desire to help other women than a need to court public sympathy. "She's trying to turn me into some sort of wife-beater ... She's trying to drag us into her world and I don't want to be dragged into her world." But looking at her now, one can't help feeling sorry for her. While her green eyes still sparkle, recent events have clearly taken their toll. "I suppose I'm just having to grow up," she says, smiling apologetically.

fields.headline: Time to be constructive
fields.standfirst:
Mary Kaldor A measure of independence for Kosovo could make possible a sort of rapprochement with Serbia
Special report: war crimes in the former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText: A n independent international report was handed to Kofi Annan, secretary general of the UN, yesterday. The Kosovo Report advocates "conditional independence" for Kosovo. Recent events in Belgrade underline the importance of this conclusion.
fields.body:
A n independent international report was handed to Kofi Annan, secretary general of the UN, yesterday. The Kosovo Report advocates "conditional independence" for Kosovo. Recent events in Belgrade underline the importance of this conclusion.

The revolution which overthrew Slobodan Milosevic was a genuine people's revolution. The miners and men from Cacak with their bulldozers and tractors stormed the parliament and the TV station. It marks a decisive break with the past 10 years.The new regime is likely to adopt a peaceful, more legalistic, approach towards solving the conflicts of the region.

But Milosevic's fall was not celebrated in Sarajevo, Pristina or Podgorica. So many tragedies have happened - no one can bring back the dead or reverse the trauma of ethnic cleansing. And the Serbia that has been revealed by liberation is a Serbia brutalised by 10 years of isolation and propaganda. Those who voted for Vojislav Kostunica did not do so because they opposed the atrocities but because of the collapse of the economy and the failure of hopes for a Greater Serbia. Those who marched on Belgrade carried Serbian flags and wore the symbols of Serbian nationalism.

Nato intervention and the sanctions precipitated economic collapse, but they also diverted attention from what the Serbs were doing to their neighbours. Kostunica is a democrat but also a nationalist. He opposed the Nato bombing and the Hague war crimes trials. On Sunday, he visited Trebinje in Republika Srpska to pay respects at the grave of a Serbian poet, although he also visited Sarajevo.

It is often argued that the best strategy for Kosovo is "constructive ambiguity". It is more important to normalise everyday life and to defer status questions for later. A period of ambiguity would give President Kostunica time to consolidate his position. But the ambiguity about Kosovo's status, as enshrined in UN Security Council Resolution 1244, which allows self-governing status for Kosovo while Yugoslavia retains sovereignty over it, is far from "constructive". It is very difficult to normalise everyday life when Kosovo has no constitution or basic law which could guide decisions on a whole range of issues including security, currency and even planning regulations.

This is one reason why it is taking so long to establish an effective administration or provide security within Kosovo and this, in turn, nurtures criminalisation. Minority Serbs are living in armed enclaves among the majority Albanians, there is growing frustration about their exclusion from governance. This week there are local elections in Kosovo and next year there will be national elections. All Albanian parties are united by the demand for independence. If this continues to be thwarted, frustration is likely to grow.

T here will also be elections for the Serbian parliament in December; it will be impossible to prevent Kosovan Serbs from participating since they voted in the Yugoslav elections in September. Without clarity about status, it is difficult to see how their situation can be ameliorated. The Serbs will continue to see themselves as part of Serbia with no necessity to accommodate towards the Kosovan Albanians, while many Albanians will continue to regard the Kosovan Serbs as a Belgrade fifth column.

Risks arise from the nationalistic stance of the present government. Because this is a time of democratic transition, the Serbian position will be heard with much greater sympathy than before and the ambiguity of Kosovo's position could grow. Both Kostunica and Zoran Djindjic, the leader of the opposition alliance, have talked about bringing Serbia and Kosovo closer together and implementing Res olution 1244, including the paragraph about sending Yugoslav and Serbian troops to Kosovo. Albanian leaders fear that the argument for independence will seem less pressing since Milosevic is no longer in power.

Opportunities arise from the democratic character of the new regime. Dialogue is all the more important to open up Serbia and to change the ingrained attitudes of the last decade. "Conditional independence" means self-government within an international framework, in which the international community retains responsibility for external security and the protection of minorities. Independence would be based on an "internal agreement" negotiated between the international community and the different peoples of Kosovo, and an "external agreement" with Kosovo's neighbours. There is a real possibility now to start those negotiations.

Baton Haxhiu, editor of Koha Ditore, a moderate newspaper in Kosovo, says there can be no dialogue with Belgrade until the Serb government acknowledges its responsibility for the genocide. But Kosovan Albanians also need to acknowledge their ethnic cleansing of Serbs in Kosovo. If there were a serious prospect of "conditional independence", it might provide the incentive for Kosovan Albanians to initiate dialogue and, perhaps, to participate in the December elections on a platform of independence.

Mary Kaldor is a member of the International Independent Commission to Investigate the Kosovo Crisis. The commission's Kosovo Report is launched tomorrow.

Read the report at www.kosovocommission.org

This is one reason why it is taking so long to establish an effective administration or provide security within Kosovo and this, in turn, nurtures criminalisation. Minority Serbs are living in armed enclaves among the majority Albanians, there is growing frustration about their exclusion from governance. This week there are local elections in Kosovo and next year there will be national elections. All Albanian parties are united by the demand for independence. If this continues to be thwarted, frustration is likely to grow. T here will also be elections for the Serbian parliament in December; it will be impossible to prevent Kosovan Serbs from participating since they voted in the Yugoslav elections in September. Without clarity about status, it is difficult to see how their situation can be ameliorated. The Serbs will continue to see themselves as part of Serbia with no necessity to accommodate towards the Kosovan Albanians, while many Albanians will continue to regard the Kosovan Serbs as a Belgrade fifth column. Risks arise from the nationalistic stance of the present government. Because this is a time of democratic transition, the Serbian position will be heard with much greater sympathy than before and the ambiguity of Kosovo's position could grow. Both Kostunica and Zoran Djindjic, the leader of the opposition alliance, have talked about bringing Serbia and Kosovo closer together and implementing Res olution 1244, including the paragraph about sending Yugoslav and Serbian troops to Kosovo. Albanian leaders fear that the argument for independence will seem less pressing since Milosevic is no longer in power. Opportunities arise from the democratic character of the new regime. Dialogue is all the more important to open up Serbia and to change the ingrained attitudes of the last decade. "Conditional independence" means self-government within an international framework, in which the international community retains responsibility for external security and the protection of minorities. Independence would be based on an "internal agreement" negotiated between the international community and the different peoples of Kosovo, and an "external agreement" with Kosovo's neighbours. There is a real possibility now to start those negotiations. Baton Haxhiu, editor of Koha Ditore, a moderate newspaper in Kosovo, says there can be no dialogue with Belgrade until the Serb government acknowledges its responsibility for the genocide. But Kosovan Albanians also need to acknowledge their ethnic cleansing of Serbs in Kosovo. If there were a serious prospect of "conditional independence", it might provide the incentive for Kosovan Albanians to initiate dialogue and, perhaps, to participate in the December elections on a platform of independence. webTitle: Leader: The new Speaker must embrace change

fields.headline: House of ill repute
fields.standfirst:
The new Speaker must embrace change
Special report: who will be the new Speaker?
fields.trailText: An introspective House of Commons, bewailing its loss of power and clout, failed its first test in restoring independence yesterday. It proved itself powerless to change even its own byzantine process of electing a speaker, let alone hold the executive to account.
fields.body:
An introspective House of Commons, bewailing its loss of power and clout, failed its first test in restoring independence yesterday. It proved itself powerless to change even its own byzantine process of electing a speaker, let alone hold the executive to account. Thwarted by the leader of the house, Sir Edward Heath, from having an open and democratic ballot of the 12 candidates, the chamber proceeded lamely with a ludicrous series of two member contests between the favourite, Michael Martin, and other contenders. Once the second favourite but fifth in sequence, Sir George Young, the liberal Tory "bicycling baronet" failed to gain sufficient votes, it became clear Mr Martin would win.

From all sides, concern was expressed over the erosion of the chamber's influence, the undue dominance of the front bench over the back bench, and the degree to which 24-hour media had replaced the commons as the central forum of debate. Yet, as Andrew Rowe, the Tory MP for Faversham and Kent noted, the future of the Commons does not depend on the new speaker nor the attitude of the government, but the readiness of backbenchers to exercise independent judgment. Tony Benn pointed to another Commons defect: it went into recess in July, since when there had been a fuel crisis, a Danish No, the collapse of the euro and a Middle East war. And what was their business tomorrow? "Insolvency bill Lords. It ought to be called Bankruptcy bill Commons because we simply don't play a role." There is an important lesson the new speaker can draw from Betty Boothroyd's farewell interviews. Having spent eight years resisting the modernisation of Commons's working practices, she relented yesterday, conceding its unsocial hours must be changed. Mr Martin, a Labour MP with a social conservative label, should support the women MPs campaigning for more rational working arrangements. He needs some astute repositioning.

webTitle: New setback for crown in Lockerbie bomb trial

fields.headline: New setback for crown in Lockerbie bomb trial
fields.standfirst: Special report: Lockerbie
fields.trailText: The Lockerbie trial suffered yet another setback yesterday as it was adjourned amid claims that fresh evidence has come to light that threatens to seriously undermine the crown's case.
fields.body:
The Lockerbie trial suffered yet another setback yesterday as it was adjourned amid claims that fresh evidence has come to light that threatens to seriously undermine the crown's case.

Reconvening after a two-week break to allow the crown to consider information recently released to it by a "foreign government", the Scottish court in the Netherlands sat for only a few minutes before it was again adjourned.

Six witnesses have been interviewed by Scottish police after the handover of the new evidence. Prosecutors received the information on October 4, but few details have been made public.

The lord advocate, Colin Boyd QC, told the court: "It relates not to the crown case, but to the defence case."

However, there is intense speculation that the information comes from Syria, whose new leader, Bashar al-Assad, is keen to end the country's isolation from the west and foster better relations with Libya.

The Libyans accused of the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 - Abdel Baset al-Megrahi and Al-Amin Khalifa Fhimah - have lodged a special defence of incrimination, blaming, among others, the Damascus-based Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine - General Command for the atrocity.

The prosecution handed the fresh evidence, an inch-thick dossier, to the defence just two hours before the court reconvened yesterday. The presiding judge, Lord Sutherland, agreed to an adjournment until today to allow the defence time to consider how long it needs to examine the information before the £3m-a-month trial can resume.

Mr Boyd told the court the crown had spent the last two weeks examining the new evidence, which "points to a number of individuals who had to be seen by the Scottish police force". He said the evidence referred to five people "in another European country and one in the United States of America". Arrangements had been made to allow the defence to interview those in the European country and the US.

Mr Megrahi, 48, and Mr Fhimah, 44, deny charges of murder, conspiracy to murder and breaching the Aviation Security Act.

webTitle: Pensioner jailed over council tax bill

fields.headline: Pensioner jailed over council tax bill
fields.trailText: A 75-year-old woman who refused to pay a £360 council tax bill because of a long-running dispute over her garden boundary was yesterday jailed by magistrates.
fields.body:
A 75-year-old woman who refused to pay a £360 council tax bill because of a long-running dispute over her garden boundary was yesterday jailed by magistrates.

The decision to imprison Mary Rooney, who had to be dragged handcuffed from court by prison officers, angered local people and campaigners for pensioners' rights.

Ms Rooney, who lives alone in Smethwick, West Midlands, has waged war on Labour-controlled Sandwell council since 1991, when she lost part of her garden in a dispute with neighbours.

Though she has thousands of pounds in savings, she has refused to pay her council tax. Yesterday she told magistrates: "I am not liable to pay tax on stolen property. If I did pay, I'd be condoning crime in Sandwell."

Miss Rooney was given a 21-day suspended sentence in January after being found "culpably negligent" of not paying her council tax and in the course of three subsequent hearings was ordered to pay £5 a week.

Ian Buckingham, representing Sandwell council, said: "This is the fifth hearing in relation to this particular debt. She has said she will not pay - the reasons are irrelevant."

Magistrates pleaded with Miss Rooney to take free legal advice from the duty solicitor but she refused. She insisted that her refusal to pay the council tax was "part and parcel" of the dispute over her land.

In 1994 she had asked for her house to be placed in a lower band because of the loss of part of her garden. The valuer had refused. Consequently, she paid only part of her council tax bill.

Yesterday, the chairman of the bench said: "In a democratic society, we have a duty to ensure payment of council tax so that appropriate services can be provided." The court was told Miss Rooney was liable for £516.70 in council tax and court costs.

She was believed to be spending last night at Brockhill prison, near Redditch in Worcestershire.

A senior Sandwell councillor, Darren Cooper, branded the jail sentence an "absolute disgrace" and called for the Warley MP, John Spellar, to intervene .

But the Sandwell cabinet member for finance and resources, cllr Richard Young, said: "Obviously, nobody here wants to see an elderly woman in this situation and I would rather see her pay than make applications to send her to prison, but she was given every opportunity.

"We are not the villains - if everyone did this then nobody, including elderly people, would get their bins emptied or meals on wheels."

Mike Allen, the chief executive of Sandwell Age Concern, said:"This is not helpful to the problems old people may be facing."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Choice/File On 4
fields.body:
In January, Sister Lavinia Byrne resigned from the Roman Catholic religious order to which she had belonged since she was 17. At the age of 52 her only material possessions were one chair and two heaters. In The Choice (9.0am, Radio 4) she talks to Michael Buerk about the pressures that brought such a traumatic decision. They started after she had written a book supporting women's ordination. In no time, the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith (the Inquisition as was) ordered it banned.

One of the key elements in the government's fight against organised crime has been its undertaking that whistle-blowers will be protected, if necessary for the rest of their days. But, as Allan Urry reports in File On 4 (8.0pm, Radio 4), the scheme seems to have experienced serious problems. Customs and Excise has been obliged to make several costly out-of-court settlements for failing to meet its side of the bargain.

webTitle: Discreet wooing pays off for Martin

fields.headline: Discreet wooing pays off for Martin
fields.standfirst: Special report: who will be the new Speaker?
fields.trailText: It was, his admirers say, the letters that won it.
fields.body:
It was, his admirers say, the letters that won it.

Mick Martin swept in as the new Commons Speaker last night after assiduously courting MPs from both sides of the house with handwritten letters of praise.

Newly elected MPs invariably found a friendly note in their Commons pigeon hole from Mr Martin on the day after they had delivered their maiden speeches. This would be followed up by words of encouragement from the deputy speaker in the Commons tea room.

Mr Martin's discreet, but relentless lobbying, paid off last night when Labour MPs rejected pressure from their own frontbench to elect the former Glasgow sheet metal worker as the new Commons speaker. His family's poverty forced him to leave school at 16 - it was not until 1987 that he passed his first O level in 1987 in his beloved Italian.

One of five children raised by his mother in a Glasgow tenement after the death of his father, Mr Martin becomes the first Catholic Speaker of the Commons since the Reformation. His faith could have counted against him because he first made his name in the Commons as a powerful opponent of current abortion laws and of equalising the age of consent for homosexuals. However, young modernising MPs set aside Mr Martin's past as they embraced the man who had done so much to court them.

"Mick has never discussed his views on those sort of issues with me," one young woman MP said. "He has been solely interested in listening to what we have to say and to our concerns."

Mr Martin, 55, was first elected to the Commons in 1979 as MP for Glasgow Springburn. Although a popular and genial figure, the former shop steward was never marked out for stardom on the frontbench - his high point came during a two year stint as a parliamentary aide to Denis Healey between 1981-83.

As a backbencher, Mr Martin was free to pursue his own interests. He voted for David Alton's bill to curb abortion in 1988 and against lowering the age of consent for homosexuals in 1994.

Back home in Scotland he led some of Labour's most savage attacks on the Scottish National party. In 1989 Mr Martin spoke of a "fascist element" within the SNP which "encouraged young children to throw stones at Labour cars". Such remarks played well with English MPs who had reservations about electing a Scot as Speaker in the wake of devolution.

Passed over for promotion by the Labour frontbench, Mr Martin began the long trek to the Speaker's chair when he was appointed chair of the Commons administration committee in 1992, a post he held throughout the last parliament.

In this role he performed two duties which endeared him to both modernisers and traditionalists. He was instrumental in introducing childcare facilities into the Commons, and he played a key role in banishing unaccompanied journalists from the Commons terrace, a move welcomed by the older generation of MPs.

MPs believe that his deft handling of the administration committee indicates that he will support Commons reform, though in a cautious way which will bring traditionalists with him.
