webTitle: Comment: Matthew Engel on the Underground

fields.headline: I'd prefer not to take the A train
fields.standfirst:
But at least in New York travellers can afford to buy the tickets

More about transport
fields.trailText: In another terrible week for rail travel in Britain, the one positive item of news emanated from the mayor of London, who announced that the underground would be run by "the man who saved the New York subway", Robert Kiley.
fields.body:
In another terrible week for rail travel in Britain, the one positive item of news emanated from the mayor of London, who announced that the underground would be run by "the man who saved the New York subway", Robert Kiley.

Ten years ago, we were told, only about 83% of New York passengers actually reached their destinations, the rest being murdered on the way by crazed crack addicts. Now, commuters from Brooklyn recline languidly while nymphettes mop their brows and peel them grapes, and the trains whoosh in to Wall Street. (I paraphrase a fraction.)

It seems to me, after a quick consumer test last week, that the New York story has been a bit exaggerated. True, you do feel safer than before. But you feel safer on the streets too, due to demographic and social changes unconnected with Mr Kiley. It's true too that the paintwork on the trains is now graffiti-free, and for that the Kiley zero-tolerance policy is indeed responsible. Unfortunately, the artists gouge their work in the windows instead.

London commuters may curse "the Northern Line minute", which is longer than any other minute. But at least the Underground has a system indicating the rough length of wait. The subway does not. If the escalators don't break down, it's because they don't exist. There are no maps on the platforms and those on the trains are obscured by passengers' heads. The seats are rock-hard, the stations dingy, the carriages sweltering, the lay-out bewildering, the announcements incomprehensible. And, given favourable winds across the Atlantic, it is quite possible for the flight back to London to take less time than the A train from uptown Manhattan to JFK.

New York's one huge advantage is that the subway is affordable: $1.50 (just over £1) a ride anywhere with a simple electronic ticketing system, compared to £1.50 and upwards in London. Does anyone know of more expensive urban transport?

What the US and Britain have in common is that they have at least re-grasped what they knew a century ago and tried to deny for decades: that underground railways are the only sensible means of moving multitudes through great cities, and that in smaller places trams or light rail can be mightily effective.

But the rest of the world has leapt ahead. Last month, three French cities - Nantes, Strasbourg and Lyons - opened light rail lines in a single week. Lille and Orleans followed this month. Istanbul has a new metro. You can also get from Oktabrskaja to Alatau (via Kommunistischeskaja) on the new subway in Alma-Ata, capital of Kazakhstan. They are even building like mad in Medellin, Colombia, where presumably the cocaine that terrorised New York helps pay the bills.

We may also presume that these lines address the main transport issues in each city. London's only new underground line, the Jubilee extension, is much admired for its style by the Dome's occasional visitors, but much criticised for the delays and cost overruns in its construction. The real flaw is that it was designed primarily to solve the political problems of Canary Wharf, rather than the transport problems of central London. The new lines London really needs remain unbuilt (the Hackney-Chelsea line, discussed forever, has now been extended to Wimbledon: a virtual extension to a non-existent railway and therefore cost-free).

The Underground is at the point the rest of Britain's railways reached in the early 90s: investment is delayed because of endless arguments about the structure. The choice between bond issues and public-private partnership is misleading, bordering on bogus. There is a legitimate debate to be had between public and private management, but there can be no dispute about who pays. We do.

Transport in cities is not a means of wealth creation. It is first and foremost a means of shifting people to and from work so they can get on with the business of wealth creation. Every unnecessary minute they spend on a train is time wasted in their lives and the economy.

So in the end it doesn't matter how the Underground is financed. In the end, the public has to pay: either through fares or through taxes. There is no other means of making money out of it. To provide an efficient system, government has to invest. To encourage extra people to use trains not cars, then government must subsidise. Ken Livingstone grasped the point when he first ran London almost 20 years ago. Successive governments go on funking it.

I'm not sure how things are working in Alma-Ata. But the best and most beautiful underground railway I have ever seen is in Moscow. No one ever runs for a train because they know another one will be along in a matter of seconds. The Moscow Metro was built by Stalin in the 1930s. Private capital is not thought to have been involved.

webTitle: This unbrave new world would be bad news for us

fields.headline: This unbrave new world would be bad news for us
fields.standfirst:
A Republican presidency offers alarming possibilities for Britain
Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Hugo Young: Tony Blair has never met George W Bush. The newest episode in the Anglo-American relationship, which may begin in a fortnight's time, will get off to a jarring start.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has never met George W Bush. The newest episode in the Anglo-American relationship, which may begin in a fortnight's time, will get off to a jarring start. Governor Bush was due to tour Europe and Asia last spring, to make himself known to foreign leaders and enrich his image back home. That's what presidential candidates do. But the visits were called off, because Bush's campaign handlers thought they wouldn't help. They feared he would make a fool of himself. Since then, the evidence has accumulated that they were right.

For Mr Blair, and therefore for Britain, a Bush presidency offers alarming possibilities. It is true that, when he woke up to the fact that he was president, Mr Bush would probably survey the world and recognise Anglo-London as a first foreign haven. Though knowledgeable about Latin-America, he is ignorant of Europeans, and would be inclined to fall back on the British bonds familiar to George Bush I.

But the culture-shock to Mr Blair will be great. He has grown close to Bill Clinton. They talk more often and more equally than any prime minister and president for 50 years, Thatcher-Reagan included. Their brains as well as ideology are a match. The third way, so-called, is a common project, their version of a globalised idea. As well as enjoying exchanges of wonkishness about healthcare or education reform, the two helped each other out of tight corners, and if Al Gore wins, the continuities will be pretty seamless.

Mr Bush comes from somewhere else. Though wallowing in a sea of unspecifics, he knows what he doesn't like, and most of it is represented by Clinton-Gore and, by extension, Blair. His biggest pitch is anti-Washington, which means anti-government. He has entered into little policy talk with the American people, so it's a fair bet there would be none with his friends across the ocean. Bush is aggressively uninterested in that way of being a political leader, let alone in the kind of social democratic world that has given several European leaders more useful relationships with Washington than have existed for decades.

But that's only the beginning. It is now clear that Bush and his people regard 21st century Europe very differently from the view that prevailed in Washington in the second half of the 20th. They positively desire a greater distancing, especially of the American army. When Bush began to hint at this a few months ago, most of the foreign policy establishment here put it down to campaign talk. The protection of our boys from crazy foreign adventures made useful headlines. Actually we now know Bush has every intention of withdrawing American troops from the Balkans, as part of a philosophy which is working towards an end to interventionism anywhere on any grounds other than US strategic interest.

His chief foreign policy adviser, Condoleezza Rice, told the New York Times that "peace-keeping" missions would be out, because they were a distraction from America's prime duties in the Gulf and the Taiwan straits. In Europe, there had to be a "new division of labour": a statement made, by the way, in apparent ignorance of the fact that Europeans currently supply more than 80% of the peacekeeping force in Bosnia and Kosovo. When Bush's spokesman was challenged with the implications of the new doctrine, he said that the governor was "100%" behind what Ms Rice had said.

So an unbrave new world beckons, which is likely to destabilise Nato as well as re-positioning Washington's global relationships. American economic dominance will grow and grow, but American responsibilities as the only super-power are set for the kind of drastic re-think that the European left once dreamed of, but which is now more likely to upset our modernised social democratic governments.

If the Bush doctrine takes hold for four years, it will pre-empt most of the British argument against Blair's efforts to build Europe's own security. Tory objections to the embryonic Euro-defence force will be emptier than ever - the St Malo agreement that got it under way will look like a singular piece of Anglo-French prescience. But, shorn of major bits of US capability, Nato could look radically different. Forget about more enlargement. Forget about much more peacekeeping. Meanwhile, a unilateral American national missile defence (NMD), pushed through without regard for what allies have to say, grows naturally out of the coming mind-set. One Washington expert, who monitors security issues with an intimate insider's eye, told me he regarded NMD as now certain to be deployed if Bush wins.

He will surround himself, of course, with advisers. General Colin Powell is regarded as the prime candidate for secretary of state, and might even be announced as such before November 7, to reel in those voters who look at Governor Bush and see only a dim-witted Reagan without the excuse of being an actor, or the defence of having a simple vision he will cling to. Reagan did have the big idea that he needed to beat the Soviets, a task in which he succeeded. Because of that governing notion, the times accommodated, and even profited from, a leader otherwise unqualified for world leadership, whose purpose everyone could easily figure out.

Modern times are different. There is neither big idea nor big challenge: no missile gap, no space race, no evil empire. Foreign policy is the task of building alliances, largely by personal persuasion. A president can't subcontract the task of choosing between advisers whose opinions, however clever, conflict. He has to decide himself, about matters of great complexity. Nor can he cajole allies or persuade Congress except by his own negotiating talents. The hands-off president is not, these days, an option. But the hands-on president needs a set of skills, including an interest in policy detail and a sophisticated alertness to the world, of which George Dubya Bush has shown staggeringly little command.

In foreign policy, Congress will be no counter-force to a new era of US-first unilateralism. Internationally, a do-nothing president will meet only the grateful acquiescence of the legislature. On the Hill, the age of internationalism is dead, something Clinton at first did not work hard to repudiate. But in the end he did so. Gore blows the same muted trumpet, and Blair, the liberal interventionist, chimes with him. The new President Bush would be the man who said earlier this year that "we should not send our troops to stop ethnic cleansing and genocide in nations outside our strategic interest". His adviser's words about Nato seem just as reckless, but just as revealing. They are not a posture, but a position. They're probably the decided view of a majority of Americans, whose ignorance, however, has until now always had an enemy in the White House.

webTitle: What makes him want the job?

fields.headline: What makes him want the job?
fields.standfirst: Special report: who will be the new Speaker?
fields.trailText: As Sir George Young joked before he lost yesterday's election for Speaker, the job is as historically dangerous as the England football manager's. Yet up to a dozen MPs wanted it.
fields.body:
As Sir George Young joked before he lost yesterday's election for Speaker, the job is as historically dangerous as the England football manager's. Yet up to a dozen MPs wanted it.

Why? In an age when Parliament's reputation has sharply declined (another of yesterday's recurring themes) the prestige and influence of the Speakership has survived, partly because television has made it famous, partly because voters identify with the person who has to keep unruly MPs in order at question time.

That is the visible, easy bit. The Speaker spends no more than 10 hours a week in the chair, handing over the long, dull hours of the white fish (Scotland) (No 2) bill to his or her deputies. There is plenty else to do.

The key functions of the office as it has evolved from 1268 when speakers often died in battle are threefold:

 to chair the Commons , as seen on TV, which means firmness and fairness, a flair for procedure and for minority viewpoints, a good head for 658 faces; but also to police the deals which parties do behind the scenes, procedural wrangles over bills or statements, too often made on the Today programme

 to chair the Commons commission which manages the ancient Palace of Westminster through a £200m annual budget, always under pressure to give MPs more staff and better facilities

 to be Westminster's ambassador among parliaments around the world. Many MPs believe the management job should be hived off, professionalised, but Michael Martin has chaired the administration committee and believes he has the experience to cope. After prickly dealings in the past the press will be watching warily, but Mr Martin's camp say relations are better now. The real task facing the 152nd Speaker will be to fight for the rights of the legislature - Parliament - against the executive, which for many years has become increasingly distainful of backbenchers, and to assert their historic power to question ministers and hold them to account for their policies. Tony Benn led a host of MPs - and candidates - in making this plea yesterday. It will be a daunting task, but Speaker Martin will have all parties behind him in the struggle ahead.

webTitle: New site aims to turn surf tide

fields.headline: New site aims to turn surf tide
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: Internet users who spend hours searching the web for information are being targeted by KeepUpdated.com, a website which goes live today.
fields.body:
Internet users who spend hours searching the web for information are being targeted by KeepUpdated.com, a website which goes live today.

The company, which is looking to raise £5m of first round funding, allows surfers to profile what they are looking for and delivers the information to their browsers. Information is updated regularly.

"We're turning the internet inside out so that you don't have to surf, what you want finds you", Peter Hoskins, KeepUpdated's chief executive officer, said.

The company employs 25 people and has been funded until now by its founder, Curtis Nash, who sold another brainchild, CD Direct, in 1994 for more than £1m.

"KeepUpdated solves the most common frustration of internet users by cutting through millions of pages on the web to bring them exactly the content they need, whether it is text, graphics, audio or video," the company said.

Although there are only 20 content partners at present, a spokesman for KeepUpdated said the number was likely to grow rapidly.

The company also aims to help online businesses attract and retain customers by offering its updating service for a fee. It says the service enhances the "stickiness" of sites.

webTitle: Britain intensifies propaganda war against Saddam

fields.headline: Britain intensifies propaganda war against Saddam
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Alarmed by increasing support in the Arab world for Saddam Hussein in the wake of the Palestinian conflict, Britain yesterday mounted a fierce attack on the Iraqi dictator in an attempt to shore up the crumbling sanctions regime against Baghdad.
fields.body:
Alarmed by increasing support in the Arab world for Saddam Hussein in the wake of the Palestinian conflict, Britain yesterday mounted a fierce attack on the Iraqi dictator in an attempt to shore up the crumbling sanctions regime against Baghdad.

Peter Hain, the Foreign Office minister, handed journalists details of Saddam City, a luxurious resort built for the Iraqi leader's friends and relatives, and accused the regime of "obscene decadence".

He also released a detailed list of large amounts of cigarettes and alcohol imported by Iraq over the past six months in what he called "further evidence of Saddam's playing politics with suffering, spending revenue on luxuries rather than food and medicine for the Iraqi people".

The Foreign Office described Saddam City, or Saddamiat Al Tharthar, 85 miles west of Baghdad, as a "sprawling resort [which] contains stadiums, an amusement park, hospitals and 625 homes of Saddam's favourites".

It said it obtained details of the complex from "intelligence". In fact the details, including a giant bronze statue of President Saddam as well as CIA satellite photos, were reported in western newspapers last year.

Sanctions do not prohibit imports of tobacco and alcohol, since they are classified by the UN as food. But the Foreign Office said that since these items were not imported under the oil-for-food programme, Iraq must be paying for them from other funds, including smuggling revenue.

Iraq would be getting $24bn from oil revenues this year, making it the world's fifth largest oil exporter, Mr Hain said. Of this, it could spend more than $16bn on food and medical supplies under the UN oil-for-food programme. Meanwhile, he added, it would earn more than $1bn this year from oil smuggling.

The government is acutely aware that the breakdown in the Middle East peace process and attacks by Israeli troops on Palestinians have heightened President Saddam's prestige among Arab populations, while the sanctions are under fiercer than ever attacks.

A body of opinion, both within Iraq and outside, believes that the sanctions are counter-productive and allow the Iraqi dictator to blame them for his country's ills.

But Mr Hain yesterday repeatedly insisted that there was "no prospect" of ending the sanctions without President Saddam first accepting UN security council resolution 1284, under which sanctions would be lifted only if Baghdad cooperates for 120 days with the UN weapons monitoring teams.

Baghdad has said it will consider admitting UN inspectors only after sanctions are lifted and Britain and the US withdraw their aircraft from the no-fly zones.

Asked about UN security council resolution 242 , which calls on Israel to leave the occupied territories, Mr Hain replied: "The UK position is that all security council resolutions should be implemented."

However, he said, the Israeli use of force was "excessive".

webTitle: MPs marvel at view from £230m new home

fields.headline: MPs marvel at view from £230m new home
fields.standfirst:
Backbenchers grateful for more working space although some question the cost of fittings

Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: It has cost £230m to build - £80m over budget - with £47m lavished on a burnished bronze roof that needed a £500,000 polish, £2m on electric blinds, £75,000 on two reception desks, and £150,000 on renting 12 fig trees.
fields.body:
It has cost £230m to build - £80m over budget - with £47m lavished on a burnished bronze roof that needed a £500,000 polish, £2m on electric blinds, £75,000 on two reception desks, and £150,000 on renting 12 fig trees.

It has been criticised as unsafe, with one woman MP hurting herself on an escalator last week, and described as monstrous by the Guardian's architecture critic.

And yet, as 210 MPs moved into Portcullis House, their opulent new home opposite the House of Commons yesterday, there was a tangible air of excitement and wonder, compounded by anxiety about just what their offices would look like.

Scurrying through the vast, Portland stone courtyard at the heart of the building - a gleamingly bright atrium with a huge timber latticework roof, two pools and the infamous fig trees, flanked by two minimalist restaurants called "the debate" and "the adjournment" - Jonathan Shaw, Labour MP for Chatham and Aylesford, appeared shell shocked as he rang up his assistant to remind him of his room number.

As he opened the frosted glass door onto the suite of light oak panelled rooms he shares with a Labour colleague, he was taken aback by his direct view of the Commons to the front, Westminster abbey to the right, and Big Ben to the left. "I must have one of the best views here," he murmured, aghast. The backbencher added: "It's a bit of a contrast to my constituency office, in a small corner of a TGWU office in Chatham."

Three floors above him, Martin O'Neill, veteran Labour MP for Ochil, was taking a guilty delight in the trappings of power, confessing: "I'm not saying it's worth 21 years on the backbenches, but..." as he played with the electric blind system which darkened his Thames-view room at the touch of a button. The chairman of the trade and industry select committee, who recalled sharing a room smaller than the size of his assistant's with three other MPs when he first joined Parliament, argued the sleek, oak lined room, with its black and metal chairs, triple glazing and soft sage carpet - at £53 a square metre - was no more opulent than that of middle ranking executives. "But whether we need the trappings, the fig trees and things like that - well, I think people got carried away with certain aspects of it," he conceded.

Norman Baker, the Lib Dem MP for Lewes who has called for an inquiry into the project, was more forthright. "Yes, it's very nice, and very comfortable and very attractive inside, but the question is whether it's appropriate to spend so much money on building for MPs. We don't say to the public sector, here's a blank cheque for schools and hospitals - but here there seems to be no expense spared."

As the contents of huge plastic crates began to line the shelves of the new offices, other MPs were experiencing problems. Christine McCafferty, Labour MP for Calder Valley, had had to move offices after her cupboard doors failed to open, while Matthew Tayor, Lib Dem MP for Truro and St Austell, was shivering due to a design fault: "They've installed the wrong windows so they're permanently open and will have to be replaced."

While the Tories' Archie Norman - proud occupant of one of the six penthouse offices with views of the London Eye - said it was "time to stop grumbling", Denis MacShane, Labour MP for Rotherham, complained: "All the plugs and television and computer sockets are at floor height when for the last 10 years they have been at workbench height."

But, in keeping with most of his colleagues, he was grateful for the space offered by his new office. "After all these years there's a place for myself and staff to work which isn't like being on the Northern line in the rush hour," he said.

While the Tories' Archie Norman - proud occupant of one of the six penthouse offices with views of the London Eye - said it was "time to stop grumbling", Denis MacShane, Labour MP for Rotherham, complained: "All the plugs and television and computer sockets are at floor height when for the last 10 years they have been at workbench height." But, in keeping with most of his colleagues, he was grateful for the space offered by his new office. "After all these years there's a place for myself and staff to work which isn't like being on the Northern line in the rush hour," he said.

fields.headline: Dangers lurking on long-haul flights
fields.standfirst: After the death of a passenger from a blood clot, report to call for better health and safety rules in aircraft cabins
fields.trailText: Pressure on the airline industry, already under fire following the death of a 28-year-old woman from a blood clot after a long haul flight from Australia, is likely to increase with the publication of a House of Lords report calling for better health and safety conditions for air travellers.
fields.body:
Pressure on the airline industry, already under fire following the death of a 28-year-old woman from a blood clot after a long haul flight from Australia, is likely to increase with the publication of a House of Lords report calling for better health and safety conditions for air travellers.

The science and technology select committee, which is due to report on the medical environment of aircraft cabins in three weeks, is expected to criticise the way air quality has deteriorated dramatically, as well as recommending that airlines give passengers more explicit preventive advice about deep vein thrombosis (DVT) before long-haul flights.

The condition, often referred to as "economy class syndrome" because it can be brought on by sitting for long periods in cramped conditions, caused the death of Emma Christofferson, a sales assistant with Marks and Spencer, who developed a blood clot after sitting in an economy seat for the 20-hour return journey from a holiday in Australia.

Her death has prompted an outcry from travel safety experts, who claim that not enough has been done to alert passengers to the risks and what precautions they should take.

According to Farrol Khan, director of the Aviation Health Institute, which researches air deaths, the amount of leg room makes many economy class airline cabins a health hazard. "Airlines should be like other industries and label their products correctly and be upfront about how their product can cause blood clots on long-haul flights," he said yesterday.

"The danger in economy class is far greater because when the passenger is sitting still the usual pumping action of the calf and thigh muscles no longer pushes the blood up to the heart while at the same time the pressure on the edge of the seat blocks the return of the venous blood," he said.

Although no detailed research has been carried out, Mr Khan estimates that as many as 6,000 passengers a year may die as a result of DVT, with as little as three hours of cramped conditions putting some people at potential risk of blood clots in the deep veins of the legs which can move to the lungs, causing a potentially fatal embolism.

The Lords select committee is expected to call on airlines to advise passengers to drink plenty of water, take aspirin - which helps to thin the blood - and exercise leg muscles during the flight to try to fend off the condition.

The inquiry, which was in part prompted by an illness contracted by the Labour peer Lord Graham on a long-haul flight, has heard expert medical evidence suggesting new research needs to be undertaken to gain a full picture of the scale of risk. Yesterday a spokesman for British Airways, which reduced the gap between its seats from 32 to 31 inches after privatisation, said what evidence there was into the causes of DVT showed it could affect passengers in first and business class just as readily as those in economy. "It really is a misnomer to call it economy class syndrome," the spokesman said. "There are examples of people experiencing DVT just from sitting still for long periods.

"Like any health issue, we take it seriously, but we already have clear guidelines in place, both in our in-flight magazine and on the British Airways website, warning people of the dangers and advising them on what to do."

Medical experts say that middle-aged or elderly passengers, pregnant women, smokers and those with cardiovascular disease are usually most at risk, but for disaster to strike other factors usually have to come into play such as dehydration, a fatty meal or oral contraception.

Simon Evans, a spokesman for the Air Transport Users Council, said the airlines could do more to alert passengers to the dangers. "Many airlines do give advice to passengers not to sit in the same position for too long and to move around, but it is perhaps an area where they could make the advice more prominent, perhaps in the form of a loudspeaker announcement."

The Lords will also make recommendations on air recycling, which is seen by travel experts as another potential health problem for airline passengers.

Since the 1970s, airlines have saved on fuel costs by mixing fresh air with 50% recycled air that has been passed through high efficiency particulate air filters that are supposed to remove dangerous pathogens, but if they become clogged or dirty their effectiveness can be reduced, leaving passengers exposed to bacteria.

There have been a number of cases of people contracting tuberculosis after long-haul flights, almost certainly as a result of breathing partly recirculated air.

The committee is expected to propose that air is not recirculated, a move that would increase airlines' fuel bill by as much as 2%. The Lords committee will argue that air filters should be regularly checked, instead of being systematically altered on the basis of their age. They may also propose that airlines are required to offer air ventilation adjusters above seats.

The committee is also understood to have been struck by the lack of an international body to oversee passenger safety or set minimum standards. Members of the select committee, including Lord Winston, believe air travel is more dangerous than other forms of transport such as long car journeys or rail trips.

Lord Winston told the committee: "You can stop the motor car and you can get out at a garage and walk around, and you cannot in an aircraft. Similarly in a train, you are not in the precisely confined seating that you really are in many modern aircraft.

fields.headline: Murdered priest 'had double life'
fields.trailText: Detectives hunting the murderer of one of Britain's leading Hindu priests said yesterday they were investigating his "double life" and links to the gay community.
fields.body:
Detectives hunting the murderer of one of Britain's leading Hindu priests said yesterday they were investigating his "double life" and links to the gay community.

Harish Purohit's body was found in an empty house in Leicester last Friday by his father and younger brother. He had been stabbed 13 times in the neck, back and legs, with the fatal wound being through his lungs.

Mr Purohit, 42, was a highly respected figure: a priest at the Shree Shakti Mandir temple, president of Britain's Hindu Federation and secretary of the National Association of Hindu Priests. He worked part-time with people with learning disabilities and ran a nursing home.

A team of more than 100 officers is following up on dozens of potential leads, making this one of the biggest inquiries Leicestershire police have conducted.

Yesterday Detective Superintendent Bryan Warraker, the officer leading the investigation, said he was particularly keen to find out more about the victim's social life.

"He had a happy domestic home life," he said, "but also had a separate social lifestyle. We need help from his friends in both these facets of his life and I can assure people that we will treat any information sensitively."

But Harish's younger brother Jai, 35, said it was "not correct at all" to suggest his brother had lived a double life. "He has a lot of friends and some are gay and lesbian," he said. "But that doesn't mean he was gay."

Detectives are trying to trace Mr Purohit's movements on the night of his murder. He left home on Thursday at 11pm for a night out and his body was found at 10.30am the next day, at a terraced house on Harrison Road owned by his family.

There were no signs of forced entry and police believe Mr Purohit may have known his killer. Forensic experts are still examining his car for clues.

webTitle: Oxbridge drop in state school applicants

fields.headline: Oxbridge drop in state school applicants
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Cambridge University yesterday reported a significant slump in applications for places on its undergraduate courses next year, after Oxford revealed a setback in its drive to attract more applicants from state schools.
fields.body:
Cambridge University yesterday reported a significant slump in applications for places on its undergraduate courses next year, after Oxford revealed a setback in its drive to attract more applicants from state schools.

Provisional figures released by the two universities for courses starting next autumn show a mixed picture. Applications to Oxford from British-based youngsters are marginally up on last year, while those to Cambridge are down by around 10%. At the same time, Oxford reported a downturn in the proportion of applicants from state schools - 54%, down from 56% last year, although it stressed that it was still receiving forms which had been delayed.

Cambridge, like Oxford, expects to see a similar pattern when it publishes its own breakdown of state and independent school applicants in December. Cambridge University said it was the first time for many years that applications had fallen significantly. Over the past 12 years the overall number of applications had risen by over 40%.

Susan Stobbs, director of admissions for the Cambridge colleges, said: "It is too early to tell whether this reflects a national pattern of applications to all universities, since applications to other universities do not have to reach Ucas (the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service) until December 15."

Cambridge said that one reason for the slump might be the introduction of rules which require applicants for veterinary medicine to apply to four institutions, rather than six.

But the final figures, when they are released, will be scrutinised by those interested in the Laura Spence affair - the case of the talented comprehensive schoolgirl who is now studying at Harvard after being rejected by Oxford.

Oxford's vice-chancellor, Dr Colin Lucas, said: "We're disappointed that there is no increase in the number of applications to Oxford from state schools. Indeed, the number has fallen slightly, against an overall rise in applications.

"We felt that we had begun to make real progress in encouraging more students from the maintained sector to apply to Oxford."

A survey compiled for Cambridge Student and published by the Guardian last week showed that one in five students at Cambridge had a parent who studied at Oxbridge.

webTitle: Leader: Barak must not give way to Israel's hawks

fields.headline: Standing up for peace
fields.standfirst:
Barak must not give way to Israel's hawks

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Ehud Barak, Israel's prime minister, would rather save his own skin than pursue the "peace of the brave" to which he committed himself after his election last year. That is the distasteful conclusion that must be drawn from his decision to invite the hawkish Likud leader, Ariel Sharon, to join a national emergency government.
fields.body:
Ehud Barak, Israel's prime minister, would rather save his own skin than pursue the "peace of the brave" to which he committed himself after his election last year. That is the distasteful conclusion that must be drawn from his decision to invite the hawkish Likud leader, Ariel Sharon, to join a national emergency government. Mr Barak appears to have little choice but to seek new parliamentary allies. Without them, his minority coalition is unlikely to survive for long once the Knesset reconvenes next week. Although his One Israel negotiators are also talking to Meretz, Shas, and other, smaller parties, it is the Likud's votes that would most surely guarantee Mr Barak's survival. But the price is too high - and there is another, more honest way.

It is true that Mr Barak has been unfortunate in his peace interlocutors, both in Syria and in Lebanon. In Yasser Arafat, Mr Barak has been confronted by a man lacking the courage to lead, who would rather sacrifice Palestine's children than make the difficult choices that peace requires. It is clear that Mr Arafat had no intention of honouring last week's Sharm el-Sheikh ceasefire, preferring to play the liberation hero to the fickle Arab gallery. His renewed talk of declaring an independent state seems like a cruel fantasy, given that it would lack land, funds, a viable economy and recognition - another of his vainglorious duplicities, except this time the dupes are his own people. Nor, during the present crisis, has Mr Barak been well served by a clumsily brutal, badly trained Israeli army that far too often has answered stones with live rounds. Mr Barak has not just lost his majority; he has lost the propaganda war, too. But the answer is not to give up on peace. There is an alternative.

The terms under which Mr Sharon may agree to join forces with Mr Barak are unacceptably destructive. As deputy prime minister (and possibly finance minister, too), he would want a veto on all diplomatic and security-related decisions. He would insist that negotiating positions adopted at Camp David, especially on Jerusalem and land transfers, be withdrawn. He would oppose any evacuation of Jewish settlements. And he would accept only an interim future accord confining the Palestinians to the 42% of the West Bank over which they currently exercise full or partial control.

Such a regression would convince Arabs that Israel did not want peace at all. It would undermine Egypt's and Jordan's leaders, invigorate extremists, and further alienate Israel's Arab community. And it would encourage the escapist talk within Israel of permanent separation - that is to say, the fencing off, literally, of the Palestinian and Jewish nations from each other; the setting in stone of historic injustice and the institutionalisation of fear and hate. This is another cruel, impracticable fantasy for two peoples who must learn to live together, or suffer alone. Yet there is another way.

Rather than duck, Mr Barak should stand and fight. Rather than cut shabby deals, he should tell Mr Sharon and the likes of Binyamin Netanyahu to get lost. If Knesset support cannot be found elsewhere, he should himself call a general election. And then he should force the public to confront the central question it has dodged since 1967: is Israel at last prepared to pay the high price of peace? If not, does it fully comprehend the awful consequences? Given the current mood, it is a gamble Mr Barak might easily lose. But somebody must show leadership and vision, must make the momentous choice clear - and it will not be Mr Arafat or rightwing Israeli has-beens. Peace or no peace? Let the people decide.

fields.headline: 50-year murder mystery reopens
fields.standfirst: As appeal starts over conviction for murder of judge's daughter, questions asked about who was the killer
fields.trailText: To say Iain Hay Gordon looks haunted is an understatement. But this week, almost half a century after the sensational events which were to shatter his life, the cadaverous 68-year-old Glaswegian is at last set to be cleared of one of the most notorious murders in Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
To say Iain Hay Gordon looks haunted is an understatement. But this week, almost half a century after the sensational events which were to shatter his life, the cadaverous 68-year-old Glaswegian is at last set to be cleared of one of the most notorious murders in Northern Ireland.

The court of appeal in Belfast will today begin to hear his application to have his conviction overturned for the murder of a high court judge's only daughter in November 1952. Sources close to the director of public prosecutions indicate there will be no attempt to sustain the verdict of guilty but insane.

The stabbing of Patricia Curran, 19, whose father, Lancelot Curran, was a former attorney general and Ulster Unionist MP at Stormont, gripped Northern Ireland. Even now, the case is spawning a minor industry in books and screenplays.

With Gordon set to be cleared, speculation will turn to who really killed Miss Curran at the Glen, the family's sumptuous house at Whiteabbey, eight miles north of Belfast. Long-time residents of the village believe Doris Cur ran, the victim's late mother, is the leading suspect.

Gordon was reluctant to be pulled into that controversy as he focused on the start of a hearing scheduled to last three days. He is staying at a hotel close to the site of the Glen, where several houses have been built since the Currans' house was demolished several years ago. He said: "I never gave up, and I feel delighted now to be on the point of vindication after all these years."

His solicitor, Margot Harvey, said his team had eight points which would each demolish the crown's case at the trial in March 1953. The crown is expected to concede that the confession, the only evidence against Gordon, was fabricated, and that the evidence of one witness, which represented a strong alibi, was not disclosed to his defence team.

Gordon was 20 and on national service with the RAF at the nearby Edenmore base at the time of the killing. Many colleagues regarded him as a misfit, but he knew Desmond Curran, the victim's brother, the only other character in the drama still alive, through a shared interest in religion.

Mr Curran, then a barrister, was later to turn his back on the law and on his Presbyter ian upbringing. He is a Catholic priest in South Africa, and says he still believes Gordon was guilty.

Gordon was arrested in January 1953 after Scotland Yard detectives were called in to aid the RUC, under pressure because of the prominence of the victim's father, who was later knighted. Gordon confessed after three days of intense interrogation, when he was told his mother would be told of a homosexual encounter unless he admitted murder. His lawyers, apparently denied evidence which could have cleared him, embarked on the one tactic they felt would save him from the rope. They produced evidence which led him to be found guilty but insane.

He was sent to Holywell mental hospital in Antrim, and spent two years in a closed ward. He was freed after seven years, on the proviso he returned to Glasgow, changed his name and never talked about the case. Only after he retired early as a warehouseman in 1993 did he begin his fight to be cleared.

From the beginning the evidence never added up. Judge Curran and his son found the body at 2am and quickly moved it to a doctor's home nearby, suggesting to an overawed policeman she was still alive even though her arm was stiff with rigor mortis. The doctor at first suggested she had been shot. She had instead been stabbed 37 times. But there was little blood at the scene, suggesting she had died elsewhere and her body dumped.

A pile of her belongings were 10 yards from the body, dry despite the rain, and placed rather than dropped in the scuffle which police had claimed had occurred. Her wristwatch was broken, as if to suggest a fight. But neither the missing hands nor any broken glass were found near the scene.

A pile of her belongings were 10 yards from the body, dry despite the rain, and placed rather than dropped in the scuffle which police had claimed had occurred. Her wristwatch was broken, as if to suggest a fight. But neither the missing hands nor any broken glass were found near the scene.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: Cheshire
fields.body:
Cheshire

The torrential rains of the past two weeks have left their mark in the valley, especially down by the river where, at the height of the downpour, the water rose quickly to over six feet above its normal level. The alder carr and willow ground in the southern woods were battered by a raging torrent from a river four to five times its normal width.

Above the valley, miniature lakes appeared on many of the fields around the village as depressions in the land filled up with the excess water, and it was not too long before the local mallards appeared on several of them, to be joined eventually by moorhens, Canada geese, and small flocks of wandering black-headed gulls.

Over the last few days the river has calmed down and returned to its usual width, but leaving behind layers of silt on the waterside paths, including some very bedraggled and sand encrusted Himalayan balsam, which had been covered in flowers before the rains came down.

Now it is left to the bright yellow of the gorse bushes higher up the bank to provide a splash of brightness over this drab setting. It is a relief to see that the little grebes on the mill pond have stayed this year, despite all the recent turmoil - in similar conditions last year they moved out very quickly - so over the past week I have watched them on several occasions repeatedly diving down into the murky water and seldom reappearing without a small silver fish in their beaks.

Despite the persistent rain, we have had a very mild autumn, so far, and a combination of damp and warmth has produced ground conditions which have been ideal for the woodland fungi.

fields.headline: The defiance of science
fields.standfirst: Last night's TV: Gareth McLean
fields.trailText: Volcano/Ruby/Changing Rooms
fields.body:
Volcanoes, like dinosaurs, exert a primal fascination over humanity. While the memories of ancient cave-dwelling ancestors perhaps still hide embedded in our neural pathways ("Tree, good. Fire, bad", that kind of thing) and keep us genetically in awe of volcanoes, that wouldn't explain our enchantment with dinosaurs. Most likely, our obsession is due to the awesome, slightly fantastical nature of both dinosaurs and volcanoes, their actual existence an affront to our fanatical ordering and taming of the world. They appeal to a deep-rooted, subliminal masochism, a desire for disorder and mayhem: the defiance of science.

Hence these days, humanity's fascination with giant lizards and flaming mountains mainly manifests itself in small boys of a certain age, who enjoy the notion of chaos. Such boys - I am speaking from experience here - draw tableau upon tableau of dinosaurs and volcanoes whenever the opportunity of being alone with a set of Berol felt tip pens arises. (Crayola crayons, I have always been convinced, are for girls, since the colours have names just like lipsticks.) In these drawings, the dinosaurs are sometimes fighting on the slopes of volcanoes. Sometimes they are running from the flowing lava and the falling ash and very occasionally - perhaps after too much orange juice - the dinosaurs are eating the volcanoes whole. (They were big dinosaurs and orange juice contained excessive tartrazine in those days.)

In a strange parallel universe then, I might have turned out like John Seach, a volcanologist who braves noxious clouds of gas, showers of volcanic rocks and smothering rivers of ash to study his chosen subject up close. Volcano (Channel 4) followed John and his colleagues up the slopes of active volcanoes ("If the volcano blew now, John and Geoff [the cameraman] would be incinerated"), down the deserted streets of a town in the shadow of a brewing, spewing volcano ("We need to get out of here now"), to acid lakes ("More corrosive than battery acid") and underwater to examine lava flows ("Blub, blub, ooh, hot").

Volcano didn't cover any ground that a hundred previous documentaries on the subject haven't, but such is the allure of volcanoes themselves, that hardly mattered. It is for the spectacle as well as the science that we watch programmes about super-natural phenomena. John and his ilk may seem like graduates from the Homer Simpson School of Doing Sensible Activities, but their bravery/stupidity is something we all envy slightly. Were it not for the likelihood of a horrible burning death, who wouldn't want to adventure like a volcanologist, if only to see lava up close. (I have always thought lava looks edible. If they ever invent raspberry treacle, it will look like lava.)

Ruby (BBC1) was up close and personal with Roseanne in the first of a 12-part series of conversations over drinks and dinner. (This is a great and underused format which would be really good if, each week, Ruby - or whoever - had a different telly chef make her and her guests a meal before they sat down to a jolly discussion. Parkinson meets Ready Steady Cook, if you will.) An encounter between Ruby and Roseanne could so easily have descended into a competition - of the who-can-strip-paint-with-their-voice-quicker variety - but both women were surprisingly restrained, with the result that a revealing, funny and tender chat developed. Thanks to sparky chemistry, Ruby turned out to be an invigorating watch and could be accorded the highest compliment for a chat show. At 40 minutes, it seemed too short.

Only one thing niggled and that was the identity and purpose of the mysterious couple who were sitting at the other table in Ruby's restaurant? Friends? Lovers? Business partners? Researchers put there to fill an empty space? Whatever, if they thought they were having an illicit meeting, boy are they mistaken.

The Teapot Incident (when Handy Andy and the lovely but shrieky Linda Barker managed to destroy a participant's prized collection of - admittedly hideous - teapots by putting them on shoddy shelves which promptly collapsed) marked an all-time low in designer-participant relations on Changing Rooms (BBC1). Amazingly, members of the public are still letting them into their homes. That isn't the biggest shock however. It would seem Carol Smillie isn't pregnant.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: A Civil Action/Arlington Road/Pi/Live Flesh
fields.body:
A Civil Action

(Steve Zaillian, 1998)

8pm, Sky Premier

John Travolta and true-life dramas really don't mix. A tannery has polluted the drinking water of a nearby town causing children to die of leukemia. The parents have tried for years to get someone to admit responsibility. This is really their story but they are marginalised with Travolta cast as a hot-shot, lawyer who lost everything trying this case. He's brash, cocky, plays by his own rules. In other words he's a Travolta type and no one plays this better than Travolta. Too much of a "movie" to move you.

Arlington Road

(Mark Pellington, 1998)

10pm, Sky Premier

Politics lecturer Jeff Bridges has his doubts about new neighbours Tim Robbins and Joan Cusack. But Bridges is himself a loose cannon, grieving for his FBI-agent wife who was killed in a raid, and preaching a radical agenda at college; so is he paranoid, or are the couple across the street terrorists? Pellington keeps us guessing, and although the climax is a tad obvious, this is anintriguing thriller.

Pi

(Darren Aronofsky, 1997)

10pm, FilmFour

In a strangely disturbing, black-and-white version of reality, Sean Gullette's wacky Max sits in his Chinatown apartment trying to unravel the mysteries of the universe - in the form of the mathematical formula that, he believes, governs the stock market. Is he a visionary embarked on a modern version of the alchemist's quest? Or is it just pi in the sky? Maths has never been this weird, or wonderful.

Live Flesh

(Pedro Almodóvar, 1997)

1.45am, Sky Premier

Almodovar's best film to date. The twisty plot, taken from a Ruth Rendell story, concerns young Victor (Javier Bardem), imprisoned for the accidental shooting of a policeman: when released, Victor finds the girl he loves married to the now paraplegic cop. The mature Almodóvar has toned down the frenetic heat of his comedies. This is an intimate picture of passion, jealousy and revenge, the characters dignified by real emotion and motivation; and all this allied to the old Pedro's vibrant visual style.

webTitle: TV: Getting personal with... Rich Hall

fields.headline: Answer me
fields.standfirst: Getting personal with... Rich Hall
fields.trailText: Getting personal with... Rich Hall
fields.body:
Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why?

As a middleweight boxer, I fought under the name of Chicken Tetrazinni. 23 bouts. Knocked out 24 times.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why?

Of course, I'm in showbusiness.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad?

Hey, there, I'm strong, confident and funny. I'm handsome and debonair, and guess what... I DON'T NEED ANYBODY!! GET IT? BACK OFF! NOBODY'S GETTIN' A PIECE OF ME. NOBODY!

What was the last illegal thing you did?

Shot a man in Reno just to watch him die.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did?

Shot a man in Bracknell just to watch him die. If you've been to Bracknell, you'll understand.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with?

Mark Lamarr.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with?

ZZT (the one without the beard).

Has a critic ever made you cry?

No.

What would you advertise without a fee?

Vincent Motorcycles.

What would you never advertise?

Manny's House of Foam Rubber (80 locations throughout Northern Ohio).

What wakes you up screaming at four in the morning?

Lemurs.

What takes you to a "happy place"?

Any of the parking-lot trams at Disney World, I suppose...

 Rich Hall is Otis Lee Crenshaw at the Jazz Cafe in London, until 26 October. Booking information: 020 7 344 0044.

webTitle: TV guide: Who's in town, and why

fields.headline: Passport control
fields.standfirst: Who's in town, and why
fields.trailText: Who's in town, and why
fields.body:
Life of the mind... A welcome breeze of high culture this week, as peerlessly erudite novelist and raconteur Gore Vidal flits over from his sun-dappled Italian villa to promote his latest novel The Golden Age (the seventh in his series of American historical epics). In fact, the old boy may well already be in town by the time you read this, what with his appointment to give a lecture at The Royal Geographic Society this evening (billed as Europe And The US: A Small Subject), before signing copies of his opus at Hatchards, Piccadilly on Wednesday night.

Notes and queries... Meanwhile, amid the hullabaloo over Cameron Crowe's forthcoming big-screen rock-hack memoir Almost Famous, there could hardly be a better time to greet the arrival of Greil Marcus, world's greatest rock critic and, in his own, professorial way, a man almost as dapper as Gore Vidal. Pitching up next Monday, Marcus is over plugging his new book (there's a lot of it about) Double Trouble: Bill Clinton And Elvis Presley In A Land Of No Alternatives, and then sticks around until Bonfire Night.

The devil has all the best tunes... Which is by way of explaining that German veterans Faust, among the more impressively demented collectives of the Krautrock era, are over to deliver a live soundtrack to FW Murnau's silent classic, Nosferatu, at the Royal Festival Hall tomorrow night. And, like, that's a really weird coincidence when you bear in mind that, after directing his vampire effort, Murnau later made a still massively influential version of ... Faust. See? Isn't that, like, totally weird?

They come from a land down under... Which just leaves time to point out that fey Australian guitar band The Go-Betweens are due over in support of their latest album Friends Of Rachel Worth, playing (perhaps predictably) the Shepherd's Bush Empire on Wednesday night.

webTitle: Boy, 11, questioned after girl is stabbed

fields.headline: Boy, 11, questioned after girl is stabbed
fields.trailText: Lothian and Borders police were last night questioning an 11-year-old boy in connection with the stabbing of a girl, aged nine, near a leisure centre in Edinburgh.
fields.body:
Lothian and Borders police were last night questioning an 11-year-old boy in connection with the stabbing of a girl, aged nine, near a leisure centre in Edinburgh.

The girl, who was stabbed five times in the back, has not been named. She was said to be stable after surgery in the city's Royal Hospital for Sick Children, following the incident just after 2pm yesterday.

It is understood that the girl staggered from a stairwell leading to an underground car park at the Fountainpark centre in the Fountainbridge area of the city. She alerted a woman at a nearby bus stop who called the emergency services and also the centre's security personnel.

Witnesses at the scene said the attack had been caught on CCTV cameras at the centre and police were yesterday reviewing the footage.

One security guard, who refused to give his name, said: "At first it looks like the two children are just speaking to each other but then you actually see the flash of a blade, which is about three inches long. The girl manages to keep on her feet, and then get out of the stairwell to get herself help."

A spokesman for Lothian and Borders police earlier said the force had been seeking a person aged between 12 and 13 years old.

Police said the parents of the girl were at her bedside and that the child's injuries were not thought to be life-threatening.

A spokesman said: "We are conducting door-to-door inquiries and carrying out an investigation around the leisure complex. We sealed the car park and questioned drivers leaving the complex. We would ask anyone who saw this attack or who saw a teenage boy leaving the scene to contact the police."

webTitle: Michael Billington on John Barton's epic play Tantalus

fields.headline: Clash of the titans
fields.standfirst: John Barton’s epic play Tantalus has been given a masterly staging by Peter Hall. So why is Barton so unhappy? Michael Billington reports from Denver
fields.trailText: John Barton’s epic play Tantalus has been given a masterly staging by Peter Hall. So why is Barton so unhappy? Michael Billington reports from Denver.
fields.body:
Borges once described the Falklands war as two bald men fighting over a comb. If the dispute that has broken out between John Barton and Peter Hall - over Hall's adaptation of Barton's epic Tantalus - is not quite that comically futile, it is still deeply dispiriting. These two men are titans of post-war theatre. And, having seen the marathon version of Tantalus, directed by Peter Hall and his son Edward, at the Denver Center for the Performing Arts on Saturday, I can only say that it doesn't feel like a betrayal of Barton's intentions.

What is the source of the dispute? Over a 20-year period, Barton has created in Tantalus a massive theatrical work that deals with the beginnings, climax and aftermath of the Trojan war, based on fragments of a lost epic cycle. These are the bits you won't find in Homer or the Greek dramatists but that complete the myth. Hall became Tantalus's ardent champion and a joint production was set up between the Denver Center and the Royal Shakespeare Company.

At the start of rehearsals, however, Hall and his co-directors (then including the Gate's Mick Gordon) decided Barton's 10-play cycle needed a tougher framework and narrative tightening. Barton refused to budge and left Denver. Rewriting took place in his absence. Hall claims that since then he has had an "abusive" letter from Barton but no further contact. Barton was conspicuously absent from the Denver premiere of the marathon version - rapturously received by the audience - but is due to see it next weekend and, according to Hall, will "almost certainly loathe it". I can't see why he should.

No great travesty has been perpetrated. A quick glance at the printed text from Oberon Books suggests the changes are largely structural, including the removal of one play, Erigone. The evening now begins and ends on a modern Greek beach, where a group of bikini-clad sunbathers are beguiled by a straw-hatted souvenir-seller who offers to tell them "an old story of the golden age and how you all destroyed it". Three questions are raised concerning the Trojan War: Who is to blame? What is the truth of it? How could it have been otherwise?

Over the next 12 hours these questions reverberate in a series of punchy 50-minute plays that are quirky, lively, ironic and sometimes deeply moving - and always looking at old myths from unfamiliar angles. For me Barton is at his best in the three central plays that deal with the actual conduct of the Trojan war. In Neoptolemus, the young son of Achilles is persuaded, despite his passion for truth, to penetrate the Trojan walls disguised as a woman. Persuasion also overcomes reason when Priam, who turns out to be a testy paedophile, is encouraged by the Trojan women to allow the wooden horse to enter the city. And in Odysseus, the morning after the fall of Troy, we see the full horror of war: the women are enslaved and branded, their children are put to the sword and the women are rescued from despair only by Hecuba, who kids Odysseus that Priam's gold is buried in Thrace.

The centre of the triptych is highly impressive. If I find Tantalus, as a whole, less stirring than The Greeks, another 10-play cycle that Barton created for the RSC in 1980, it is for several reasons. There, seven of the 10 plays came from Euripides; Tantalus is entirely Barton's own work and, with all due respect, he is not a genius on the Euripidean scale. The Greeks also dealt with familiar material: not just the fall of Troy but the murder of Agamemnon and the vengefulness of Orestes and Electra. By dealing with the "lost bits" of the myth, Barton here inevitably tackles material that is more marginal, curious and contradictory. Claude Lévi-Strauss once wrote that "the object of myth is to provide a logical model capable of overcoming a contradiction." But here it is the contradictions themselves - such as the doubt over whether Trojan Helen was raped or was a voluntary fugitive - that are part of the work's appeal.

But what will surprise people, since we expect everything Attic to be dusty, is the work's lightness of texture and variety of tone. Everything is played in a circular sandpit strangely reminiscent of a Troilus and Cressida that Peter Hall directed - with Barton doing the fights - at Stratford in 1960; while the costume and lighting designers do a brilliant job of giving every play a different feel. But their visual masterstroke comes in Priam, which starts with Cassandra sitting atop a gigantic, fallen marble head and ends with the upstage reflecting walls parting to reveal the tumbrel-like progress of the vast wheels of the wooden horse.

Hall père et fils , without distorting Barton's intentions, also bring out the work's comedy. The horror of Troy's fall is counterpointed by the absurdity that accompanies it - never more clearly than in the second play, where Agamemnon, having set sail for Troy, returns home prematurely because the fleet forget to take a pilot and land in the wrong place. The arbitrariness of gender is constantly invoked, with the cross-dressed Neoptolemus being reminded: "If you want to be a man, you must first be a girl."

The production's most contentious feature is its attachment to full masks. I can only say that they are less irritating than they were in Hall's 1981 National Theatre production of the Oresteia. They have the practical value of enabling actors to switch character quickly, and that they yield one unforgettable moment when Cassandra and Agamemnon unmask to reveal their longing for each other.

All the acting from the mixed Anglo-American cast is first rate. David Ryall lends his caustic wit to sundry chauvinist gods, Ann Mitchell is a towering Hecuba, Robert Petkoff is the raging Achilles and his son, and Annalee Jefferies switches easily from Clytemnestra to Helen. The overall impression is of a grand production that captures the variety and vigour of these lost myths.

John Barton may feel aggrieved that the purity of his texts has been defiled. But the theatre is a pragmatic place, and the truth is that the two Halls have, out of Barton's vision, created an intriguing, thought- provoking and exhilarating spectacle.

fields.headline: What Kramer did next
fields.standfirst: Tonight, Michael Richards - aka Seinfeld's Cosmo Kramer - launches his new show in the US. But will fans ever be able to see him as anything other than New York's craziest resident?  Mark Morris  reports
fields.trailText: Tonight, Michael Richards - aka Seinfeld's Cosmo Kramer - launches his new show in the US. But will fans ever be able to see him as anything other than New York's craziest resident?
fields.body:
Michael Richards isn't a real New Yorker, but he played one for long enough. Which means he should have a firm grasp of the concept of denial, so beloved of analysts of the old school. But when people ask him whether there is life beyond his glory days as the distinctively coiffured Cosmo Kramer, Richards is liable to get a touch, well, defensive.

In a recent American interview, he said: "Look at Charlton Heston. You never heard people saying, 'Do you think he'll be able to get past Moses?' Has Tom Cruise ever been anybody other than Tom Cruise? I can't say, 'Can I be anything other than Kramer?' Because it is a character and I push on it as a voice, as a mannerism. If you look at my body of work, you'll see there are different characters along the way. I get as far as I can with the material I'm given."

Charlton Heston, it might be noted, never played the motel clerk in Coneheads or the obit writer in So I Married An Axe Murderer. Like it or not, Richards has to accept the fact that we haven't been immersed in his "body of work". Frankly, we know him for Seinfeld or nothing, unless you were one of the few people who saw 1997's Trial And Error. No? Soon, though, we'll start to have a better idea whether Richards really does have another trick up his sleeve, because tonight The Michael Richards Show is making its belated debut in the States. Richards is expecting a bumpy ride.

"My biggest concern is that I may not be given the time to develop the show because expectations are so high. The critics will be merciless. They'll expect it to be the 130th episode of Seinfeld."

It hasn't been a smooth gestation, either. The sitcom has Richards playing Vic Nardozza, an aspiring but far from competent private eye. Inspector Clouseau has been mentioned as the easy reference point, and when early scenes from the show were shown to an advertising conference, they consisted entirely of slapstick. The programme was originally pencilled in as what is known as a mid-season replacement, with a short run, to start in early 2000 rather than the higher pressure, 22-episode autumn debut. From the start, though, the NBC network hedged their bets and said if development was slow, the show could wait till autumn. They opted for the later date early on. By the spring, Richards was having to make statements like "There's no trouble here. I know it seems that way because you haven't seen a pilot. We've got months to prepare."

The show was rejigged, new cast members (including indestructible smoothie - and Knots Landing veteran - William Devane) added. And rumours had it that Richards was being encouraged to play it, well, a little more like Cosmo Kramer. The first and second episodes were swapped at the last moment; an NBC spokesperson claimed that "We wanted to put our best foot forward."

Richards is entitled to point out that Seinfeld was not launched in a blaze of glory. In the early days, the network was very tentative about this odd, low-key sitcom, and it took the public a while to discover it. Even Richards says he didn't have it right from the start. "The real key came about eight or nine shows in. I had been playing Kramer as if he were slow-witted - always one step behind. Then I learned to play Kramer as if he were blocks ahead of what everyone's saying, and I had him."

But The Michael Richards Show will have a very different dynamic from Seinfeld. After all, Seinfeld was about three averagely obsessive, neurotic and discreetly unhinged New Yorkers - and Kramer. Kramer's manic enthusiasms and bursts of rage played off the constant grouching and sniping of the others. Seinfeld was modifying a classic template for the modern sitcom laid down by Taxi. In Taxi, you had the central characters you could empathise with - mournful Judd Hirsch and long-suffering Marilu Henner - and then Christopher Lloyd and Andy Kaufman were free to wreak surreal havoc round the edges (Richards cites Kaufman as a major influence). But the core roles were what pass for normal on TV. Think of how Friends uses Lisa Kudrow as Phoebe. The only major US sitcom of recent times to buck the trend is Third Rock From The Sun, where the main characters are all really eccentric.

So The Michael Richards Show, built around the oddball private eye, will be attempting something difficult. Richards once said that his favourite Seinfeld moments were "Anything that I do where I'm not speaking. I like doing funny rather than saying funny." After a generation of script-reliant sitcoms, having Richards as your star requires trying something a little different. Which could explain why the show has undergone so much tweaking.

But Richards is wrong when he says that critics are gearing up to attack the show. The gap that Seinfeld left is so vast that any small part being filled again will be welcomed. Whatever happens, Richards says he is ready. "I think I'm doing a decent show here. We'll see how it goes. But I can take it on the chin."

webTitle: More measures pledged to help parents to work

fields.headline: More measures pledged to help parents to work
fields.trailText: Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, yesterday stressed the need to reform outdated and inflexible employment practices to allow more parents to return to work.
fields.body:
Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, yesterday stressed the need to reform outdated and inflexible employment practices to allow more parents to return to work.

In a speech to the National Family and Parenting Institute, Mr Byers said a raft of practical measures was needed to overcome the difficulties facing businesses and parents in encouraging parents to return to work.

"In this changing world, it is vital to recognise the pressures on working parents and business," he added.

In June the government launched a discussion document on how parents can be given more choices in balancing their responsibilities at home and work.

A forthcoming green paper would be the most compre hensive review of work and parents ever undertaken, Mr Byers said.

Businesses, especially smaller firms, find existing provisions complex and bureaucratic, particularly on maternity leave and pay while research had also shown that many parents are not aware of their existing rights, Mr Byers added.

Initial findings suggested that awareness of legal rights to take time off for family emergencies is low among employers and parents alike. In addition, the right from last autumn to four weeks paid holiday is not widely known, Mr Byers said.

Earlier this year it was announced that millions more parents would get new rights on family friendly working after ministers opted to extend proposed improvements to include mothers of all children up to 16.

fields.headline: New Lib-Lab deal for poll
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair and Charles Kennedy are preparing to repeat a pre-election arrangement in which Labour and the Liberal Democrat moderate attacks on each other and hold back from pouring resources into the other party's target seats.
fields.body:
Tony Blair and Charles Kennedy are preparing to repeat a pre-election arrangement in which Labour and the Liberal Democrat moderate attacks on each other and hold back from pouring resources into the other party's target seats.

The agreement has the support of the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, who indirectly proposed a similar deal in the run-up to the 1997 election, according to the diaries of Sir Paddy Ashdown, the former Liberal Democrat leader.

The pre-1997 deal was formalised in an understanding between Peter Mandelson and Lord Holme, the parties' campaign managers. A senior Liberal Democrat source said: "There is nothing to stop us doing something similar again. We are bound to reach an implicit understanding on campaign resources."

Sir Paddy insisted yesterday that he was convinced that Mr Blair had not been duplicitous in assuring him at a series of secret meetings that he personally favoured electoral reform.

Throughout the meetings the former Lib Dem leader insisted the prime minister's personal support for electoral reform in a referendum was an indispensable precondition for a coalition.

However, the prime minister's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, said yesterday that he had never heard Mr Blair express support for electoral reform for the Commons. The formal public line has been that Mr Blair is "not persuaded of the case for change".

Sir Paddy said yesterday he was also convinced that Mr Blair would have preferred a post-election coalition with the Liberal Democrats to his wholly unexpected Commons majority of 179. The unexpected size of the majority led the two leaders to abandon their plans for a coalition in which Liberal Democrats would have joined the cabinet.

The idea was revived six months into the Labour government at an October 1997 meeting not covered in this set of diaries. At the meeting Mr Blair and his chief of staff, Jonathan Powell, regretted the failure to act on a coalition on polling day, but discussed the idea of Alan Beith and Menzies Campbell joining the cabinet in 1998.

Mr Blair said at this meeting he needed more time to prepare the ground in his party.

Sir Paddy said yesterday he was convinced that Mr Blair had not abandoned his long-term ambition to achieve a realignment of the left. He said: "Mr Blair does think large and I think he understands the importance of a long-term vision for the left and the country and I think that is in the front of his mind still. I don't think this is a vision which we will easily let go away."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Wolfwhistle warning
fields.body:
Wolfwhistle warning

Council cleaners and repair workers in Gloucester have been sent a memorandum warning them they could face action if they are caught wolf-whistling or shouting sexual innuendoes. The warning comes after harassment complaints made to the council's city services department.

MP beats off Lisbon mugger

Anne McGuire, Labour MP for Stirling, fended off a mugger who tried to steal her handbag on the first day of a holiday in Lisbon during the last week of the Commons' summer recess. She said: "The incident was over very quickly and I think that he got the message that separating a Scottish woman from her money is very difficult."

500kg cocaine seizure

Police and customs yesterday seized 500kg (1,100lb) of cocaine worth £40m after a dawn raid off the coast of the Isle of Wight. The drugs were being transferred from a US-registered sloop on to an inflatable boat. Five people including a British man were arrested at the scene and three women were arrested in towns on the south coast later.

TB screening action urged

New action to counter the rise in tuberculosis, including the screening of immigrants, was urged yesterday in a report from the British Lung Foundation. It said the number of adults and children with the disease had hit a 15-year high.

Crocodile theft

A three-year-old 2kg (4.4lb) west African dwarf crocodile was stolen yesterday from Dudley Zoo. Police believe the 2ft reptile, which could remove someone's fingers with one bite, was taken by children.

Weight risk for baby boys

Baby boys who weigh under 1.5kg (3lb5oz) at birth have much higher death rates and more health problems than low birthweight girls, according to a study published in the Archives of Disease in Childhood yesterday. Male babies also suffered more complications, including poorer lung function, more breathing problems and bleeding in the brain

Export ban on Blake painting

A three-month export ban was imposed on a William Blake watercolour, God Blessing the Seventh Day, yesterday in an attempt to raise about £650,000 to keep it in the country. Two 15th-century silver gilt figures of St Sebastian and St Christopher were also made subject to temporary bars.

Couple die after blast

A couple injured after their next-door neighbour's home in Dundee was wrecked in a gas explosion have died in Ninewells hospital. William Bailey, 67, and his wife, Mary, 58, were injured when the fire spread to their home.

Watch stolen in crutch con

West Midlands police yesterday issued a warning to shopkeepers after a tattooed confidence trickster hobbled into a jewellery shop in Dudley on crutches and sprinted off with a £10,000 18ct gold Rolex Oyster watch.

Young 'more charitable'

Young people are much more willing to give up an hour's pay for charity than their elders, according to a survey for Children's Promise. They found that 79% of 15- to 24-year-olds were prepared to donate an hour's wages to help a child living in poverty, compared to 53% of people over 65.

Game effort

Marilyn Elliott, 46, from Glasgow, the only women in the final of the World Monopoly Championship in Toronto, was the first person to be declared bankrupt. The winner was Yutaka Okada, 33, from Japan.
