fields.headline: Eating disorders blight racing
fields.standfirst: Jockey Club denies anorexia is rife among riders, as Dunwoody becomes latest to confess long battle against condition
fields.trailText: The spectre of eating disorders returned to haunt horse racing yesterday when the former champion jump jockey Richard Dunwoody, one of the sport's leading figures, admitted that his hugely successful career had been blighted by anorexia.
fields.body:
The spectre of eating disorders returned to haunt horse racing yesterday when the former champion jump jockey Richard Dunwoody, one of the sport's leading figures, admitted that his hugely successful career had been blighted by anorexia.

Dunwoody, one of racing's most engaging and popular figures and champion jockey three times, admitted that the desire to make it as a jockey led him to suffer from the eating disorder at the age of 16.

He revealed in his autobiography, Obsessed, which was published yesterday, that while still at school he was admitted to hospital after collapsing and subsequently became obsessed with his weight.

"Concern with my weight became an obsession. The less I ate the less I wanted to eat," he writes. "I hated what anorexia had done to me and hated feeling so helpless. Basically, I had starved myself to be a jockey but in doing so had lost the strength necessary to ride horses."

Jockeys are under constant pressure to keep their weight at a certain level, leading to claims that illnesses such as anorexia and bulimia are common among the country's 400 professional flat and jump jockeys. The former champion jockey Lester Piggott was known for his daily diet of a cup of tea and a cigar.

Dunwoody joins a notable list of jockeys who have revealed that they suffered from eating disorders in an attempt to maintain their weight at a low level.

The former champion jump jockey Steve Cauthen, who was known as the Kentucky Kid, confessed after retiring from horse racing that he suffered from bulimia, while another jump jockey, Walter Swinburn, who retired earlier this year, said he suffered from a similar disease.

There are no figures available on how many jockeys suffer from eating disorders and few who are currently racing are willing to confess to any problems, fearing that it might lead to an end to their careers. In the macho world of horse racing the issue of male eating disorders has also proved difficult to raise.

Dunwoody, who retired last December, wrote: "There was not much understanding of these things and it was unheard of for boys to be anorexic."

According to horse racing rules, jump jockeys must weigh between 10 stone and 12 stone, while flat racing jockeys have to weigh between 7 stone 7 lb and 9 stone.

Almost all jockeys take long, hot baths and saunas on a daily basis in an attempt to maintain their weight. The taking of laxatives and diuretics, pills which help one to urinate frequently, was also quite common, but both substances were banned in 1998 by the Jockey Club, horse racing's governing body. Jockeys who test positive for these drugs face being barred from the sport. Until now, only one has tested positive.

A spokeswoman for the Jockey Club said: "We don't have any evidence of eating disorders being widespread within horse racing. It is not a big problem.

"We are constantly monitoring the situation and if there was any concern that jockeys are finding it difficult to reach certain weights then we would address it."

The jockeys themselves, however, confess that they are constantly under pressure in the battle to keep their weight down. The current champion jump jockey, Tony McCoy, said that he often survives on a cup of tea and a bar of chocolate a day when he is racing.

McCoy, who has won 93 races this season, also confessed to taking laxatives while an apprentice jockey.

McCoy said: "When I am racing I eat once a day, if I'm lucky. You get used to dealing with hunger, it's about having the right mental attitude. I have taken laxatives in the past and I would not do that again but I was desperate to get my weight down.

"There is a lot of pressure on jockeys, particularly the younger ones who are trying to get rides. It can be very difficult to maintain your weight at a low level. It is a constant battle. I would love to have breakfast and dinner every day but its not something I can do when I'm racing."

McCoy, who is 26, weighs 10st 8lb, and is 5ft 10in tall, added: "When I have to ride at 10 stone then it can be a real struggle to get my weight down. All I will have is a cup of tea during the day. Under normal circumstances a man of my size should weigh about 11 and a half stone."

In an attempt to make jockeys aware of eating disorders, the Jockey Club has been running an awareness campaign informing them about healthy diets and the best way to restrict weight increase. Seminars about diet are regularly held and leaflets are available to jockeys on healthy eating.

Ultimately, however, all those within horse racing concede that because the weight of a jockey is so crucial in the sport it will always remain a problematic area.

A spokesman for the Jockeys' Association, which represents the country's jockeys, said: "The problems associated with a jockey's weight have been with us since horse racing was invented.

"Jockeys have to diet very hard, they can't lead a normal eating existence. Very few are able to eat like you or I, it just can't be done. It's always been like that for jockeys."

The Jockey Club: www.thejockeyclub.co.uk

fields.headline: Jury hears boy's 999 murder call
fields.trailText: A six-year-old boy pleaded with his father not to kill him during a 999 call which the boy made shortly before his throat was cut, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A six-year-old boy pleaded with his father not to kill him during a 999 call which the boy made shortly before his throat was cut, a court heard yesterday.

Zainulabedin Zaidi, 34, is accused of murdering his former wife, Shazia, and their children Saba, seven, and her younger brother, Zeshan, six, at their home in Bracknell, Berkshire.

While his father was stabbing his mother and sister, Zeshan managed to phone the emergency services and the call was taped, Reading crown court heard. The 109-second call was played to a jury yesterday.

The boy told an operator: "My dad is getting my mum and stabbing and killing her."

Shortly after the call was made, Zaidi allegedly cut his son's throat.

Adrian Redgrave QC, prosecuting, told the court that Zaidi had driven to his former wife's home in Great Hollands, Bracknell, in March and attacked her with a knife.

"He stabbed her in the face, the chest and several times in the neck," Mr Redgrave said. "She suffered wounds as deep as 20 centimetres, which killed her. The two children saw that happening."

Mr Redgrave said a minute or so after Shazia was killed, a child's voice could be heard screaming: "Don't kill me daddy."

"But he did. In cold blood, he stabbed those two children," Mr Redgrave said. "The conclusion is inescapable - the child that was last to die must have witnessed not only the killing of their mother, but also the other child.

"Each of those children died from stab wounds in their neck and to the throat and their bodies lay a few feet from one another."

The court was told that the children were found dead in an upstairs bedroom and their mother's body was discovered in the living room.

The jury heard that after the murder, Zaidi asked a friend for shelter, saying that he had domestic problems. But the friend went to the police after hearing of the murders and Zaidi was arrested.

The couple's six-year marriage had ended in 1997 and they divorced the following year. Shazia, 28, remarried in 1999 and she tried to keep the news of the wedding a secret from her first husband, who had weekend access to their children.

The first marriage had failed because of Zaidi's jealousy. He had forbidden his wife from leaving the house by herself, the court heard.

Zaidi denies murder and claims that his former wife's new husband, Saeed Dogar, murdered the family.

The prosecution said it was impossible for Mr Dogar to have been at the house at the time of the murders. At 3.45pm he was at a butcher's shop in Chalvey, near Slough, a half-hour drive away. Zeshan's call was logged at 4.09pm.

The trial continues.

fields.headline: No: 1747
fields.standfirst: Bill and Ben
fields.trailText: Bill and Ben
fields.body:
Who are they? Famed neighbours given to speaking in jargon impenetrable to adult ears.

You mean Tony Blair and Gordon Brown? No, I mean those two TV favourites bouncing around at the bottom of the garden.

Ah. Charlie Dimmock. Wrong again. I mean those guys who hung around with a Little Weed.

The shadow cabinet. D'oh!

Just my little joke. It's the seminal kids' telly show, isn't it? Indeed. From 1952 until 1971, nippers across the land wowed to the Flowerpot Men's unforgettable adventures.

What kind of adventures? Well, they got out of their flowerpots from time to time, lolloped about and then got back in again.

Not exactly The Odyssey, is it? Ah, but those were innocent times. Witness the title of Bill and Ben's umbrella series, Watch with Mother.

You wouldn't get that these days. Watch with Parent or Guardian of Either Gender doesn't have the same ring.

Orthodox theory of Bill and Ben's success: Sprogs couldn't get enough of their "flobbalob, shobbalob" conversation, devised by narrator Peter Hawkins.

Unorthodox theory of their success: Bill symbolises Baal, the Phoenician sun god, while Ben symbolises Big Ben and the mechanisation of time.

Bill and Ben's theory of their success: Flobbalob, shobbalob.

So is this another kids' TV comeback story? Indeed. The hardy perennials of tots' telly are being cultivated afresh by the BBC next summer - in full colour, with new characters, and using stop-motion animation instead of string puppets.

No strings. Whatever next? Rumours of a computer-generated Muffin the Mule are as yet unconfirmed.

Token assurance to purists: "It is very much a slight progression," says the BBC, "from where Bill and Ben were before."

Likely to be discussed by: Drunken thirtysomethings at dinner parties; Phoenician theology scholars.

Unlikely to be watched by: 21st-century children.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • We are delighted to introduce readers to a New Labour chameleon to put even Mr Tony Blair, the lovable leprechaun of political craic, to shame. He is would-be MP Shahid Malik, and his ubiquity is matched only by his imagination. When seeking selection in Preston (he's also tried Brent East, Tottenham, Leeds Central and others), he wrote: "Although I was brought up in Burnley, I spent much of my teenage years playing snooker at Preston's Royal Snooker Suite." Aha. He announces himself as the first black or Asian person to win election to Labour's NEC constituencies section (news to Diane Abbott), and boasts of "a role in two of our country's defining moments - the Good Friday Agreement and the Stephen Lawrence inquiry." And in a glossy leaflet packed with Michael Winner-style poses with Gerry Adams, Mo Mowlam, Baldrick and others, this intriguing Zelig figure reveals: "I was born in a mining hospital in Burnley". A what? What a character. Will someone please find him a seat forthwith?

 We are delighted to introduce readers to a New Labour chameleon to put even Mr Tony Blair, the lovable leprechaun of political craic, to shame. He is would-be MP Shahid Malik, and his ubiquity is matched only by his imagination. When seeking selection in Preston (he's also tried Brent East, Tottenham, Leeds Central and others), he wrote: "Although I was brought up in Burnley, I spent much of my teenage years playing snooker at Preston's Royal Snooker Suite." Aha. He announces himself as the first black or Asian person to win election to Labour's NEC constituencies section (news to Diane Abbott), and boasts of "a role in two of our country's defining moments - the Good Friday Agreement and the Stephen Lawrence inquiry." And in a glossy leaflet packed with Michael Winner-style poses with Gerry Adams, Mo Mowlam, Baldrick and others, this intriguing Zelig figure reveals: "I was born in a mining hospital in Burnley". A what? What a character. Will someone please find him a seat forthwith?

 BBC1's unbearably exciting breakfast show reveals sound editorial judgment. Yesterday Gore Vidal was on, talking about the American election, and they gave him about 90 seconds before interrupting him mid-sentence in favour of bus timetable news or something equally diverting. Brilliant. Although this column had a spat with Gore a while back (I recall a fax referring to someone as "Nellie Norman"), we love this wittiest and most splendid of men to bits. Ah, but if only he hadn't been riven by self-doubt, who knows what he might not have made of himself.

 Many will share the regret of Fatty "Nicholas" Soames, Kenneth Roy and others at the lack of deference in modern society. So well done Harrow council, for deciding to gift Harrow public school its own road! Harrow already owns part of Grove Hill, but the council wants to extend this right up to the school gates - and at no cost to the £15,000 per annum school. Harrow claims this is essential for safety reasons, but locals, furious at the council's sycophancy, insist usual calming measures (humps, that sort of thing) would be fine. These people should know their place. Even if they can't bring themselves to line up on Grove Hill on the first day of term and do a bit of hat-doffing, the least the silly arses can do is hold their peasant tongues.

 Thanks to all the readers who have suggested possible cast members for Carry On Up the Cabinet. Our email postbag is bulging, if digital messages can be said to bulge. I'm especially intrigued by the high number of nominations for Hattie Jacques to play the role of weirdo chancellor Gordon Brown. We are likely to stretch this subject out over the months to come, so keep the ideas coming.

 A mayday call has been picked up from the world of high art. The performers behind the acclaimed interpretative show Puppetry of the Penis, running at the Whitehall Theatre in London, have run into a problem. Their insurers are insisting that they take on an understudy as soon as possible. "Obviously they would need to have a talent for genital origami and an excellent stretch factor," says Katherine Camps, a spokesperson for the show. They'd also need an Australian or similar accent. The potential understudies will be called to a closed audition, and may be asked to perform some of the more complex installations, such as "The Pelican". Anyone interested should get in touch with the Diary. No photographs, please.

 On the subject of Australian high art, today sees the opening of the magnificent new exhibition by Roger Law of Spitting Image fame at the Rebecca Hossack Gallery (35 Windmill Street, W1). The show's open until November 25, but queues are probably already forming around the block. (Can we please keep the Gerald Kaufman puppet now, Roger?)

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Banks act over dirty money
fields.body:
Banks act over dirty money

Twelve leading banks have agreed a uniform international code for combating money laundering and will present the accord on Monday, Switzerland's biggest bank, UBS, said in Zurich yesterday.

The Wolfsberg guidelines, named after the UBS training centre in Switzerland where they were agreed, aim to prevent criminal proceeds entering the world financial system.

The guidelines apply to private banking, where banks cater to wealthy individuals. UBS did not name the other banks involved.

Lauda rescues his airline

Former Formula One triple world champion Niki Lauda yesterday pressed through a rescue package for his beleaguered airline Lauda Air.

Lauda and his biggest shareholder, Austrian Airlines, had been at odds over how to keep the airline in the air after mounting losses risked bankrupting the country's number two carrier.

But after another marathon meeting yesterday, the supervisory board of Lauda Air tacitly accepted Lauda's plan to free up hidden reserves of 1.1bn schillings ($67m) through a sale-and-leaseback deal on five aircraft.

OFT to judge Go-Ahead bid

The office of fair trading is to try to extract concessions from French consortium C3D and Rhne Capital, which are bidding to take over road and rail operator Go-Ahead Group, it emerged yesterday.

The OFT has four months to reach a decision after the European commission referred the case back to British authorities. If the OFT fails to resolve the matter amicably it can pass it on to the competition commission.

Brussels said yesterday that the takeover might create a dominant position on bus routes in London and acknowledged that British authorities were best placed to judge this.

Consumer affairs minister Kim Howells welcomed the decision.

Kingfisher frees Holmes

Marks & Spencer's new retail director, Roger Holmes, will start work at the beginning of January, following agreement from his current employer, Kingfisher, that he can leave without serving his full notice period.

Kingfisher had threatened legal action to hold Mr Holmes to his 12-month contract as boss of its electrical division. However, the two companies have reached a compromise without any money changing hands.

Industry sources said Kingfisher had realised it was not practical to force a senior director to continue working.

EC approves Glaxo Aids drug

Glaxo Wellcome has received approval from the European comission to market its protease inhibitor Aids drug, Agenerase, in all 15 countries of the European Union.

The drug, which recorded sales of £25m in the first half of 2000, is currently approved and marketed in 10 countries, including Brazil, Ghana, Israel and the US.

fields.headline: 'Too good to pass up' GE snares Honeywell for $45bn
fields.trailText: General Electric's acquisition of Honeywell for $45bn in stock at the weekend further solidifies the company's presence in aerospace. Chairman Jack Welch is postponing his planned retirement until the end of 2001 to oversee consolidation of the deal.
fields.body:
General Electric's acquisition of Honeywell for $45bn in stock at the weekend further solidifies the company's presence in aerospace. Chairman Jack Welch is postponing his planned retirement until the end of 2001 to oversee consolidation of the deal.

He said Honeywell was too good to pass up, and derided suggestions that GE should have been shopping for a new economy company. "We're merging two real hi-tech companies, with real earnings that do real things," said the manwidely credited with transforming a company best known for making light bulbs and appliances into an empire.

GE will pay 1.055 of its shares or $54.99 for each of Honeywell's 801m outstanding shares but also assume an unspecified amount of Honeywell debt. The latter's headquarters in Morristown, New Jersey, will be closed and about 550 employees there may lose their jobs. The deal is also expected to raise anti-trust concerns among US and European regulators, who could require the combined company to divest some of its businesses.

fields.headline: Lucent sacks top officials
fields.standfirst: Telecommunications firm announces yet another profits warning
fields.trailText: Lucent, America's largest telecommunications equipment manufacturer, ousted its chairman and chief executive yesterday as it announced its fourth profits warning this year.
fields.body:
Lucent, America's largest telecommunications equipment manufacturer, ousted its chairman and chief executive yesterday as it announced its fourth profits warning this year.

The decision to slash expectations for the current quarter and announce a root-and-branch reorganisation hurt the global telecommunications equipment industry.

In London, Marconi lost 5% at one stage, ending 18p off at 920. Alcatel shares were knocked in Paris, slipping 0.45 euros to 76 euros in heavy trading.

Shares in Lucent rose 4% to $23.50 on the news, however, as investors welcomed the departure of Richard McGinn as chief executive after a disastrous nine months. Lucent, a former stock market darling, was trading at $84 last December before the first of a series of warnings.

The company dispensed with the usual platitudes on the departure of a chief executive yesterday in a statement accompanying the profits warning. The board said it was "determined that an immediate change in leadership was necessary".

Mr McGinn, who helped to launch Lucent when it was spun off from AT&T three years ago, was unavailable for comment. As recently as last week, he told the Wall Street Journal that he was not considering stepping down and that the board had not asked him to do so.

The board apparently changed its mind this weekend when it found that earnings in the final three months of this year would be even worse than expected just two weeks ago.

Lucent now expects simply to break even after suffering a 7% decline in pro-forma revenues in the three months to the end of December. Analysts reduced their earnings expectations to 17 cents just two weeks ago, according to First Call/Thomson Financial.

The company, which moved forward its fourth-quarter earnings results by a day, was expected to announce a charge related to a significant restructuring. Lucent is spinning off non-core businesses, including its microelectronics unit, to focus on high-growth areas such as the broadband market.

Henry Schacht, the 66-year-old who led the company before Mr McGinn, is to become interim chief executive while Lucent seeks a replacement.

Steve Ballmer, the chief executive of Microsoft, the software group, yesterday predicted further disappointments when he said that some hi-tech stocks still remained overvalued.

fields.headline: Geo Interactive rejects ex-investor's claim
fields.trailText: Geo Interactive, the Israeli company whose products permit video-quality images and sound to be transmitted to mobile phones and computers, yesterday dismissed as "pathetic" a former investor's claim that it was entitled to a 50% share-holding in the firm.
fields.body:
Geo Interactive, the Israeli company whose products permit video-quality images and sound to be transmitted to mobile phones and computers, yesterday dismissed as "pathetic" a former investor's claim that it was entitled to a 50% share-holding in the firm.

"This claim has no legal merits, it is totally baseless, legally wrong and is totally composed of false statements," a statement from Geo said of the claim from the Jerusalem-based software house Malam Systems.

"The sole purpose of their claim is a pathetic and opportunistic attempt to extort Geo into a cash settlement via massive public pressure."

Geo's stinging indictment was issued after reports of the pending legal action from Malam had knocked its share price back 12%.

The statement appeared to calm investors fears and the shares rallied in afternoon, closing down just 5% at £10.10p.

The background to the claim is complex but relates to an investment that Malam made in Geo in the mid-90s which was later declared null and void. The investment was made when Geo was just a tiny company and Malam says that it was misled into nullifying its investment.

Malam now wants to return to Geo the 1.6m Israeli shekels (£270,000) that it originally invested and claim 50.1% of the company. Malam is reported to be claiming that it has documents to support its case but could not be contacted for comment yesterday.

A Geo spokesman said he was mystified as to why the claim had suddenly been made.

The two firms have had contrasting fortunes since the investment was annulled. Malam is now valued at $51m on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange, while Geo is worth around $1.7bn in London.

webTitle: AT&T may demerge to counter share price fall

fields.headline: AT&T may demerge to counter share price fall
fields.trailText: US telecommunications group AT&T is considering a plan to split itself into four separate businesses in a dramatic attempt to lift its flagging share price.
fields.body:
US telecommunications group AT&T is considering a plan to split itself into four separate businesses in a dramatic attempt to lift its flagging share price.

The move would be the most significant restructuring of the company since it was forcibly broken up by government decree in 1984. It would also reverse the strategy, adopted by Michael Armstrong when he was appointed chief executive three years ago, of building a cable and telecommunications giant.

It also comes at a time when AT&T and British Telecom are looking at plans to merge their business divisions, and possibly forge even closer links.

A spokesman for AT&T declined to comment on reports that the board was due to announce the restructuring tomorrow at the same time as unveiling third-quarter results.

Wall Street analysts and fund managers have been calling for action from the company for several months as revenues at its core long-distance service for consumers have fallen sharply.

Shares in the company have fallen from a 52-week high of $61 in April to a low of $21.25 earlier this month. Yesterday, they edged up marginally to $27.06 as shareholders waited for details of the announcement to emerge.

Under the proposal, understood to have been put to board members yesterday, AT&T would spin off its low-margin consumer division as well as its wireless, broadband and corporate arms. Adam Quinton, analyst at Merrill Lynch, said yesterday that such a four-way split would be "dramatic given the scale of the company".

He described the code name understood to have been given to the plan - Project Grand Slam - as "appropriate perhaps".

AT&T, which already has an international joint venture with BT, is $57bn in debt. This would need to be doled out to its four offspring in the event of a demerger.

Despite the enormity of the proposals, Concert, the company's existing joint venture with BT, could remain largely unaffected as it has a separate management team.

fields.headline: Bullying victim wins £1,500
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: A teenager has won £1,500 damages from his local authority because a grammar school failed to prevent him being bullied - the first successful legal action over bullying in over 30 years.
fields.body:
A teenager has won £1,500 damages from his local authority because a grammar school failed to prevent him being bullied - the first successful legal action over bullying in over 30 years.

The 17-year-old student, who cannot be named, suffered an 18-month campaign of verbal abuse when he was 12 and form captain at a grammar school in Greater Manchester. He was nicknamed the lanky loner and suffered verbal abuse about his sexual orientation which culminated in a sexual attack by two room-mates during a school trip abroad.

Judge Richard Holman at Manchester county court concluded on October 11 that the school was in breach of its duty of care for failing to stop the verbal abuse. But he ruled that teachers could not have foreseen the bullying would escalate to sexual assault.

He said: "The school is not on trial. All three teachers who gave evidence are plainly dedicated, with the interests of the children at heart, but nobody is perfect."

The boy had started a bullying diary to record his experiences and tried to record jibes on a pocket-sized tape recorder but failed. When his teacher asked him if everything was alright, he told her it was.

The boy's parents have called for the school's headteacher to resign.

Trafford council's director of education, Chris Pratt, said: "We decided to defend the case in court rather than settle outside and that has proved to be justified. The school did a lot to try and support this young boy, but the jury felt staff may not have been sufficiently proactive in challenging the perpetrators.

"The case was very regrettable, but the judge said he was not criticising individual members of staff. I don't think the head should resign. I have every confidence in her."

Helen Rimington, director of the education unit at the Children's Legal Centre, said the case was the first successful legal action since 1969. But the number of cases coming to court for compensation against bullying was increasing.

Another teenager who claimed she had been left pyschologically scarred by three years of "persistent and prolonged bullying" at a school in West Sussex yesterday began a battle for £75,000 damages at the high court in London.

Leah Bradford-Smart, now 19, alleged that West Sussex county council failed to protect her from persistent bullying at Ifield middle school, Crawley. She told the court that she had been taunted, chased around the playground, thrown against fences and was once pushed into the road in front of a car as she waited for the school bus.

The county council denies liability, claiming that the school's then headteacher had a stringent anti-bullying policy in place.

The case continues.

fields.headline: Blu wrecks Italian auction
fields.trailText: Italy's sale of its third generation mobile phone licences descended into farce last night after the British Telecom backed Blu consortium brought the auction to a juddering halt, leaving the country's treasury with only half the expected proceeds.
fields.byline: Mark Milner  and  Rory Carroll  in Rome
fields.body:
Italy's sale of its third generation mobile phone licences descended into farce last night after the British Telecom backed Blu consortium brought the auction to a juddering halt, leaving the country's treasury with only half the expected proceeds.

The government came under heavy criticism for the flop. There were calls for the auction to be annulled and demands for top level resignations, including those of prime minister Giuliano Amato and communications minister Salvatore Cardinale.

The sale had been expected to raise between 20bn euros and 30bn euros but Blu's withdrawal - which left the same number of bidders as licences - brought the auction to an end with just 12bn euros on the table.

Ministers were called to a hastily assembled meeting as the search got underway for legal grounds to annul the result and rerun the bidding process.

BT tried hard over the weekend to keep Blu in the bidding - offering to increase its 20% stake in the consortium and to make a one-off payment of 500bn lire.

But it managed to muster just over 50% support to continue the bid, instead of the necessary 80% and, crucially, it failed to persaude the Benetton family which, directly and indirectly, speaks for 41% of Blu.

"BT was prepared to raise its stake and take more of the risk in Blu but could not take the amount that other shareholders demanded as the price of continuing the bidding," the company said in a statement.

Italian industry sources said some of the Blu shareholders had been pressing for a rebalancing of the share structure for some time. "It was a problem of the weight of the stakes," said one.

The UK company declined to detail the level to which it was prepared to raise its stake but there has been speculation that it would have gone to the 30% level. However other shareholders wanted it to go much higher.

With BT already burdened with debts running at a figure approaching £30bn, its room for manoeuvre was limited. "We could not continue at any price. It would not have made financial sense to take the increased risk ... that would have come from a very large stake [in Blu]," said a spokeswoman.

BT's strategy and development director Pat Gallagher said he was disappointed by the outcome but said BT would continue with its Italian strategy and would continue to look for ways to "plug the gap" left by the failure to win a licence.

News of the less costly than expected outcome to the auction was greeted by relief among telecoms investors worried about the level of debt being incurred by companies in their efforts to build up portfolios of 3G licences.

Merrill Lynch analyst Victoria Granger noted that BT was not the only telecoms company to accept compromise. "Remember that Deutsche Telekom did not even bid in Italy," she said.

But if there was relief in the financial markets that Italian licences would be cheaper than those in the UK and Germany, the Rome government found its newly launched election campaign in tatters as it stood accused of losing a windfall that could have helped regions devastated by floods.

Meanwhile BT and One2 One were in the High Court in London yesterday in a dispute over the UK mobile phone auction.

The two claim they have been disadvantaged by the extension of time given to rivals Vodafone and Orange to come up with payment to the government, following their successful multi-billion pound bids for the new licences.

The challenge is expected to last four days.

fields.headline: Europe keeps outsourcing within bounds
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Despite the hype about new technology allowing companies to locate call centres and support services anywhere in the world, European companies stick close to home.
fields.body:
Despite the hype about new technology allowing companies to locate call centres and support services anywhere in the world, European companies stick close to home.

Holland is the e-work capital of the region, research published today shows.

Of the top 10 locations for remote information working, the Netherlands accounts for four, according to the research by the Institute of Employment Studies in Brighton.

"For every English company setting up a call centre in India, there's 10 more establishing one in the north-east," said Ursula Huws, who directs the Emergence research project.

Although countries as diverse as Morocco, Australia, India, Canada, Japan and South Africa are establishing niches in e-work, the majority of European companies prefer to outsource their activities to their own regions.

Only 12% of firms look further afield.

The most popular location for outsourced business activities is Lombardy in Italy, followed by the west Netherlands, the Madrid region, north-east Spain, north-east Italy, east Netherlands, south Netherlands, the Paris region, Brussels region and north Netherlands.

Ms Huws said firms were attracted to northern Italy by a favourable tax regime which encourages bigger firms to break down their activities into several different business units. Holland benefited from a multilingual workforce.

"Nearly everyone speaks good English, German and French," said Ms Huws.

The Netherlands is also a clear leader in teleworking from home, with 10% of all employers using full-time home teleworkers, followed by Sweden and Denmark, each with 5%, and Austria and Belgium, each with 4%.

Despite the profusion of laptops, mobile phones and other electronic devices, which in theory allow people to work any time, any place, only 6% of employers are using new technology to allow their employees to work nomadically.

Nomadic workers are most common in Poland and Denmark (15%), followed by the Czech Republic (13%), Finland (10%), Sweden and Belgium (7%), Austria and Spain (7%), Italy, the Netherlands and Portugal (5%), and France, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Ireland and Britain (4%).

The finding are based on interviews with nearly 8,000 employers in 18 countries.

webTitle: Head's relief as mistreatment claims dropped

fields.headline: Head's relief as mistreatment claims dropped
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Marjorie Evans, the headteacher cleared of slapping a boy across the face last month, will not be charged over separate claims of mistreating pupils, police said yesterday.
fields.body:
Marjorie Evans, the headteacher cleared of slapping a boy across the face last month, will not be charged over separate claims of mistreating pupils, police said yesterday.

The fresh allegations of inappropriate emotional and physical handling of pupils at St Mary's junior school in Caldicot, Monmouthshire, were made last month after Mrs Evans, 56, successfully appealed against conviction and a three-month suspended prison sentence for common assault against the 10-year-old special needs pupil.

Chief Inspector Nigel Russell of Gwent police said all information from the investigation would be forwarded to Monmouthshire county council for any action it, and the governors, considered appropriate.

Mrs Evans has been suspended from her position since the first allegations were made in September 1999.

School governors are to meet tomorrow to discuss whether disciplinary action will be taken against her or whether she will be reinstated.

Mrs Evans said yesterday that she was relieved that the CPS had decided not to prosecute her but angry that proceedings had taken so long.

"I have lost a year of my life despite having done nothing wrong," she said. "I was an ordinary headteacher, carrying out the same duties as thousands of other head teachers across the country.

"It distresses me to think that any one of the teaching profession could have false or malicious allegations made against them and have to suffer the same ordeal."

Mrs Evans said she was waiting for the National Union of Teachers to discuss her return to work with the school and the local education authority.

The crown prosecution service examined 33 witness statements, video evidence and records of interviews concerning the 10 allegations of assault and cruelty against 11 children at St Mary's. Police were told that there was no realistic prospect of conviction.

Mrs Evans's supporters have claimed there has been a witch-hunt, but a CPS spokesman said that police had investigated her case "without any preconceptions".

At last month's appeal hearing at Cardiff crown court, Mr Justice McKinnon, quashing her conviction following a trial before Abergavenny magistrates in July, said evidence against Mrs Evans was "conflicting" and "unsatisfactory".

The special needs pupil had accused her of slapping him when he became difficult after being told that he could not go swimming with his classmates because of previous bad behaviour.

Phil Cooke, director of life-long learning at Monmouthshire county council, said that the school governors had given "no conditions and no time-frame" for Mrs Evans's reinstatement when they suspended her last year.

Dyfan Jones, a spokesman for the National Union of Teachers Cymru, said that Mrs Evans wanted to return to the school. "I don't think she'd be able to return at the moment on health grounds. The stress has made her ill," he said.

Two other teachers at the school who were investigated in connection with the allegations of mistreatment have also been cleared.

Janet Bowen, one of the teachers, has been unable to return to work due to illness caused by the stress of the investigation.

Gethin Lewis, secretary of NUT Cymru said: "We had no doubts about Marj's innocence. We don't think the proper procedures for dealing with allegations against teachers were followed in this case.

"It's important to listen to the children but also to recognise that people who work in schools are vulnerable."

Graham Powell, who lost his post as chairman of governors at St Mary's last month and has been a strong supporter of Mrs Evans throughout her suspension, called for the governors to reinstate her at the earliest opportunity.

"On what grounds can they not reinstate her? The law has decided she's innocent. Failure to do so is open to severe criticism," he said.

Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the NUT said: "There are lessons to be learned from the way this matter has been conducted." He added that new guidelines on dealing with disruptive children will be distributed to union members this week.
fields.bodyText: Marjorie Evans, the headteacher cleared of slapping a boy across the face last month, will not be charged over separate claims of mistreating pupils, police said yesterday. The fresh allegations of inappropriate emotional and physical handling of pupils at St Mary's junior school in Caldicot, Monmouthshire, were made last month after Mrs Evans, 56, successfully appealed against conviction and a three-month suspended prison sentence for common assault against the 10-year-old special needs pupil. Chief Inspector Nigel Russell of Gwent police said all information from the investigation would be forwarded to Monmouthshire county council for any action it, and the governors, considered appropriate. Mrs Evans has been suspended from her position since the first allegations were made in September 1999. School governors are to meet tomorrow to discuss whether disciplinary action will be taken against her or whether she will be reinstated. Mrs Evans said yesterday that she was relieved that the CPS had decided not to prosecute her but angry that proceedings had taken so long. "I have lost a year of my life despite having done nothing wrong," she said. "I was an ordinary headteacher, carrying out the same duties as thousands of other head teachers across the country. "It distresses me to think that any one of the teaching profession could have false or malicious allegations made against them and have to suffer the same ordeal." Mrs Evans said she was waiting for the National Union of Teachers to discuss her return to work with the school and the local education authority. The crown prosecution service examined 33 witness statements, video evidence and records of interviews concerning the 10 allegations of assault and cruelty against 11 children at St Mary's. Police were told that there was no realistic prospect of conviction. Mrs Evans's supporters have claimed there has been a witch-hunt, but a CPS spokesman said that police had investigated her case "without any preconceptions". At last month's appeal hearing at Cardiff crown court, Mr Justice McKinnon, quashing her conviction following a trial before Abergavenny magistrates in July, said evidence against Mrs Evans was "conflicting" and "unsatisfactory". The special needs pupil had accused her of slapping him when he became difficult after being told that he could not go swimming with his classmates because of previous bad behaviour. Phil Cooke, director of life-long learning at Monmouthshire county council, said that the school governors had given "no conditions and no time-frame" for Mrs Evans's reinstatement when they suspended her last year. Dyfan Jones, a spokesman for the National Union of Teachers Cymru, said that Mrs Evans wanted to return to the school. "I don't think she'd be able to return at the moment on health grounds. The stress has made her ill," he said. Two other teachers at the school who were investigated in connection with the allegations of mistreatment have also been cleared. Janet Bowen, one of the teachers, has been unable to return to work due to illness caused by the stress of the investigation. Gethin Lewis, secretary of NUT Cymru said: "We had no doubts about Marj's innocence. We don't think the proper procedures for dealing with allegations against teachers were followed in this case. "It's important to listen to the children but also to recognise that people who work in schools are vulnerable." Graham Powell, who lost his post as chairman of governors at St Mary's last month and has been a strong supporter of Mrs Evans throughout her suspension, called for the governors to reinstate her at the earliest opportunity. "On what grounds can they not reinstate her? The law has decided she's innocent. Failure to do so is open to severe criticism," he said. Doug McAvoy, general secretary of the NUT said: "There are lessons to be learned from the way this matter has been conducted." He added that new guidelines on dealing with disruptive children will be distributed to union members this week.

fields.headline: Another wolf at our door
fields.standfirst:
Exactly like the Roaring 20s, the latest economic 'miracle' has been bought on credit

Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Jeremy Rifkin: While the US presidential debates were in full swing, I was pondering what I would ask the candidates if I had the opportunity to pose just one question. So here it is, Vice President Gore and Governor Bush: are you at all concerned about the mounting consumer debt spreading across every demographic sector of the United States population?
fields.body:
While the US presidential debates were in full swing, I was pondering what I would ask the candidates if I had the opportunity to pose just one question. So here it is, Vice President Gore and Governor Bush: are you at all concerned about the mounting consumer debt spreading across every demographic sector of the United States population?

Gore and Bush seem to agree that the economy is humming, and have chosen to debate merely how best to allocate all of the surplus revenues. In the meantime, they both ignore a darker reality, one that could quickly change all of the up-beat economic forecasts coming out of Wall Street and Washington.

Although economists and politicians don't want to talk about it, the fact is that the "American miracle" has, to a great extent, been bought on credit. It is impossible to understand the dramatic growth of the American economy and reduction in US unemployment in recent years without examining the close relationship that has developed between economic expansion, job creation and the amassing of record consumer debt. Consumer credit has been growing for nearly a decade. Credit card companies are extending credit at unprecedented levels. Millions of American consumers are buying "on credit", and because they are, millions of other Americans have gone back to work to make the goods and perform the services being purchased. As a result, the economy seems healthier than ever.

Today, according to the Federal Reserve, Americans are spending more than they are taking in, marking the first time since the Great Depression that the country has experienced a negative savings rate. Just eight years ago the average savings rate in the US was 8% of after-tax income. Savings are now at their lowest level - 0.2 % - since monthly records began in 1959.

Britain is fast following the American lead. In just the past year, the UK household savings rate plunged from 6.7% to 3%. If it continues to decline at this pace, the savings rate will likely be negative by this time next year, with potentially ominous consequences for the economy and society.

An analogous situation occurred in the 1920s. Like today, that was a period of great economic change. Electricity replaced steam power across every major industry, greatly increasing the productive capacity of the country. Productivity gains, however, were not matched by a significant increase in worker compensation. Wages remained relatively flat, while many marginal workers lost their jobs in the wake of cheaper, more efficient technology substitutions. By the late 1920s, American industry was running at only 75% of capacity in most key sectors. The fruits of the new productivity gains were not being distributed broadly enough among workers to sustain increased consumption. Concerned over ineffective consumer demand, banks and retailers extended cheap credit in the form of instalment buying to encourage workers to spend more and keep the economy growing. By late 1929, consumer debt was so high it could no longer be sustained. Even the bull market was being stoked by record purchases of stocks on brokers' credit. Finally, the entire house of cards collapsed.

The short-term substitution of consumer credit in lieu of a broad redistribution of new productivity gains is a subject that has received little, if any, attention among economists. Still, the fact remains that great technology revolutions generally spread quickly, once all of the critical elements are in place. The problem is that it generally takes at least a generation or more after a defining new technology finally comes on line, for social movements to build enough coherence and momentum to demand a fair share of the vast productivity gains that have been made possible. In the 1920s, the crisis of increased productive capacity and ineffective consumer purchasing power was met by the extension of consumer credit to unprecedented levels.

The same phenomenon is occurring today. The productivity gains brought on by the information and telecommunication revolutions are finally being felt and, in the process, virtually every major industry is facing global underutilisation of capacity and insufficient consumer demand. Once again, in the US, consumer credit has become the palliative, a way to keep the economic engines throttled up, at least for a time.

Consumer credit is growing by a staggering 9% annual rate and personal bankruptcies are increasing. In 1994, 780,000 Americans filed for bankruptcy. By 1999, the number of bankruptcies had soared to 1,281,000.

If countries of the European Union were to lower their current family savings rate to zero, as the US has, they could probably accelerate economic growth and reduce unemployment to under 4%. Millions of people spending money "on credit" would assuredly grow the economy and bring millions of European workers back to work to make the goods and perform the services being purchased on credit. But following the US lead would only result in a short-term fix and create the conditions for an even more profound long-term period of economic instability when the extension of credit reached its limits, pushing consumers into default and the economy into a downward spiral, as occurred in the late 1920s and early 1930s.

The issue at hand is: how long can Americans continue to spend more than they make, moving deeper and deeper into commercial debt? In the current situation, any number of external events could tip the scale, with potentially calamitous consequences. If the energy crisis were to deepen, raising fuel and energy costs, or the stock market were to experience a sudden and sustained down-turn, or major lending institutions were to pull back on their loans, the effect on all of our lives could be sobering indeed.

The new economy won't be a reality until we have found a way to distribute the productivity gains of the e-commerce revolution broadly, to ensure enough consumer purchasing power to match the increases in productive capacity. In the past, that has always meant increases in wages and benefits and a reduction in work hours. If, instead, wages and benefits for middle and working-class Americans are allowed to remain relatively stagnant, as they have been for nearly a decade, and instead artificially prop up purchasing power by pushing millions of Ameri cans into record debt, we may squander the historic opportunity we now have to create a truly new economy that works for everyone.

It is unlikely that either of the presidential candidates will focus on the troubling spectre of negative savings. Yet, whoever takes over the White House, it's a sure bet that sooner or later, the issue of ever-expanding consumer debt will force all of us to take notice. We may look back on the current "prosperity" with the same cynical regard as earlier generations who lived through the short-lived boom years of the Roaring 20s.

Jeremy Rifkin is the author of The Age of Access: How the Shift From Ownership to Access is Transforming Capitalism

fields.trailText: I'm a fan of John Prescott's, but the goal of keeping the Tories for ever in opposition is so vital that even the prospect of losing the plain-speaking ex-merchant seaman's skills from the cabinet doesn't lessen my enthusiasm for coalition government and reform of the electoral process (Prescott dismisses coalition 'dreams', October 23).
fields.body:
I'm a fan of John Prescott's, but the goal of keeping the Tories for ever in opposition is so vital that even the prospect of losing the plain-speaking ex-merchant seaman's skills from the cabinet doesn't lessen my enthusiasm for coalition government and reform of the electoral process (Prescott dismisses coalition 'dreams', October 23).

Brian Hughes
Cheltenham

The hounding out of the chair of a TV watchdog by a newspaper owned by a television magnate (Comment, October 23) amply justifies the way some of us cherish the memory of Denis Potter naming his cancer Rupert.

Rev Geoff Reid
Bradford

The lines quoted by Steven Morris (The lady who lives in a car, October 21) are not from a poem, nor are they a sad and curious lament. They are lines from a reasonably cheerful old ballad which begins "I'll be your sweetheart/ if you will be mine". Sometimes I think that you should employ some older reporters.

Frances Wilson
Boston, Lincs

Whilst planning my TV today, I saw that you refer to a Downs syndrome sufferer in the film Eighth Day. I have Downs syndrome in the same way that I have brown eyes. I do not suffer from it. My parents might, but not me!

Ellen Wharam (age 16)
Cromer, Norfolk

For our school science project I have been collecting the phases of the moon pictures published in the Guardian each day. To my amazement there have been six half-moons in the past month. Is this due to global warming?

Anna Blakebrough (age 11)
Malpas, Cheshire

I see José Canabis, who has died (Obituaries, October 21), was known for writing romantic fantasies. Pot boilers?

Ewen Wannop
Box, Wiltshire

webTitle: Scandals deny redress for slave workers of Nazis

fields.headline: Scandals deny redress for slave workers of Nazis
fields.trailText: As Germany struggles to launch its multibillion pound compensation scheme for surviving slave labourers of the Third Reich, large sums already paid out to Russia and Ukraine have allegedly gone missing before reaching the intended beneficiaries.
fields.body:
As Germany struggles to launch its multibillion pound compensation scheme for surviving slave labourers of the Third Reich, large sums already paid out to Russia and Ukraine have allegedly gone missing before reaching the intended beneficiaries.

A Ukrainian MP has been arrested in Germany, accused of swindling almost £30m in compensation payments from Berlin. At least another £4m handed over for Russian victims of the Nazis has been lost through poor investments by the Russian charity which administers the money.

Otto von Lambsdorff, the former German economics minister appointed by the chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, to negotiate the new DM10bn (£3bn) German industry fund for former slave labourers, told a Moscow conference that the monies transferred to Russia were being "used ineffectively". He ordered audits into what was happening with payments in the Russian, Ukrainian, Belarus and Czech capitals.

"We've been fighting about this for years," said Elena Zhemkova, a Russian expert on the reparations issue with the Memorial human rights organisation.

Understanding and Reconciliation, the Russian charity in charge of distributing some £134m to 400,000 surviving Russian victims of the Nazis, has been run, since last week, by Alexander Sazonov, a former KGB general.

The charity deposited millions in compensation payments with a bank that sank in Russia's financial crash of 1998, and lost almost £4m by investing in treasury bills on which the government then defaulted.

The hundreds of millions in Russia and Ukraine came from a scheme agreed in 1992 between the former Russian and German leaders, Boris Yeltsin and Helmut Kohl. The end of the cold war unfroze the reparations issue and triggered claims on Germany from the former Soviet empire. Bonn shelled out DM1bn (£300m) to Russia, Ukraine, and Belarus.

The running of the funds in the former Soviet Union highlights the problems entailed in getting the benefits to the actual victims, as opposed to profiteers born after the war.

The biggest scandal is in Ukraine, where a 42-year-old independent MP and former banker, Viktor Zherditsky, is alleged to have embezzled £30m intended for Nazi victims. He was arrested in the north German town of Hanover last week while allegedly trying to withdraw £34,000 from a bank.

Of the DM400m that the Germans paid to Ukraine after 1992, DM153m passed through Gradobank, headed by Mr Zherditsky. But only DM66m was paid out to the beneficiaries, according to the Ukrainian general prosecutor's office.

Mr Zherditsky's bank was declared bankrupt in 1997 and German prosecutors say that DM87m disappeared.

webTitle: Italy's left banks on US-style poll blitz

fields.headline: Italy's left banks on US-style poll blitz
fields.standfirst: Insults and kisses set tone for election campaign
fields.trailText: Francesco Rutelli, the telegenic mayor of Rome, embarked yesterday on a mission to save Italy's centre-left government from electoral annihilation.
fields.body:
Francesco Rutelli, the telegenic mayor of Rome, embarked yesterday on a mission to save Italy's centre-left government from electoral annihilation.

Newly anointed as the coalition's candidate for prime minister, Mr Rutelli unveiled an American-style campaign to repel a comeback by Silvio Berlusconi, the centre-right opposition leader. A "listening tour" launched in Milan will crisscross the country until elections next spring.

Trading insults with the opposition, Mr Rutelli, 46, vowed to unify the coalition and reverse Mr Berlusconi's opinion poll lead with a campaign blitz never seen before in Italy.

Although Mr Rutelli is little known outside Rome, the government is gambling that the mayor's youth, good looks and fresh image will compensate for four years of infighting which chewed up three prime ministers.

He gave a flavour of the campaign by attending Mass, lunching at the home of a working class family, meeting craftsmen and appearing on chatshows.

Mr Berlusconi, 64, a media magnate who was bounced from power six years ago, mocked his rival as a male model and TV frontman for unrepentant communists.

Crime, immigration, jobs and taxes are expected to dominate the campaign, but Mr Rutelli has yet to draw up specific policies. "Bullets have to be fired at the right time. I will build my programme by listening to the people of Italy," he told one voter.

Mr Rutelli challenged Mr Berlusconi, long regarded as Italy's master communicator, to monthly television debates.

The seven years in office of Rome's mayor have seen him transformed from a radical environmentalist to a Catholic centrist. "My task is to tell Italians how the government has done so much, and how we are going to do much better," Mr Rutelli told the Guardian.

"Yes, Berlusconi is ahead now, but we have six months to counter-attack. That's a long time. We will give him some surprises."

A college dropout who passed through the Radical and Green parties before settling in the Democrats, Mr Rutelli remarried his journalist wife, Barbara Palombello, in church before establishing warm ties with the Vatican.

The campaign has already turned dirty. Mr Berlusconi has called him an abortionist. His ally, the Northern League's Umberto Bossi, scorned the mayor for adopting an Ecuadorean boy.

Mr Rutelli retaliated that Mr Berlusconi, who has mostly shaken off corruption allegations, was a divorcee who used images of a much younger self on his billboards.

A shrewd tactician, it was his idea to recruit Stanley Greenberg, an American pollster who is credited with stage managing Al Gore's passionate kiss with his wife at the Democratic convention.

Last weekend's "crowning" convention in Milan featured a lengthy kiss between the mayor and his wife.

fields.headline: Own brand
fields.trailText:
For discerning shoppers who wish to benefit from the value for money offered by own brand products but also know who manufactured the product (Letters, October 23), look no further than your local Co-op store. The Co-op is the only retailer which has a "right to know" policy and will tell you who makes the products so that, if you wish to boycott a manufacturer, you can do so.
Martin Henderson
Co-operative Wholesale Society

fields.headline: Next wave of UK films
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw tells only part of the story when he regrets that Christopher Nolan, one of our talented film-makers, feels most at home in "American" (Memento review, October 20).
fields.body:
Peter Bradshaw tells only part of the story when he regrets that Christopher Nolan, one of our talented film-makers, feels most at home in "American" (Memento review, October 20). Nolan's acclaimed debut film, Following, was indeed shot in Britain, but it was completed with money from Next Wave, a US completion fund. It is striking that at a time when British newspapers were criticising the lack of quality of our cinema, this US fund should choose a UK film.

American financiers have a very different mindset from ours. They recognise the quality of British film-making talent - and back it with real money. They also see the need for (and potential profits from) paying to finish good low-budget films which otherwise would not be made.

We at the New Producers Alliance urge the industry, the City and now the new Film Council to take the same view.
Charles Harris

fields.body:
Re Raymond Gubbay's comments about ticketing at the Royal Opera House (House master, G2, October 23): on October 12 I was told by the box office that stalls tickets normally priced at £115 might be available for Tales of Hoffmann on the next day at the standby price of £15. Unfortunately about 20 of us were disappointed; some were senior citizens who had travelled up specially. That night the curtain rose on some 70 unsold seats in the stall.

On October 16 no standby seats were available and 120 stalls seats went begging. Neither were standby tickets available on October 19. Staff took great care not to disclose to me precisely how many seats remained unsold, but there were a handful.

Robert Jones London

fields.headline: Greens still growing well
fields.trailText: So, waste reduction policies are not a vote winner and the "dismal fate of green parties" is evidence of this (Leader, October 23).
fields.body:
So, waste reduction policies are not a vote winner and the "dismal fate of green parties" is evidence of this (Leader, October 23). Elected greens are now a permanent feature of the political landscape in Europe. Although British greens lagged behind, one must ask where the Guardian has been for the past 18 months. Three of us were elected to the 25-member London assembly in May with over 11% of the vote across London. Last year saw two greens elected to the European parliament and a green elected to the Scottish parliament. We also have growing numbers of councillors. It will take more than a speech from Tony Blair to prevent further electoral breakthroughs

Darren Johnson
Greater London Authority
darren.johnson@london.gov.uk

Michael Meacher was perfectly right to say that, in the hypothetical situation of falling oil prices, the government should use a fuel tax escalator in the future to ensure that the costs of motoring continue to increase gradually (Meacher is rebuked, October 23). The revenues from any tax increase would be used to invest in public transport and make the alternatives to burning fossil fuels much cheaper.

A more sensible way of compensating motorists for the high oil price would be to cut vehicle excise duty - the road tax disc - for small- and average-sized vehicles. This would benefit the average driver, even in rural areas, and penalise the gas guzzler.

Vicky Cann
Sera, the Labour environment campaign
seraoffice@aol.com

webTitle: Candidates make politics a family affair

fields.headline: Candidates make politics a family affair
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: In a Pentecostal church in Dallas, Al Gore took time out from discussing the Middle East and taxation to declare: "The centre of my life is faith and family."
fields.body:
In a Pentecostal church in Dallas, Al Gore took time out from discussing the Middle East and taxation to declare: "The centre of my life is faith and family."

While the Democratic candidate was stressing to the congregation the importance of family values this weekend, television viewers saw a new Republican campaign ad featuring the nephew of his rival.

"I am a young Latino and I'm very proud of my bloodline," the 24-year-old law student said. "I have an uncle that is running for president. His name? The same as mine - George Bush."

With just two weeks until the election, George W Bush and Al Gore are brushing up their image as devoted family men. In sharp contrast to Britain, where a brush with family values in the 1990s put most politicians off for good, familial love has been put at the heart of this year's campaign in America.

The dynastic quality of the campaign came to the fore at the party conventions this summer. Members of the Bush and Gore clans gave primetime platform speeches about the candidate as a husband, son, dad, while senior members of both parties were kept on the sidelines.

"Welcome to the next president of America and a fine dad," gushed Karenna Gore Schiff, Al's telegenic eldest daughter and the head of Gorenet, an outreach programme for young Democrats.

The use of family members is not new in presidential politics. It is simply that this year's campaign has given them all more prominent roles.

Marshall Whittman, senior fellow at the Hudson Institute, a non-partisan public policy thinktank, argues that this is both a reaction to the Clinton administration's scandals and the current state of the American psyche. "America is economically prosperous but there is a fear that there is a values deficit," he said. "Having a loving extended family is a way to inoculate yourself on values."

The Gore campaign, in particular, has used the vice-president's family credentials both to humanise him and to distance him from Bill Clinton. It seemed to work in Los Angeles when Mr Gore's passionate kiss with his wife was credited with boosting his ratings.

He regularly watches his only son play football on Saturdays, so much so that some of his aides fear that such time-consuming devotion could be costly as the campaign reaches its climax.

It would have been hard for candidates from two well-known political dynasties to ignore their surnames. George and Al were named after presidential and senatorial fathers respectively. Several commentators argue that neither man would have been in the running had it not been for their family connection to politics.

This adds a whiff of nepotism to the otherwise cheery picture of family life. To that end, Mr Bush Sr has played a relatively limited public role in his son's campaign. Pundits suggest that advisers got rid of him after he referred to a man standing for the US's highest elected office as "the boy" during the campaign's early days.

Both candidates have been accused of the cynical packaging of family life. Tarek Milleron, who works as a driver and dogsbody for his uncle, the Green party candidate, Ralph Nader, is critical of Ms Schiff's platform performance in support of Mr Gore. "She is obviously an intelligent person and there she is giving a speech she could have given when she was 14," he said.

Others believe that this year's campaign is simply a feature of the Oprahfication of US politics, which started with America's best-known political family: the Kennedys.

webTitle: Taste of a future thick with lawyers

fields.headline: Taste of a future thick with lawyers
fields.standfirst: City eyes on Charter row
fields.trailText: An impressive spat developed yesterday between Charter, the British engineering group, and Lincoln, the US welding specialist which has been threatening to complete a takeover for six months.
fields.body:
An impressive spat developed yesterday between Charter, the British engineering group, and Lincoln, the US welding specialist which has been threatening to complete a takeover for six months.

Lincoln lapsed its £386m bid after the market had closed on Friday, provoking a furious statement over the weekend from Charter saying, in effect, that Lincoln had no right to pull out so soon. It added that negotiations over the sale had proved so tortuous that the underlying business had been affected. As a result, second-half operating profits from Charter would now be significantly below expectations.

A new statement from Lincoln followed, insisting that the American company was fully entitled to lapse its offer, adding that Charter was made fully aware of its reasons for doing so - in advance. The market's response was swift and brutal. Faced with both a failed bid and a profits warning, the share price was chopped from 330p on Friday evening to 155p at the close of play yesterday.

After a couple more statements from each party, the information flow came to a screaming halt, with both sides deep in discussion with their lawyers. The outcome of any legal action may be of interest because the row would seem to turn on whether Charter can somehow claim breach of contract over an as-yet non-statutory rule book - the Panel on Takeovers and Mergers.

Working on this basis the Code, as it is known, has served the City well for many years. The European commission wants to put it on a legal footing and standardise rules across Europe. A move in this direction looks inevitable and so the Charter-Lincoln scrap gives us a little taste of the future - thick with lawyers.

But there are other immediate aspects of this non-bid which might require certain participants in the London market to consult their defence attorneys. Lincoln's advisers seem to have told their counterparts at Charter that the whole thing was off around Friday lunchtime. Thereafter, Charter's shares began to fall sharply, with a series of trades knocking the price from 380p to 330p.

There can be no suggestion that either company or their advisers acted improperly. Yet three hours before a formal announcement on the matter, clairvoyant types at some of the City's most prestigious investment banks were telling all callers with some confidence that the deal was off.

Insider dealing is rife in the City; it is more common still in the financial centres of continental Europe. Yet trying to eradicate it completely risks undermining the very thing that lubricates markets - namely, a flow of information.

The onus is on companies and their advisers to release information quickly and widely when it becomes clear that something price-sensitive has leaked. The sort of nonsense seen in London on Friday simply hurries the day when draconian measures are introduced like the one which hit Wall Street yesterday.

Called Regulation FD (for fair disclosure), this securities & exchanges commission initiative slaps a ban on any selective disclosure of market moving information.

It sours the cosy relationship between companies and investment bank analysts, killing off "guidance" on trading performance and leaks to friendly news outlets. The idea is to protect retail investors who, for too long, have been dealing at a disadvantage to the big professional players. The price will be increased volatility as news, good and bad, surprises rather than confirms. The market, sadly, will also be a bit less fun.

Feeling Blu
Italy's auction of its third generation mobile phone licences has turned into a tale of red, white and blue. The Italian government, generally, is red with embarrassment, while budget ministers there are blanching at the size of the hole that has appeared in their fiscal arithmetic.

British Telecom is the one left feeling blue. It tried hard within the limits of its balance sheet and shareholders patience (both fairly stretched) to keep its Blu consortium in the bidding. To no avail. Some of its partners proved to have less of an appetite for risk.

As a result its strategy now has a gap instead of a 3G licence. It does still have a foothold in Europe's biggest mobile market via earlier Blu licences but this will slip once its rivals are able to launch UMTS -based services.

Yet, for BT the setback could be a blessing in disguise. In Britain it has control of its 3G fate and will be in the same position in Germany when it doubles its stake in Viag to 90%.

In Spain, however, it is a minority player - as it would have been in Italy and will be in France if Cegetel gets a licence. BT would do well to consider whether its resources are concentrated in ventures where it calls the shots or scattered more widely into deals where its ambitions are at the mercy of partners which may not share its priorities.

webTitle: US firm buys Laird's car interests

fields.headline: US firm buys Laird's car interests
fields.trailText: Laird Group, in a further restructuring of the British vehicle components industry, yesterday announced the sale of its main car parts business to a US group for £142m.
fields.body:
Laird Group, in a further restructuring of the British vehicle components industry, yesterday announced the sale of its main car parts business to a US group for £142m.

The British group, which said it wanted to concentrate resources on opportunities in the fast-growing electronics industry, is in talks about the sale of the rest of its automotive operations.

The UK car components industry has been feeling the effects of the strong pound, with manufacturers demanding price cuts or sourcing parts more cheaply from overseas.

Laird's decision to switch from car components to electronics reflects investors' low rating of the automotive operations.

Other big manufacturing groups have either sold or are planning to sell their car parts businesses. TI Group, for example, has put its automotive business up for sale, with a price tag of over £1bn. Invensys, the merged Siebe and BTR business, has also been reducing its dependence on car component manufacturing.

Laird has agreed to sell Draftex, its car body sealing systems business, to the US-based GenCorp for £142m. Draftex last year made an operating profit of £11.9m on sales of £258.6m, accounting for 55% of Laird's automotive turnover.

The valuations of so-called old economy stocks have suffered compared to other sectors. The FTSE all share engineering and machinery index has an average price-to-earnings (PE) ratio of 8.1 - far below the average FTSE all share index PE of 19.3, according to financial publisher Barra.

Commenting on the unpopularity among investors of old economy stocks, Laird chief executive Ian Arnott said: "You can't stand still and accept the valuations placed on you by the market. You've got to go out there and do something about it."

He said a decision on the sale of the rest of the automotive businesses - probably to international groups - would probably be made within the next two to three months.

Part of the proceeds from the Draftex sale will be used to repay some of the debt associated with Laird's acquisition in August of the US-based Instrument Specialties Company for £178m.

GenCorp said its Draftex acquisition would make it the second-largest automotive vehicle sealing supplier in the world. GenCorp added that the takeover would enhance earnings immediately.

A Laird spokesman said he did not expect any job cuts in Britain as a result of the sale, adding that it was a matter for GenCorp, rather than Laird, to deal with.

Laird is radically restructuring its operations. It sold its printing and packaging activities last year. It is now a leading supplier of electromagnetic interference shielding products for use in the electronics and telecommunications industries.

Investment bank Lazard Brothers advised Laird on the Draftex sale.

fields.headline: More slings at Arafat
fields.trailText: "The Palestinians ... actively invite casualties," we are told by Peter Preston (Comment, October 23).
fields.body:
"The Palestinians ... actively invite casualties," we are told by Peter Preston (Comment, October 23). He joins several commentators in "exposing" how teenagers are cynically placed in the front line in the apparent hope that they will be shot in front of the world's media. Really? I suppose then, that we can only be grateful the PLO does not lead marches of schoolchildren (and only schoolchildren) into confrontation with the authorities as the ANC did in Soweto.

Arafat et al will, of course, try to make political capital out of anything they can - but I fear that in the current David and Goliath situation, we are a bit too desperate in our search for David's flaws.
Robert Fitzgerald
Dublin

 While I agree with the letter from Noam Chomsky (October 19), the biggest problem is that the Muslim countries are so divided and racked by violence against each other, they are powerless to help their fellow Muslims. In Pakistan, Somalia, Algeria, Afghanistan, Iraq and elsewhere, Muslims are slaughtering one another. If they were not so divided, the likes of Israel, America, Russia, or other non-Muslims would pose no problem at all to them.
T Khan
London

 Anthony Sampson's article on the oil crisis (Comment, October 17) refers to a "wave of Arab resentment and a hardline Israeli attitude". At Camp David in July, Ehud Barak offered President Arafat restoration of 90% of the West Bank, land swaps in Israel to match territories on which the major Israeli settlements have been established in the West Bank, and effective governance of parts of Jerusalem - if not the outright sovereignty the Palestinians demand.

These are not hardline proposals. What a disaster that Arafat did not have the vision or the courage to face down the street and counsel his people on the need for moderation and compromise.
John Levy
Academic Study Group on Israel & the Middle East

 Armed with little more than small arms and vastly outnumbered, Arafat surely cannot believe he can outmatch the might of the Israeli army? Is his strategy that if the casualties mount there will be a Kosovo-type intervention by the west driven by an ethical foreign policy? The stark example that should keep him awake at night is the fate of Chechnya: a superior military force comprehensively armed and geared for total warfare and a western alliance, that worthy protestations apart, would look the other way.
FJ Boothman
Hereford
