webTitle: Old enemies return to the battleground

fields.headline: Old enemies return to the battleground
fields.standfirst: Special report: Korea
fields.trailText: China's defence minister, Chi Haotian, was in Pyongyang when Madeleine Albright arrived there yesterday. He is there to celebrate the 50th anniversary of China's intervention - against the US - in the Korean war.
fields.body:
China's defence minister, Chi Haotian, was in Pyongyang when Madeleine Albright arrived there yesterday. He is there to celebrate the 50th anniversary of China's intervention - against the US - in the Korean war.

Mr Chi has called for China and North Korea to strengthen their relations, evoking the spirit of 1950 when the two countries were "as close as lips and teeth".

The presence of these two senior figures from Beijing and Washington is an apt reminder that both countries continue to have competitive interests in the Korean peninsula, as they did 50 years ago. China dates its intervention in Korea to October 25 1950.

Though China welcomes the easing of tension on the Korean peninsula, analysts in Beijing doubt whether it would be happy with too rapid a US-North Korean thaw. The official People's Daily newspaper this weekend stressed that "the two countries still have to overcome significant obstacles before bilateral relations can be normalised".

Both Washington and Beijing are keen to claim credit for their roles in promoting detente between Pyongyang and Seoul.

But according to Seoul officials, the North has asked the South not to force the pace of the recon ciliation. This is partly due to "a desire to concentrate on improving ties with the US and Japan".

Pyongyang has already delayed exchanging names for a second North-South round of displaced family visits, which had been scheduled for November 2 to 4.

European countries, including Britain, are now rushing to recognise North Korea, despite previously insisting that such a move was premature.

Though China welcomes the easing of tension on the Korean peninsula, analysts in Beijing doubt whether it would be happy with too rapid a US-North Korean thaw. The official People's Daily newspaper this weekend stressed that "the two countries still have to overcome significant obstacles before bilateral relations can be normalised". Both Washington and Beijing are keen to claim credit for their roles in promoting detente between Pyongyang and Seoul. But according to Seoul officials, the North has asked the South not to force the pace of the recon ciliation. This is partly due to "a desire to concentrate on improving ties with the US and Japan". Pyongyang has already delayed exchanging names for a second North-South round of displaced family visits, which had been scheduled for November 2 to 4. European countries, including Britain, are now rushing to recognise North Korea, despite previously insisting that such a move was premature.

fields.headline: Choice of roads to travel
fields.trailText: Congratulations to Larry Elliott (Return ticket to state control easily bought, October 23) for arguing what so few commentators have had the guts to say - the privatisation of the railways has been a failure and it's time to do something about it.
fields.body:
Congratulations to Larry Elliott (Return ticket to state control easily bought, October 23) for arguing what so few commentators have had the guts to say - the privatisation of the railways has been a failure and it's time to do something about it. Insofar as there is any logic to privatisation, it's that competition creates more efficiency and consumer choice. Railway privatisation is a joke: if I'm not satisfied with the only rail company providing a service between Cambridge and London, what am I supposed to do - go to Birmingham instead?

Nor am I convinced every business hides endless opportunities for greater efficiency and that only the lack of a profit motive prevents these being recognised. My father worked for Post Office Telephones for 45 years before they were privatised and he, like many of his fellow workers, had a commitment to providing a cheap, effective public service. Surely there's more than one way of motivating people?

In any case, "efficiency" usually means fewer people working longer hours for less money. Call me old-fashioned, but I have a moral objection to that. Even Tory voters recognise the truth of the old maxim, you get what you pay for. Efficiency usually involves cutting corners - one can always get a job done cheaper if you're willing to accept shoddier standards. But when it comes to rail safety, how many more corners are we willing to see cut? Doesn't anyone remember why the railways were nationalised in the first place?

The announcement that billions more will be poured into improving rail safety is welcome. But why do we need to enrich Railtrack shareholders? I'd rather see my money spent on addressing environmental concerns, by making rail travel so cheap, safe and convenient that people will leave their cars at home.
Jim Endersby
Cambridge jje21@cam.ac.uk

 Why struggle on with an outdated piece of industrial cast-iron heritage; £14.9bn, £677 per household, is enough to tarmac 12,000 miles of tracks and give cars and buses, the choice of transport for 85% of voters, unprecedented access to town and city centres. Or perhaps the new road-tracks-network could be devoted to commercial traffic and clear our roads of monster trucks.

Railways, steel wheels slipping on steel tracks, have always been very inefficient in energy engineering terms, and per passenger carried are more polluting than any other surface transport. Even busy railways are grossly underused compared to trunk roads. Add back the sabotaged Beeching lines and the UK's transport congestion problems will be solved for a generation at least.
Noel Hodson
Oxford noelhodson@msn.com

 So Railtrack has imposed speed restrictions on 1,000 miles of track at 81 country-wide sites. Did the Health and Safety Executive know of these? If we asked them for their locations, they would be exempt under clause 28 of the Freedom of Information Bill. Peers are likely to press amendments making this information more accessible, but the government will then whip Labour MPs into making safety information more secret again. How can this be tolerable after Southall, Paddington and Hatfield?
Barry White
Campaign for Press and Broadcasting Freedom freepress@cpbf.demon.co.uk

 Low speed limits on all corners and junctions in the UK road system where there have been accidents in the last few years would bring about a huge reduction in casualties and lives lost.
Sara Robin
Director, York Cycleworks

webTitle: Parthus shares fall as backers look to sell

fields.headline: Parthus shares fall as backers look to sell
fields.trailText: Backers of the Irish chip designer, Parthus Technologies, are itching to sell shares to take advantage of a threefold increase in the company's market value since flotation five months ago.
fields.body:
Backers of the Irish chip designer, Parthus Technologies, are itching to sell shares to take advantage of a threefold increase in the company's market value since flotation five months ago.

The company, now worth more than £1.4bn, yesterday said it was "considering a follow-on offering" of about $200m, largely to allow management and venture capitalists to place some of their stock.

Those wishing to liquidate part of their investments include Goldman Sachs, which has an 18% stake, and chief executive Brian Long, with 23%. Directors own 34% of the company. Enterprise Ireland has 8.9%.

The firm said it would issue "a small amount" of new equity, raising money for acquisitions and expansion.

The news went down badly with the market and Parthus's shares slipped 33.5p to 266.5p. Analysts drew comparisons with Bookham - another recently floated technology firm that went for a secondary placing - triggering a sharp fall in investor confidence.

Michael Blogg, an analyst at Charterhouse Securities, said: "It does remind me a little bit of Bookham but then again, it's all part and parcel of a flotation with a very limited free float."

Parthus specialises in mobile phone technology. One product can pinpoint a phone within 10 seconds, using satellite tracking.

fields.headline: Predators eye Countrywide
fields.standfirst: Market forces  Neil Hume
fields.trailText: Subject to completion it looks like the sold sign will soon be going up outside the offices of Countrywide Assured, the UK's biggest estate agent.
fields.body:
Subject to completion it looks like the sold sign will soon be going up outside the offices of Countrywide Assured, the UK's biggest estate agent.

According to marketplace gossips, Countrywide, owner of the Bairstow Eves chain, will in the course of the next week reveal the conclusions of its strategic review by accepting a bid from an overseas predator.

At least three buyers, including one from Italy and another from North America, are said to have tabled offers for Countrywide, which they view as the perfect vehicle to gain a toehold in the competitive British mortgage market.

Aside from the estate agency business, Countrywide has two other legs: an army of financial advisers, which specialise in selling mortgages and life assurance products to new homeown ers; and a property survey business.

Apparently, almost 50% of the customers who use Countrywide's 750-strong chain of agencies also buy a mortgage from one of its financial advisers. A large proportion also snap up life assurance, critical illness and home insurance products.

However, Countrywide is prepared to walk away from the talks if the price is not right. An offer of 130p would be considered derisory and force Countrywide to consider a break-up or remaining as a listed company.

Since delivering its disastrous interim figures back in August, trading conditions are said to have improved with the company on course to make around £60m this year.

Should Countrywide opt for a break-up it is likely that the management would take the estate agency and surveying businesses private and trade sale the rest. Countrywide refused to comment on the speculation and the shares closed down 3p at 107p.

After falling into the red early in the afternoon (thanks to another profit warning from Lucent), leading shares recovered their poise to end higher for a third straight session. The FTSE 100 closed up 39.6 points at 6,315.9, driven by the strong performance of drug stocks and Vodafone, up 5p to 281p.

Nevertheless, it was old economy stalwarts that dominated the FTSE 100 leaderboard. Railtrack, 58.5p better at £11.08, ended top of the pile after the industry regulator set aside almost £15bn of mostly state cash for the nation's rail network.

Automation and controls group Invensys rose 3p to 137p on the back of continued bid speculation and a Dresdner Kleinwort Benson upgrade.

In the light of General Electric's bid for Honeywell, a major control systems player, Dresdner reckons Invensys looks cheap. The speculation dragged engineering group GKN, up 30.5p to 738p.

Newly demerged P&O Princess Cruises ended at 292p, having touched 317p at one point in the session. The other half, P&O, closed up 2.5p at 242.5p.

Elsewhere, BG fell 10p to 270p after its split, while spin-off Lattice ended near its highs at 153.25p. On the downside tech stocks were out of favour, hit by a flurry of profit-taking after last week's late gains. ARM Holdings fell 35p to 679p, and Bookham Technology fell 69p to £25. The Techmark ended 24.11 points lower at 3,426.43.

Lower down the market, Shire Pharmaceutical rose 32p to £13.95. After the market closed index compiler FTSE International said the company will be taking Woolwich's place in the blue chip index tomorrow. Chemicals distributor Ellis & Everard leapt 13.5p to 148.5p in heavy volume on talk of a bid.

The figure being mentioned in City dealing rooms is an offer of around 200p.

Dealers pointed out that Ellis chairman Keith Hopkins recently said the company was considering all options to enhance shareholder value.

Engineering group Charter crashed 183.5p to 155p, as investors reacted to Friday's late news that 410p-a-share bid talks are off.

Hewden unhappiness

The market remains convinced something is going on at plant hire company Hewden-Stuart. Despite denials from the company, professionals insist the group, which has issued three profit warnings, has received a number of bid approaches.

Moreover, some of its largest shareholders, are said to be deeply unhappy with its performance - Hewden shares have fallen 34% so far this year - and are determined to do something about it.

They are said to be furious at reports that Hewden received and rejected a 110p-115p a share offer from private equity group Alchemy Partners. But they may have the last laugh.

One management buyout team is said to be plotting an offer, while two other groups - one said to be the private equity arm of Deutsche Bank - are also running the rule over the company. Hewden shares closed up 4p at 69p in heavy volume yesterday.

webTitle: Business: WPP results hit Olympian high

fields.headline: WPP results hit Olympian high
fields.trailText: WPP, the world's biggest advertising group, yesterday announced bumper figures on the back of millennium celebrations, the Olympics and new business from global companies such as Ford and Nike.
fields.body:
WPP, the world's biggest advertising group, yesterday announced bumper figures on the back of millennium celebrations, the Olympics and new business from global companies such as Ford and Nike.

The company, which has just finalised the takeover of New York-based agency Young & Rubicam, said it had signed a batch of lucrative contracts and was yet to feel the effects of the slowdown predicted to sweep across the industry.

It said sales in the third quarter had shot up 21% to £679.4m, helped by the economic recovery in Asia and Latin America, while net new billings were up 14% at £830m.

Sir Martin Sorrell, WPP chief executive, said the company's growth rate excluding acquisitions was 15%, compared to an industry average of 7%.

Last night he confirmed the company had held preliminary takeover talks with Finsbury and the Maitland Consultancy, two City-based public relations agencies, but said that no agreements had been reached.

He also refused to be drawn on speculation WPP had been forced to widen its search for a new chairman to replace the retiring Hamish Maxwell.

The list of potential Young & Rubicam candidates had been exhausted.

Sir Christopher Lewinton, the chairman of TI Group, is still understood to be on the list, despite some City dissatisfaction with the idea.

"We are looking at everyone," said Mr Sorrell.

He said that an appointment would be made over the next couple of months.

In its trading statement, WPP said major sporting and political occasions, coupled with better economic condi tions, had helped fuel the growth in revenues.

The company, which also owns US agencies J Walter Thompson and Ogilvy & Mather, is launching a new global network focusing on companies fighting for the lead position in their markets.

The plan is for a joint venture between three of its agencies - Conquest, Batey Adver tising of Singapore and Seattle-based Cole & Weber.

WPP said revenues were up 34.3% in continental Europe, 24.8% in Asia, Latin America, Africa and the Middle East, while those in Britain had risen 11.2%. North America provides almost half the group's total revenue.

Its core advertising and media sector, which still accounts for almost half the group's business, had grown by 19.7%, while the public relations side, which includes City agency Buchanan Communications, rose 44.7%.

The recent boom in dot.com clients, which accounted for 15% of the group's total revenue, is expected to fall away and be supported by more traditional advertising avenues.

The results delighted the City, with the shares rocketing up 14p to 870p as the London markets closed last night. This is some way off their 1344.5p year high, but comfortably ahead of the 688p low.

Richard Jones, media analyst at UBS Warburg, said: "The numbers were pretty good and probably a bit better than we expected."

But the real test is likely to come beyond the fourth quarter which won't be boosted by one-off events such as the Olympics.

Rachael Biggs, a media marketing analyst with Commerzbank, said: "We are going to see a gradual slowdown in 2001 in the advertising market with growth around 5% to 6%."

webTitle: Daewoo Motor runs out of road

fields.headline: Daewoo Motor runs out of road
fields.standfirst: News Analysis: Peace is in the air but South Korea is gripped by a sense of crisis on the industrial front
fields.trailText: South Koreans should be celebrating the best of times right now. Decades of conflict with the north are starting to ease, their president has just won the Nobel peace prize and the economy has bounced back from the Asian financial crisis with double-digit growth.
fields.body:
South Koreans should be celebrating the best of times right now. Decades of conflict with the north are starting to ease, their president has just won the Nobel peace prize and the economy has bounced back from the Asian financial crisis with double-digit growth.

But on the streets of Seoul few people are in the mood to party. President Kim Dae-jung has slumped in the opinion polls, the stock market is plunging and the conversation of everyone from taxi-drivers to corporate executives is peppered with pessimism. The concern centres on Daewoo Motor, once one of the driving engines of the South Korean economy but now in the limbo of bankruptcy.

Daewoo Motor has been on a financial life support system since last year, when its parent, the sprawling Daewoo conglomerate, collapsed with debts of $709bn.

Parts of the group were packaged up and offered for sale. In a much heralded sign of South Korea's willingness to embrace globalisation, Ford was chosen as the preferred buyer for Daewoo Motor.

But Ford suddenly pulled out of negotiations last month, amid rumours that it had found Daewoo's liabilities to be far worse than it had been led to believe. Creditors are now looking to General Motors, which is reportedly offering less than a third of the $7bn bid tabled by Ford.

The government wants a deal by the end of the year, but analysts say the process of due diligence is likely to take months. Whether Daewoo can survive that long is far from certain. This week Daewoo will once again take a begging bowl to its creditors for funds to stay afloat.

One or two banks would rather pull the plug on the firm, which is losing $90m per month. But, given the crisis that would follow such a move, the main creditor - the government-run Korea Development Bank - is expected to approve new funds, though only on a short-term basis. In recognition of this latest humiliation, Daewoo is expected to announce a new management reshuffle next week and begin work on a fresh restructuring package. According to the Korean media, 30% of the company's 20,000 jobs in South Korea will be cut.

A sense of crisis pervades the company. Last month, workers at Daewoo Motor's design research facility in Worthing, Surrey, were alarmed to be told that they would have to wait for their salaries while the company negotiated new funds. The greatest fear, however, is that the company's market will dry up as consumers lose confidence in the brand.

With the value of the company falling by the day, General Motors and its partner Fiat are believed to be in no hurry to close a deal. At least one creditor has already written off all debts it is owed by Daewoo Motor, suggesting the company could go for almost nothing.

But whether it goes at all is open to question. GM is reportedly in favour of a part purchase of Daewoo's assets in South Korea, which would leave creditors with the bill for liquidating the company's least profitable operations.

This break-up of the firm is fiercely opposed by Daewoo's main union, which has threatened to strike. It is demanding a large-scale injection of public money to put the company back on its feet.

Such a pseudo-nationalisation is becoming increasingly likely given the political situation, say analysts. President Kim has completed more than half of his term in office and the ruling party do not want to create large-scale unemploy ment ahead of the next election.

Anything but a sale to GM, however, would rattle foreign investors. With other negative signs for the Korean economy such as rising oil costs and falling prices of semiconductors, they have been deserting the stock market in droves.

This outflow of capital comes at a worrying time. Many corporate bonds, taken out during the financial crisis two years ago, will come up for repayment in the next two months. With domestic banks still too weak to lend much, many analysts forecast a credit crunch by the end of the year that would come just as the economy starts to slow. After racking up 10.7% growth in 1999, Korea's output is forecast to expand by 8% this year and 6% in 2001.

Few people expect a repetition of the near-meltdown that took place in 1997. The government's finances are far sounder, currency reserves are greater and important reforms have been carried out.

But, without at least a sense of crisis, analysts say it may be difficult for the government to push ahead with the tough decisions needed for Daewoo and other sectors of the economy.

Anything but a sale to GM, however, would rattle foreign investors. With other negative signs for the Korean economy such as rising oil costs and falling prices of semiconductors, they have been deserting the stock market in droves. This outflow of capital comes at a worrying time. Many corporate bonds, taken out during the financial crisis two years ago, will come up for repayment in the next two months. With domestic banks still too weak to lend much, many analysts forecast a credit crunch by the end of the year that would come just as the economy starts to slow. After racking up 10.7% growth in 1999, Korea's output is forecast to expand by 8% this year and 6% in 2001. Few people expect a repetition of the near-meltdown that took place in 1997. The government's finances are far sounder, currency reserves are greater and important reforms have been carried out. But, without at least a sense of crisis, analysts say it may be difficult for the government to push ahead with the tough decisions needed for Daewoo and other sectors of the economy.

webTitle: Beleaguered Gore faces battles on three fronts

fields.headline: Beleaguered Gore faces battles on three fronts
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Vice-President Al Gore entered the final fortnight of the election campaign yesterday behind in the polls and fighting battles on three fronts - struggling to motivate apathetic Democrats and trying to win over swing voters while fending off a radical challenge from Ralph Nader, the Green candidate.
fields.body:
Vice-President Al Gore entered the final fortnight of the election campaign yesterday behind in the polls and fighting battles on three fronts - struggling to motivate apathetic Democrats and trying to win over swing voters while fending off a radical challenge from Ralph Nader, the Green candidate.

By contrast, the Texas governor, George W Bush, is able to focus almost solely on undecided voters in a handful of swing states, in the knowledge that the Republican core electorate tends to turn out in greater numbers than its Democratic counterpart.

In the crucial last days of the closest presidential race in four decades, Mr Bush can also draw on a bigger campaign chequebook, principally because of the record amount of "soft money" (unregulated donations to the political parties) raised by the Republican national committee in the past few months.

All the major opinion polls yesterday gave Mr Bush a lead over the vice-president, but the margins differed widely. While a Gallup/CNN/USA Today poll had the Republican contender nine points ahead, surveys in the Washington Post and the New York Times showed a smaller, statistically insignificant, lead of only 2%. Pollsters observed that the margin was eroding as Mr Gore's abrasive performance in the debates receded.

The tactical choices facing each candidate were reflected in their campaigns yesterday. Appearing in Kansas City, Missouri, under the banner "barnstorming for reform", Mr Bush stuck to his "anti-establishment outsider" theme, declaring: "When I go to Washington, I won't be looking for arguments, I'll be looking for answers."

The line has been market-tested among undecided voters, who pollsters found had negative reactions to the word "Washington". Meanwhile the Democratic party issued a new political broadcast attacking Mr Bush's record as Texas governor, especially in education. The advertisement claimed that 40% of Texas high school students fail to graduate.

Democratic aides acknowledge that it is unusual to be so focused on specific issues so late in the election. The Gore campaign is now trying to win back voters who agree with the vice-president on the issues but were alienated by his hectoring performance in the first and third debates.

At the same time the Gore camp is facing the possibility that Mr Nader, the Green party candidate, could draw away enough Democratic votes to swing the election in as many as six swing states. Although Mr Nader still has less than the 5% support needed to win federal funding in the next election, he poses a threat to Mr Gore in states where the environment is a leading issue, such as Oregon and Washington, or where leftwing populism is still strong, such as Wisconsin, Minnesota, Michigan and Maine.

In response to this threat, the Gore camp has launched a rearguard campaign, portraying a vote for Mr Nader as a vote for Mr Bush.

fields.headline: Hyundai overhauls to stay afloat
fields.trailText: South Korea's Hyundai Engineering & Construction is to lay off around a quarter of its 255 executive-level employees and overhaul its business lines in what analysts called a desperate attempt to stay afloat. "We will cut a combined 63 executive-level officials," a statement said.
fields.body:
South Korea's Hyundai Engineering & Construction is to lay off around a quarter of its 255 executive-level employees and overhaul its business lines in what analysts called a desperate attempt to stay afloat. "We will cut a combined 63 executive-level officials," a statement said.

The lay-off plan is a follow-up to a self-rescue plan Hyundai delivered to creditors last week, pledging 581bn won (£356m) in new fund-raising and upping its year-end target for the sale of assets to 1.6 trillion won. The company will also close two domestic offices and four overseas units in order to reduce costs.

The builder said it would seek foreign investment and alliances with foreign partners.

Analysts said the lay-off plan was a step in the right direction but warned cash-generating restructuring steps needed to be realised.

"Hyundai's decision to cut executives in the face of mounting pressure to reduce its debts shows its will to make every effort for restructuring, but I don't see how this will help much," said Lee Kye-joon, an analyst at Daishin Securities. "But if other strong rescue plans are followed later, it will make a difference."

Fears of liquidity problems at Hyundai were reignited last week after the firm said it had raised only a third of the 1.5 trillion won it told creditors in May it would raise this year.

Hyundai's shares closed down 60 won at 1,610 won.

fields.headline: At this price?  Carphone Warehouse
fields.trailText: Most Carphone Warehouse investors got their first chance to sell their shares yesterday, as a three-month "lock-in" period ended following the company's flotation.
fields.body:
Most Carphone Warehouse investors got their first chance to sell their shares yesterday, as a three-month "lock-in" period ended following the company's flotation.

Unfortunately, the price has fallen from its initial level of 200p to just 160p, amid murmurs that the firm's growth prospects have been a little over-hyped.

Doubters point out that WAP phones, which offer access to the internet, have hardly taken the world by storm so far. Bad news from handset manufacturers such as Ericsson and Motorola have fuelled the general pessimism, and there are fears that the company could suffer as more network providers open their own high-street shops.

Chairman Charles Dunstone has been the biggest loser - his 36.6% stake has declined in value from £620m to less than £500m.

However, the shares have performed little worse than the market as a whole over the summer. Carphone Warehouse still has good growth prospects - 90m phones were sold in western Europe last year, and the figure is likely to rise to 315m by 2005.

Although WAP technology has got off to a slow start, the real high-speed technology is yet to arrive and most analysts still believe that phones will be the most popular way of accessing the internet within five years. Carphone Warehouse is bound to benefit - as more complicated phones hit the market, the already impenetrable jungle of price deals is likely to get thicker and customers will need advice more than ever.

The travails of the likes of Ericsson and Motorola could create a slight squeeze, as these try to squeeze better margins out of retailers. But with more than 1,000 shops across Europe, Carphone Warehouse is in a very strong bargaining position.

The shares are trading on well over 35 times expected earnings, which remains a hefty rating in the downtrodden retailing sector. However, the company's annual results, due on November 6, could calm a few critics and investors should hold on at least until then.

webTitle: North Korea thaw as Albright meets Kim

fields.headline: North Korea thaw as Albright meets Kim
fields.standfirst: Special report: Korea
fields.trailText: The world's last cold war confrontation moved a step closer to a thaw yesterday when the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, met the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, in the highest level contact ever between the two states.
fields.body:
The world's last cold war confrontation moved a step closer to a thaw yesterday when the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, met the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, in the highest level contact ever between the two states.

In talks lasting more than three hours, Ms Albright is believed to have discussed the possibility of a visit by President Bill Clinton, the North's missile programme and improved diplomatic relations.

The visit, which was arranged in just 48 hours, is seen as a high-stakes gamble by Mr Clinton to leave a positive diplomatic legacy before he leaves the White House in January.

Ms Albright arrived in Pyongyang to a low-key welcome that belied the importance of the visit to both sides. There was little pomp and ceremony and her motorcade drove through almost deserted streets - few people in the North can afford petrol, let alone cars.

The reception was a sharp contrast to the flag-waving crowds that greeted the leaders of South Korea and Russia in the summer when they made their first visits to the North, which is slowly emerging from decades of isolation.

But the handshake between Ms Albright and Mr Kim, which came just six years after the two sides almost went to war over the North's suspected nuclear weapons programme, was more significant.

"This is new from a historical point of view," said the North's leader. "I feel absolutely delighted."

"I'm very glad to be here in your beautiful city," she responded.

The two talked longer than expected and in the evening, Mr Kim - who has a knack of impressing his guests with unexpected warmth - suddenly announced a change in the schedule so that he could host a dinner for Ms Albright.

US officials played down expectations of any new initiatives during the secretary of state's two-day trip, which is primarily designed to test the water for Mr Clinton. The US president has pushed for a rapid improvement in bilateral relations, despite concerns about Pyongyang's record on human rights.

Two weeks ago, during a visit to Washington by Jo Myong Rok - Mr Kim's right-hand man - the two states pledged "to take steps to improve their bilateral relations in the interests of enhancing peace and security in the Asia-Pacific region". Ms Albright is in Pyongyang to assess the sincerity of Mr Kim's intentions, particularly over the North's missile programme, the main issue of concern for Washington and one reason why the US has pushed ahead with research into a "son of star wars" anti-missile system.

If Mr Clinton visits the North, he will expect an assurance that Pyongyang will halt sales of ballistic missiles to states such as Syria and Iraq. Currently, this trade is one of the main sources of foreign currency for the impoverished communist country.

In return for any such concession, Mr Kim would want the US to remove North Korea from its list of state sponsors of terrorism - the main obstacle to foreign trade and investment that Pyongyang desperately needs after a decade of drought, famine and economic decline.

Last week, Britain, Germany, Spain and Belgium announced that they were ready to establish full diplomatic relations, but Mr Kim knows that he needs American support to gain access to the World Bank, and to receive development assistance from Japan.

Analysts believe that the growing likelihood of a victory by George W Bush - who has been far more hawkish towards Pyongyang - in the US presidential election next month could push the North to give ground.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.body:
In our report, page 18, October 21, on the trial of General Krstic in the Hague for alleged crimes committed in and around the town of Srebrenica in July 1995, a statement made by General Mladic, the commander of the Bosnian Serb forces, threatening revenge on the "Turks", meaning the Muslim people, was wrongly attributed to General Krstic. An ambiguity in the filed report was wrongly resolved in the editing.
Manet's painting, A Bar at the Folies-Bergère, only a detail of which was shown as the Portrait of the week, page 5, Saturday Review, October 21, was reversed. Apologies.
The bird captioned "Nightingale: invisible", page 7, G2, yesterday, is visibly a skylark, as the caption supplied to us clearly said.
In our report about Sir Eduardo Paolozzi, page 6, yesterday, we intended to refer to him as a senior academician (a senior member of the Royal Academy of Arts), rather than as a senior academic.
A condensed version of a story about the sudden drop in value of the Queen's stake in Getmapping.com, page 11. later editions October 21, made our mathematics look bizarre. It said that HM's shares, which at the time the company was floated were worth £912,000, "halved to £195,840 yesterday". Earlier editions made it clear that "halved" referred to the fact that "nearly half of the value of the stake" was lost in a single day.
The pupils killed in the Lyme Bay tragedy, page 2, Guardian Education, October 17, came from Plymouth, in Devon, not from Dorset.
In a report headed, Uncivil service for staff with low morale, page 6, yesterday, we referred to the head of the civil service as Sir Richard Butler, conflating the names of the present holder of the office and his predecessor. The head of the civil service from 1988 to 1998 was Sir Robin Butler (now Lord Brockwell). Since then it has been Sir Richard Wilson. Apologies to both.
In our map of venues for the forthcoming Rugby League World Cup we placed Craven Park, Barrow, on the south shore of the Humber estuary, some way from its real location on the opposite coast of England, in south Cumbria.
The world chess championship is being played over 16 games, not 20 as we wrongly stated in our report, Long day's journey into knight, page 9, Sport, October 21.

webTitle: Blair accused of failing the environment

fields.headline: Blair accused of failing the environment
fields.standfirst:
The prime minister is preparing to deliver his first speech on green issues in nearly four years. But he is deeply at odds with campaigners
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Green groups waiting for Tony Blair's first speech on the environment in almost four years yesterday challenged the prime minister to admit that Labour had failed to advance many environmental issues since coming to power.
fields.body:
Green groups waiting for Tony Blair's first speech on the environment in almost four years yesterday challenged the prime minister to admit that Labour had failed to advance many environmental issues since coming to power.

Charles Secrett, director of Friends of the Earth, said: "He and his inner circle still think that the environmental agenda is against people, against science, against business and against the poor. It's a desperately outdated social democrat myth."

Mr Blair promised in 1997 to "put concern for the environment at the heart of Labour policy-making", after criticising the Tories' environmental record.

But he has turned to openly blaming major lobby groups for opposing him over GM, traffic reduction, fuel duties, waste, and road safety. He is widely expected to accuse the environment groups of "dogma" later today.

One view, backed by No 10, is that Labour had too many other priorities, such as education and health, to deal with in their first term and would move firmly behind a fuller environmental agenda during a second term.

But the goodwill on both sides has evaporated, with Mr Blair's advisers questioning green groups' authority and the groups in turn accusing him of running scared.

Lord Melchett, director of Greenpeace, said : "With John Prescott and Michael Meacher Labour has got the most committed environment team ever. Yet there's a view in certain parts of the party of environment being an old Labour preoccupation. It's so ignorant, it's hard to believe."

"It's been all spin without the substance", a Green party spokesman said.

"Mr Blair appointed an oil mogul [Lord Simon of BP] as a minister of competitiveness and an avowed GM enthusiast [Lord Sainsbury] as a minister of science.

"He takes advice from people who would gain from not addressing environmental concerns. He has failed to address the social and economic cases for environmental policies."

Lynn Sloman of Transport 2000 said: "Labour started with a huge commitment to tackle transport but, although the department of the environment has done really good work, No 10 is now running scared of the extreme motorists' lobby".

Damian Green, the Conservative environment spokesman, yesterday praised Mr Meacher but said that "when he goes up to Blair there's just nothing there. Blair doesn't think [environment] is an important issue."

The specific charges are that Mr Blair and his close advisers have been more concerned with winning over the business community than with effecting real environmental improvements. The marginalisation of the environment came, they say, weeks after Mr Blair's only speech on the environment when he ditched the In Trust for Tomorrow policy paper which was considered progressive.

Since then, Mr Blair and No 10 have scotched the fuel escalator tax, blocked minimal targets for traffic reduction and rejected a pesticide tax which would have penalised rich farmers.

On GM, they say, Mr Blair's support for the controversial technology sought to appease the US and large companies over the genuine concerns of the majority of people. No 10 has also, they say, specifically said "yes" to heavier lorries and backed down on action to reduce speeds.

They also accuse Mr Blair of running scared of tackling congestion, preferring to try to limit the growth in car numbers, reintroducing a road building policy by stealth and not recognising the potential of alternative energies.

But there is widespread approval of the Department for the Environment, which has pushed through the wildlife and countryside bill which protects habitats and allows walkers access to hundreds of thousands of acres previously denied them.

More surprisingly, there is growing support for the Treasury, which has introduced a series of environmental taxes, and the Department of Trade and Industry.

Lord Melchett said: "Until recently, the DTI was the evil empire, little better than under the Tories.

"But Stephen Byers has made some very significant shifts, even calling for a green industrial revolution."

Labour's balance sheet

Transport

For The 10 year transport spending plan should eventually improve public transport and will make more money available for traffic management schemes. Plans to allow local authorities to levy money via road pricing and car parking are in the pipeline. More money has gone to local authorities for transport plans.

Against The number of car journeys is still rising, leading to more congestion and environmental problems. Public transport has still not improved much. The 10 year plan also raises the prospect of a return to widespread road building, which may be bitterly resisted by local communities.

Food

For The government has set up the independent food standards agency and tried to educate the public over nutrition. There has been a small rise in the level of support for organic farming and a glimmering of understanding that environmentally sensitive farming pays social and economic dividends.

Against Agriculture is in long-term crisis with the smallest farms going under. The government has consistently backed GM technology and is proceeding as fast as politically possible with its commercial development.

Energy

For The government announced a 10% target for renewable energy by 2010, a significant improvement on the previous government.

Against The 10% target is welcome but does not go nearly far enough. The Commons environment committee and Friends of the Earth have argued for a 20% target by 2010.

Wildlife and countryside

For Labour's significant green contribution should now go through parliament early next month. The countryside and rights of way bill gives legal protection to Britain's finest wildlife sites. There has also been action to defend peatlands.

Economy

For Labour, says Friends of the Earth, has begun to understand the idea that the quality of economic growth matters, not just its quantity. The 1999 Budget contained more than 20 green measures: taxes on pollution and waste, and reduced taxes on employment. There have also been moves towards putting taxes on aggregates, landfill and company cars.

Climate change

For Tony Blair is credited with taking a lead on reducing carbon emissions, the main greenhouse warming gas. Labour has promised to cut carbon dioxide emissions by 2010 by 20% from 1990 levels. The government eventually gave tacit support to the warm homes bill, designed to end the scandal of fuel poverty and excess winter deaths.

For The government has produced the first targets for household recycling.

fields.bodyText: Green groups waiting for Tony Blair's first speech on the environment in almost four years yesterday challenged the prime minister to admit that Labour had failed to advance many environmental issues since coming to power. Charles Secrett, director of Friends of the Earth, said: "He and his inner circle still think that the environmental agenda is against people, against science, against business and against the poor. It's a desperately outdated social democrat myth." Mr Blair promised in 1997 to "put concern for the environment at the heart of Labour policy-making", after criticising the Tories' environmental record. But he has turned to openly blaming major lobby groups for opposing him over GM, traffic reduction, fuel duties, waste, and road safety. He is widely expected to accuse the environment groups of "dogma" later today. One view, backed by No 10, is that Labour had too many other priorities, such as education and health, to deal with in their first term and would move firmly behind a fuller environmental agenda during a second term. But the goodwill on both sides has evaporated, with Mr Blair's advisers questioning green groups' authority and the groups in turn accusing him of running scared. Lord Melchett, director of Greenpeace, said : "With John Prescott and Michael Meacher Labour has got the most committed environment team ever. Yet there's a view in certain parts of the party of environment being an old Labour preoccupation. It's so ignorant, it's hard to believe." "It's been all spin without the substance", a Green party spokesman said. "Mr Blair appointed an oil mogul [Lord Simon of BP] as a minister of competitiveness and an avowed GM enthusiast [Lord Sainsbury] as a minister of science. "He takes advice from people who would gain from not addressing environmental concerns. He has failed to address the social and economic cases for environmental policies." Lynn Sloman of Transport 2000 said: "Labour started with a huge commitment to tackle transport but, although the department of the environment has done really good work, No 10 is now running scared of the extreme motorists' lobby". Damian Green, the Conservative environment spokesman, yesterday praised Mr Meacher but said that "when he goes up to Blair there's just nothing there. Blair doesn't think [environment] is an important issue." The specific charges are that Mr Blair and his close advisers have been more concerned with winning over the business community than with effecting real environmental improvements. The marginalisation of the environment came, they say, weeks after Mr Blair's only speech on the environment when he ditched the In Trust for Tomorrow policy paper which was considered progressive. Since then, Mr Blair and No 10 have scotched the fuel escalator tax, blocked minimal targets for traffic reduction and rejected a pesticide tax which would have penalised rich farmers. On GM, they say, Mr Blair's support for the controversial technology sought to appease the US and large companies over the genuine concerns of the majority of people. No 10 has also, they say, specifically said "yes" to heavier lorries and backed down on action to reduce speeds. They also accuse Mr Blair of running scared of tackling congestion, preferring to try to limit the growth in car numbers, reintroducing a road building policy by stealth and not recognising the potential of alternative energies. But there is widespread approval of the Department for the Environment, which has pushed through the wildlife and countryside bill which protects habitats and allows walkers access to hundreds of thousands of acres previously denied them. More surprisingly, there is growing support for the Treasury, which has introduced a series of environmental taxes, and the Department of Trade and Industry. Lord Melchett said: "Until recently, the DTI was the evil empire, little better than under the Tories. "But Stephen Byers has made some very significant shifts, even calling for a green industrial revolution." The 10 year plan also raises the prospect of a return to widespread road building, which may be bitterly resisted by local communities. webTitle: General's 'Songs for Timorese' branded a sick stunt

fields.headline: General's 'Songs for Timorese' branded a sick stunt
fields.standfirst: Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Crooning slushy, sentimental ballads in a style that would make Eurovision song contest entrants cringe does not feature often in the political repertoire of Indonesia's former military chief and strongman, retired General Wiranto.
fields.body:
Crooning slushy, sentimental ballads in a style that would make Eurovision song contest entrants cringe does not feature often in the political repertoire of Indonesia's former military chief and strongman, retired General Wiranto.

But the disgraced officer, dismissed after being held responsible for much of last year's violence in East Timor, has released his debut album with the proceeds purportedly being used to aid tens of thousands of the victims of his policies and actions. More than 120,000 of these are East Timorese who are living in squalid conditions in West Timor.

On Sunday, in front of 200 people , who each paid £70 for the pleasure, Gen Wiranto, 53, launched his CD, For You My Indonesia, with a concert of his hits. The self-confessed karaoke addict, who belted out Feelings at a veterans' gathering last year as his troops were massacring innocent East Timorese, warbled through several numbers.

During a break for dinner he told the audience that 7,300 copies of the CD had already been sold, raising some 500m rupiah (£40,000) for the refugees. A further 351m rupiah was raised through an auction of golden discs.

Gen Wiranto earlier denied any political motivation behind his new career. "I'm doing this because I can," he said. "Don't say that this is anything to do with politics. It's not."

Human rights activists are horrified by his charm offensive. "This is a sick and tasteless attempt to rehabilitate his reputation," said Munir, a leading human rights lawyer who believes that Gen Wiranto's antics are part of a long road back to acceptability and then political power.

Gen Wiranto was sacked in February as President Abdurrahman Wahid took increasing flak over the atrocities in East Timor. He has denied that he was responsible for the violence in East Timor.

webTitle: Lesbians 'bigger risk takers' than straight women

fields.headline: Lesbians 'bigger risk takers' than straight women
fields.trailText: Lesbians and bisexual women are more promiscuous than straight women and just as vulnerable to sexually transmitted diseases, a study indicates.
fields.body:
Lesbians and bisexual women are more promiscuous than straight women and just as vulnerable to sexually transmitted diseases, a study indicates.

Australian researchers also found that women who had sex with other women were more likely to have got pregnant, had abortions or injected drugs.

A team led by Katherine Fethers at Sydney hospital analysed the medical records of almost 3,000 women, about half of whom had experienced lesbian sex. All had attended a public sexual health clinic.

Records suggest that women who have sex with women "show considerable sexual and non-sexual risk-taking behaviours", the researchers said.

Some 93% of them reported sexual contact with a man - 9% with more than 50 partners, compared with 2% of heterosexual women. They were three times more likely to have had sex with a homosexual or bisexual man. In addition, a history of pregnancy and abortion was more common.

Women with female sexual partners were six times more likely to inject drugs, and were significantly more at risk from hepatitis B and C. Of the total, five lesbians and three heterosexuals were HIV positive.

Press Association

webTitle: BBC's MacIntyre to sue police force

fields.headline: BBC's MacIntyre to sue police force
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: The investigative journalist Donal MacIntyre launched a libel action against a police force yesterday over comments it made about his report into abuse at a care home.
fields.body:
The investigative journalist Donal MacIntyre launched a libel action against a police force yesterday over comments it made about his report into abuse at a care home.

Kent police had claimed the documentary was misleading, but Mr MacIntyre stood by his programme and said the remarks had damaged his reputation as a journalist. He has not yet decided whether to take legal action against the Sunday Telegraph, which reported the police concerns.

Mr MacIntyre, whose action is understood to be funded by the BBC, stood outside Broadcasting House to announce that he had issued a writ. It names the chief constable of Kent, a detective inspector and the force's media spokesman.

Accompanied by the BBC's director of television, Mark Thompson, Mr MacIntyre said that issuing the writ was a matter of "personal regret". The force said it would "vigorously contest" the legal action.

The row centres on an edition of MacIntyre Undercover broadcast in November last year, in which the reporter investigated the Brompton Care Home in Gillingham, Kent. He claimed to have unearthed a culture of neglect, and within 24 hours of the secretly filmed programme Medway council closed the home down. Four other homes were also shut down with the loss of 84 jobs.

Two people were cautioned for assault, but detectives said their findings "paint a very different picture to the one we expected to find" after the documentary was aired. Detectives criticised the programme for "misleading editing": Mr MacIntyre obtained 41 hours of tape during covert filming.

The force said it had considered whether to sue for the £50,000 cost of the police investigation, but the BBC said it had not yet received a writ.

Mr MacIntyre said: "What is really important here is the level of neglect and abuse that we uncovered. It is a fundamental purpose of journalism to give voice to those who are unable to speak for themselves. It would not serve public interest if our findings were diminished by defamatory comments by Kent police."

Mr Thompson said the corporation "fully supports" Mr MacIntyre's actions. "We believe we have a duty to defend the reputation and integrity of our journalists and programme makers. We are also determined to ensure that public confidence in the findings of the programme is not undermined."

Kent police confirmed that the force had received a writ naming Chief Constable Sir David Phillips, Detective Sergeant Michael Costello and the force's media services manager, Mark Pugash.

webTitle: Spain lured by romance of the Legion

fields.headline: Spain lured by romance of the Legion
fields.standfirst: The previously shunned legionnaire is crucial to Madrid's military revival
fields.trailText: The Spanish Foreign Legion, the most eccentric and controversial of the country's army units, has had to survive defeat abroad and ostracism at home because of its links with the late dictator, General Franco. But with Spain's armed forces due to become fully professional by 2002, and conscription being phased out, the legion - with its tough reputation - could become the country's top elite force.
fields.body:
The Spanish Foreign Legion, the most eccentric and controversial of the country's army units, has had to survive defeat abroad and ostracism at home because of its links with the late dictator, General Franco. But with Spain's armed forces due to become fully professional by 2002, and conscription being phased out, the legion - with its tough reputation - could become the country's top elite force.

Despite high unemployment, Spanish youngsters remain wary of a military career. For years after Franco's reign, the army, badly paid and poorly equipped, was viewed with suspicion.

Now Spain's increasing role on the world stage means that the government is intent on modernising the armed forces. The romantic image of the legion - which celebrated the 80th anniversary of its foundation last month - means that it has less difficulty attracting recruits than most other units. It even accepts women in frontline roles, although they form a tiny percentage of recruits.

Mysticism

"The legion carries an element of mysticism about it," its commander in chief, General Enrique Gomariz de Robles, said. "It's a very special interpretation of military life - like a wife, you either love her and accept her unconditionally, or leave."

Set up in 1920 to safeguard Spain's possessions in North Africa, the legion was modelled closely on its French counterpart. No questions were asked as long as recruits accepted the harsh conditions and the unit's strict code of honour.

With soldiers in its ranks from more than 30 countries, the legion is famous for its fast marching step (120 paces to the minute), its glamorous uniforms and its song, Death's Lover.

It was strongly identified with Franco, one of its early commanders, who launched his military uprising from North Africa. But for today's legionnaires, Franco is little more than a footnote. They revere the legion's charismatic founder, Jose Millan de Astray, who envisaged the unit as a place where outcasts could be redeemed and proposed a Samurai-like code of honour.

"For a time we were identified with a particular period in our history and a particular political regime," said one officer. "It was unfair, the legion has served governments across the political spectrum faithfully, but it happened and we very nearly disappeared as a result."

In the 1980s, socialist administrations imposed defence cuts. The legion lost its power to recruit foreigners and the special pay rates which rewarded tougher conditions. Many legionnaires took up the offer of generous retirement pay-offs.

Then, Spain's incorporation into the international community saved the legion. "We were the closest Spain came to an elite force, to a professional army with real esprit de corps, and readiness to operate on the front line," one veteran said.

It has now been reorganised into four divisions - two protecting Ceuta and Melilla, Spain's African enclaves, two specialising in rapid deployment and peacekeeping - and is the nucleus of Spain's special forces.

"There is a before and an after Bosnia in our history," said Gen Gomariz de Robles. Coverage of the conflict, where the legion provided the bulk of Spain's peacekeepers, made legionnaires heroes once more.

Colonel Enrique de Vivero, who commands the Melilla contingent, said: "[In the past] people would join to wipe out the past, often not caring whether they lived or died. Now our recruits are a pretty fair representation of young Spaniards, of society as a whole."

Grumbles

But for some old-timers, the changes have gone too far. They grumble about a "decaffeinated legion" where the talk is all of peace and never of war. Troops are encouraged to live outside barracks. Their quarters within would put many university residences to shame.

The biggest change of all is the incorporation of women. "The romance of it appeals to women as much as men," said one female recruit. "I sing the Death's Lover as loudly as them and get the same shivers up my spine."

The legionnaires celebrated the 80th birthday of their unit dancing in desert tents and drinking panther's milk, a mix of condensed milk and gin invented when legionnaires ran out of water in the desert.

"I joined in 1986", recalled one sergeant. "I was a biker in trouble with the police. Here no one asked questions. I've lived the dark side of life and I'm not afraid of death. I've got a wife and a child but I'm convinced I'll die in a trench somewhere. That's the legion. But tell that to one of these 18-year-olds who's never seen the dark side of anything and try to push him into the front line."

"Yes, just try", retorted a bunch of recruits. "And see what we can do."

fields.headline: International news in brief
fields.trailText: Boesak's prison sentence cut
fields.body:
Boesak's prison sentence cut

The South African prison authorities have cut 10 months off the flamboyant cleric Allan Boesak's three-year jail sentence, for good behaviour. He will be eligible for parole next June.

Boesak, a prominent anti-apartheid campaigner during the 1980s, was convicted of stealing 1.3m rand (£118,000) of donor funds.
Reuters, Cape Town

Dead coral reefs warning

More than a quarter of the world's coral reefs have been destroyed by pollution and global warming, and most of the remaining reefs could be dead in 20 years, scientists at a symposium in Bali, warned yesterday.
AP, Indonesia

Secrets of old city uncovered

Construction workers uncovered 62 ancient lead and bronze tablets in Argos, southern Greece, the culture ministry said yesterday. The slabs, dating from between 480 and 338BC, show how the ancient city was run.
AP, Athens

Tamil Tigers hit naval base

Tamil Tiger rebels in explosive-laden boats launched a suicide bomb attack on a naval base at Trincomalee, 150 miles north-east of Colombo, at dawn yesterday, sinking one vessel and damaging a gunboat. They later shot down a Sri Lankan air force helicopter.
AP, Colombo

Landmine kills five children

A landmine disguised as a child's toy exploded in Pakistan yesterday, killing five children. It happened in Kharsappa, 12 miles from Peshawar, the capital of the Northwest Frontier Province.
AP, Pakistan

fields.headline: Louis Moss
fields.standfirst: Idealistic pioneer in the field of social research
fields.trailText: Louis Moss, who has died aged 84, was one of the great architects of Britain's eminent position in social research.
fields.body:
Louis Moss, who has died aged 84, was one of the great architects of Britain's eminent position in social research. In 1941, he set up the wartime social survey, which researched such issues as public morale, and which, as part of Duff Cooper's Ministry of Information, was dubbed "Cooper's Snoopers". It was a time when many of the fundamentals of information gathering, such as probability sampling, trained interviewer inquiry and structured questionnaires, were in their infancy. Moss led the development and use of these and other techniques that soon became established methods of social inquiry, both within government and more widely. But he did more than that. He also pioneered rigorous standards of good practice and a culture of integrity in high-quality, innovative research.

Moss laid the organisational groundwork for a government social-survey capability within the post-war Central Office of Information and later the Office of Population Censuses and Surveys - now a division of the Office for National Statistics - which became the leading survey research organisation in Britain, with an enviable international reputation. He also had an eye for talent and the ability to draw out the best in his colleagues. He was director of the social survey from 1941 to 1970, after which he became adviser for survey research until 1975.

During Moss's stewardship, many of today's major survey programmes that assist several important areas of government policy were designed and implemented. These included, since 1957, the family expenditure survey, the international passenger survey since 1961 and, from 1970, the general household survey. He was also responsible for many other inquiries into nearly all areas of social policy concern, in an age before desktop computers or even electronic calculators were part of the basic toolkit of statistical researchers. He was a tireless campaigner for entrenching sample survey inquiry as an instrument for government policy and for the open publication of results and methods.

His work took him overseas, and among his many trips were two secondments that he held in particular affection: in 1955 he appraised the need for a study of Puerto Rico's official agricultural services and then, in 1958-59, he worked, under the Colombo Plan, for the government of the then Ceylon reviewing their data methods.

After retiring from government service in 1975, Moss continued his work and interest in social research as a visiting professor in the department of statistics at Birkbeck College, London, until 1984. He also wrote a history of the social survey for its 50th anniversary in 1991.

Moss was born in the east end of London, the eldest son of first-generation east European immigrants. He was the first in the family to go to grammar school, the first to go abroad (Spain), to go to university (the London School of Economics) and to be a socialist. He had a democratic vision of what the world should be like. His philosophy was that work should be serious and should be part of making a better world.

His capacity to participate in political and social affairs and to pursue his private loves of walking in London and tending his garden were slowly diminished by Parkinson's disease. Typically, he found out all he could about the disease and took satisfaction in there being a National Health Service and a local social services system, sufficiently intact, to serve him for the rest of his days.

His wife Winifred died in 1984. He is survived by his partner, Jean Atkinson, and his sons Andrew and Stephen.

In 1941, he set up the wartime social survey, which researched such issues as public morale, and which, as part of Duff Cooper's Ministry of Information, was dubbed "Cooper's Snoopers". It was a time when many of the fundamentals of information gathering, such as probability sampling, trained interviewer inquiry and structured questionnaires, were in their infancy. Moss led the development and use of these and other techniques that soon became established methods of social inquiry, both within government and more widely. But he did more than that. He also pioneered rigorous standards of good practice and a culture of integrity in high-quality, innovative research. Moss laid the organisational groundwork for a government social-survey capability within the post-war Central Office of Information and later the Office of Population Censuses and Surveys - now a division of the Office for National Statistics - which became the leading survey research organisation in Britain, with an enviable international reputation. He also had an eye for talent and the ability to draw out the best in his colleagues. He was director of the social survey from 1941 to 1970, after which he became adviser for survey research until 1975. During Moss's stewardship, many of today's major survey programmes that assist several important areas of government policy were designed and implemented. These included, since 1957, the family expenditure survey, the international passenger survey since 1961 and, from 1970, the general household survey. He was also responsible for many other inquiries into nearly all areas of social policy concern, in an age before desktop computers or even electronic calculators were part of the basic toolkit of statistical researchers. He was a tireless campaigner for entrenching sample survey inquiry as an instrument for government policy and for the open publication of results and methods. His work took him overseas, and among his many trips were two secondments that he held in particular affection: in 1955 he appraised the need for a study of Puerto Rico's official agricultural services and then, in 1958-59, he worked, under the Colombo Plan, for the government of the then Ceylon reviewing their data methods. After retiring from government service in 1975, Moss continued his work and interest in social research as a visiting professor in the department of statistics at Birkbeck College, London, until 1984. He also wrote a history of the social survey for its 50th anniversary in 1991. Moss was born in the east end of London, the eldest son of first-generation east European immigrants. He was the first in the family to go to grammar school, the first to go abroad (Spain), to go to university (the London School of Economics) and to be a socialist. He had a democratic vision of what the world should be like. His philosophy was that work should be serious and should be part of making a better world. His capacity to participate in political and social affairs and to pursue his private loves of walking in London and tending his garden were slowly diminished by Parkinson's disease. Typically, he found out all he could about the disease and took satisfaction in there being a National Health Service and a local social services system, sufficiently intact, to serve him for the rest of his days. His wife Winifred died in 1984. He is survived by his partner, Jean Atkinson, and his sons Andrew and Stephen. Louis Moss, social researcher, born November 7 1915; died September 29 2000

webTitle: Two square miles of housing hell

fields.headline: Two square miles of housing hell
fields.standfirst: Residents of Headingley in Leeds claim their community is being wrecked by unscrupulous landlords and their rowdy student tenants
fields.trailText: Every morning Harold Best, Labour MP for Leeds North West, gets up early to pick the chip trays out of his flower beds. Clutching a plastic bag, he makes his way past the rats and the occasional spray of vomit to clear up the burger buns in the street. His wife, Glyn, 61, stays inside. She is recovering from depression after two years of the neighbours kicking a football at 2am against the nine-inch wall that separates the two semi-detached houses. Last month, the Bests had their neighbours - eight students - evicted and a public inquiry has ruled that the house should no longer accommodate students.

Every morning Harold Best, Labour MP for Leeds North West, gets up early to pick the chip trays out of his flower beds. Clutching a plastic bag, he makes his way past the rats and the occasional spray of vomit to clear up the burger buns in the street. His wife, Glyn, 61, stays inside. She is recovering from depression after two years of the neighbours kicking a football at 2am against the nine-inch wall that separates the two semi-detached houses. Last month, the Bests had their neighbours - eight students - evicted and a public inquiry has ruled that the house should no longer accommodate students.

This is Headingley, two square miles of leafy Leeds suburb, last year classified by an economic and research council survey as the perfect home for twentysomethings. Two-thirds of Headingley's 22,000 residents are second and third year students living in shared houses. It is now the scene of a war between long-term family residents and absentee private landlords. This week, government ministers and representatives from Edinburgh, Birmingham and other cities will attend a conference to see what they can learn from Headingley, where residents say the trend for shared houses is destroying the fabric of community life.

Exodus of families

Twenty years ago, Headingley was a quiet Tory suburb, where students lodged with families. Now a Labour seat, around half the properties are shared houses owned by private landlords, many absentee. There are roughly 40 letting shops in a one mile radius. In the past three years, more than 8,500 families have left. Last year 1,600 houses were converted to house students. House prices have risen by 50%, knocking first-time buyers out of the market. Schools fear closure because of a shortage of children in the area.

Because students move on, there is an electoral roll-over of 52% a year in Headingley, compared with an average 8% in other Leeds wards. When last year's council elections were held in the holidays, there was a 16% turnout. Local shops have been replaced by takeaways. Council services are feeling the strain and at least 40% of residents do not pay council tax, because students are exempt. Residents complain of foxes and rats.

"The universities in Leeds are like William Blake's dark satanic mills. They are polluters blighting the landscape and the polluter must pay," said Mr Best. "The proliferation of shared houses with absentee landlords is like a medieval plague. Landlords will pillage until there is no more left, until they have turned Headingley into a desert, and then they will move on.

"Geographers are studying the problem, but by the time they complete their PhDs in five years' time, the destruction of Headingley will be complete." He said one elderly resident had come to him in tears after asking some students to turn their music down at 2am. They had told her: "Shut up you fucking old cow, this is a student area."

The Headingley issue is not town versus gown. The area has six residents associations fighting what they term landlordism - profit-driven, absentee landlords cramming as many students as possible into houses, ignoring noise problems and leaving gardens unkempt, even though Headingley rents of £45 a room per week are £10 higher than other areas of Leeds. When one group, Headingley Against Landlordism (Heal) issued a leaflet telling local residents to call landlords directly and complain, preferably at 3am, the Leeds Property Association, which represents landlords, threatened legal action, arguing that landlords were being harassed.

Bill Rollinson, chairman, of Heal, said: "We have all had leaflets asking us to think about selling our houses for landlord developments. We dread landlords moving into our streets. Families who are selling up always try to make sure they sell to other families. But prospective landlords are coming round to view houses with children in tow to try to fool us."

Residents say they have no grudge against students. Many residents studied in Leeds and have stayed on in the area. Bronwen Holden, secretary of Heal, has student children and her husband is professor of physiology at the University of Leeds - the third largest employer in the city, providing more than 10,000 jobs and contributing £500m annually to the local economy. One in five Leeds University graduates from outside West Yorkshire stay in Leeds after their degrees - many in Headingley.

The University of Leeds and Leeds Metropolitan University say they take residents' complaints seriously and are leading the country in setting up schemes to ease community relations. In partnership with the local council they have created the first post in the country to liaise between residents and the universities - the post has been given to a 24-year-old former student with experience of Headingley.

On North Lane in Headingley, at R K Harris greengrocer's, a student placed one baking potato worth 22p on the scales, exchanged it for a smaller one worth 17p, then counted out the change in coppers. Keith Harris, who has run the shop for 25 years, said students brought excellent business in term time which compensated for the drought in the holidays.

'Yorkshire pride'

Damien Timms, 20, a third year student from London, said: "Students have put this city on the map, we have sparked redevelopment and attracted loads of young professionals who live their own shared-house lifestyles. Students have brought Harvey Nichols here. Residents only complain because they're Yorkshire people. They're proud."

The government has a national target for 28% of the population to be educated to a higher level by 2002 and other cities are already experiencing the Headingley phenomenon. In Birmingham, 40% of properties in parts of Selly Oak, 60% in some streets, have been turned into shared houses.

In Southampton, the same is happening in the Polygon and Portswood areas, as it is in parts of south Edinburgh. In Newcastle, the market has fallen slightly in the Fenham area, and left a surplus of shared houses empty, while values plummet - something letting agents are warning could happen in Headingley if the market overheats.

Harold Best has led a long list of MPs campaigning to restrict the conversion of family homes into houses of multiple occupancy. He is also campaigning for special wardens to patrol neighbourhoods such as Headingley.

Meanwhile, the Labour council in Leeds is losing Headingley seats to the Liberal Democrats, who claim the government is not implementing its promises to sort the situation out.
