fields.headline: Judy Fryd
fields.standfirst: Founder of Mencap and champion of those with learning difficulties
fields.trailText: Judy Fryd, who has died aged 90, would not take no for answer. This was a vital trait for the woman who altered the public's perception of learning disability. Judy Fryd sowed the seeds of Mencap, now the largest disability organisation in the country.
fields.body:
Judy Fryd, who has died aged 90, would not take no for answer. This was a vital trait for the woman who altered the public's perception of learning disability. Judy Fryd sowed the seeds of Mencap, now the largest disability organisation in the country.

Although modest in private, in public Fryd was a dynamic campaigner for children and adults with learning disabilities - people considered 50 years ago as "backward". Today, a person with a learning disability serves on the recently formed Disability Rights Commission and many of those previously in long-stay "sub-normality" hospitals now live independently. The Disability Discrimination Act has further strengthened the rights of disabled people, though the fight is far from over.

Much of this change is largely due to Fryd, who along with a group of fellow parents, banded together more than 50 years ago to form the Association of Parents of Backward Children. This organisation evolved to become the Royal Society for Mentally Handicapped Children and Adults in the 1980s, better known as Mencap.

Born in Hornsey, London, the daughter of a post-office sorter, Fryd was educated at Minchenden School, Southgate and Ruskin College, Oxford, where she met her husband John Fryd: they both read economics and political science. They married in London in 1936 and moved to Leeds, where Fryd gave birth to their first child, Felicity, in 1938. When Felicity showed signs of slow development, Judy and John sought help. It was a frustrating search. After only half a day at a mainstream primary school she was rejected as being too disruptive.

Later, although found a suitable placement, she was deemed "not suitable" and her immediate removal was requested. She was summarily returned to her family who were left to cope alone with her autism and challenging behaviour (then described as juvenile schizophrenia). The lack of understanding from society and the professionals who were supposed to support her angered Fryd.

Her initial step, in 1946, was to respond to a letter in Nursery World magazine which asked if there were other parents struggling to cope with a learning-disabled child at home. Fryd suggested that she and other parents of such children should band together in an effort to receive some kind of recognition - and amelioration - of their desperate plight. Within a month more than 1,000 parents, largely mothers, had joined forces.

Throughout the 50s and 60s, Fryd promoted and researched the needs and potential of people with learning disabilities. She was editor of Parents' Voice for over 25 years. This monthly magazine enabled parents to keep in touch, spread information and rally for positive action. It also helped parents overcome the supposed shame of having a learning-disabled child.

At home, the Fryds were a musical family. Felicity, known by her family as Filly, participated fully within this musical environment, where she would twirl around in circles dancing to Fryd's accomplished piano playing. Along with the rest of the family, Filly had perfect pitch, and her outbursts were often affectionately referred to as her "arias".

Fryd led a campaign which resulted in the 1971 Education (Handicapped Children) Act, overturning the previous thinking that children with a learning disability were ineducable. Until then, parents had to find (and pay for) private education; even so, the children were denied post-war support such as free school milk and vitamin supplements. If private schooling was unavailable or too costly, parents had to look after their son or daughter at home. Or they were certified as mentally defective and dispatched to an NHS long-stay sub-normality hospital.

Although most of what Fryd fought for came too late for her own daughter to benefit, she saw her tiny association grow into Mencap, with a turnover of £100m, 5,500 staff and more than 20,000 volunteers. Today people with learning disabilities serve on the board of trustees, which was unthinkable even 10 years ago. Fryd was positive about Mencap's most recent changes, and felt it made sense to have one-third of its national assembly being people with learning disabilities.

A lifelong member of the Labour Party, Fryd was honoured at the 1991 annual conference in Brighton for outstanding voluntary service to the party. She was a vice-president of Mencap for the last 20 years.

Fryd's husband died in 1981. She is survived by two daughters and a son, and her only grandchild, Elly, born in 1969, who lived with her for the last 10 years. Fryd's daughter Felicity died in 1993.

fields.headline: How I got my First
fields.standfirst: Is a no-fun, all-work egghead your idea of top degree material?   Not a bit of it, say three academic achievers, who did not set out   for glory but somehow found ways and means to get there
fields.trailText: Is a no-fun, all-work egghead your idea of top degree material? Not a bit of it, say three academic achievers, who did not set out for glory but somehow found ways and means to get there.
fields.body:
Mark McArdle

Gained a first-class honours degree in management at Lancaster University

Don't get too drunk at the college bar, do turn up for most lectures and tutorials and do submit all coursework - eventually. That, I was told by a PhD during freshers' week, was all I needed to do to get a 2:2. For a 2:1, I'd require a better attendance record and have to work harder, but not at the expense of being cut off from civilisation. And for a First I would have to become some sort of social outcast, go to every lecture and tutorial (scribbling notes madly), spend every waking moment immersed in academic books, and be among the last to be thrown out of the university library at 10pm closing time. Otherwise I could kiss goodbye to getting the 70% plus marks required.

Well, I am no genius and I would not, and did not, give up my life for study. I didn't attend every lecture and tutorial. I didn't write down every word spoken in lectures. I didn't get 70% or more in every essay, project, test or exam. I was usually behind with my reading and occasionally mystified by the syllabus. Sometimes I couldn't be bothered to go to university and stayed at home instead. But I always knew where I was, what I had to do, and what not to bother with. And I always worked hard on the things that counted: assessments.

I can tell you how I got my first-class degree but I don't necessarily recommend it as good practice. Students have to discover their own methods. This is not a guide to getting a First - it's how I got my First. Getting a degree is about learning, but it isn't just about learning biology, history, English or whatever. It's about understanding what you need to succeed - what, in fact, the university wants from you and what you will get in return. You have to get a feel for the education market and really sell your inspirations. What does the lecturer want? What is the essay marker searching for? What is the examiner expecting?

Some students try to offer something not wanted. Others want to give very little - they steal the thoughts of others and submit them as their own. But they all want to be rewarded. Exchange, but don't steal, and you'll get a degree. Think of the university as a customer and give it what it wants. Delight it and that degree will be a First. Along the way you may learn something. I could guarantee every book on my reading list was out on long loan from the university library within five seconds of the list being issued. This was worrying at first, but I quickly learned that it was impossible to read all of the books on an average reading list, anyway. I sought shortcuts. Collections of selected readings or journal articles were excellent sources that often saved me the bother of reading the original texts. And academic books can be difficult to read and understand. If I found myself re-reading sentences or nodding off, I'd stop. Once I started burrowing into books, it was easy to become engulfed in fine detail.

References in books dragged me all over the place but, with all the courses I had to do, there wasn't enough time to be led too far. I would flick through the book, read the introduction, note any summaries, look at diagrams, skim the index, and read any conclusions. In all my time at university, I did not read one book from start to finish - I plucked out what was needed and made my escape. I knew students who tried to scribble down their lecturer's every word. I did too, at first, but I then quickly realised when it came to revision that most of my lecture notes were useless. I preferred to write selected notes. Most of all, though, I would listen. If you are constantly writing, you are not really listening and the essential feel of the subject is lost. Lecturers are imparting their wisdom in exchange for your attention. The least you can do is listen.

Academics were my customers and I identified two types. There were those for whom lecturing was an unwelcome interruption to their research work. Tutorials served to compound established wisdom, not to confront it. After all, we were students and what did we know? I would deliberately pitch my essays to this kind of academic so that my opinions appeared more as evidence that I had read and understood the key contributions to the debate, rather than as an attempt to pull down monuments. I did not want to be marked down for being an upstart. The other types were those who enjoyed teaching and discussing new ideas. They wanted more. They wanted something different, inspirational, iconoclastic. I would present my arguments to show that I had done my reading and understood the key concepts, but I would also try to add something more to the issue rather than rake over familiar ground. More importantly, I felt safe doing it. Essentially, it was a case of working out what was wanted and then delivering it.

I can't state exactly how successful this tactic was, except to say that I sold more essays than I had returned as faulty. I revised by discarding subject areas I could not face revising; reading; compiling notes; and then condensing them onto one or two sheets of A4 for each subject area. Leading up to the exam, I would concentrate on just the condensed notes and rely on my memory to drag out the detail behind them when the time came. I didn't practice writing exam questions, although it was recommended. I knew the subject areas to be examined but didn't know what kind of interpretation or analysis was required until I turned over the exam paper. It really is a question of understanding this on the day and I prefer to be spontaneous and open-minded. I don't want pre-formed conclusions filling my mind before I've even read the questions.

 Mark McArdle is a contributor to How I Got My First Class Degree edited by Peter Tolmie, Independent Studies, Lancaster University, supported by the Guardian £9.95 (inc p&p), tel: 01524 593430, email: IndStud@lancaster.ac.uk

Kerry Boorman

She failed her 11-plus exam but got a first-class honours degree in theatre studies at Lancaster University

I have no secret to tell. I was just willing to try. Actually, I was trying for a 2:1 but, with a First suddenly coming into sight, my degree gave me 3D perception. That is, my life began to relate to the three dimensions of discipline, dedication and determination. Discipline is not about having your head stuck in a book every second but about being organised - developing a programme and sticking to it. Unfortunately, for me this was not the essay overnight, but a slow and painfully paced effort over three to four weeks. I knew if I did not give an essay this time I would either panic or fall behind. I also knew that structure was my weak point. To compensate, I needed a worthier content, which meant more time, more reading, more effort.

So I often set my own deadlines for about a week earlier than the official ones. This way, even when I did miss my goal, I still hit the important one. But this didn't mean I had no life. Good time management includes study time, personal time and social time, with all three being equally important. Times when I became obsessed with study and sacrificed my social life were unhealthy and ineffective. So discipline and a balanced diet. Most games rely on teamwork, particularly so when it comes to theatre and performance. While pushing others to the limits, I pushed myself and in turn was pushed by them. Tiring, frustrating but rewarding.

Secondly: dedication to the game - that is, to the subject and the result. I was never a swot but I cared about my work. I wanted to win! Not because I had to but because I wanted to and because I deserved to. By setting such high expectations I placed myself under tremendous pressure at times. Yet I went on assigning myself targets I was determined to hit. My practical work struck firsts, but the mark of a first in an essay was an objective I aimed for for two and a half years. Each time I managed near misses - until my last two papers. So, if at first you don't succeed, try again until you do. It's all about determination.

Donna Taylor

She gained a first-class honours degree in English at Edge Hill College

We entered the results hall at about midday. There weren't as many people there as I'd anticipated. There I was, alone. Or so it felt. My friend, Peter, had gone to find my results but I think it was Claire who first saw my name under the title of First Class Hons. Seeing my name there in black capital letters made me feel faint. An entire collection of emotions ran through me: surprise, euphoria, excitement. I couldn't believe I'd got a first. In my book firsts were always for the really bright people and not for the likes of me. Before the surprise could set in and render me still and helpless, a barrage of former tutors and professors came up to offer me their congratulations. However, to be honest, I wasn't really listening to them. My mind was still rigidly fixed upon those letters ...

Actually, it's surprising how getting a first ignites the jealousy in others. You will undoubtedly hear cries of 'Oh well, she had to work really hard' or 'she must have worked hard, she didn't get that mark with natural talent'. Maybe I did, maybe not. I prefer to think my degree mark reflects a combination of hard work and talent. To me they are inextricably linked: you can work as hard as you like but, if you don't understand the work, you'll get nowhere!

There's no secret to getting a first. But if you are following my advice, here is the primary rule: Do not think you are aiming for a first. Set your sights high by all means, but don't start to write every assignment worrying that you have got to get above 70% otherwise your grade will slip. I once started worrying about the 'potential' of one of my essays. As it happens, this assignment got one of my lower marks. Which all goes to prove you can't hope to wave a magic wand and come out of your graduation day dressed like Batman clutching a first-class honours degree. You have to work. But there's a big but. Don't work because you have to, do it because you want to. In brief, then: work, plan, research and don't write anything while drunk. Enjoy yourself - and your work. A happy student is one who gets the balance right between work and play. Then again, what would I know? I'm obviously an egghead!

That, I was told by a PhD during freshers' week, was all I needed to do to get a 2:2. For a 2:1, I'd require a better attendance record and have to work harder, but not at the expense of being cut off from civilisation. And for a First I would have to become some sort of social outcast, go to every lecture and tutorial (scribbling notes madly), spend every waking moment immersed in academic books, and be among the last to be thrown out of the university library at 10pm closing time. Otherwise I could kiss goodbye to getting the 70% plus marks required. Well, I am no genius and I would not, and did not, give up my life for study. I didn't attend every lecture and tutorial. I didn't write down every word spoken in lectures. I didn't get 70% or more in every essay, project, test or exam. I was usually behind with my reading and occasionally mystified by the syllabus. Sometimes I couldn't be bothered to go to university and stayed at home instead. But I always knew where I was, what I had to do, and what not to bother with. And I always worked hard on the things that counted: assessments. I can tell you how I got my first-class degree but I don't necessarily recommend it as good practice. Students have to discover their own methods. This is not a guide to getting a First - it's how I got my First. Getting a degree is about learning, but it isn't just about learning biology, history, English or whatever. It's about understanding what you need to succeed - what, in fact, the university wants from you and what you will get in return. You have to get a feel for the education market and really sell your inspirations. What does the lecturer want? What is the essay marker searching for? What is the examiner expecting? Some students try to offer something not wanted. Others want to give very little - they steal the thoughts of others and submit them as their own. But they all want to be rewarded. Exchange, but don't steal, and you'll get a degree. Think of the university as a customer and give it what it wants. Delight it and that degree will be a First. Along the way you may learn something. I could guarantee every book on my reading list was out on long loan from the university library within five seconds of the list being issued. This was worrying at first, but I quickly learned that it was impossible to read all of the books on an average reading list, anyway. I sought shortcuts. Collections of selected readings or journal articles were excellent sources that often saved me the bother of reading the original texts. And academic books can be difficult to read and understand. If I found myself re-reading sentences or nodding off, I'd stop. Once I started burrowing into books, it was easy to become engulfed in fine detail. References in books dragged me all over the place but, with all the courses I had to do, there wasn't enough time to be led too far. I would flick through the book, read the introduction, note any summaries, look at diagrams, skim the index, and read any conclusions. In all my time at university, I did not read one book from start to finish - I plucked out what was needed and made my escape. I knew students who tried to scribble down their lecturer's every word. I did too, at first, but I then quickly realised when it came to revision that most of my lecture notes were useless. I preferred to write selected notes. Most of all, though, I would listen. If you are constantly writing, you are not really listening and the essential feel of the subject is lost. Lecturers are imparting their wisdom in exchange for your attention. The least you can do is listen. Academics were my customers and I identified two types. There were those for whom lecturing was an unwelcome interruption to their research work. Tutorials served to compound established wisdom, not to confront it. After all, we were students and what did we know? I would deliberately pitch my essays to this kind of academic so that my opinions appeared more as evidence that I had read and understood the key contributions to the debate, rather than as an attempt to pull down monuments. I did not want to be marked down for being an upstart. The other types were those who enjoyed teaching and discussing new ideas. They wanted more. They wanted something different, inspirational, iconoclastic. I would present my arguments to show that I had done my reading and understood the key concepts, but I would also try to add something more to the issue rather than rake over familiar ground. More importantly, I felt safe doing it. Essentially, it was a case of working out what was wanted and then delivering it. I can't state exactly how successful this tactic was, except to say that I sold more essays than I had returned as faulty. I revised by discarding subject areas I could not face revising; reading; compiling notes; and then condensing them onto one or two sheets of A4 for each subject area. Leading up to the exam, I would concentrate on just the condensed notes and rely on my memory to drag out the detail behind them when the time came. I didn't practice writing exam questions, although it was recommended. I knew the subject areas to be examined but didn't know what kind of interpretation or analysis was required until I turned over the exam paper. It really is a question of understanding this on the day and I prefer to be spontaneous and open-minded. I don't want pre-formed conclusions filling my mind before I've even read the questions.  Mark McArdle is a contributor to How I Got My First Class Degree edited by Peter Tolmie, Independent Studies, Lancaster University, supported by the Guardian £9.95 (inc p&p), tel: 01524 593430, email: IndStud@lancaster.ac.uk Kerry Boorman She failed her 11-plus exam but got a first-class honours degree in theatre studies at Lancaster University I have no secret to tell. I was just willing to try. Actually, I was trying for a 2:1 but, with a First suddenly coming into sight, my degree gave me 3D perception. That is, my life began to relate to the three dimensions of discipline, dedication and determination. Discipline is not about having your head stuck in a book every second but about being organised - developing a programme and sticking to it. Unfortunately, for me this was not the essay overnight, but a slow and painfully paced effort over three to four weeks. I knew if I did not give an essay this time I would either panic or fall behind. I also knew that structure was my weak point. To compensate, I needed a worthier content, which meant more time, more reading, more effort. So I often set my own deadlines for about a week earlier than the official ones. This way, even when I did miss my goal, I still hit the important one. But this didn't mean I had no life. Good time management includes study time, personal time and social time, with all three being equally important. Times when I became obsessed with study and sacrificed my social life were unhealthy and ineffective. So discipline and a balanced diet. Most games rely on teamwork, particularly so when it comes to theatre and performance. While pushing others to the limits, I pushed myself and in turn was pushed by them. Tiring, frustrating but rewarding. Secondly: dedication to the game - that is, to the subject and the result. I was never a swot but I cared about my work. I wanted to win! Not because I had to but because I wanted to and because I deserved to. By setting such high expectations I placed myself under tremendous pressure at times. Yet I went on assigning myself targets I was determined to hit. My practical work struck firsts, but the mark of a first in an essay was an objective I aimed for for two and a half years. Each time I managed near misses - until my last two papers. So, if at first you don't succeed, try again until you do. It's all about determination. There I was, alone. Or so it felt. My friend, Peter, had gone to find my results but I think it was Claire who first saw my name under the title of First Class Hons. Seeing my name there in black capital letters made me feel faint. An entire collection of emotions ran through me: surprise, euphoria, excitement. I couldn't believe I'd got a first. webTitle: Resource: Changing the law on cannabis

fields.headline: Trouble with plants
fields.standfirst: Should we change the law on use of the drug, cannabis? Jerome Monahan looks at the arguments for an against
fields.trailText: Should we change the law on use of the drug, cannabis? Jerome Monahan looks at the arguments for an against.
fields.body:
PSHE/citizenship: key stages 3 & 4

Queen Victoria is known to have taken cannabis to help relieve her period pains. Today, someone doing that risks arrest, imprisonment and a criminal record. Things have changed, but now the pressure is on the government to re-examine the laws forbidding the possession and use of the drug.

Why is cannabis in the news?

Recently, a senior member of the Conservative party, Anne Widdecombe, called for tougher penalties for people caught with cannabis. Immediately, the police condemned her ideas saying they were "unworkable". Then 10 of Widdecombe's political colleagues admitted to smoking cannabis in their youth. It was embarrassing for the Conservatives but the muddle prompted a public debate about cannabis and the law.

What is cannabis?

It is a plant related to nettles. People have grown cannabis for thousands of years both as a medicine and a source of a tough fibre called hemp. It originates in Central Asia and probably arrived in Europe in the Middle Ages. One of its most common forms is marijuana.

What is the effect of using it?

Chemicals in cannabis called cannabinoids stimulate certain brain receptors and seem to affect the body's pain relief mechanisms. What people experience depends on the drug's strength and how it is taken. The drug's effects range from making people happy and talkative to feeling insecure (paranoid). The physical impact of the drug is just as varied. Some people who suffer certain serious illnesses such as multiple sclerosis claim cannabis is helpful because it relaxes muscles.

Why is cannabis illegal?

Some people fear cannabis is dangerous. It increases the heart rate and so can harm people with heart conditions. The National Drugs Helpline says cannabis is not physically addictive, but can make people think they want it. Also, people who smoke the drug often mix it with tobacco, which is highly addictive and causes cancer. However, unlike most other drugs, it is impossible to overdose on cannabis. By contrast over 4,000 people die every year in the UK because of drinking alcohol. The other great worry is that cannabis is a "gateway" drug which encourages people to try more dangerous substances such as heroin and cocaine. This argument is weakened if you look at Holland, where decriminalisation of cannabis has not had this effect.

What is "decriminalisation"?

In Holland cannabis remains officially illegal, but people are allowed to possess it for personal use and it can be sold in specific, carefully monitored "coffee shops". This differs from complete "legalisation" which would allow cannabis to be sold anywhere.

What is the law in this country?

Under The Misuse of Drugs Act 1971, cannabis is classed Grade B. People caught with it can face anything up to five years in prison and/or an unlimited fine. The penalties are worse if someone is convicted of "dealing" - supplying the drug, even to a few friends. Often the police decide to caution people they arrest but this still results in an official police record. Over a million people in the UK are in this position. And having a police record makes certain kinds of jobs (teaching) and countries (America) out of bounds.

Isn't this all rather tough?

Some people think so. They argue it's absurd for otherwise law-abiding people to suffer such consequences, saying penalties are not applied equally across the UK and that tough laws do not seem to be stopping anyone from using the drug anyway.

Who are these critics?

The list includes influential people and organisations such as the British Medical Association which has declared that cannabis is "very safe"; senior policemen fed up with asking their staff to do an impossible job and wanting to concentrate on the fight against really dangerous drugs; a House of Lords committee that suggested two years ago that cannabis should be made legal for medical use; and recently the Police Foundation, which recommended those cautioned or fined for cannabis offences should not be penalised with a police record.

Are they being listened to?

Tony Blair is resisting the calls for a Royal Commission investigation into the issue, which could lead to a change in the law.

More information:

 Drugs Scope: www.drugscope.org.uk

 For the most recent enquiry into cannabis visit: www.parliament.uk clicking on "index", then "r" for "research" followed by "House of Commons Library" and then "2000 reports".

 Legalise Cannabis Alliance: lca-uk.org

 The Independent Drugs Monitoring Unit: www.idmu.co.uk

 Police Foundation: police-foundation.org.uk

 National Drugs Helpline, the 24-hour confidential advice and information service can be contacted on 0800 776600.

fields.headline: On the web:  British history
fields.trailText: From the Battle of Hastings to the Battle of Britain
fields.body:
Norman Conquest

*****

Aimed at: KS3 onwards

This most detailed and exciting of the 1066 sites includes a scroll-along, interactive Bayeux Tapestry, panoramic images of the battlefield and soldiers, and audio files suggesting what Saxon and Norman French sounded like.

Imperial War Museum

***

Aimed at: KS3 onwards

Themes include the Battle of Britain, the Enigma code-breaking machine, art from the two world wars and the role of factors during the second world war. Don't miss its sound archive of first-hand war accounts.

Spartacus 1700-1950

****

Aimed at: KS3 onwards

Mainly a collection of primary sources such as photos, cartoons, eyewitness accounts and maps, the encyclopaedia's entries are heavily hyperlinked.

BBC history games

***

Aimed at: KS2 onwards and teachers

Re-enact the battles of Waterloo and Hastings from both sides' perspectives, or run an archaeological investigation. With some teachers' notes

The Black Death

**

Aimed at: KS3 onwards

This somewhat over-rated history of the 14th-century plague has some intriguing transcripts, but it's poorly designed and merely an introduction. Children will appreciate the squeaking rat and background coughs.

Historical Map sites

*****

Aimed at: KS3 onwards and teachers

This is a cartographer's heaven - a long list of historical maps on the web. They include former British colonies, old London maps and medieval maps of Britain, plus links to the rest of the world. The older world maps show Britain's egocentric world view.

British Museum

**

Aimed at: teachers

Thought this site might have some good online learning tools? Think again! The Ancient Egypt microsite is outstanding, but there is little else of interest to teachers of British history.

The Workhouse

****

Aimed at: KS3 onwards and teachers

Detailed exploration of the 19th-century workhouse. Regional pages allow you to search for the details of local institutions, follow a tour of the buildings, listen to a former inmate talking about his experience or examine ballads and writing on the subject.

Black history map

***

Aimed at: KS4 onwards

Channel 4's site is at present a collection of links, organised by date and geographical location. But features are promised soon.

Stone pages ***

Aimed at: teachers, parents, KS3+

Considering a visit to an ancient monument? The Stone Pages chronicles 359 of them, including barrows, hill forts, stone circles and cairns.

 You can find more British history sites at www.educationunlimited.co.uk/netclass or contact Ros Taylor at ros.taylor@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Internet know-how:   pressure groups
fields.trailText: Useful sites for ethical issues
fields.body:
If you found a pupil examining a site on publishing photos of "mutilated corpses, dead people, and loads of more disgusting stuff", you'd probably disapprove. But suggest they research for a class debate on abortion by visiting the Society for the Protection of Unborn Children's website, and you probably wouldn't.

Yet the images they will find there are in many ways more disturbing. SPUC publishes photos of foetuses at different stages of gestation and after being aborted.

What's the justification? "The victims of abortion deserve to be known," writes the site's author. "Out of respect for these children who died, please do not misuse these pictures or send them to others unsolicited."

The general secretary of SPUC, Paul Tully, is more expansive. "We feel partly that educational needs are perhaps best met by information not designed for an educational forum. We've been appalled how many school textbooks deal with the subject of abortion. They do so in a very desultory and unsatisfactory manner." He adds the images are not intended for children as young as 11.

Unlike the pro-choice Marie Stopes or Education for Choice sites, SPUC has no online resources aimed at pupils and teachers, though this may change. National Abortion Campaign chair Sarah Coleorne described the existing site as "extremist tactics from an extremist organisation," suggesting the photos may breach medical confidentiality. She said most children of secondary school age had some form of web access.

The proliferation of such "resources" can be difficult for teachers, particularly in schools with a strong religious affiliation. If you suggest key stage 4 pupils investigate abortion for homework, do you mention SPUC's site, the National Abortion Campaign, Marie Stopes or all three? Similarly, Animal Aid and the Countryside Alliance offer teaching resources online.

Few teachers will worry about about suggesting Action on Smoking and Health's website. But for deeper debate, do you go to British American Tobacco to get the tobacco industry's view?

webTitle: If you ask me...about clashes with teachers

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.standfirst: My son's in year 8 and hates his new geography teacher, resulting in him bunking off lessons. I went into school to talk it through with the teacher, and it was obvious the feeling was mutual! It's a real personality clash, which is detrimentally affecting my son's education. What can I do about this?
fields.trailText: My son's in year 8 and hates his new geography teacher, resulting in him bunking off lessons. I went into school to talk it through with the teacher, and it was obvious the feeling was mutual! It's a real personality clash, which is detrimentally affecting my son's education. What can I do about this?
fields.body:
Roger Theobald, deputy head at Orleans Park school, Twickenham, London

Sit down with your son - investigate with him why there's a "personality clash". Has he done something to upset the teacher? For example, no homework, constant chatter, a casual attitude to work or poor behaviour? This may provoke a discussion on school in general. Does he find the work difficult? Has he sought help and, if so, has he had any?

Is there anything specific that the teacher has done to upset your child, wittingly or unwittingly, and is he aware of it? Were you able to speak to the teacher without your son present? Was there a frank and fair exchange of views? Could you agree some strategies to help repair the relationship?

You could speak to the head of department, provided he or she is not the same teacher. A more senior or perhaps more experienced member of staff may help to resolve the situation. It might be possible to move to a different geography class being taught at the same time, although don't rely on this. Often school timetables have only one group for a subject being taught at any one time, especially if they're mixed ability classes, as it depends on the availability of a teacher.

If it's still unresolved, consider involving the head of year as well. It may be possible to change tutor groups, which could lead to a different geography teacher. However, consider the implications of a move to another class. Your son may no longer be with friends or, indeed, with teachers he likes and with whom he is making good progress.

There's often not a simple solution. Sometimes pupils will have to learn to deal with difficulties like the one you've described. This, too, can be a valuable learning process. We all have to work with people we don't always get on with; that's just part of life!

Susan Rees, from the Advisory Centre for Education

It's not unusual for children to make subjective judgments about teachers, but it's rarer - and unprofessional - for a teacher to respond in the same way. Your son's geography teacher should be making the first move to overcome the impasse between them. After all, he is the adult!

I'd suggest that you go back into the school, see the teacher about the situation and ask how he or she will address it. You could try holding out an olive branch by asking what exactly your son does to irritate him, and offer to speak to your son. Sometimes it can be due to nothing more than a breakdown in effective communication between teacher and pupil: perhaps quietness is misinterpreted as sullenness or a particular stance wrongly perceived as aggressive.

If this doesn't resolve things, try approaching either the head of department or the head of year. In this case, be as specific as possible about what has been happening, ie actual incidents and forms of words used which will illustrate your concerns. Or it could simply be that your son is moved into another geography class.

Such matters need to be taken to a senior member of staff and nipped in the bud before they escalate, and they represent a serious abuse of the power relationship in a classroom. A teacher who rips up a child's work, or is rude and sarcastic on a very personal level, can set the tone for the rest of the class, who often follow this lead.

fields.headline: Eager beavers
fields.standfirst: As another colleague escapes over the wall  Janet Jones wonders what it's all about
fields.trailText: As another colleague escapes over the wall Janet Jones wonders what it's all about.
fields.body:
"You lot," our colleague gestured round the staffroom at the rest of us, "you lot," he shook his head sorrowfully, "I'm afraid to say," he shook his head again, "if you don't mind me saying ..."

We knew he was going to say what he was going to say whether we minded or not. We shrank into our desks and braced ourselves. We had a general idea of what was coming next but we did not have a precise idea.

We knew that our colleague was about to GO. The "when I get out of here" that we all hear so often had become "now I am getting out of here" and, by the time he reads this, "now I have got out of there."

We knew our colleague was speaking with the freedom, the confidence, the insight and the perspective of someone breaking out of the System. Someone with nothing to lose. Someone who did not have to mind his manners or his politics or his tongue. Someone with a job fixed up outside further education.

"You lot ..."

Us lot sat still as rabbits - caught in the beam of his vision.

"You lot, I'm afraid to say, seem to spend a great deal of time doing things of no importance."

Us lot shuffled about a bit. What were we doing? I was writing a memo to a person who works in a room two flights of stairs above the room where I work. To that piece of paper I was attaching two more pieces of paper and those two more pieces of paper were asking for copies of dozens more pieces of paper that were all in that room above mine. In my memo I was explaining that I had been asked, on another piece of paper, to ask for those pieces of paper, and that once I had received those pieces of paper from the room upstairs I had been asked to put them all in another room, four flights downstairs.

When I had finished my memo to the person two flights upstairs, I was going to take it six flights downstairs to his pigeon hole.

Our colleague who was GOing had a point.

The next day, however, us rabbits were transformed into beavers. Staffroom activities took on a sense of import and urgency. As things stood, we had not written to a single person and asked them to come and be a student on our courses.

If we were to have any students, we had to sit down at once and write to every one of them and invite them along. There we sat, writing hundreds of brown envelopes by hand. It took hours. I did wonder how many of us in further education spend hours writing brown envelopes by hand.

Perhaps, like some shameful vice, we all do it but none of us admits it.

At least we could see the point of what we were doing. And our colleague who has escaped to that great place, Outofhere, could see that we do, us lot, some of the time, do some things of some importance.

webTitle: So you want to learn... plumbing

fields.headline: So you want to learn...
fields.standfirst: Plumbing
fields.trailText: Plumbing.
fields.body:
Stay where you are. You what?

I just want to look at you. You being funny?

Please. It's just so rare these days to see a plumber. Look, mate, time's money.

Oh, yes. How much do I owe you? Let's see: £100 call-out plus half-hour - £200 total.

What. Just for one tap? That's the rate, mate.

That's it. I'm leaving teaching. What does plumbing involve? Basically any work associated with pipework - water supply, space heating, gas installations, sanitary appliances, discharge outlets and drainage.

Is it all done inside? Oh no, mate. Course, we do work indoors, maintaining hot and cold water supplies, sanitation, waste disposal, oil, gas and solid fuel appliances, central heating, air-conditioning etc. Outside buildings, we make weather-proofing joints in roofs and walls and install gutters and drainpipes.

I suppose there's a lot of skill involved? Phwoar! You kidding me? It demands a wide variety of skills and technical knowledge.

Plenty of variety, too. Yeah, well. We're basically either putting in stuff into new buildings or repairing and maintaining.There's a lot of problem solving, especially on the repair side.

What other skills are needed? Good hand skills and a flair for methodical planning. We've also got to measure things accurately, understand plans and follow instructions. Reasonable fitness and the strength to lug a lot of tools and materials about. Also a head for heights and ability to work in confined spaces. Safety awareness is very important. We must be able to work as part of a team as well as get on with things alone.

Any specific entry requirements? Not as such. Some GCSEs (D-G) or equivalent vocational qualifications, such as foundation GNVQ, are usually needed for entry as a trainee craftsperson. Maths, English and technology subjects are useful for parts of the job that involve measurements and calculations and for theoretical training. Entrants for apprenticeships or training schemes may have to pass a selection test.

What about training? Plumbers can train for qualifications, eg NVQs 2 and 3 in plumbing, while working, with day release at a college or training centre. For people aged 16 plus, there's a four-year apprenticeship scheme operated through the Joint Industry Board for Plumbing, Mechanical and Engineering Services.

webTitle: Connexions will guide teenagers into the world

fields.headline: Well connected
fields.standfirst: Connexions will guide teenagers into the world, says  Malcolm Wicks, minister for lifelong learning
fields.trailText: Connexions will guide teenagers into the world, says Malcolm Wicks, minister for lifelong learning.
fields.body:
The choices teenagers make clearly affect the rest of their lives. They need all possible help and support to make the most of opportunities. Indeed, as opportunities expand - curriculum 2000, enhanced vocational options, etc - effective independent advice is more vital than ever. For some, the position is clear. It is simply not good enough that one in 11 young people is not in work or in education.

I want to build on the work by careers and youth services over the years and transform it into something far more effective - Connexions, a new advice and support service available to all 13- to 19-year-olds. Connexions will have a third more resources, as David Blunkett announced yesterday, and a new proactive role to reach out to young people who most need help, as well as providing an improved service for all teenagers.

Connexions will be a universal service, providing not only careers guidance but also a range of informal learning opportunities in youngsters' own communities. In pilot schemes, local youth services have seized the chance to help shape the new service. We hope that will continue when the full service begins in some areas next April.

As parents, teachers and other further education professionals know only too well, youngsters who most need guidance are often those least likely to ask for help. Connexions will work closely with local youth services. There will be extra support for young people who find it difficult to seek advice and for those with particular needs for specialist services, for instance youngsters who are homeless, or need drug treatment, or are leaving institutions or care.

To get it off to the best possible start we have made sure Connexions is well funded, to the tune of £420m by the end of 2002-03 - that's £177m more than the careers service currently gets.

From April next year, 16 partnerships will be funded to run the Connexions service in their areas of England. These will be available to all young people, whether at school, in further education, in or out of work.

In the next two to three years, the whole of England will be covered by Connexions partnerships.

The crucial thing is that young people will be involved from the start in designing the service, because if it is not attractive to young people, they won't use it and we will have failed in our objective.

Not only will youngsters help to design and plan the services offered by the 16 new partnerships, but also all the agencies involved, in the public, private and voluntary sectors, will put young people and their needs at the centre of Connexions.

It is not enough just to give information. Young people need someone to guide them through their options. That is why we are making sure personal advisers will be available to everyone, to assess their individual needs, to help them get the information they need from specialist services. The co-ordination of these services to provide coherent support to young people, and to ensure they continue to get support, will be one of the key things that makes Connexions different. There will be expert careers guidance for young people starting a new college course or apprenticeship. Vital information about further education or vocational learning should help to keep more young people in education and training.

Teachers should also benefit. The additional support Connexions will bring to schools will allow them to focus more on teaching rather than being social workers. It will offer more than guidance on career and education choices. It is a service to help teenagers also deal with health and family relationship problems. Personal advisers will provide a broader personal development service.

Connexions will help teenagers to make the successful transition from secondary education into the world. We want to make a real difference to their lives by making sure all get the right information to make informed decisions about their futures.

fields.headline: Your accessible friend
fields.standfirst: E-learning - by gum, it's never been so easy to swot
fields.trailText: E-learning - by gum, it's never been so easy to swot.
fields.body:
Labour's big idea for tackling the nation's growing shortage of essential economic skills will finally be launched tomorrow.

Ufi, formerly known as the University for Industry, will officially be opened by David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, although it has been operational for months now.

At events around the country a string of celebrities will sign up for courses via learndirect, billed as Britain's first "e-learning network", which is at the heart of the Ufi concept.

According to its former chairman Lord Dearing, the lifelong learning flagship promises to be as great an achievement for New Labour as the Open University turned out for the Wilson government, after initial scepticism.

The concept has moved on since Gordon Brown, then shadow chancellor, unveiled his vision of a university for industry in the Guardian.

A big idea is certainly needed if the latest survey on the national workforce is to be believed. Nearly three quarters of British firms are suffering skills shortages, a jump of 26% compared to the previous six months, according to research published by Reed, the recruitment specialist.

This is a record increase in reported shortages since the company began its Skills Index over three years ago. The shortfalls are particularly acute in accountancy and information technology.

Ufi's mission is to "make it easy for everyone to get into learning whenever and wherever they want to," says Anne Wright, Ufi's chief executive. "We're concentrating on what they need for work. The kind of skills we're offering are IT, basic literacy and numeracy, and the skills for small businesses."

Accessibility is seen as crucial for making inroads on the critical mass of adults who left school with few or no skills and have so far been disinclined to return to education, often because their first experience of it was unhappy.

These are the group targeted by the government's "widening participation" programme but who have not responded to colleges' considerable efforts to entice them in.

So far Ufi and its learndirect network, with an £84m budget this year, have opened more than 600 learning centres across England where the public can come in and start a course straight away or find out where they can go for what they need, says Wright.

The centres are situated in venues where people often go anyway, such as shopping malls, pubs, community centres and football clubs.

Perhaps the oddest venue is Big Top learndirect, which moves around Birmingham with the Robert Wilkinson's travelling funfair.

"It's sandwiched between the dodgems and the shooting arcade," says Wright.

So far 36,000 people have registered and 77,000 courses have been completed. These have ranged from a one-hour session on time management to programmes of more than 300 hours.

Ufi's other important arms are its website - www.learndirect.co.uk - and the learndirect helpline which has taken more than two million calls in two years.

webTitle: The role of the Learning and Skills Council

fields.headline: Spend it wisely
fields.standfirst: It has a vast amount of money and a huge mission to fulfil. So how will Britain's biggest quango decide who gets what, asks  Nick Tester
fields.trailText: It has a vast amount of money and a huge mission to fulfil. So how will Britain's biggest quango decide who gets what, asks Nick Tester.
fields.body:
A week from today, after a few brief introductions, 16 men and women will sit down around a table and start working out how to spend six billion pounds.

It has to be said that they will not be doing this in the grandest of settings, fine institution though London's Birkbeck College is.

But there is a symbolic appropriateness in the choice of venue for the first meeting of Britain's biggest quango. What better place for the fledgling Learning and Skills Council than one of Britain's most celebrated institutions for mature students

Inevitably the national council, appointed by the government last week, will have David Blunkett at the back of their minds as they traipse through Birkbeck's front doors. The Education and Employment Secretary is expected next month to furnish them with a detailed operational remit, explaining how he expects the council to deliver explicit recruitment targets and achieve rigorous levels of quality assurance and funding.

The "reality", according to one of those helping the council get up and running, is that "we do what the department says". The most intriguing part of its work, however, could be how the 47 local learning and skills councils use their own discretionary powers to spend between 10% and 15% above the national tariff.

Sixteen looks an awfully small number to represent all interests, let alone carry £6bn. Only one member, Imtiaz Farookhi, chief executive of the National House Building Council is from an ethnic minority. There is no obvious heavy industry/engineering representative, nor for that matter anyone for private learning providers. Nor, to the irritation of Natfhe, the lecturers' union, is there any representative of college staff.

The new body will be expected to keep its ears to the ground, far away from Whitehall, by heeding the array of more conflicting voices in local and regional communities and businesses. The same answers will not be apposite in all parts of the land.

"We can't just do what the Training and Enterprise Councils did, which was often confusing and not in tune with any national strategy," the source said.

Colleges were hoping to hear the first concrete hints from civil servants yesterday about how the spoils, including the considerable 25% worth of work-based training money, might be shared out in the new regime.

The message they didn't hear, however, was how the Learning and Skills Council members intend to rule over the most momentous change ever in post-16 education and training.

What a graveyard the past has proved. Just going back a few years reveals some stark burials, from the Industrial Training Board system, the Manpower Services Commission and most lately the TECs, whose performance sparked the entire further education shake-up.

Will the Learning and Skills Council go the same way? John Monks, general secretary of the TUC, one of the 14 - he is also going to chair its dedicated adult education committee - says: "We have to earn our spurs and hope the council has sufficient calibre to be successful. If not, then we'll have failed."

Another appointee, Leisha Fullick, chief executive of Islington Council, London, says the old TEC culture must be broken: "There's a lot of bedding down to be done with the local learning and skills councils. But if they turn out a continuation of the old TECs then it is all going to die."

The Learning and Skills Council, chaired by BP Amoco managing director Bryan Sanderson and led by the highly rated chief executive, John Harwood, has a huge mission. John Merry, the only elected local government councillor (he's currently deputy leader of Salford Council) says "the absolutely massive task is to try and touch everyone's lives. But none of us knows how any of this is going to work in practice."

Fullick doesn't subscribe to the notion that Harwood has only been put on the payroll to rubber-stamp every ministerial announcement.

fields.headline: Take me back
fields.standfirst: At an age when others are swearing by Grecian 2000,  David Marsh returns to uni to do an MA
fields.trailText: At an age when others are swearing by Grecian 2000, David Marsh returns to uni to do an MA.
fields.body:
It's your worst nightmare. There you are, enjoying a drink in the union with your mates after a hard day of lectures ... when who do you spy propping up the bar? Oh God, it's your dad! One of the main reasons you decided to move away to university in the first place.

No wonder my son Dominic chose Leeds over a London university. His brother Oliver is safely ensconced even farther away, in Newcastle. The risk of bumping into their old man in London was just too great.

Yes, I have gone back to school (as Americans say, appropriately since that is exactly what it feels like), studying at University College London alongside people who weren't even born when I was taking my history finals at Sheffield in 1974.

Not that things have changed very much. True, Afghan coats are less in evidence and there are definitely fewer people protesting against the Vietnam war and apartheid. But who were the first people I saw after getting off the tube at Euston Square and setting off down Gower Street? That's right: the Berlin wall and iron curtain may have come down, but the Socialist Workers Party is still going strong. Well, still going.

One thing that has changed, though, is that in every sense there are far more mature students today, both undergraduate and postgraduate. This can be the only explanation of the fact that, after I had accidentally stumbled into my first freshers' fair for three decades, no one asked who the old bloke with the grey hair was.

On the contrary, the various groups courted me as assiduously (or desperately) as they did everyone else. This seemed particularly true of the jazz society: perhaps by some amazing insight they shared my romantic view of myself as the cool but cynical ageing sax player, a man who has seen it all and lived life to the full. Or perhaps not.

In addition to the jazz, I am also trying to get onto University Challenge. So look out for the only team with a member who is actually older and more irritable than Jeremy Paxman.

In many ways student life is much the same whether you are 18 or 48. It's just that when you are pushing 50 the hangovers last a bit longer. And the work seems harder. When I decided to spend two of my declining years studying Modern English Language, I confess that the thought of being an MA appealed more than the thought of doing an MA. Let's face it, we all like the idea of having letters after our name. The other motives were an interest in language and linguistics that not even a quarter of a century in journalism has managed to quell, and the realisation that time was running out if I ever again wanted to use my brain to think - not essential in my chosen profession, as you will be aware if you've ever read a newspaper.

Unfortunately, what I had not given much thought to was the fact that getting an MA, unless you go to Oxbridge, takes lots of work. Or maybe I am just taking it all more seriously than I did as a teenager. After all, this time it's costing me money - £2,740. But, to be fair, it is worth every penny: the course is great, and so is the teaching. It's just hard. When you have spent your working life relying on instinct, it comes as a shock to be confronted with an essay title that you don't begin to understand. But then, linguists never use one word ("word") when you can use two ("lexical item"). And you do get the hang of it after a while.

As a part-time student, the phonetics half of my two-year course has been deferred until next year. While this means UCL is to be denied my phonetically perfect impression of Marcus, the narrator (and true star) of Big Brother, for 12 months, it has the benefit of allowing me to concentrate on my grammatical studies - or, as I now prefer to put it, polish up my techniques of syntactic argumentation. Two seminars a week, an essay and a tutorial a fortnight and more reading in a term than I did in a year at Sheffield - as well as a full-time job - are quite enough, thank you.

By the way, the student union bar at UCL is superb.

 Dress down. Think army surplus rather than Armani.

 Forget the briefcase, buy a backpack. It will help you blend in.

 Studying academic textbooks is not like flipping through the Sun. It takes time (10 to 12 pages an hour is the best I can manage). So allow plenty of reading time.

 Organise your time efficiently. Prepare a weekly timetable (including reading and written assignments as well as lectures and seminars). This way you will at least feel that you know what you are doing.

 Remember: you are doing this because you want to, not because you have to. So enjoy it.

 David Marsh is news production editor of the Guardian.

webTitle: Behind the facades of top US universities

fields.headline: American beauties
fields.standfirst: Gordon Marsden,  MP,  on the hard figures behind the facades of top US universities
fields.trailText: Gordon Marsden, MP, on the hard figures behind the facades of top US universities.
fields.body:
Think of a system whose elite universities have endowment assets worth thousands of billions of pounds, but where the cost of being a student for four years can top £100,000. A country with no nationwide secondary school curriculum, and no A-level-style subject exams with grades to guide college admissions. Instead, imagine "think about us" mail-outs to targeted groups of up to 200,000 freshmen - who in turn can file up to 20 applications to different universities.

This is America in 2000. But the key concerns are the same as in the UK - fair access, measuring standards, debt and funding. Time and again they came up as I crossed from coast to coast with other members of the Education Select Committee, talking to a range of state, private and community colleges.

Just as in Britain, education has moved rapidly to the top of the US political agenda. Though it's not a federal responsibility, college education has been an issue in the presidential election for the first time in pundits' memory: Al Gore promised a $10,000 tax credit to help middle America pay its college tuition fees.

Britain today is heading towards the mass higher education system the US has had since the end of the war - kick started by a GI bill which funded 2m American veterans through college. But with two-thirds of American high school graduates going on to some form of college, theirs is a system which sports everything, in football terms, from Super League to Vauxhall Conference status.

For those out to win an Ivy League or equivalent place, competition is stiff. Less than 10% of those who applied for Stanford's graduating class of 2003 got in. Other top universities - public as well as private - have comparable ratios.

Yet far from trying to damp down applications, American elite universities embark on annual campaigns to woo the brightest and best that would stagger their British counterparts. Roadshows of deans, professors, faculty staff, and past and present students take off countrywide - backed up by internet and email marketing.

Anyone in the UK looking, in the wake of the Laura Spence case, for some superior objective and transparent holy grail will be disappointed. Even with the highest SATs and GPAs, far more hopefuls leap the hurdles than there are places at a Harvard, Stanford, Berkeley or Princeton.

"We are seen by students as having a difficult-to-predict admissions system," says Stanford's vice provost for student affairs, James Montoya. "There is simply no way, given the competition, to have an entirely objective process."

Though affirmative action - effectively admission quotas for minority groups - has been on the retreat after a number of state court and political decisions, the imperative to excellence can lead to some discreet tilting of the playing field.

"If you're saying would we admit a minority student who had cleared the threshold despite having arrived in the US as a refugee only four or five years ago above a middle-class white student with the same or marginally better SAT score, sure we would," was how one Berkeley insider put it.

But British egalitarians might be less happy with the practice at Stanford, Princeton and Harvard of privileging "legacy" applicants - children of alumni - in the battle between equals for the last few places. Thirteen per cent of Princeton's undergraduate admissions are "legacies" - 40% of the children of alumni who apply get in.

In-bred intelligence - or a US variant of the old school tie? And what about the blue-collar white boy from rural Alabama or Iowa who is not in the running for a minorities scholarship? Will he even be primed to apply in the first place?

The funding packages - a mixture of soft loans, grants, scholarships and paid work on campus - vary. American students have salaried job opportunities - administration, library duties, tour guides, helping faculty staff - to a degree that would amaze (or alarm) their British counterparts.

But not all packages cover the full cost. New York University is a private institution that was originally a New York-focused "commuter school". Today it has transformed itself into a campus-based university with country-wide admissions and high-cost residential accommodation in the heart of Manhattan for students and staff. And for NYU the lack of a Princeton-style endowment (despite a new and vigorous fundraising campaign) means there are gaps.

"NYU may be needs-blind in admissions, but we can't guarantee to satisfy every student's financial needs fully," I was told.

Perception of costs does affect applications. Undergraduates at Rutgers - where an excellent state university education comes at a more modest $10-11,000 a year all in - said it had helped deter applications to Ivy League universities.

Alumni contacts - and hopefully giving - are crucial here. "We see it as joining a family for life," says Bill Stone, president of Stanford's alumni association, which has 11-12,000 alumni on its books as volunteers.

Princeton raised $36.8m last year just from individual gifts for general purposes - one year's graduating class alone raised $2m. For Stanford being in the heart of Silicon Valley is a bonus. Jim Clarke's recent endowment of $150m for a biosciences centre leapfrogged Bill Gates's previous highest endowment.

As for the students, like their British counterparts they tend to be apolitical, with weak student unions and no sabbatical officers. There was no evidence that the tight Gore-Bush race was firing up campuses, even at universities like Berkeley with a strong radical tradition.

The class of 2000 tends to be career-focused and sometimes fiercely entrepreneurial - like the Stanford student who was aiming for a Nasa programme but meanwhile building his future in computer science via his own dot.com company. There is public service ethos - via a plethora of civic activities and internships, many of which can earn credits in America's broad-based four-year degree courses. At Rutgers this has been honed in the Case Service Learning programme, which has taken 12,000 undergraduates through expertise given to not-for-profit organisations in the local community since its launch in the mid-90s.

"We give our students some of the soft skills future employers want. We teach citizenship by doing, not preaching and at the end of the day they get a credit for it," explained Case director Professor Mike Shaffer.

That "can do, will do" spirit has also fuelled the high-tech contributions of campus academics to national prosperity. This is not confined to Silicon Valley. In New Jersey, pump-priming by a state concerned to create new industries from a rust-belt past has spawned dozens of companies and patents via institutions at Princeton and Rutgers. These were set up by faculty staff and encompassed photonics, fibre optics and biotechnology.

"Every successful faculty member has to be some kind of entrepreneur - whether it's in business, intellectual property or hustling for federal or foundation funds. It doesn't make any difference if it's a public or private institution," James Sturm, head of Princeton's POEM Photonics Institute emphasised. That attitude, and the contribution of America's locally-based community colleges - which can feed bright students midway into four-year university degrees - helps explain why, despite rising costs and reductions in state and federal money, demand at all levels for a college degree is buoyant.

The scale of endowments and fundraising in the US makes nonsense of suggestions that floating off Britain's so-called top universities would have an American effect. But there's much about the marketing of admissions, fostering alumni, entrepreneurship and citizenship that government and vice-chancellors could urgently learn from Uncle Sam - helped by more tweaking of the tax system by a sympathetic Gordon Brown.

 Gordon Marsden is MP for Blackpool South and a member of the Commons Select Committee on Education. He is just back from a visit to the US as part of their enquiry into higher education.

webTitle: Are languages for the middle-classes only?

fields.headline: Elite corps
fields.standfirst: Last week, we highlighted the decline of 'minority' language degrees. Today,  Hilary Footitt warns that the courses that remain come almost bottom of the access league tables (second only to medicine). Do we really want languages to become simply a middle-class accomplishment?
fields.trailText: Last week, we highlighted the decline of 'minority' language degrees. Today, Hilary Footitt warns that the courses that remain come almost bottom of the access league tables (second only to medicine). Do we really want languages to become simply a middle-class accomplishment?
fields.body:
As one 16-year-old explained to me the other day, it simply never entered her mind to study languages at A-level: "No one in my family speaks a foreign language. No one in my extended family speaks a foreign language. It doesn't seem like something we do."

This sort of perception should be unacceptable, unless of course we are content to see the future translators, interpreters and international business people we so desperately need drawn from a relatively restricted group in society.

Of all the students who were accepted to British degree courses in 1999, 9.1% came from social categories IV (partly skilled) and V (unskilled). Within this band, according to the Higher Education Statistics Agency, subjects performed in very different ways. At the bottom of the access league table was medicine, which took 4.2% of students from these two groups. Rather more of a shock was the discipline that came second from bottom - languages and related studies, which accepted only 6.8% from these same groups. Worryingly, 88% of UK language students are white.

The composer James MacMillan recently lamented the fact that children take part in instrumental music lessons only if their parents can afford to pay for them. Music is becoming, he argued, a privatised accomplishment for the relatively well off. As we start the 21st century, there are real concerns that foreign languages are destined to go the same way.

If the languages/music comparison seems a little far-fetched, consider for a moment what is happening to language teaching at primary and secondary level. The sad fact is that at both levels there are truly excellent initiatives, but the effect of not generalising these out is to leave a vacuum in which specialist language learning may become more, rather than less, a preserve of the elite.

Around 25% of state primary schools in England offer a foreign language. Pupils in the other 75% reach secondary school without any direct experience of foreign languages at all. The exceptions are inevitably the children of parents who can afford to buy the extra language classes for their children, much as they may buy extra music classes.

The tradition of independent preparatory schools has long been to offer foreign languages. Now what we are seeing on the ground is commercial language providers stepping in to teach the children of better-off parents in the maintained sector - and in many areas this is an increasingly thriving market. In the vacuum of pre-secondary language-learning, the private market has taken up the challenge. The results are often good, but learning is inevitably confined to relatively restricted social groups.

By the time children have reached secondary school, it may thus be that some of the social patterns of foreign language learning are already set. For the majority, despite the endeavours of hard-working and committed teachers, languages will tend to be something "strange", one of the few subjects they did not come across at primary school. Initiatives like the excellent language colleges have not so far halted the apparent privatisation of specialist language learning. Figures on the percentage of dual linguist candidates at A-level - and it is from these students that the largest number of applicants to specialist language degrees is drawn - are considerably higher in the independent sector - 5% of all A-level candidates - than in the maintained sector, where the figure is 2.2%.

University language departments have made tremendous efforts to widen the range of the language courses they offer, to combine languages with other subjects and to make up the national languages deficit by offering languages for all students at university. They will not, however, be able to crack the real problem of widening participation on their own. Unless we start to "join up the thinking" on this, as the Nuffield Language Inquiry recommended, we shall produce more 16-year-olds who regard the specialist study of languages as "something that people like us don't do".

There are at least two things we might consider urgently. Firstly, there is a message on the employability value of language study that needs to get out. Figures on graduate unemployment show that language degrees give you a better chance of a job than almost all the other subjects. Better than computing, or physical sciences, or psychology, or business studies (Higher Education Statistics Agency, 1998/99). The more parents in all social groups hear that message, the more they will demand that their children receive the skills of language learning as of right.

Secondly, in our efforts to widen participation, we may need to focus more of our attention on the experience of individual subjects, rather than that of types of institution. With encouragement, language depart ments in higher education could work more closely with language teachers in their regions in secondary schools, in language colleges and in further education, to "bridge the gap" which so clearly exists.

Foreign languages are much too important to our national future to allow us to accept the situation as it is. Foreign Languages are an access issue for us all, and it is time we recognised this and acted upon it. Let's hope that January 2001, the start of the European Year of Languages, will provide an opportunity for some constructive New Year resolutions!

 Hilary Footitt is chair of the University Council of Modern Languages. Information on UCML can be obtained at the website: www.ucml.org.uk

webTitle: It's official: fees put people off university (in Australia, at least)

fields.headline: Walk on by ...
fields.standfirst: It's official: fees put people off university (in Australia, at least)
fields.trailText: It's official: fees put people off university (in Australia, at least).
fields.body:
There is growing international evidence that tuition fees put people off university, and that rising fees and student debts are alienating students from poor backgrounds in particular. These are the central conclusions of one of the first UK based studies of the impact of fees in Australian and New Zealand universities, carried out by researchers at the Association of University Teachers.

The paper comes amid signs that English education ministers are increasingly isolated in their contention that students are not being deterred from degree courses by rising financial burdens. The Welsh and Northern Ireland Assemblies look set to follow the Scottish Parliament's footsteps and split away from what are seen as socially divisive student support arrangements originally established for the whole of the UK.

Since introducing tuition fees and scrapping maintenance grants for students two years ago, English ministers have claimed that the main factors affecting university enrolments are the attitudes, values and expectations of students from poorer backgrounds, not the increasing costs of degree courses.

This cultural explanation figured prominently in official responses to the Oxford admissions row after the state school pupil Laura Spence failed to win a place there. The government is now, for example, allocating funds to universities to hire recruitment spotters and run summer schools.

But some fear that financial factors - particularly loss of grants for students' living expenses - are being overlooked in the university access debate. Vice-chancellors last month made a point of considering the restoration of maintenance grants as part of their university funding inquiry. The latest performance figures for universities meanwhile revealed a drop in mature entrants since fees were introduced, and evidence that financial costs are the key factor in explaining different student drop-out rates.

The paper, being presented to AUT's education policy committee this week, concludes that demand for degrees is affected by the income, socio-economic background, and academic achievement of students, but also the 'net price' of courses - the combination of tuition fees discounted by financial aid. Research on university enrolments in the USA shows that lower income groups are the first to be influenced by any price changes. "There is growing international evidence that economic factors such as tuition costs and expected future returns to education are significant barriers to participation in higher education," concludes the paper.

In New Zealand, where university fees have almost tripled in 10 years, the cost of courses has proved a disincentive to particular groups, including Maori, Pacific Islanders, mature students and those from poor backgrounds. Increased borrowing per student has led to a major increase in student debt.

A two-tier system for rich and poor students, meanwhile, is emerging in Australia, with students from affluent backgrounds more likely to secure places on courses where full fees are charged. In 1997, student fees were raised to contribute to 37% of the average cost of undergraduate courses. Universities are now able to impose full-cost fees for up to 25% of students enrolling on a particular course.

Increasing pressure is being exerted by a cartel of leading Australian research universities, like the Russell Group universities in the UK, to consider the complete deregulation of fees.

But it may be a political storm closer to home that eventually forces English education ministers to review student funding arrangements. One pledge to emerge last week from the three-year, power-sharing agreement between Liberal Democrat and Labour MPs in the Welsh Assembly is "an immediate investigation into student hardship and funding". Northern Ireland MPs, have urged the Northern Ireland Assembly to abolish full-time undergraduate tuition costs and re-introduce means-tested maintenance grants.

Meanwhile, the National Union of Students next month plan to hold a national day of action against fees.
